$Aerssen.en_GB: Joost Peter baron van Aerssen Beijeren van Voshol was born in Zwolle, as the son of Baron Albrecht Nicolaas, former officer in the infantry at the Cape of Good Hope and later lieutenant colonel and member of the Knighthood of Holland. Van Aerssen was a non-commissioned officer in the field artillery and later a first lieutenant in the militia in the province of Overijssel. He worked as a supernumerary officer and attaché at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (RD 18 Feb 1842 no 62), then in the same capacity in Brussels (RD 23 April 1844 no 65). By RD, he was promoted on 6 March 1844 (no. 68) to captain à la suite in the second battalion of resting militia in Overijssel, where he was granted leave for two years on 6 April 1845 (RD no. 97), to accompany Governor-General J.J. Rochussen, former envoy to Brussels and as such his former superior, to Java, with the 'title and rank' of envoy secretary without remuneration (RD 16 April 1846 no. 90). He subsequently became envoy secretary in Vienna (RD 5 Feb 1848 no 55) and Paris (RD 10 Jan 1852 no 13), and council of legation there (RD 25 Sept 1852 no 79). In Paris, he married the British Anna Maria Sutton (1809-1909) on 12 December 1853. 'To restore his health', Van Aerssen was granted indefinite leave a year later (RD 13 July 1854 no 78). Thereafter he served, among others, as resident minister at Lisbon (RD 15 Oct 1856 no 81) and chamberlain to the King in extraordinary service. He died at Sintra near Lisbon.
$Aerssen.it_IT: Joost Peter barone van Aerssen Beijeren van Voshol nacque a Zwolle, figlio del barone Albrecht Nicolaas, ex ufficiale di fanteria del Capo di Buona Speranza e poi tenente colonnello e membro del Cavalierato d'Olanda. Van Aerssen fu un sottufficiale dell'artiglieria da campo e in seguito un tenente della milizia nella provincia di Overijssel. Lavorò come ufficiale soprannumerario e addetto al Ministero degli Affari Esteri (RD 18 febbraio 1842 n. 62), poi con la stessa carica a Bruxelles (RD 23 aprile 1844 n. 65). Da RD, fu promosso il 6 marzo 1844 (n. 68) a capitano à la suite nel secondo battaglione della milizia in riposo a Overijssel, dove gli fu concesso un permesso di due anni il 6 aprile 1845 (RD n. 97), per accompagnare il governatore generale J.J. Rochussen, già inviato a Bruxelles e come tale suo ex superiore, a Giava, con «titolo e grado» di segretario inviato senza compenso (RD 16 aprile 1846 n. 90). Successivamente divenne segretario dell'inviato a Vienna (RD 5 febbraio 1848 n. 55) e Parigi (RD 10 gennaio 1852 n. 13), e lì al consiglio di legazione (RD 25 settembre 1852 n. 79). A Parigi sposò il 12 dicembre 1853 la britannica Anna Maria Sutton (1809-1909). «Per ristabilirsi in salute», Van Aerssen ottenne un anno dopo un congedo a tempo indeterminato (RD 13 luglio 1854 n. 78). Successivamente prestò servizio, tra gli altri, come ministro residente a Lisbona (RD 15 ottobre 1856 n. 81) e ciambellano del re in servizio straordinario. Morì a Sintra vicino a Lisbona.
$Aerssen.nl_NL: Joost Peter baron van Aerssen Beijeren van Voshol werd geboren in Zwolle als zoon van baron Albrecht Nicolaas, gewezen officier bij de infanterie op Kaap de Goede Hoop en later luitenant-kolonel en lid Ridderschap van Holland. Van Aerssen was onderofficier bij de veldartillerie en later eerste luitenant bij de schutterij in de Provincie Overijssel. Hij werkte als surnumerair ambtenaar en attaché bij het ministerie van Buitenlandse Zaken (KB 18 febr. 1842 no. 62), daarna in dezelfde hoedanigheid te Brussel (KB 23 april 1844 no. 65). Per KB werd hij op 6 maart 1844 (no. 68) bevorderd tot kapitein à la suite bij het tweede bataljon rustende schutterij in Overijssel, waar bij op 6 april 1845 (KB no. 97) verlof kreeg voor de tijd van twee jaar om gouverneur-generaal J.J. Rochussen, oud-gezant te Brussel en als zodanig zijn voormalige chef, naar Java te vergezellen, met de 'titel en rang' van gezantschapssecretaris 'buiten bezwaar' (KB 16 april 1846 no. 90). Vervolgens werd hij gezantschapssecretaris te Wenen (KB 5 febr. 1848 no. 55) en Parijs (KB 10 jan. 1852 no. 13), en raad van legatie aldaar (KB 25 sept. 1852 no. 79). In Parijs trouwde hij op 12 december 1853 met de Britse Anna Maria Sutton (1809-1909). 'Tot herstel van zijn gezondheid' kreeg Van Aerssen een jaar later verlof voor onbepaalde tijd (KB 13 juli 1854 no. 78). Daarna was hij onder meer minister-resident te Lissabon (KB 15 okt. 1856 no. 81), kamerheer des konings in buitengewone dienst. Hij overleed te Sintra bij Lissabon.

$Aghemo.en_GB: Count Giovanni Natale Aghemo, from Moncalieri near Turin, studied Law and then had a career in public service. After 1861, he joined the cabinet of the Italian king Victor Emanuel II; in 1864, he became chief of cabinet. In an effort to remain personally involved in Italy's foreign policy, the king used Aghemo as an intermediary and spokesman, mostly regarding Italy's complicated relations to the Holy See and Austria. For instance, Aghemo had several meetings with Cardinal Secretary of State Giacomo Antonelli. In 1877, on the king's initiative, Aghemo became his liaison with the Austrian ambassador to Rome, Baron Heinrich Karl von Haymerle. Aghemo spent the last years of his life in Turin, where he was municipal councillor from 1896 until his death in 1914.
$Aghemo.it_IT: Il conte Giovanni Natale Aghemo, di Moncalieri vicino a Torino, studiò Giurisprudenza e poi svolse la carriera nel pubblico servizio. Dopo il 1861 entrò a far parte del gabinetto del re italiano Vittorio Emanuele II; nel 1864 divenne capo di gabinetto. Nel tentativo di rimanere personalmente coinvolto nella politica estera italiana, il re usò Aghemo come intermediario e portavoce, soprattutto per quanto riguardava le complicate relazioni dell'Italia con la Santa Sede e l'Austria. Aghemo, ad esempio, ebbe diversi incontri con il cardinale segretario di Stato Giacomo Antonelli. Nel 1877, su iniziativa del re, Aghemo divenne il suo collegamento con l'ambasciatore austriaco a Roma, il barone Heinrich Karl von Haymerle. Aghemo trascorse gli ultimi anni della sua vita a Torino, dove fu consigliere comunale dal 1896 fino alla morte avvenuta nel 1914.
$Aghemo.nl_NL: Graaf Giovanni Natale Aghemo, afkomstig uit Moncalieri bij Turijn, studeerde Rechten en had daarna een carrière in overheidsdienst. Na 1861 trad hij toe tot het kabinet van de Italiaanse koning Victor Emanuel II; in 1864 werd hij kabinetschef. In een poging om persoonlijk betrokken te blijven bij het buitenlandbeleid van Italië, zette de koning Aghemo veel in als tussenpersoon en woordvoerder, veelal ten aanzien van Italië (gecompliceerde) relaties met de Heilige Stoel en Oostenrijk. Zo had Aghemo verschillende ontmoetingen met kardinaal-staatssecretaris Giacomo Antonelli. In 1877 werd hij op initiatief van de koning diens liaison met de Oostenrijkse ambassadeur te Rome, baron Heinrich Karl von Haymerle. Aghemo spendeerde de laatste jaren van zijn leven in Turijn, waar hij gemeentelijk raadsadviseur was van 1896 tot zijn dood in 1914.

$Agostini.en_GB: Cesare Agostini was an Italian patriot during the Risorgimento. In Rome in 1849, he supported the immediate proclamation of the Roman Republic, against the ideas of Terenzio Mamiani. He took part in drafting the new constitution and was appointed Minister of Arts, Agriculture, Industry and Trade. After the fall of the Roman Republic, he went into exile to London, where he became secretary of the Italian National Committee and collaborated with Giuseppe Mazzini, from whom he distanced himself after the failure of the Milanese uprising Mazzini had instigated in February 1853. Agostini abandoned politics and became an Italian language teacher in London, where he died.
$Agostini.it_IT: Cesare Agostini fu un patriota del Risorgimento italiano. A Roma nel 1849 sostenne contro Terenzio Mamiani l'immediata proclamazione della Repubblica romana. Prese parte alla elaborazione del Costituzione e fu nominato ministro delle Arti, Agricoltura, Industria e Commercio. Dopo la caduta della Repubblica Romana andò in esilio a Londra, dove divenne, come segretario del Comitato nazionale italiano, collaboratore di Giuseppe Mazzini, da cui si allontanò dopo il fallimento del moto milanese del febbraio 1853. Abbandonò l'attività politica divenendo insegnante della lingua italiana a Londra, dove morì.
$Agostini.nl_NL: Cesare Agostini was een Italiaanse patriot ten tijde van het Risorgimento. In Rome steunde hij in 1849 het onverwijld uitroepen van de Romeinse Republiek, tegen het standpunt van o.a. Terenzio Mamiani. Hij had een aandeel in het opstellen van de grondwet en werd benoemd tot minister van Kunst, Landbouw, Industrie en Handel. Na de val van de Romeinse Republiek vluchtte hij naar Londen, waar hij secretaris werd van het Italiaanse Nationale Comité en samenwerkte met Giuseppe Mazzini, van wie hij zich evenwel afkeerde na het mislukken van de opstand in Milaan die Mazzini in februari 1853 had geïnstigeerd. Agostini verliet de politiek en werd leraar Italiaans in Londen, waar hij stierf.

$Albites.en_GB: Francesca ('Fanny') Albites was the daughter of a retired administrator in the papal army and, in 1820, married Mathieu Kessels, a sculptor from Maastricht. Fanny likely modelled for the funerary monument Kessels made for countess De Celles (d. 1828), wife of the ambassador of the Netherlands in Rome. In 1836, the monument was put in the San Giuliano dei Fiamminghi in Rome. Fanny is also depicted on the design for a funerary monument for Kessels himself (1836), for which she likely commissioned sculptor Jan Antonie van der Ven after her husband's death. Fanny's brother Achille C. Albites published a biography of Kessels in French, in 1837, Brussels.
$Albites.it_IT: Francesca ('Fanny') Albites era la figlia di un amministratore in pensione dell'esercito pontificio e, nel 1820, sposò Mathieu Kessels, uno scultore di Maastricht. Fanny probabilmente posò come modella per il monumento funebre che Kessels realizzò per la contessa De Celles (morta nel 1828), moglie dell'ambasciatore dei Paesi Bassi a Roma. Nel 1836 il monumento fu collocato nella chiesa di San Giuliano dei Fiamminghi a Roma. Fanny venne ritratta anche nel disegno del bozzetto per il monumento funebre per lo stesso Kessels (1836), che venne commissionato allo scultore Jan Antonie van der Ven dopo la morte del marito. Il fratello di Fanny, Achille C. Albites, pubblicò una biografia di Kessels in francese nel 1837 a Bruxelles.
$Albites.nl_NL: Francesca ('Fanny') Albites was de dochter van een gepensioneerde administrateur bij het pauselijke leger toen ze in 1820 te Rome trouwde met de Maastrichtse beeldhouwer Mathieu Kessels. Ze kregen zes kinderen. Fanny heeft waarschijnlijk model gestaan voor het grafmonument dat Kessels maakte voor gravin De Celles (overl. 1828), echtgenote van de Nederlandse ambassadeur in Rome, dat in 1836 in de San Giuliano dei Fiamminghi in Rome werd geplaatst. Ook is ze, samen met haar kinderen, te zien op het ontwerp voor een grafmonument voor Kessels zelf (1836), waartoe ze na zijn overlijden vermoedelijk de opdracht gaf aan de beeldhouwer Jan Antonie van der Ven. Fanny's broer Achille C. Albites publiceerde in 1837 in Brussel een Franstalige biografie van Kessels.

$Alewijn.en_GB:
Henry, Henrick or Hendrick Alewijn - in Italy Enrico Alewin - was a Dutch merchant and consul-general in Genoa, distinguished as a Knight of the Order of the Dutch Lion (cf. Opregte Haarlemsche Courant, 10 August 1837) and Commander in the Order of the Oak Crown. He came from a distinguished family and was born as one of five children of the merchant Jacob Alewijn (1756-1789), originally from Amsterdam but working in London for a long time, and Cornelia Henrietta Backer (1761-1838). Of Henrick's four siblings, engineer and commissioner of city public works of Amsterdam Cornelis Alewijn (1788-1839) was the best known. 
On 20 May 1819, Henrick married - in Genoa - Eugenia Francisca Becker from Hamburg. It is clear from the marriage certificate that the marriage had been arranged by the Dutch consul in Genoa Joseph Dodero and was performed by Thomas Trevor Trevor L.L.D., Predendary of the Anglican Church in the bride's parental home. Also at Dodero's insistence and authority, the marriage was registered in Amsterdam (13 July 1819). Notification in the Amsterdamsche Courant followed a day later. The couple had five daughters, three of whom died in infancy. Their births were declared in Genoa to the vice-consul of the Netherlands Paolo Domenico Dodero, again in the knowledge that this meant the children could also be registered in the birth register of Amsterdam.
Apart from the documentation unlocked by the DELEGATO project, very little is known about Alewijn's consular activities. However, there are several accounts of his role as host in Genoa for travellers from the Netherlands. On 8 November 1839, the ship De Rhijn, commanded by Prince Hendrik 'the Navigator' of the Netherlands, called at the port of Genoa. When the quarantine period had ended, envoy Heldewier and consul-general Alewijn made their appearance on board and witnessed as many as 60 cannon shots with which all dignitaries were welcomed on board. From 29 July to 6 August, and again from 19-25 August 1829, Alewijn was visited by his brother Dirk Jacob (1787-1863) and sister-in-law Jacoba Elisabeth Dedel (1794-1875) as they travelled through Germany, Zwtiserland and Italy. They visited his villa outside the city and through his mediation they were able to visit the royal and some noble residences in the city, which says a lot about Alevin's status. This much is also clear from the fact that around 1840 he was living on Via Balbi (No 93), the street where the highest Genovese nobility resided.
Alewijn assisted other Dutch travellers besides his family. In the same year (1829), he had managed to negotiate two lodges at the Teatro Carlo Felice for lieutenant P.A. Talma on his Journey (1835) through mediation with the 'authorities'. Some year later, Johan Hendrik Beucker Andreae also recalled how, during his trip to Italy in 1840-41, he was warmly received by Alewijn in his 'dear villa' outside the city, with a splendid view. Apart from the sights and trivia about Genoa, the gentlemen spoke 'in a quiet touching mood about striking losses', including the recent death of Alewijn's two teenage daughters (see also Opregte Haarlemsche Courant, 17-11 1840). The finest portrait of Alewijn, however, is probably that by Johannes Jacobus Franciscus Wap, who visited Genoa on his way to Rome in the spring of 1837. With a pack of Dutch newspapers that he had received from envoy Heldewier in Turin for Alewijn, he made his way to the consulate general's office, then located on the Ponte delle Legne (called Ponte Calvi since about 1872), in the old harbour. Alewijn provided entrance tickets and credentials to meet leading scientists, such as physician and cholera researcher Evandro Accame. Gratefully, Wap penned the following sketch of Alewijn: 'Mr Alewijn is a man in the prime of years, highly active in his industrious office, very courteous, generous and casual in his dealings, a warm Dutchman, ardent supporter of the arts and sciences, tender husband of a talented wife, and an exemplary father of very lovely children. During my stay in Genoa the Alewijn family behaved in the most obliging manner to me.'
The death certificate for Henrick Alewijn was prepared by Ernest Vaucher, Reformed Protestant pastor at the Protestant chapel in Genoa. The certificate learns that burial took place on 27 February 1850 in the cemetery of 'La Cava', located at the end of today's Via Corsica, a cemetery for non-Catholics also used by Genoa's Jewish community until the cemetery was cleared in 1886.
$Alewijn.it_IT:
Henry, Henrick o Hendrick Alewijn - in italiano Enrico Alewin - fu un mercante olandese e console generale a Genova, che ebbe il titolo di Cavaliere dell'Ordine del Leone d'Olanda (cfr Opregte Haarlemsche Courant, 10 agosto 1837) e Commendatore dell'Ordine della Corona di Quercia. Proveniva da una famiglia della buona borghesia e nacque come uno dei cinque figli del mercante Jacob Alewijn (1756-1789), originario di Amsterdam ma attivo a lungo a Londra, e di Cornelia Henrietta Backer (1761-1838). Dei quattro fratelli di Henrick, Cornelis Alewijn (1788-1839), fu il più conosciuto come ingegnere e commissario ai lavori pubblici della città di Amsterdam. 
Il 20 maggio 1819 Henrick sposò - a Genova - Eugenia Francisca Becker di Amburgo. Dal certificato di matrimonio risulta chiaramente che il matrimonio era stato organizzato dal console olandese a Genova Joseph Dodero e fu celebrato da Thomas Trevor Trevor L.L.D., Predentario della Chiesa Anglicana nella casa dei genitori della sposa. Anche per l' insistenza e l'autorità di Dodero, il matrimonio fu registrato ad Amsterdam (13 luglio 1819). La notifica nell'Amsterdamsche Courant venne fatta il giorno dopo. La coppia ebbe cinque figlie, tre delle quali morirono in tenera età. La loro nascita venne dichiarata a Genova al viceconsole dei Paesi Bassi Paolo Domenico Dodero, sempre nella consapevolezza che ciò avrebbe portato a iscrivere i bambini anche nel registro delle nascite di Amsterdam.
A parte la documentazione recuperata dal progetto DELEGATO, si sa molto poco delle attività consolari di Alewijn. Tuttavia, ci sono diversi resoconti del suo ruolo di ospite a Genova per i viaggiatori provenienti dai Paesi Bassi. L'8 novembre 1839 la nave De Rhijn, comandata dal principe Hendrik 'il Navigatore' dei Paesi Bassi, fece scalo nel porto di Genova. Terminato il periodo di quarantena, fecero la loro comparsa a bordo l'inviato Heldewier e il console generale Alewijn e assistettero a ben 60 colpi di cannone con cui tutti i dignitari furono accolti a bordo. Dal 29 luglio al 6 agosto, e di nuovo dal 19 al 25 agosto 1829, Alewijn ricevette la visita del fratello Dirk Jacob (1787-1863) e della cognata Jacoba Elisabeth Dedel (1794-1875) mentre viaggiavano attraverso la Germania, la Svizzera e l'Italia. Visitarono la sua villa fuori città e grazie alla sua mediazione poterono visitare la residenza reale e alcune residenze nobiliari della città, il che la dice lunga sullo status di Alevin. Ciò risulta evidente anche dal fatto che intorno al 1840 abitava in via Balbi (n. 93), la strada dove risiedeva la più alta nobiltà genovese.
Alewijn assistette altri viaggiatori olandesi oltre alla sua famiglia. Nello stesso anno (1829), era riuscito a negoziare due logge al Teatro Carlo Felice per il tenente P.A. Talma durante il suo viaggio (1835) attraverso la mediazione con le “autorità”. Qualche anno dopo, anche Johan Hendrik Beucker Andreae ricordava come, durante il suo viaggio in Italia nel 1840-41, fosse stato accolto calorosamente da Alewijn nella sua “cara villa” fuori città, con una splendida vista. Oltre ai luoghi e alle curiosità su Genova, i due gentiluomini parlarono “in uno stato d'animo tranquillo e commovente di perdite impressionanti”, tra cui la recente morte delle due figlie adolescenti di Alewijn (cfr. anche Opregte Haarlemsche Courant, 17-11 1840). Il più bel ritratto di Alewijn  è probabilmente quello di Johannes Jacobus Franciscus Wap, che visitò Genova mentre si recava a Roma nella primavera del 1837. Con un pacco di giornali olandesi che aveva ricevuto dall'inviato Heldewier a Torino per Alewijn, si diresse verso l'ufficio del consolato generale, allora situato sul Ponte delle Legne (chiamato Ponte Calvi dal 1872 circa), nel porto antico. Alewijn fornì i biglietti d'ingresso e le credenziali per incontrare scienziati di spicco, come il medico e ricercatore sul colera Evandro Accame. Con gratitudine, Wap scrisse il seguente identikit di Alewijn: “Il signor Alewijn è un uomo nel fiore degli anni, molto attivo nel suo laborioso ufficio, molto cortese, generoso e disinvolto nei suoi rapporti, un olandese caloroso, ardente sostenitore delle arti e delle scienze, tenero marito di una moglie di talento e padre esemplare di bambini molto belli. Durante il mio soggiorno a Genova la famiglia Alewijn si è comportata nel modo più cortese con me”.
Il certificato di morte di Henrick Alewijn fu redatto da Ernest Vaucher, pastore protestante riformato della cappella protestante di Genova. Dal certificato si apprende che la sepoltura avvenne il 27 febbraio 1850 nel cimitero de “La Cava”, situato alla fine dell'attuale via Corsica, un cimitero per non cattolici utilizzato anche dalla comunità ebraica genovese fino allo sgombero del cimitero nel 1886.
$Alewijn.nl_NL:
Henry, Henrick of Hendrick Alewijn – in Italië Enrico Alewin – was een Nederlandse koopman en consul-generaal in Genua, onderscheiden als Ridder in de Orde Nederlandse Leeuw (vgl. Opregte Haarlemsche Courant, 10 augustus 1837) en Commendeur in de Orde van de Eikenkroon. Hij was afkomstig uit een deftige familie en werd geboren als één van vijf kinderen van koopman Jacob Alewijn (1756-1789), afkomstig uit Amsterdam maar langdurig werkzaam in Londen, en Cornelia Henrietta Backer (1761-1838). Van Henricks vier broers en zussen was ingenieur en commissaris van stadspublieke werken van Amsterdam Cornelis Alewijn (1788-1839) de bekendste. 
Op 20 mei 1819 trouwde Henrick - in Genua - met Eugenia Francisca Becker uit Hamburg. Uit de huwelijksakte wordt duidelijk dat het huwelijk door de Nederlandse consul in Genua Joseph Dodero was geënsceneerd en werd voltrokken door Thomas Trevor Trevor L.L.D., Predendary van de Anglicaanse Kerk in het ouderlijk huis van de bruid. Ook op aandringen en gezag van Dodero wordt het huwelijk in Amsterdam geregistreerd (13 juli 1819). Een dag na inschrijving van het huwelijk in Amsterdam volgde de kennisgeving in de Amsterdamsche Courant. Het echtpaar kreeg vijf dochters, van wie er drie op jonge leeftijd overleden. Hun geboorten werden in Genua aangegeven bij de vice-consul der Nederlanden Paolo Domenico Dodero, opnieuw in de wetenschap dat daarmee de kinderen ook in het geboorteregister van Amsterdam konden worden geregistreerd. 
Afgezien van de documentatie die dankzij het DELEGATO-project wordt ontsloten, is over Alewijns consulaire activiteiten heel weinig bekend. Wel zijn er verschillende getuigenissen van zijn rol als gastheer in Genua voor reizigers uit Nederland. Op 8 november 1839 deed het schip De Rhijn onder bevel van Prins Hendrik 'de Zeevaarder' der Nederlanden de haven van Genua aan. Na afloop van de quarantaineperiode maakten gezant Heldewier en consul-generaal Alewijn hun opwachting aan boord en waren getuige van de wel 60 kanonschoten waarmee allee hoogwaardigheidsbekleders aan boord werden verwelkomd. Van 29 juli tot 6 augustus, en opnieuw van 19-25 augustus 1829 kreeg Alewijn zijn broer Dirk Jacob (1787-1863) en schoonzus Jacoba Elisabeth Dedel (1794-1875) op bezoek, tijdens hun reis door Duitsland, Zwitserland en Italië. Ze bezochten zijn villa buiten de stad en door zijn bemiddeling konden ze de koninklijke en enkele adellijke residenties in de stad bezoeken, hetgeen veel zegt over Alewijns status. Zoveel blijkt ook wel uit het feit dat hij rond 1840 woonachtig was aan de Via Balbi (nr. 93), de straat waar de hoogste Genovese adel resideerde.
Alewijn stond behalve zijn familie ook andere reizigers bij. In hetzelfde jaar (1829) had hij voor luitenant P.A. Talma op diens Reistogtje (1835) door bemiddeling met de 'autoriteiten' twee loges in het Teatro Carlo Felice weten te bespreken. Ook Johan Hendrik Beucker Andreae herinnerde zich hoe hij tijdens zijn reis naar Italië in 1840-41 hartelijk door Alewijn was ontvangen in diens 'lieve villa' buiten de stad, met schitterend uitzicht. Behalve over de beziens- en wetenswaardigheden over Genua spraken de heren 'in een stille aandoenlijke stemming over treffende verliezen', waaronder het recente overlijden van Alewijns twee tienerdochters (zie ook Opregte Haarlemsche Courant, 17-11 1840). Het mooiste portretje van Alewijn is echter vermoedelijk dat van Johannes Jacobus Franciscus Wap, die in het voorjaar van 1837 op weg naar Rome Genua aandeed. Met een pak Nederlandse kranten die hij van gezant Heldewier in Turijn voor Alewijn had meegekregen, begaf hij zich naar het kantoor van het consulaat-generaal, toen gevestigd aan de Ponte delle Legne (sinds ca. 1872 Ponte Calvi genoemd), in de oude haven. Alewijn zorgde voor toegangsbewijzen en geloofsbrieven om vooraanstaande wetenschappers te kunnen ontmoeten, zoals medicus en cholera-onderzoeker Evandro Accame. Dankbaar tekende Wap de volgende schets van Alewijn op: 'De heer Alewijn is een man in de kracht der jaren, hoogst werkzaam in zijn bedrijvig ambt, zeer wellevend, gul en ongedwongen van omgang, warm Nederlander, vurig voorstander van kunsten en wetenschappen, teeder echtgenoot eener talentvolle gade, en voorbeeldig vader van allerliefste kinderen. Gedurende mijn verblijf te Genua heeft de familie Alewijn zich op de verpligtendste wijze mijnwaart gedragen.'
De overlijdensakte voor Henrick Alewijn werd opgemaakt door Ernest Vaucher, gereformeerd-protestantse voorganger bij de protestantse kapel in Genua. De akte leert dat de begrafenis plaatsvond op 27 februari 1850 op het kerkhof van 'La Cava', gelegen aan het einde van de huidige Via Corsica, een begraafplaats voor niet-katholieken waarvan ook de Joodse gemeenschap van Genua gebruikmaakte, tot het kerkhof in 1886 werd geruimd.

$Altieri.en_GB: Cardinal Ludovico Altieri was born as the son of Paluzzo Altieri (1760-1834), the fifth prince of Oriolo and senator of Rome. Among other things, he served as apostolic nuncio in Austria and as bishop of Ephesus, before pope Gregory XVI elevated him to the cardinalate in 1840. In addition, pope Pius IX named him president (governor) of Rome and the Comarca, a post he maintained until 1849, and again from 1850 to 1855. After the fall of the Roman Republic of 1849 and the restauration of papal authority in Rome, he became a member of the Governmental Commission Commission for Reform of the Papal States, together with cardinals Gabriele Della Genga Sermattei and Luigi Vannicelli Casoni. In this role, he made, ultimately futile, attempts at political reconciliation. Altieri was a great lover of art and – according to rumour – of women. He died during the cholera epidemic of 1867.
$Altieri.it_IT: Il cardinale Ludovico Altieri, fu uno dei figli di Paluzzo Altieri (1760-1834), quinto principe di Oriolo e senatore di Roma. Tra le altre cose, prestò servizio come nunzio apostolico in Austria e come vescovo di Efeso, prima che papa Gregorio XVI lo elevasse al cardinalato nel 1840. Papa Pio IX lo nominò Governatore di Roma e della Comarca, carica che ricoprì fino al 1849, e successivamente dal 1850 al 1855. Dopo la caduta della Repubblica Romana del 1849 e il ripristino dell'autorità pontificia a Roma, divenne membro della Commissione Governativa per la Riforma dello Stato Pontificio, insieme ai cardinali Gabriele della Genga Sermattei e Luigi Vannicelli Casoni. In questo ruolo effettuò tentativi, alla fine inutili, di riconciliazione politica. Altieri fu un grande amante dell'arte e – secondo alcune indiscrezioni – delle donne. Morì durante l'epidemia di colera del 1867.
$Altieri.nl_NL: Kardinaal Ludovico Altieri werd geboren als zoon van Paluzzo Altieri (1760-1834), vijfde prins van Oriolo en senator van Rome. Hij was onder meer apostolisch nuntius in Oostenrijk en bisschop van Efeze, voordat hij in 1840 door paus Gregorius XVI tot kardinaal werd benoemd. Daarnaast maakte paus Pius IX hem in 1847 president (gouverneur) van Rome en de Comarca, een functie die hij tot 1849 bekleedde, en wederom tussen 1850 en 1855. Na de val van de Romeinse Republiek van 1849 en het herstel van de pauselijke macht in Rome werd hij lid van de regeringscommissie van de Pauselijke Staat, samen met kardinalen Gabriele Della Genga Sermattei en Luigi Vannicelli Casoni. Altieri zette daarbij vergeefs in op een politiek van verzoening. Hij was een groot kunstverzamelaar en – volgens geruchten – vrouwenliefhebber. Tijdens de cholera-epidemie van 1867 overleed hij.

$Amici.en_GB: Camillo Amici completed his ecclesiastical studies and in 1836 entered the Signatura of Justice of the Papal States, becoming its Dean. He subsequently devoted himself to administrative affairs. He was a member of the Public Safety Commission set up to deal with the cholera epidemic of 1837. In 1839-1840 he was apostolic delegate of Spoleto. In 1846, he was appointed secretary of the Commission for the Construction of Railways by the new pope, Pius IX. The following year, he became secretary of the Council of Ministers, as well as a member of the commission for the press law. Subsequently he was entrusted with the Ministry of the Interior. After the restoration of the papal government following the fall of the Roman Repoublic of 1849, he was sent to Ancona as apostolic delegate and was appointed Minister of the Interior and Police. In 1856, he was transferred to Bologna as commissioner for the legation of Romagna. In 1859, he was called back to Rome, where he was appointed as Minister of Commerce, Fine Arts and Public Works. From 1861 to 1870, he remained in government and was also appointed consultant to the Sacred Congregation of Bishops and Regulars and member of the Commission for Sacred Archaeology. After becoming blind, he eventually died in Rome on 1 April 1877.
$Amici.it_IT: Camillo Amici compì gli studi ecclesiastici e nel 1836 entrò nella Segnatura di giustizia dello Stato Pontificio, divenendo Decano. Successivamente si dedicò agli affari amministrativi. Fece parte della Commissione di pubblica incolumità per fronteggiare l'epidemia di colera del 1837. Nel 1839-1840 fu delegato apostolico di Spoleto. Nel 1846 da Pio IX fu nominato segretario della Commissione per la costruzione delle strade ferrate. L'anno successivo divenne segretario del Consiglio dei ministri e fece parte della commissione per la legge sulla stampa e gli venne affidato il ministero degli Interni. Dopo la restaurazione del governo pontificio nel 1849,  fu inviato ad Ancona come delegato apostolico e fu nominato Ministro degli Interni e di polizia. Nel 1856 fu trasferito a Bologna, come commissario per la legazione delle Romagne. Nel 1859 fu richiamato a Roma, dove fu nominato Ministro del Commercio, Belle Arti e Lavori pubblici. Dal 1861 al 1870 rimase al governo e fu nominato anche consultore della S. Congregazione dei Vescovi e Regolari e membro della Commissione di archeologia sacra. Divenuto cieco morì a Roma il 1 aprile 1877.
$Amici.nl_NL: Camillo Amici voltooide zijn kerkelijke studies en trad in 1836 toe tot de Segnatura van Justitie van de Pauselijke Staten, waarvan hij decaan werd. Vervolgens legde hij zich toe op bestuurlijke taken. Hij maakte deel uit van de Commissie voor openbare veiligheid die de cholera-epidemie van 1837 het hoofd moest bieden. In 1839-1840 was hij apostolische gedelegeerde van Spoleto. In 1846 werd hij door de nieuwe paus Pius IX benoemd tot secretaris van de Commissie voor de aanleg van spoorwegen. Het jaar daarop werd hij secretaris van de Ministerraad en lid van de commissie voor de wet op de drukpers; ten slotte werd hem de leiding over het ministerie van Binnenlandse Zaken toevertrouwd. Na het herstel van het pauselijk gezag van de val van de Romeinse Republiek van 1849 werd hij als apostolisch legaat naar Ancona gestuurd en benoemd tot minister van Binnenlandse Zaken en Politie. In 1856 werd hij overgeplaatst naar Bologna, als commissaris voor de legatie van Romagna. In 1859 werd hij teruggeroepen naar Rome, waar hij werd benoemd tot minister van Handel, Schone Kunsten en Openbare Werken. Van 1861 tot 1870 bleef hij deel uitmaken van de regering en werd hij ook benoemd tot adviseur van de Heilige Congregatie van Bisschoppen en Regulieren; ook was hij lid van de Commissie voor Christelijke Archeologie. Uiteindelijk werd hij blind en stierf op 1 april 1877 in Rome.

$Antonelli.en_GB: Giacomo Antonelli, nicknamed “the Italian Richelieu”, immediately belonged to the inner circle of pope Pius IX after the conclave of 1846. He was elevated to the cardinalate in June 1847 and was immediately selected in the first papal council of ministers; in the first government of lay ministers (March 1848), he became secretary of state, or the head of government, a position taken over by Pellegrino Rossi soon after. In the summer of 1848, Antonelli turned his back on reformist politics and worked towards a rapprochement with the Austrian Empire instead. After the murder of Rossi (15 December 1848), Antonelli was the one who advised the pope to flee to Gaeta. There he became cardinal-secretary of state again, a function he retained until 1870, thereby ensuring he remained the most influential politician in the (State of the) Church besides Pius IX. After the fall of the Roman Republic of 1849 and the restoration of papal authority in Rome, Antonelli's regime was reactionary and repressive.
$Antonelli.it_IT: Giacomo Antonelli, soprannominato “il Richelieu italiano”, fece subito parte della cerchia ristretta di papa Pio IX dopo il conclave del 1846. Fu elevato a cardinale nel giugno 1847 e fu subito scelto nel primo consiglio dei ministri pontificio; nel primo governo di ministri laici (marzo 1848), divenne segretario di Stato, ovvero capo del governo, incarico assunto poco dopo da Pellegrino Rossi. Nell'estate del 1848 Antonelli voltò le spalle alla politica riformista e lavorò invece per un riavvicinamento all'Impero austriaco. Dopo l'omicidio del Rossi (15 dicembre 1848), fu proprio Antonelli a consigliare al papa di fuggire a Gaeta. Lì divenne nuovamente cardinale segretario di Stato, funzione che mantenne fino al 1870, assicurandosi così di rimanere il politico più influente nello Stato della Chiesa accanto a Pio IX. Dopo la caduta della Repubblica Romana del 1849 e la restaurazione dell'autorità papale a Roma, il regime di Antonelli fu reazionario e repressivo.
$Antonelli.nl_NL: Giacomo Antonelli, bijgenaamd 'de Italiaanse Richelieu', behoorde na het conclaaf 1846 direct tot de inner circle van Pius IX. In juni 1847 werd hij tot kardinaal gewijd en kwam hij meteen in de eerste pauselijke ministerraad; in de eerste regering met lekenministers (maart 1848) werd hij staatssecretaris, ofwel regeringsleider, een positie die hij weldra moest afstaan aan Pellegrino Rossi. In de zomer van 1848 keerde Antonelli de hervormingspolitiek echter de rug toe en zocht hij toenadering tot het Keizerrijk Oostenrijk. Na de moord op Rossi (15 december 1848) was het Antonelli die de paus adviseerde naar Gaeta te vluchten. Daar werd hij opnieuw kardinaal-staatssecretaris, een functie die hij tot 1870 behield, waarmee hij in de Kerk(elijke Staat) de meest invloedrijke politicus naast Pius IX bleef. Na de val van de Romeinse Republiek van 1849 en de restauratie van de pauselijke macht in Rome, voerde hij een reactionair en repressief bewind.

$ArataA.en_GB: Alessandro Arata, sometimes Arati, was a merchant and consul for the Kingdom of the Netherlands in Civitavecchia, the main port of the Papal States on the Tyrrhenian Sea. He was from a lineage originally from Liguria. In the late 18th and 19th centuries, the Aratas were among Civitavecchia's most influential families. Alessandro's grandfather Teofanio (1770-1838) had also been consul for several European countries, in addition to the Netherlands, Denmark and Russia. In addition, he was honorary chamberlain to the pope. Alessandro's father Luigi became acting consul for Denmark in 1837; his brother Giovanni for Russia and the Netherlands. After Giovanni's death, Luigi also took over both those consulates and soon became full consul for the Netherlands (RD of 2 March 1838, Dagblad van 's-Gravenhaghe, 13 March 1838). On 1 September 1873, Alessandro Arata took over his father's office (Nederlandsche Staatscourant, 8 September 1873), until he too was honorably discharged on 21 November 1878 and handed over the consulate to his niece Celestina' s husband , Count Gustavo De Marsanich (born 1834), who in turn handed over his duties to his son Gualtiero in 1901.
$ArataA.it_IT: Alessandro Arata, talvolta Arati, fu un mercante e console del Regno dei Paesi Bassi a Civitavecchia, il principale porto dello Stato Pontificio sul Mar Tirreno. Era di una famiglia originaria della Liguria. Alla fine del XVIII e del XIX secolo, gli Arata erano tra le famiglie più influenti di Civitavecchia. Il nonno di Alessandro, Teofanio (1770-1838), era stato anche console per diversi Paesi europei, oltre che per i Paesi Bassi, la Danimarca e la Russia. Inoltre, era stato camerlengo onorario del Papa. Il padre di Alessandro, Luigi, divenne console ad interim per la Danimarca nel 1837; suo fratello Giovanni per la Russia e i Paesi Bassi. Dopo la morte di Giovanni, anche Luigi assunse entrambi i consolati e presto divenne console titolare per i Paesi Bassi (RD del 2 marzo 1838, Dagblad van 's-Gravenhaghe, 13 marzo 1838). Il 1° settembre 1873, Alessandro Arata subentra nella carica paterna (Nederlandsche Staatscourant, 8 settembre 1873), finché anch'egli non viene congedato con onore il 21 novembre 1878 e cede il consolato al marito della nipote Celestina, il conte Gustavo De Marsanich (nato nel 1834), che a sua volta cede le funzioni al figlio Gualtiero nel 1901.
$ArataA.nl_NL: Alessandro Arata, soms Arati, was een koopman en consul voor het Koninkrijk der Nederlanden in Civitavecchia, de belangrijkste haven van de Pauselijke Staten aan de Tyrreense Zee. Hij was afkomstig uit een geslacht dat oorspronkelijk uit Ligurië kwam. In de late achttiende en negentiende eeuw behoorden de Arata's tot de invloedrijkste families van Civitavecchia. Alessandro's grootvader Teofanio (1770-1838) was eveneens consul geweest voor verschillende Europese landen, behalve Nederland ook Denemarken en Rusland. Daarnaast was hij honorair kamerheer van de paus. Alessandro's vader Luigi werd in 1837 waarnemend consul voor Denemarken; diens broer Giovanni voor Rusland en Nederland. Na de dood van Giovanni nam Luigi ook die beide consulaten over en werd weldra volwaardig consul voor Nederland (KB van 2 maart 1838, Dagblad van 's-Gravenhaghe, 13 maart 1838). Op 1 september 1873 nam Alessandro Arata het ambt van zijn vader over (Nederlandsche Staatscourant, 8 september 1873), tot ook hem op 21 november 1878 eervol ontslag werd verleend en hij het consulaat overdroeg aan de man van zijn nicht Celestina, graaf Gustavo De Marsanich (geb. 1834), die op zijn beurt in 1901 zijn taken overdroeg aan zijn zoon Gualtiero.

$ArataG.en_GB: Giovanni Arata, sometimes Arati, was a merchant and consul for the Kingdom of the Netherlands in Civitavecchia, the main port of the Papal States on the Tyrrhenian Sea. He was from a lineage originally from Liguria. In the late 18th and 19th centuries, the Aratas were among Civitavecchia's most influential families. Giovanni's father Teofanio (1770-1838) was also consul for several European countries, apart from the Netherlands also Denmark and Russia. In addition, he was honorary chamberlain to the pope. Teofanio's sons Giovanni and Luigi succeeded him as consul: in 1837 Giovanni became acting consul for Russia and the Netherlands and Luigi for Denmark. When Giovanni died on 23 January 1838, Luigi also took over both his brother's duties. From 2 March 1838 (RD in Dagblad van 's-Gravenhaghe, 13 March 1838), Luigi was appointed full consul for the Netherlands, until on 1 September 1873 his son Alessandro Arata - Giovanni's nephew - took over, until he in his turn was dismissed on 21 November 1878. Giovanni's daughter Celestina married Count Gustavo De Marsanich (born 1834), who would also serve as Dutch consul from 1879, as would his son Gualtiero (from 1901). It seems unlikely that the consul general of the Kingdoms of the Two Sicilies and Sardinia in Amsterdam during the second quarter of the nineteenth century, Paolo Domenico Arata, was a close relative.

Hij was afkomstig uit een geslacht dat oorspronkelijk uit Ligurië kwam. In de late achttiende en negentiende eeuw behoorden de Arata's tot de invloedrijkste families van Civitavecchia. Giovanni's vader Teofanio (1770-1838) was eveneens consul voor verschillende Europese landen, behalve Nederland ook Denemarken en Rusland. Daarnaast was hij honorair kamerheer van de paus. Teofanio's zonen Giovanni en Luigi volgden hem op als consul: in 1837 werd Giovanni waarnemend consul voor Rusland en Nederland en Luigi voor Luigi voor Denemarken. Het lijkt onwaarschijnlijk dat de consul-generaal van de koninkrijken der Beide Siciliën en Sardinië in Amsterdam tijdens het tweede kwart van de negentiende eeuw, Paolo Domenico Arata, naaste familie was.

$ArataL.en_GB:
Luigi Arata, sometimes Arati, was a merchant and consul for the Kingdom of the Netherlands in Civitavecchia, the main port of the Papal States on the Tyrrhenian Sea. He was from a lineage originally from Liguria. In the late 18th and 19th centuries, the Aratas were among Civitavecchia's most influential families. Luigi's father Teofanio (1770-1838) was also consul for several European countries, besides the Netherlands also Denmark and Russia. In addition, he was honorary chamberlain to the pope. Teofanio's sons Giovanni and Luigi succeeded him as consuls: in 1837, Luigi became acting consul for Denmark and Giovanni for Russia and the Netherlands. After the latter's death (23 January 1838), Luigi also took over both his brother's duties; for the Netherlands, he was appointed consul by royal decree on 2 March 1838 (Dagblad van 's-Gravenhaghe, 13 March 1838). He held this post until, on 1 September 1873, his son (?) Alessandro Arata took over (Nederlandsche Staatscourant, 8 September 1873), who in turn granted honourable discharge on 21 November 1878. 
During his term of office, Luigi Arata promoted not only the interests of the aforementioned countries but also, intermittently, those of the 'Levantines': European trading posts in coastal towns of Eastern Mediterranean (present-day Greece, Turkey, Syria, Palestine, Egypt). He was married to Anna Flaminia Alibrandi. His niece Celestina, daughter of his brother Giovanni, married Count Gustavo De Marsanich (born 1834), who in turn would serve as Dutch consul from 1879, as would his son Gualtiero (from 1901). It seems unlikely that the consul general of the Kingdoms of the Two Sicilies and Sardinia in Amsterdam during the second quarter of the nineteenth century, Paolo Domenico Arata, was a close relative. Luigi Arata was knighted in 1837. In 1847, he was one of the founders of the Cassa di Risparmio di Civitavecchia and secretary of its board; in 1852, he was appointed vice-president of the Civitavecchia Chamber of Commerce. According to the Rivista di legislatura e di giurisprudenza of 1851 and 1864, which reported, among other things, the most important appointments in the magistracy of the Papal States, he was gonfaloniere (mayor) of his city in those years. The Aratas also owned real estate in Civitavecchia and had an estate (the 'Farnesiana') in the nearby Monti della Tolfa, where they fell victim to looting and arson by a gang of bandits in 1867 - a traumatic event about which Luigi left a letter.
Particularly during the revolutionary biennio 1848-1849, Luigi Arata meticulously reported events in Civitavecchia to the Dutch envoy in Rome, Count Liedekerke de Beaufort. In late November 1848, for example, he wrote about rumours that the pope, who had fled Rome, had sailed from Civitavecchia to France on the ship the Ténaire, with several cardinals and the diplomatic representatives of France and Portugal, among others. In April 1849, he frequently informed both the secretary of the Dutch Legation Magrini (in Rome) and envoy Liedekerke (in Gaeta) about the landing in Civitavecchia of a French expeditionary corps, which was soon to march against the Roman Republic. When it came to trade relations between the Netherlands and the Papal States, according to Liedekerke, A. displayed 'un zèle aussi louable qu'éclairé'. For example, he championed new trade treaties and direct contacts - i.e. without distributive trade or brokering - with Rome and Civitavecchia by the trading houses in Rotterdam and Amsterdam, in order to improve, in particular, the access of colonial goods from the Dutch East Indies to the Papal States. He also reported regularly on the (increasing) number of Dutch merchant ships in Civitavecchia, not only in his annual Rapporto commerciale del porto di Civitavecchia.

Luigi Arata, talvolta Arati, fu un mercante e console del Regno dei Paesi Bassi a Civitavecchia, il principale porto dello Stato Pontificio sul Mar Tirreno. Era di una famiglia originaria della Liguria. Alla fine del XVIII e del XIX secolo, gli Arata erano tra le famiglie più influenti di Civitavecchia. Il padre di Luigi, Teofanio (1770-1838), fu anche console per diversi Paesi europei, oltre che per i Paesi Bassi anche per la Danimarca e la Russia. Inoltre, fu camerlengo onorario del Papa. I figli di Teofanio, Giovanni e Luigi, gli succedettero come consoli: nel 1837, Luigi divenne console ad interim per la Danimarca e Giovanni per la Russia e i Paesi Bassi. Dopo la morte di quest'ultimo (23 gennaio 1838), Luigi assunse anche le funzioni di entrambi i fratelli; per i Paesi Bassi fu nominato console con decreto reale il 2 marzo 1838 (Dagblad van 's-Gravenhaghe, 13 marzo 1838). Mantenne questa carica fino a quando, il 1° settembre 1873, gli subentrò il figlio (?) Alessandro Arata (Nederlandsche Staatscourant, 8 settembre 1873), che a sua volta concesse il congedo con onore il 21 novembre 1878. 
Durante il suo mandato, Luigi Arata promosse non solo gli interessi dei Paesi citati ma anche, a intermittenza, quelli dei “Levantini”: le postazioni commerciali europee nelle città costiere del Mediterraneo orientale (attuali Grecia, Turchia, Siria, Palestina, Egitto). Si sposò con Anna Flaminia Alibrandi. Sua nipote Celestina, figlia di suo fratello Giovanni, sposò il conte Gustavo De Marsanich (nato nel 1834), che a sua volta servirà come console olandese dal 1879, così come suo figlio Gualtiero (dal 1901). Sembra improbabile che il console generale del Regno delle Due Sicilie e della Sardegna ad Amsterdam nel secondo quarto del XIX secolo, Paolo Domenico Arata, fosse un parente stretto. Luigi Arata fu nominato cavaliere nel 1837. Nel 1847 fu tra i fondatori della Cassa di Risparmio di Civitavecchia e segretario del suo consiglio di amministrazione; nel 1852 fu nominato vicepresidente della Camera di Commercio di Civitavecchia. Secondo la Rivista di legislatura e di giurisprudenza del 1851 e del 1864, che riportava, tra l'altro, le nomine più importanti della magistratura dello Stato Pontificio, in quegli anni era gonfaloniere (sindaco) della sua città. Gli Arata possedevano anche beni immobili a Civitavecchia e una tenuta (la “Farnesiana”) sui vicini Monti della Tolfa, dove nel 1867 furono vittime di saccheggi e incendi dolosi da parte di una banda di briganti - un evento traumatico sul quale Luigi lasciò una lettera.
Soprattutto durante il biennio rivoluzionario 1848-1849, Luigi Arata riferì meticolosamente gli eventi di Civitavecchia all'inviato olandese a Roma, il conte Liedekerke de Beaufort. Alla fine di novembre del 1848, ad esempio, scriveva di voci secondo cui il Papa, fuggito da Roma, sarebbe salpato da Civitavecchia verso la Francia con la nave Ténaire, insieme a diversi cardinali e ai rappresentanti diplomatici di Francia e Portogallo, tra gli altri. Nell'aprile del 1849, egli informò frequentemente sia il segretario della Legazione olandese Magrini (a Roma) sia l'inviato Liedekerke (a Gaeta) dello sbarco a Civitavecchia di un corpo di spedizione francese, che presto avrebbe marciato contro la Repubblica Romana. Quando si trattava di relazioni commerciali tra i Paesi Bassi e lo Stato Pontificio, secondo Liedekerke, A. mostrava “un zèle aussi louable qu'éclairé”. Ad esempio, si fece promotore di nuovi trattati commerciali e di contatti diretti - cioè senza commercio distributivo o intermediazione - con Roma e Civitavecchia da parte delle case commerciali di Rotterdam e Amsterdam, al fine di migliorare, in particolare, l'accesso dei beni coloniali dalle Indie Orientali Olandesi allo Stato Pontificio. Inoltre, riferiva regolarmente sul numero (crescente) di navi mercantili olandesi a Civitavecchia, non solo nel suo annuale Rapporto commerciale del porto di Civitavecchia.

Tijdens zijn ambtsperiode behartigde Luigi Arata behalve de belangen van de genoemde landen ook, met tussenpozen, die van de 'Levantijnen': Europese handelsposten in kustplaatsen van Oostelijke Middellandse Zeegebied (het huidige Griekenland, Turkije, Syrië, Palestina, Egypte). Hij was getrouwd met Anna Flaminia Alibrandi. Zijn nichtje Celestina, dochter van zijn broer Giovanni, trouwde met graaf Gustavo De Marsanich (geb. 1834), die op zijn beurt vanaf 1879 als Nederlandse consul zou dienen, net als diens zoon Gualtiero (vanaf 1901). Het lijkt onwaarschijnlijk dat de consul-generaal van de koninkrijken der Beide Siciliën en Sardinië in Amsterdam tijdens het tweede kwart van de negentiende eeuw, Paolo Domenico Arata, naaste familie was. Luigi Arata werd in 1837 geridderd. In 1847 was hij een van de oprichters van de Cassa di Risparmio di Civitavecchia en secretaris van het bestuur van die bank, in 1852 werd hij benoemd tot vice-president van de Handelskamer van Civitavecchia. Volgens de Rivista di legislatura e di giurisprudenza van 1851 en 1864, waarin onder meer de belangrijkste benoemingen in de magistratuur van de pauselijke staten werden medegedeeld, was hij in die jaren gonfaloniere (burgermeester) van zijn stad. De Arata's bezaten ook vastgoed in Civitavecchia en hadden een landgoed (de 'Farnesiana') in de nabijgelegen Monti della Tolfa, waar ze in 1867 het slachtoffer werden van plundering en brandstichting door een bende bandieten – een traumatische gebeurtenis waarover Luigi een brief naliet.
Met name tijdens het revolutionaire biennio 1848-1849 berichtte Luigi Arata de Nederlandse gezant in Rome, graaf Liedekerke de Beaufort, nauwgezet over de gebeurtenissen in Civitavecchia. Eind november 1848 schreef hij bijvoorbeeld over de geruchten dat de paus, die uit Rome gevlucht was, met het schip de Ténaire vanuit Civitavecchia naar Frankrijk zou zijn uitgeweken, met enkele kardinalen en de diplomatieke vertegenwoordigers van o.a. Frankrijk en Portugal. In april 1849 informeerde hij zowel de secretaris van de Nederlandse Legatie Magrini (in Rome) als gezant Liedekerke (in Gaeta) zeer frequent over de landing in Civitavecchia van een Frans expeditiekorps, dat weldra zou optrekken tegen de Romeinse Republiek. Als het ging om de handelsrelatie tussen Nederland en de Pauselijke Staten legde A. volgens Liedekerke 'un zèle aussi louable qu'éclairé' aan de dag. Hij maakte zich bijvoorbeeld sterk voor nieuwe handelsverdragen en directe contacten – dus zonder tussenhandel – vanuit Rome en Civitavecchia met de handelshuizen in Rotterdam en Amsterdam, om met name de toegang van koloniale waren uit Nederlands-Indië tot de Pauselijke Staten te verbeteren. Ook over het (toenemende) aantal Nederlandse koopvaardijschepen in Civitavecchia rapporteerde hij geregeld, niet alleen in zijn jaarlijkse Rapporto commerciale del porto di Civitavecchia.

$Arborio.en_GB: Giuseppe Arborio Mella was a prelate from the Sardinian town of Sassari and was the son of the second count of S. Elia, Girolamo Arborio Mella. In the summer of 1841, Mella was appointed apostolic delegate to Benevento, where he remained for three years before being called back to Rome. On 22 July 1844, he was appointed a member of the tribunal the Congregation of the Consulta, a post he held again after the fall of the Roman Republic in 1849 and the restoration of papal authority in Rome. From 1856, he successively held the positions of: clerk of the Apostolic Chamber (16 June 1856), state adviser of finance (23 December 1858), apostolic delegate to Rome and the Comarca (before 20 December 1859), vice-president of the Council of State (22 June 1866) and vice-chamberlain of the Church. The quadriportico of the Campo Verano cemetery contains his tomb with a marble bust in low relief.
$Arborio.it_IT: Giuseppe Arborio Mella fu un prelato della città sarda di Sassari, figlio del secondo conte di S. Elia, Girolamo Arborio Mella. Nell'estate del 1841, Mella fu nominato delegato apostolico a Benevento, dove rimase per tre anni prima di essere richiamato a Roma. Il 22 luglio 1844 fu nominato membro del tribunale della Congregazione della Consulta, incarico che ricoprì nuovamente dopo la caduta della Repubblica Romana nel 1849 e il ripristino dell'autorità papale a Roma. Dal 1856 ricoprì successivamente le cariche di: commesso della Camera Apostolica (16 giugno 1856), consigliere di Stato per le finanze (23 dicembre 1858), delegato apostolico a Roma e in Comarca (prima del 20 dicembre 1859), vicepresidente del Consiglio di Stato (22 giugno 1866) e vice-camerlengo della Chiesa. Nel quadriportico del cimitero di Campo Verano si trova la sua tomba con un busto marmoreo a basso rilievo.
$Arborio.nl_NL: Giuseppe Arborio Mella was een prelaat uit de Sardijnse stad Sassari en was de zoon van de tweede graaf van S. Elia, Girolamo Arborio Mella. In de zomer van 1841 werd Mella benoemd tot apostolisch afgevaardigde in Benevento, waar hij drie jaar bleef voordat hij naar Rome werd teruggeroepen. Op 22 juli 1844 werd hij tot lid van het tribunaal de Congregatie van de Consulta benoemd, een functie die hij opnieuw bekleedde na de val van de Romeinse Republiek in 1849 en het herstel van het pauselijk gezag in Rome. Vanaf 1856 had hij achtereenvolgens de functies van: klerk van de Apostolische Kamer (16 juni 1856), staatsadviseur van financiën (23 december 1858), apostolisch afgevaardigde in Rome en de Comarca (voor 20 december 1859), vice-voorzitter van de Raad van State (22 juni 1866) en vice-kamerheer van de Kerk. In de quadriportico van de begraafplaats van Campo Verano bevindt zich zijn graf met een marmeren buste in laagreliëf.

$Artom.en_GB: Isacco Artom was an Italian politician and diplomat. While still a student at the University of Pisa, he enlisted in the Tuscan university volunteer battalion at the outbreak of the first Italian War of Independence (1848). He later studied law in Turin and became friends with Costantino Nigra, after which he went to work for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Kingdom of Sardinia. In 1856, he replaced Nigra in Cavour's private secretariat and became one of the latter's closest associates. In 1860-1861, Artom was concerned with the Roman Question and the problematic relationship between the Kingdom of Italy and the Church. He went to Paris to negotiate with Napoleon III, but already in 1862 he was appointed chief of staff to the Minister of Foreign Affairs, a position he held until 1864. After the Third Italian War of Independence (1866), he took part in the peace negotiations with the Austrians in Vienna. After his appointment in 1867 as Minister Plenipotentiary in Copenhagen, a year later he was sent to Karlsruhe in the Grand Duchy of Baden. In 1869, he was sent on a mission to Vienna. In September 1870, after the defeat at Sedan and the end of the Second French Empire, Artom became Secretary-General at the Italian Ministry of Foreign Affairs. The end of the 'Historical Right' governments also meant the end of Artom's political career, and he was removed from his position as Secretary-General in 1876. He died in Rome in 1900.
$Artom.it_IT: Isacco Artom fu un politico e diplomatico Italiano. Ancora studente universitario a Pisa si arruolò nel battaglione universitario toscano allo scoppio della prima guerra d'indipendenza (1848). Successivamente si  laureò in giurisprudenza a Torino e divenne amico di Costantino Nigra entrando nel  ministero degli Affari esteri del Regno di Sardegna. Nel 1856  prese il posto di Nigra nelle segreteria particolare di Cavour divenendo un suo stretto collaboratore. Nel 1860-1861 si occupò della questione romana e dei problemi della Chiesa nel Regno d'Italia. Si recò a Parigi per trattare con Napoleone III ma già nel 1862 assunse la carica di capo di gabinetto del ministro degli Esteri, che mantenne fino al 1864. Dopo la Terza guerra d'Indipendenza, nel 1866, prese parte a Vienna ai negoziati di pace. Nel 1867  fu nominato ministro plenipotenziario a Copenaghen e l'anno successivo fu inviato a Karlsruhe nel Granducato di Baden. Nel 1869 fu mandato in missione a Vienna. Nel settembre del 1870, dopo la sconfitta di Sedan e la fine del Secondo Impero francese, divenne Segretario generale del ministero degli Affari esteri. La caduta della Destra significò la fine della carriera politica di Artom, che fu esonerato dalle funzioni di segretario generale nel 1876. Morì a Roma nel 1900.
$Artom.nl_NL: Isacco Artom was een Italiaanse politicus en diplomaat. Toen hij nog student was aan de universiteit van Pisa, meldde hij zich bij het uitbreken van de Eerste Italiaanse Onafhankelijkheidsoorlog (1848) aan bij het Toscaanse universitaire vrijwilligersbataljon. Later studeerde hij rechten in Turijn en raakte hij bevriend met Costantino Nigra, waarna hij bij het ministerie van Buitenlandse Zaken van het Koninkrijk Sardinië ging werken. In 1856 nam hij de plaats van Nigra in bij het particuliere secretariaat van Cavour en werd een van diens naaste medewerkers. In 1860-1861 hield Artom zich bezig met de Romeinse kwestie en de problematische realtie van het Koninkrijk Italië met de Kerk. Hij ging naar Parijs om met Napoleon III te onderhandelen, maar al in 1862 werd hij kabinetschef van de minister van Buitenlandse Zaken, een functie die hij tot 1864 bekleedde. Na de Derde Italiaanse Onafhankelijkheidsoorlog (1866) nam hij deel aan de vredesonderhandelingen met de Oostenrijkers in Wenen. Na zijn benoeming in 1867 tot gevolmachtigd minister in Kopenhagen werd hij een jaar later naar Karlsruhe gestuurd in het Groothertogdom Baden. In 1869 werd hij op missie naar Wenen gestuurd. In september 1870, na de nederlaag bij Sedan en het einde van het Tweede Franse Keizerrijk, werd Artom secretaris-generaal van het Italiaanse ministerie van Buitenlandse Zaken. Het einde van de regeringen van 'Historisch Rechts' betekende ook het einde van de politieke carrière van Artom, die in 1876 uit zijn functie als secretaris-generaal werd ontheven. Hij stierf in 1900 in Rome.

$Azeglio.en_GB: Marquis Massimo Taparelli d'Azeglio was a politician, patriot, writer and painter from Turin. After being very successful as a painter of landscapes and a writer of historical novels, from 1843-1844 onwards he started dedicating himself to politics, with treatises such as Degli ultimi casi di Romagna (1846), which addresses papal mismanagement, and Proposta d'un programma per l'opinione nazionale italiana (1847), which praises pope Pius IX and the king of Piedmont-Sardinia Charles Albert as leaders of a new liberal Italy. During the First Italian War of Independence (1848-1849), d'Azeglio was adjutant of the papal general Giovanni Durando. By invitation of Victor Emanuel II, successor of Charles Albert, d'Azeglio, himself a moderate catholic-liberal, subsequently led a cabinet (May 1849 to November 1852). Prime Minister Camillo Cavour appointed him governor of Milan, which had been annexed to the Kingdom of Sardinia. He resigned in March 1861, because of differences of opinion on political matters. He opposed what he called the 'premature' unification of Northern and Southern Italy and the prospect of making Rome the Italian capital. In his last years, d'Azeglio wrote down his memoirs while staying politically engaged.
$Azeglio.it_IT: Il marchese Massimo Taparelli d'Azeglio fu un politico, patriota, scrittore e pittore torinese. Dopo aver avuto molto successo come pittore di paesaggi e scrittore di romanzi storici, dal 1843-1844 in poi iniziò a dedicarsi alla politica, con trattati come “Degli ultimi casi di Romagna” (1846), che affrontava la cattiva amministrazione papale, e “Proposta d 'un programma per l'opinione nazionale italiana” (1847), che elogiava papa Pio IX e il re di Piemonte-Sardegna Carlo Alberto come leader di una nuova Italia liberale. Durante la Prima Guerra d'Indipendenza italiana (1848-1849), d'Azeglio fu aiutante del generale pontificio Giovanni Durando. Su invito di Vittorio Emanuele II, successore di Carlo Alberto, d'Azeglio, egli stesso cattolico-liberale moderato, guidò successivamente un gabinetto legislativo (dal maggio 1849 al novembre 1852). Il primo ministro Camillo Cavour lo nominò governatore di Milano, quando avvenne l'annessione al Regno di Sardegna. Si dimise nel marzo 1861, a causa di divergenze di opinioni su questioni politiche. Si oppose a quella che definì l'unificazione “prematura” del Nord e del Sud Italia e alla prospettiva di fare di Roma la capitale italiana. Nei suoi ultimi anni d'Azeglio scrisse le sue memorie pur rimanendo impegnato politicamente.
$Azeglio.nl_NL: Markies Massimo Taparelli d'Azeglio was een politicus, patriot, schrijver en schilder uit Turijn. Na grote successen te hebben geoogst als schilder van landschappen en schrijver van historische romans, wijdde hij zich vanaf ca. 1843-1844 aan de politiek, met geschriften als Degli ultimi casi di Romagna (1846), een aanklacht tegen het pauselijk wanbeleid, en Proposta d'un programma per l'opinione nazionale italiana (1847), waarin hij paus Pius IX en koning Karel Albert van Sardinië-Piemonte prees als leiders van een nieuw liberaal Italië. Tijdens de Eerste Italiaanse Onafhankelijkheidsoorlog (1848-1849) was d'Azeglio adjudant van de pauselijke generaal Giovanni Durando. Op uitnodiging van Victor Emanuel II, opvolger van Karel Albert, leidde hij vervolgens als gematigd katholiek-liberaal een kabinet (mei 1849 tot november 1852). Premier Camillo Cavour benoemde hem in 1860 tot gouverneur van Milaan, dat inmiddels bij het Koninkrijk Sardinië was ingelijfd. In maart 1861 diende hij zijn ontslag in, vanwege politieke verschillen van inzicht. Zo verzette hij zich tegen de 'premature' vereniging van Noord en Zuid-Italië en het idee om Rome hoofdstad van Italië te maken. In zijn laatste jaren schreef D'Azeglio zijn memoires en bleef politiek betrokken.

$Bake.en_GB: William Archibald Bake was a painter, lithographer and engraver born in Liège and educated at the Stadstekenacademie (City Drawing Academy) in The Hague. In 1845, he travelled to Rome via Paris, Munich and Dresden, to join his mentor Cornelis Kruseman (1797-1857),  who had high expectations for Bake's future as a history painter (Leydse Courant, 1 July 1846). Sadly, however, Bake died in Ariccia on 3 June 1846, due to malaria fevers.
$Bake.it_IT: William Archibald Bake fu un pittore, litografo e incisore nato a Liegi studiò alla Stadstekenacademie (Accademia di disegno cittadino) dell'Aia. Nel 1845 si recò a Roma, passando per Parigi, Monaco e Dresda, per raggiungere il suo mentore Cornelis Kruseman (1797-1857), che nutriva grandi aspettative per il futuro di Bake come pittore storico (Leydse Courant, 1 luglio 1846). Purtroppo, però, Bake morì ad Ariccia il 3 giugno 1846, a causa di febbri malariche.
$Bake.nl_NL: Willem Archibald (1821-1846) was een schilder, lithograaf en graveur geboren in Luik, opgeleid aan de Haagse stadstekenacademie. In 1845 reisde hij via Parijs, München en Dresden naar Rome om zich te voegen bij zijn leermeester Cornelis Kruseman, die hoge verwachtingen van zijn toekomst als historieschilder had (Leydse Courant, 1 juli 1846). Bake stierf echter al op 3 juni 1846 in Ariccia aan malariakoortsen.

$Baraguay.en_GB: Achille Baraguay or Baraguey d'Hiliers was a French military commander and politician. After the French February Revolution of 1848, he was chosen as representative in the Constituent Assembly. In November 1849, he was sent to Rome to take command of the French forces occupying Rome, replacing general Louis de Rostolan. During the Crimean War (1853-1856), he was nominated commander of the so-called 'Baltic expedition'; afterwards, he was appointed Marshal of France and senator. During the Italian campaign of 1859 (or the Second Italian War of Independence), when France declared war on Austria as an ally of the Kingdom of Sardinia, he achieved an important victory at Solferino as commander of the First Army Corps.
$Baraguay.it_IT: Achille Baraguay o Baraguey d'Hiliers fu un comandante militare e politico francese. Dopo la Rivoluzione francese di febbraio del 1848, fu scelto come rappresentante nell'Assemblea Costituente. Nel novembre 1849 fu inviato a Roma per prendere il comando delle forze francesi che occupavano Roma, in sostituzione del generale Louis de Rostolan. Durante la guerra di Crimea (1853-1856) fu nominato comandante della cosiddetta “spedizione baltica”; in seguito fu nominato maresciallo di Francia e senatore. Durante la campagna d'Italia del 1859 (o Seconda Guerra d'Indipendenza italiana), quando la Francia dichiarò guerra all'Austria in quanto alleata del Regno di Sardegna, ottenne un'importante vittoria a Solferino come comandante del Primo Corpo d'Armata.
$Baraguay.nl_NL: Achille Baraguay of Baraguey d'Hilliers was een Frans commandant en politicus. Na de Franse Februarirevolutie van 1848 werd hij als gedeputeerde gekozen in de (Grond)wetgevende Vergadering. In november 1849 werd hij naar Rome gezonden om het commando over de Franse bezettingsmacht in Rome over te nemen van generaal Louis de Rostolan. Tijdens de Krimoorlog (1853-1856) kreeg hij het bevel over de zogenaamde 'Baltische expeditie'; aansluitend werd hij Maarschalk van Frankrijk en senator. Tijdens de Italiaanse campagne van 1859 (ook wel de Tweede Italiaanse Onafhankelijkheidsoorlog), toen Frankrijk als bondgenoot van het Koninkrijk Sardinië de oorlog verklaarde aan Oostenrijk, boekte hij als commandant van het Eerst Legerkorps een belangrijke overwinning bij Solferino.

$Bargagli.en_GB: Scipione Bargagli was a Tuscan courtier and diplomat during the final phase of the Grand Duchy of Tuscany. A nobleman from Siena, he was chamberlain to the Grand Duke of Tuscany until 1846, when he was appointed 'Minister' (envoy) of Tuscany in Rome to the Holy See. As such, he sympathised with the so-called Neo-Guelph ideology. In 1848, he took part in the negotiations to establish the Italian League, taking a moderate stance. During the Roman Republic of 1849, he refused to represent Tuscany's radical Guerrazzi-Montanelli government. Having fled Rome, he took refuge in Gaeta in the retinue of the papal court of Pius IX. Bargagli took part in the negotiations for a concordat between Tuscany and the Holy See in 1851 and continued to hold the office of resident-minister in Rome. His residence, Palazzo Firenze, from 1860 onwards became a refuge for legitimist exile, who continued to support the claims of the Habsburg-Lorraine family to the Tuscan throne. With the Treaty of Vienna in 1866, which led to Austria's recognition of Tuscany's decline as an independent state, he ended his political career. He died in Rome in 1868.
$Bargagli.it_IT: Scipione Bargagli fu un uomo di corte e diplomatico toscano durante l'ultima fase del Granducato di Toscana. Nobile senese fu ciambellano del Granduca di Toscana finché nel 1846 venne nominato ministro della Toscana a Roma presso la Santa Sede dove aderì all'ideologia neo-guelfa. Nel 1848 prese parte alle trattative per costituire la Lega italiana collocandosi su posizioni  moderate. Durante la Repubblica Romana del 1849 si  rifiutò di rappresentare il governo Guerrazzi-Montanelli e. fuggito da Roma,  si rifugiò a Gaeta al seguito della corte pontificia di Pio IX.  Prese parte alle  trattative per un concordato tra la Toscana e la Santa Sede del 1851 continuando a ricoprire la carica di ministro residente in Roma e la sua sede, a  Palazzo Firenze, dal 1860 divenne rifugio di fuorusciti legittimisti. Con il trattato di Vienna del 1866 che portò al riconoscimento austriaco della decadenza della Toscana, mise termine alla sua attività politica. Morì a Roma nel 1868.
$Bargagli.nl_NL: Scipione Bargagli was een Toscaanse hoveling en diplomaat tijdens de laatste fase van het Groothertogdom Toscane. Hij was een edelman uit Siena en was kamerheer van de groothertog van Toscane tot 1846, toen hij werd benoemd tot 'minister' (gezant) van Toscane bij de Heilige Stoel. Als zodanig sympathiseerde hij met de zogenaamde 'neowelfische' ideologie. In 1848 nam hij deel aan de onderhandelingen om een Italiaanse Liga op te richten, waarbij hij een gematigd standpunt innam. Tijdens de Romeinse Republiek van 1849 weigerde hij de radicale regering van Toscane onder Guerrazzi-Montanelli te vertegenwoordigen. Nadat hij uit Rome was gevlucht, zocht hij zijn toevlucht in Gaeta, in het gevolg van het pauselijk hof van Pius IX. Bargagli nam in 1851 deel aan de onderhandelingen voor een concordaat tussen Toscane en de Heilige Stoel en bleef de functie van resident-minister in Rome bekleden. Zijn residentie, Palazzo Firenze, werd vanaf 1860 een toevluchtsoord voor legitimistische ballingen, die de aanspraken van de Habsburg-Lotharingers op de Toscaanse troon bleven steunen. Met het Verdrag van Wenen in 1866, dat leidde tot de erkenning door Oostenrijk van het einde van Toscane als onafhankelijke staat, beëindigde hij zijn politieke carrière. Hij stierf in 1868 in Rome.

$Barnabo.en_GB: Alessandro Barnabò was a cardinal from Foligno, in the Italian region of Umbria. Barnabò was initially sent to the military school Prytanée National Militaire in the French town of La Flèche, but returned to Italy after two years to become a priest. While studying law at the Università La Sapienza in Rome, he was assistant of the future cardinal Paolo Polidori. Barnabò fulfilled a variety of positions during the pontificate of Gregory XIV, and was made secretary to the Congregation of Propaganda Fide by pope Pius IX. After Barnabò was elevated to the cardinalate on 16 June 1856, Pius IX named him prefect of the Congregation of Propaganda Fide, a post he retained until his death in 1874.
$Barnabo.it_IT: Alessandro Barnabò fu un cardinale da Foligno, nell'Umbria. Barnabò fu inizialmente inviato alla scuola militare Prytanée National Militaire nella cittadina francese di La Flèche, ma tornò in Italia dopo due anni per diventare prete. Mentre studiava giurisprudenza all'Università La Sapienza di Roma, fu assistente del futuro cardinale Paolo Polidori. Barnabò ricoprì diversi incarichi durante il pontificato di Gregorio XIV e fu nominato segretario della Congregazione di Propaganda Fide da papa Pio IX. Dopo che Barnabò fu elevato al cardinalato il 16 giugno 1856, Pio IX lo nominò prefetto della Congregazione di Propaganda Fide, incarico che mantenne fino alla morte nel 1874.
$Barnabo.nl_NL: Alessandro Barnabò was een kardinaal uit Foligno, in de Italiaanse Umbrië-regio. Barnabò werd aanvankelijk naar de militaire school Prytanée National Militaire gestuurd in het Franse La Flèche, maar hij keerde na twee jaar terug naar Italië om priester te worden. Tijdens zijn studie Rechten aan de universiteit 'La Sapienza' te Rome, was hij assistent van de latere kardinaal Paolo Polidori. Hij bekleedde verschillende kerkelijke functies tijdens het pontificaat van Gregorius XIV, en werd door paus Pius IX benoemd tot secretaris van de Congregatie van Propaganda Fide. Nadat Barnabò kardinaal werd op 16 juni 1856, benoemde Pius IX hem tot prefect van de Congregatie van Propaganda Fide, een functie die hij behield tot zijn dood in 1874.

$Beaumont.en_GB: Eduoard de Beaumont was a French painter and lithographer, son of the sculptor Jean Marie Bonaventure Baumont. He exhibited landscapes at the Paris Salon of 1838-1840, after which he left on a study trip to Italy. After returning to France in 1847, he painted mainly genre pieces, which he exhibited again at the Salon between 1853 and 1868. He owed his fame, however, to his illustrations in magazines such as the Revue pittoresque and novels such as Victor Hugo's Notre-Dame de Paris. In 1879, he co-founded the Société d'aquarellistes français, of which he also became president.
$Beaumont.it_IT: Eduoard de Beaumont fu un pittore e litografo francese, figlio dello scultore Jean Marie Bonaventure Baumont. Espose paesaggi al Salon di Parigi del 1838-1840, dopodiché partì per un viaggio di studio in Italia. Tornato in Francia nel 1847, dipinse soprattutto opere di genere, che espose al Salon tra il 1853 e il 1868. La sua fama, tuttavia, è dovuta alle illustrazioni di riviste come la Revue pittoresque e di romanzi come Notre-Dame de Paris di Victor Hugo. Nel 1879 fu cofondatore della Société d'aquarellistes français, di cui divenne anche presidente.
$Beaumont.nl_NL: Eduoard de Beaumont was een Franse schilder en lithograaf, zoon van de beeldhouwer Jean Marie Bonaventure Baumont. Hij exposeerde landschappen op de Parijs Salon van 1838-1840, waarna hij op studiereis naar Italië vertrok. Na zijn terugkeer in Frankrijk in 1847 schilderde hij met name  genrestukken, die hij tussen 1853 en 1868 ook weer op de Salon tentoonstelde. Zijn bekendheid dankt hij evenwel aan zijn illustraties in tijdschriften als de Revue pittoresque en romans als Victor Hugo's Notre-Dame de Paris. In 1879 was hij medeoprichter van de Société d'aquarellistes français, waarvan hij ook voorzitter werd.

$BediniGa.en_GB: Gaetano Bedini was an Italian cardinal who was originally from Senigallia. As special envoy for the Holy See in Brasil (1845-1847), he sent Pius IX the offer by Italian patriots Giuseppe Garibaldi and Francesco Anzani, proposing to deploy the Italian Legion they had commanded in the defence of Montevideo for the Italian War of Independence. After Bedini's return to Rome, he became substitute for the secretary of state (1848) and followed the pope to Gaeta in November 1848. After the fall of the Roman Republic of 1849, Bedini was appointed special commissioner to the four Legations, as well as pro-legate of Bologna. Subsequently, he was appointed nuncio in Brasil (1852), a post he would however never reach. Before his nunciature could begin, he was sent to the United States as a special envoy (1853) where he faced increasing hostility and threats, in large part from Mazzinian exiles spurred on by Alessandro Gavazzi, the former chaplain of the first pontifical and later garibaldinian volunteers. Bedini was forced to return to Rome. Eventually, on 27 September 1861, Pius IX named him cardinal.
$BediniGa.it_IT: Gaetano Bedini fu un cardinale italiano originario di Senigallia. Come inviato speciale della Santa Sede in Brasile (1845-1847), trasmise a Pio IX l'offerta dei patrioti italiani Giuseppe Garibaldi e Francesco Anzani, che proponevano di schierare la Legione Italiana da loro comandata nella difesa di Montevideo per la Guerra d'Indipendenza italiana. . Dopo il ritorno di Bedini a Roma, divenne sostituto della segreteria di Stato (1848) e seguì il papa a Gaeta nel novembre 1848. Dopo la caduta della Repubblica Romana nel 1849, Bedini fu nominato commissario straordinario delle quattro Legazioni, nonché prolegato di Bologna. Successivamente fu nominato nunzio in Brasile (1852), incarico che però non raggiunse mai. Prima che la sua nunziatura potesse avere inizio, fu inviato negli Stati Uniti come inviato speciale (1853) dove dovette affrontare crescenti ostilità e minacce, in gran parte da parte degli esuli mazziniani, spinti da Alessandro Gavazzi, già cappellano pontificio e poi volontario garibaldino. Bedini fu costretto a tornare a Roma. Infine, il 27 settembre 1861, Pio IX lo nominò cardinale.
$BediniGa.nl_NL: Gaetano Bedini was een Italiaans kardinaal, afkomstig uit Senigallia. Als speciaal gezant namens de Heilige Stoel in Brazilië (1845-1847) stuurde hij Pius IX het aanbod door van de Italiaanse patriotten Giuseppe Garibaldi en Francesco Anzani, die het Italiaans Legioen waarmee ze de Republiek van Montevideo hadden verdedigd, wilden inzetten voor de Italiaanse onafhankelijkheidsstrijd. Na terugkeer in Rome was Bedini plaatsvervangend staatssecretaris (1848) en volgde hij de paus toen die in november 1848 naar Gaeta vluchtte. Na de val van de Romeinse Republiek van 1849 werd Bedini buitengewoon commissaris voor de vier Legaties en pro-legaat van Bologna. Zijn post als nuntius van Brazilië (1852) zou hij nooit bezetten: nog voor hij kon beginnen werd zijn nuntiatuur overschaduwd door zijn missie als speciaal gezant naar de Verenigde Staten (1853), waar hem een vijandige ontvangst wachtte. Dit was mede door de invloed van Mazziniaanse ballingen, onder leiding van Alessandro Gavazzi, voormalig kapelaan van de pauselijke en daarna de garibaldijnse vrijwilligers. Bedini zag zich gedwongen om van New York naar Rome terug te keren. Pius IX benoemde hem op 27 september 1861 tot kardinaal.

$Belgrado.en_GB: Carlo Belgrado was a prelate, born as the son of count Alfonso Belgrado from Udine, in the Italian region of Friuli. Pope Gregory XVI appointed him apostolic delegate to Benevento (25 January 1844), and later to Perugia (15 January 1845). Pope Pius IX subsequently appointed him extraordinary delegate to Fermo (8 July 1847). Between 1848 and 1855, Belgrado acted as internuncio and apostolic delegate in The Hague, during which time he negotiated the papal restoration of the episcopal hierarchy in the Netherlands. After his return to Italy in 1855, he was named bishop of Ascoli, a post he resigned from on 25 January 1860. Eventually, Pius IX named Belgrado the Latin patriarch of Antioch on 21 May 1862, a post he retained until his death in 1866.
$Belgrado.it_IT: Carlo Belgrado fu un prelato, figlio del conte Alfonso Belgrado di Udine, nella regione italiana del Friuli. Papa Gregorio XVI lo nominò delegato apostolico a Benevento (25 gennaio 1844), e successivamente a Perugia (15 gennaio 1845). Qualche anno dopo papa Pio IX lo nominò delegato straordinario a Fermo (8 luglio 1847). Tra il 1848 e il 1855 Belgrado fu internunzio e delegato apostolico all'Aia, periodo durante il quale negoziò la restaurazione papale della gerarchia episcopale nei Paesi Bassi. Dopo il suo ritorno in Italia nel 1855, fu nominato vescovo di Ascoli, incarico dal quale si dimise il 25 gennaio 1860. Infine, Pio IX nominò Belgrado patriarca latino di Antiochia il 21 maggio 1862, incarico che mantenne fino alla sua morte nel 1866.
$Belgrado.nl_NL: Carlo Belgrado was een prelaat uit Udine, in de Italiaanse regio Friuli. Paus Gregorius XVI benoemde hem tot apostolisch afgevaardigde in Benevento (25 januari 1844) en Perugia (15 januari 1845), waarna hij door paus Pius IX werd benoemd tot speciaal gezant te Fermo (8 juli 1847). Tussen 1848 en 1855 was Belgrado apostolisch internuntius in Den Haag, en onderhandelde hij over het pauselijk herstel van de bisschoppelijke hiërarchie in Nederland. Na zijn terugkeer in Italië in 1855 werd hij bisschop van Ascoli, een post waar hij op 25 januari 1860 afstand van deed. Pius IX benoemde Belgrado ten slotte op 12 mei 1862 tot de Latijnse patriarch van Antiochië, een functie die hij vervulde tot zijn dood in 1866.

$Bellando.en_GB: Giuseppe (also known as 'Joseph') Bellando was an Italian merchant and for many years vice-consul for the Kingdom of the Netherlands in Taranto, Calabria from 1851. He was succeeded as vice-consul in 1902 by his son Tommaso Bellando Randone, who in turn passed on the office to his son, Tommaso Bellando Randone (jr.) in 1934.
$Bellando.it_IT: Giuseppe (noto anche come “Joseph”) Bellando fu un commerciante italiano e per molti anni viceconsole del Regno dei Paesi Bassi a Taranto, in Calabria, dal 1851. Nel 1902 gli successe come viceconsole il figlio Tommaso Bellando Randone, che a sua volta passò la carica al figlio Tommaso Bellando Randone (jr.) nel 1934.
