$Bellando.nl_NL: Giuseppe (ook wel 'Joseph') Bellando was een Italiaanse koopman en jarenlang vice-consul voor het Koninkrijk der Nederlanden in Taranto in Calabrië vanaf 1851. Hij werd in 1902 als vice-consul opgevolgd door zijn zoon Tommaso Bellando Randone, die op zijn beurt het ambt doorgaf aan zijn zoon, Tommaso Bellando Randone (jr.) in 1934.

$Belli.en_GB: Francesca (Maria) Belli was the second wife of Dutch painter Charles Quaedvlieg, who settled in Rome in 1853. They married on September 3, 1856.
$Belli.it_IT: Francesca (Maria) Belli fu la seconda moglie del pittore olandese Charles Quaedvlieg, che si stabilì a Roma nel 1853. Si sposarono il 3 settembre 1856.
$Belli.nl_NL: Francesca (Maria) Belli was de tweede echtgenote van de Nederlandse schilder Charles Quaedvlieg, die zich in 1853 in Rome vestigde. Ze trouwden op 3 september 1856.

$Bentinck.en_GB: Count Arnold Adolf Bentinck van Nijenhuis was a Dutch diplomat and briefly interim minister of Foreign Affairs (17 May 1848 to 21 November 1848). From 1841 to 1845, he was resident minister at the courts of Baden, Bavaria and Württemberg, and between 1845 and 1851 he twice served in Brussels as special envoy to the young Kingdom of Belgium. During his ministry, his main concern was the growing unrest in the Dutch region of Limburg. Ever since the Treaty of London in 1839, the region had formally become a part of the Netherlands, but, as a duchy of its own, it also remained part of the Deutsche Bund. Bentinck was confronted with an upsurge of the separatist movement in Limburg, following the March 1848 revolutions in the German states. In 1851, Bentinck was appointed ambassador in London, where he stayed until his death in 1868.
$Bentinck.it_IT: Il conte Arnold Adolf Bentinck van Nijenhuis fu un diplomatico olandese e per breve tempo ministro ad interim degli Affari esteri (17 maggio 1848-21 novembre 1848). Dal 1841 al 1845 fu ministro residente presso le corti di Baden, Baviera e Württemberg, e tra il 1845 e il 1851 prestò servizio due volte a Bruxelles come inviato speciale presso il giovane Regno del Belgio. Durante il suo ministero, la sua principale preoccupazione furono i crescenti disordini nella regione olandese del Limburgo. Dal “Trattato di Londra” del 1839, la regione era formalmente diventata parte dei Paesi Bassi, ma, come ducato a sé stante, rimanendo anche parte del Deutsche Bund. Bentinck dovette confrontarsi con un'impennata del movimento separatista nel Limburgo, in seguito alle rivoluzioni del marzo 1848 negli stati tedeschi. Nel 1851 Bentinck fu nominato ambasciatore a Londra, dove rimase fino alla sua morte nel 1868.
$Bentinck.nl_NL: Graaf Arnold Adolf Bentinck van Nijenhuis was een Nederlands diplomaat en korte tijd minister van Buitenlandse Zaken (17 mei 1848 tot 21 november 1848). Hij was tussen 1841 en 1845 minister-resident bij de hoven van Baden, Beieren en Württemberg, en van 1845 tot 1851 tweemaal buitengewoon gezant in Brussels bij het jonge Koninkrijk België. Tijdens zijn ministerschap had hij veel te maken met de onrust in Nederlands Limburg. Die regio was sinds het Verdrag van Londen (1839) bij Nederland gevoegd, maar als hertogdom tot 1866 ook lid van de Duitse Bond gebleven. Van 1842 tot 1849 wilde de Limburgse Separatistische Beweging, zich van Nederland losmaken en opgaan in de Duitse Bond. In 1848 kreeg Bentinck te maken met een opleving van de beweging in navolging van de maartrevoluties in Duitsland. Later, in 1851, werd hij uitgezonden naar Londen, waar hij verbleef tot zijn dood in 1868.

$Berardi.en_GB: Berardi was a lawyer from Ceccano, who became a prelate after the death of his wife and daughter (1844) and was later made cardinal by Pius IX (13 March 1868). From the start of his career, he had good contacts in the Roman Curia, a.o. with cardinal Mario Mattei and cardinals-secretary of state Luigi Lambruschini and Giacomo Antonelli. During the pontificate of Gregory XVI, he held several positions in the magistrature of the Church. When Pius IX fled to Gaeta at the end of 1848, Berardi joined him. After the fall of the Roman Republic of 1849, he restored papal authority in the provinces Marittima and Campagna, in Rieti, parts of Umbria and the Comarca. In 1851 Berardi was named substitute to the cardinal secretary of state, a post he occupied until his succession to the College of Cardinals in 1868. Subsequently he was appointed as pro-Minister of Trade, Agriculture, Industry, Fine Arts and Public Works, and helped organize the First Vatican Council. He remained a friend and political ally of cardinal Antonelli throughout his career.
$Berardi.it_IT: Berardi fu un avvocato di Ceccano, divenuto prelato dopo la morte della moglie e della figlia (1844); fu eletto cardinale da Pio IX (13 marzo 1868). Fin dall'inizio della sua carriera ebbe buoni contatti nella Curia Romana, tra l'altro. con il cardinale Mario Mattei e i cardinali-segretari di Stato Luigi Lambruschini e Giacomo Antonelli. Durante il pontificato di Gregorio XVI ricoprì diversi incarichi nella magistratura della Chiesa. Quando Pio IX fuggì a Gaeta alla fine del 1848, Berardi lo raggiunse. Dopo la caduta della Repubblica Romana nel 1849, restaurò l'autorità papale nelle province Marittima e Campagna, a Rieti e in parte dell'Umbria e nella Comarca. Nel 1851 Berardi fu nominato sostituto del cardinale segretario di Stato, incarico che mantenne fino alla successione al Collegio cardinalizio nel 1868. Successivamente fu nominato pro-ministro del Commercio, dell'Agricoltura, dell'Industria, delle Belle Arti e dei Lavori Pubblici, e contribuì all'organizzazione del Concilio Vaticano I. Rimase amico e alleato politico del cardinale Antonelli per tutta la sua carriera.
$Berardi.nl_NL: Giuseppe Berardi was afkomstig uit Ceccano, was aanvankelijk advocaat maar koos voor het priesterambt na het overlijden van zijn vrouw en dochter (1844). Op 13 maart 1868 werd hij door Pius IX tot kardinaal gewijd. Vanaf het begin van zijn carrière had hij goede relaties binnen de Curie, o.a. met kardinalen Mario Mattei, Luigi Lambruschini en Giacomo Antonelli. Onder Gregorius XVI bekleedde hij verschillende functies in de kerkelijke magistratuur. Toen Pius IX eind 1848 naar Gaeta vluchtte, ging Berardi mee. Na de val van de Romeinse Republiek van 1849 wist hij het pauselijk gezag te herstellen in de provincie Campagna en Marittima, in Rieti, delen van Umbrië en de Comarca. In 1851 werd hij benoemd tot plaatsvervangend kardinaal-staatssecretaris, een functie die hij officieel zou bekleden tot hij zelf kardinaal werd in 1868. Hierna was hij onder andere pro-minister van Handel, Landbouw, Industrie, Schone Kunsten en Openbare Werken en was hij belangrijk bij de organisatie van het Eerste Vaticaanse Concilie. Antonelli bleef gedurende zijn hele carrière zijn bondgenoot.

$Berlijn.en_GB: Anton Berlijn was a Dutch composer from an Amsterdam Jewish family. He studied with the Dutch composer and violinist Bernard Koch and then at various places abroad, including Berlin. In 1843 he was awarded the Order of the Oak Crown by King William II. During a study stay in Brussels and Paris, some of his works were performed there. After returning to Amsterdam in 1845, he became director of the Stadsschouwburg, was music director for the municipal ballet and conducted a number of choirs, including that of the Jewish society Plancius. He was also involved with the Diamond Workers/Musicians Orphans Fund. His approximately 200 works, including operas, ballets, songs, concertos and some symphonies, are largely forgotten today.
$Berlijn.it_IT: Anton Berlijn fu un compositore olandese di famiglia ebraica di Amsterdam. Studiò con il compositore e violinista olandese Bernard Koch e poi in varie località all'estero, tra cui Berlino. Nel 1843 fu insignito dell'Ordine della Corona di Quercia dal re Guglielmo II. Durante un soggiorno di studio a Bruxelles e a Parigi, alcune sue opere furono eseguite. Tornato ad Amsterdam nel 1845, divenne direttore dello Stadsschouwburg, fu direttore musicale del balletto municipale e diresse diversi cori, tra cui quello della società ebraica Plancius. Fu anche coinvolto nel Fondo per gli orfani dei lavoratori dei diamanti e dei musicisti. Le sue circa 200 opere, tra cui opere, balletti, canzoni, concerti e alcune sinfonie, sono oggi in gran parte dimenticate.
$Berlijn.nl_NL: Anton Berlijn was een Nederlandse componist, afkomstig uit een Amsterdamse Joodse familie. Hij studeerde bij de Nederlandse componist en violist Bernard Koch en daarna op verschillende plekken in het buitenland, waaronder in Berlijn. In 1843 werd hij door koning Willem II onderscheiden in de Orde van de Eikenkroon. Tijdens een studieverblijf in Brussel en Parijs werd daar een aantal van zijn werken opgevoerd. Na terugkeer in Amsterdam in 1845 werd hij directeur van de Stadsschouwburg, was hij orkestmeester voor het stedelijk ballet en dirigeerde hij een aantal koren, waaronder dat van de Joodse sociëteit Plancius. Ook was hij betrokken bij het Diamantwerkers/Muzikanten Wezenfonds. Zijn ca. 200 werken, waaronder opera's, balletten, liederen, concerten en enkele symfoniën, zijn vandaag goeddeels vergeten.

$Bert.en_GB: Amedeo (Amédée Josué) Bert was a pastor, born in Torre Pellice in one of the three so-called Waldensian Valleys, at that time the main home base of the Waldensian (Evangelical) Church, an Italian protestant community in the predominantly catholic area of Piedmont. From 1833 to 1864, he was chaplain of the protestant embassies to the royal Savoia court in Turin, and as such built up a network in diplomatic and political circles.  He was, for instance, a friend of the leading Piedmontese politician and later the first prime minister of Italy Camillo Benso di Cavour. When the Dutch chargé d'affaires in Turin, Willem van der Duyn passed away in 1858, Bert attended his funeral. For foreign travellers and others interested in protestant communities in Italy, he was an important point of reference; his name can therefore be found in various travel diaries. In 1864, he retreated to his native town of Torre Pellice, where he died in 1883.
$Bert.it_IT: Amedeo (Amédée Josué) Bert fu un pastore, nato a Torre Pellice in una delle tre cosiddette Valli Valdesi, a quel tempo sede principale della Chiesa valdese (evangelica), una comunità protestante italiana nella zona a maggioranza cattolica di Piemonte. Dal 1833 al 1864 fu cappellano delle ambasciate protestanti presso la reale corte sabauda a Torino, e come tale si fece conoscere negli ambienti diplomatici e politici. Fu, ad esempio, amico di uno dei più eminenti politici piemontesi,  e in seguito primo primo ministro,  Camillo Benso di Cavour. Quando l'incaricato d'affari olandese a Torino, Willem van der Duyn morì nel 1858, Bert partecipò al suo funerale. Per i viaggiatori stranieri e per coloro che si interessavano alle comunità protestanti in Italia fu un importante punto di riferimento; il suo nome si trova quindi in diversi diari di viaggio. Nel 1864 si ritirò nella natia Torre Pellice, dove morì nel 1883.
$Bert.nl_NL: Amedeo (Amédée Josué) Bert was een predikant afkomstig uit Torre Pellice, gelegen in een van de drie zogenaamde Waldenzenvalleien, de belangrijkste thuisbasis van de Waldenzische (Evangelische) Kerk, een protestantse geloofsgemeenschap in het verder overwegend katholieke Piemonte. Bert was van 1833 tot 1864 kapelaan van de protestantse ambassades bij het hof van de koning van Sardinië in Turijn, en bouwde een netwerk op binnen diplomatieke en politieke kringen. Zo was hij bevriend met de vooraanstaande Piemontese staatsman en de eerste premier van Italië Camillo Benso di Cavour. Toen de Nederlandse chargé d'affaires in Turijn, Willem van der Duyn, in 1858 overleed, woonde Bert diens begrafenis bij. Voor buitenlandse reizigers en en anderen die zich interesseerden voor de protestantse gemeenschappen in Italië was Bert een belangrijke bron; hij wordt dan ook in meerdere dagboeken genoemd. In 1864 trok hij zich terug in Torre Pellice, waar hij in 1883 overleed.

$Betz.en_GB: Gerardus Henri Betz was a Dutch Minister of Finance (1 Feb 1862-27 Nov 1865). A self-taught man, he began his career at the age of fifteen at a notary's office in Wijchen, in the province of Gelderland. In 1837, his father bought him and his brother a syrup factory (Gebroeders Betz), which was sold in 1859. Betz went to live in Rotterdam after his marriage to Johanna C. van Staveren (1841), where, in addition to his work on the factory, he committed himself to municipality politics. This led to his being elected to the Dutch House of Representatives in 1859 (for the constituency of Rotterdam), where he advocated for the reform of the Dutch financial system. Liberal-minded Betz was subsequently elected Minister of Finance in cabinet-Thorbecke II. He was forced to resign in Nov 1865 because of the so-called “letter affair of Limburg”, concerning tax increases in Limburg, in which the Minister of Foreign Affairs, T. van der Maesen de Sombreff, was also involved. From 3 Jan to 1 Feb 1863, Betz was also minister of Colonies ad interim. After resigning, he turned to his studies and remained particularly interested in colonial politics; in 1866, he became co-editor of the Tijdschrift voor Nederlandsch-Indië. Just before his death on 20 May 1868, Betz was elected to the Provincial States of South Holland.
$Betz.it_IT: Gerardus Henri Betz fu Ministro delle Finanze olandese (1° febbraio 1862 - 27 novembre 1865). Autodidatta, iniziò la sua carriera all'età di quindici anni presso uno studio notarile a Wijchen, nella provincia di Gheldria. Nel 1837, suo padre acquistò per lui e suo fratello una fabbrica di sciroppi (Gebroeders Betz), che fu venduta nel 1859. Betz si trasferì a Rotterdam dopo il matrimonio con Johanna C. van Staveren (1841), dove, oltre al lavoro nella fabbrica, si dedicò alla politica comunale. Questo lo portò ad essere eletto alla Camera dei Rappresentanti olandese nel 1859 (per la circoscrizione di Rotterdam), dove si batté per la riforma del sistema finanziario olandese. Di idee liberali, Betz fu successivamente eletto Ministro delle Finanze nel governo Thorbecke II. Fu costretto a dimettersi nel novembre del 1865 a causa del cosiddetto 'affare delle lettere del Limburgo', riguardante l'aumento delle tasse nel Limburgo, in cui era coinvolto anche il Ministro degli Affari Esteri, T. van der Maesen de Sombreff. Dal 3 gennaio al 1° febbraio 1863, Betz fu anche Ministro delle Colonie ad interim. Dopo le dimissioni, si dedicò agli studi e mantenne un particolare interesse per la politica coloniale; nel 1866 divenne co-redattore del Tijdschrift voor Nederlandsch-Indië. Poco prima della sua morte, avvenuta il 20 maggio 1868, Betz fu eletto deputato degli Stati Provinciali dell'Olanda Meridionale.
$Betz.nl_NL: Gerardus Henri Betz was Nederlands minister van Financiën (1 feb. 1862-27 nov. 1865). Hij was een autodidact, en begon zijn carrière op 15-jarige leeftijd bij een notariskantoor in Wijchen, Gelderland. In 1837 kocht zijn vader voor hem en zijn broer een siroopfabriek (Gebroeders Betz), die in 1859 weer verkocht werd. Betz ging na zijn huwelijk met Johanna C. van Staveren (1841) in Rotterdam wonen, waar hij zich, naast het fabriekswerk, ging inzetten voor de gemeente. Dit leidde ertoe dat hij in 1859 door het kiesdistrict Rotterdam werd gekozen in de Tweede Kamer, waar hij zich vooral ging inzetten voor de hervorming van het Nederlandse financiële stelsel. De liberale Betz werd vervolgens in kabinet-Thorbecke II gekozen als minister van Financiën. Hij zag zich gedwongen om in november 1865 af te treden vanwege het zogenaamde Limburgse brievenschandaal (aangaande belastingverhoging in Limburg), waar de minister van Buitenlandse Zaken, T. van der Maesen de Sombreff, ook bij betrokken was. Van 3 jan. tot 1 feb. 1863 was Betz ook minister van Koloniën ad interim. Na zijn aftreden richtte hij zich op de studie, en bleef hij in het bijzonder geïnteresseerd in koloniale politiek; zo werd hij in 1866 medereadacteur van het Tijdschrift voor Nederlandsch-Indië. Vlak voor zijn dood op 20 mei 1868, werd Betz nog tot lid gekozen van de Provinciale Staten van Zuid-Holland.

$Bismarck.en_GB: Otto Eduard Leopold von Bismarck-Schönhausen was a Prussian and German statesman. From 1862 to 1890 he was Prime Minister of Prussia, from 1867 Chancellor of the North German Confederation, from 1871 Chancellor of the German Empire, of which he is considered the architect. He was a self-proclaimed Realpolitiker, for whom the end always justified the means (if necessary 'Blut und Eisen'). That end was primarily the establishment and perpetuation of the German nation-state and the maintenance of domestic stability and an international balance of power. The means were war and diplomacy in foreign policy; in domestic affairs repression and sometimes dosed reform - not out of idealism, but out of political strategy. Central to his domestic policy was the creation of internal enemies, first of all the socialists and catholics. Against the latter he conducted a Kulturkampf in the 1870s; the Dogma of Papal Infallibility by Pope Pius IX (1870) was thereby the occasion for forcibly submitting the Church to the authority of the young German Empire, contra the German Catholic Zentrumspartei. In 1890 he was put on the sidelines by the new Kaiser Wilhelm II; after which he became the object of a cult; hundreds of monuments throughout Germany were erected to his honour.
$Bismarck.it_IT: Otto Eduard Leopold von Bismarck-Schönhausen fu uno statista prussiano e tedesco. Dal 1862 al 1890 fu Primo Ministro della Prussia, dal 1867 Cancelliere della Confederazione Tedesca del Nord, dal 1871 Cancelliere dell'Impero Tedesco, di cui è considerato l'”architetto”. Era un autoproclamato Realpolitiker, per il quale il fine giustificava sempre i mezzi (se necessario “Blut und Eisen”). Il fine era principalmente l'istituzione e la perpetuazione dello Stato nazionale tedesco e il mantenimento della stabilità interna e dell'equilibrio di potere internazionale. I mezzi erano la guerra e la diplomazia in politica estera; negli affari interni la repressione e talvolta una riforma dosata - non per idealismo, ma per strategia politica. Il fulcro della sua politica interna fu la creazione di nemici interni, primi fra tutti i socialisti e i cattolici. Contro questi ultimi condusse un Kulturkampf negli anni Settanta del XIX secolo; il dogma dell'infallibilità papale di Pio IX (1870) fu quindi l'occasione per sottomettere con la forza la Chiesa all'autorità del giovane Impero tedesco, contro la Zentrumspartei cattolica tedesca. Nel 1890 fu messo in disparte dal nuovo Kaiser Guglielmo II; in seguito divenne oggetto di un culto; centinaia di monumenti in tutta la Germania furono eretti in suo onore.
$Bismarck.nl_NL: Otto Eduard Leopold von Bismarck-Schönhausen was een Pruisisch en Duits staatsman. Van 1862 tot 1890 was hij minister-president van Pruisen, vanaf 1867 Bondskanselier van de Noord-Duitse Bond, vanaf 1871 rijkskanselier van het Duitse Keizerrijk, waarvan hij als de architect geldt. Hij was een zelfverklaard Realpolitiker, voor wie het doel altijd de middelen (indien nodig 'Blut und Eisen') heiligde. Dat doel was primair de vestiging en bestendiging van de Duitse natiestaat en het behoud van een binnenlandse stabiliteit en internationaal machtsevenwicht. De middelen waren oorlog en diplomatie in de buitenlandse politiek; in de binnenlandse repressie en soms gedoseerde hervorming – niet uit idealisme, maar uit politieke strategie. Centraal in zijn binnenlandse politiek stond het scheppen van interne vijanden, allereerst de socialisten en de katholieken. Tegen de laatsten voerde hij in de jaren 1870 een Kulturkampf; het Dogma van de Pauselijke Onfeilbaarheid door paus Pius IX (1870) was daarbij de aanleiding om de Kerk met geweld aan het gezag van het jonge Duitse Keizerrijk te onderwerpen, contra de Duitse katholieke Zentrumspartei. In 1890 werd hij door de nieuwe keizer Wilhelm II opzijgezet; waarna hij het middelpunt werd van een cultus en honderden monumenten door heel Duitsland kreeg.

$Bixio.en_GB: Nino Bixio was an Italian soldier and patriot and one of the most prominent figures of the Risorgimento. After his training in the Piedmontese navy, he joined Giuseppe Mazzini's patriotic movement Giovine Italia (Young Italy, 1831) in 1846. He took part in the First Italian War of Independence and became a captain under Giuseppe Garibaldi during the defence of the Roman Republic (1849). Thereafter, he served in all major military operations up to the capture of Rome in 1870, in the latter case as commander of the second division of the Italian army. He also became politically active when he was elected to the Italian parliament in 1861, following the proclamation of the Kingdom of Italy. In 1870, he became a senator. Among other things, during the following years he was devoted to shipbuilding and shipping. In 1873, he died at sea of cholera. His ruthless actions in Sicily during Garibaldi's expedition in 1860 made him particularly notorious as a military commander.
$Bixio.it_IT: Nino Bixio fu stato un soldato e patriota italiano, una delle figure più importanti del Risorgimento. Dopo l'addestramento nella marina piemontese, nel 1846 aderì al movimento patriottico Giovine Italia di Giuseppe Mazzini (1831). Partecipò alla prima guerra d'indipendenza italiana e diventa capitano sotto Giuseppe Garibaldi durante la difesa della Repubblica Romana (1849). In seguito, partecipò a tutte le principali operazioni militari fino alla presa di Roma nel 1870, in quest'ultimo caso come comandante della seconda divisione dell'esercito italiano. Divenne anche attivo politicamente quando fu eletto al Parlamento italiano nel 1861, dopo la proclamazione del Regno d'Italia. Nel 1870 divenne senatore. Negli anni successivi si dedicò, tra l'altro, alla costruzione di navi e alla navigazione. Nel 1873 morì in mare di colera. Le sue dure azioni in Sicilia durante la spedizione di Garibaldi nel 1860 lo resero particolarmente noto come comandante militare
$Bixio.nl_NL: Nino Bixio was een Italiaans militair en patriot en een van de meest prominente figuren van het Risorgimento. Na een opleiding bij de Piemontese marine trad hij in 1846 toe tot Giuseppe Mazzini's patriottistische beweging Giovine Italia (Jong Italië, 1831). Hij nam deel aan de Eerste Italiaanse Onafhankelijkheidsoorlog en werd kapitein onder Giuseppe Garibaldi tijdens de verdediging van de Romeinse Republiek (1849). Daarna diende hij tijdens alle belangrijke militaire operaties tot en met de inname van Rome in 1870, in het laatste geval als commandant van de tweede divisie van het Italiaanse leger. Hij raakte ook op politiek vlak betrokken, toen hij in 1861, na de proclamatie van het Koninkrijk Italië, in het Italiaanse parlement werd gekozen. In 1870 werd hij senator. Hij richtte zich in de daaropvolgende jaren onder meer op de scheepsbouw en scheepvaart. In 1873 overleed hij op zee aan cholera. Vooral zijn meedogenloze optreden op Sicilië tijdens Garibaldi's expeditie in 1860 maakte hem als militair berucht.

$Blasiis.en_GB: Francesco De Blasiis was an Italian patriot and politician. He took part in the uprisings in Naples of 1848, becoming a member of the Neapolitan parliament, but the Bourbon reaction forced him into exile. Taking refuge in Tuscany, he participated in the events of 1859, which lead to the departure of Grand Duke, the establishment of of provisional government and eventually a plebiscite, after which Tuscany joined the Kingdom of Sardinia. Later he became Minister of the Interior of the temporary Luogotenenza (Steward) of Naples in 1860, and a member of the Italian parliament from 1861 to 1873. In 1867, during the Rattazzi administration, he served as Minister of Agriculture.
$Blasiis.it_IT: Francesco De Blasiis fu un patriota e uomo politico Italiano. Prese parte ai moti napoletani del 1848 divenendo deputato al parlamento napoletano; la reazione borbonica lo costrinse ad andare in esilio. Rifugiatosi in Toscana, partecipò ai fatti del 1859 e in seguito fu deputato al parlamento italiano dal 1861 al 1873). Ministro degli Interni della luogotenenza di Napoli nel 1860, fu nel 1867 ministro dell'Agricoltura col Rattazzi.
$Blasiis.nl_NL: Francesco De Blasiis was een Italiaans patriot en politicus. Hij nam deel aan de opstanden in Napels in 1848 en werd lid van het tijdelijke Napolitaanse parlement, maar door de reactie van de Bourbons werd hij spoedig gedwongen in ballingschap te gaan. Zijn toevluchtsoord werd Toscane, waar hij deelnam aan de roerige gebeurtenissen van 1859, die leidden tot het vertrek van de groothertog, de oprichting van een voorlopige regering en uiteindelijk een volksstemming, waarna Toscane zich aansloot bij het Koninkrijk Sardinië. Later werd De Blasiis minister van Binnenlandse Zaken van de tijdelijke 'Luogotenenza' (stadhouderschap) van Napels in 1860 en lid van het Italiaanse parlement van 1861 tot 1873. In 1867, tijdens de regering van Rattazzi, was hij minister van Landbouw.

$Bloem.en_GB: Heertje Willem Bloem was a well-known teacher from Amsterdam. For years he ran a day boarding school there for children from the bourgeoisie, first on the Keizersgracht near the Molenpad, later on the Heerengracht near Oude Spiegelstraat. He was secretary of the board of the Nederlandsch Onderwijsgenootschap (Dutch Society for Education) from 1859 until his death, and commissioner of the associated Levensverzekeringsmaatschappij (Life Insurance Company, 1863-1880). He was editor of the Tijdschrift voor reken-, stel- en meetkunde and the Tijdschrift voor wis-, natuur- en werktuigkunde (two journals for mathematics, physics and engineering), among others. He also translated educational books from the German, such as E.T. Goltzsch's Einrichtungs- und Lehrplan für Dorfschulen (1859).
$Bloem.it_IT: Heertje Willem Bloem fu un noto insegnante di Amsterdam. Per anni gestì un collegio diurno per bambini della borghesia, prima sul Keizersgracht vicino al Molenpad, poi sull'Heerengracht vicino a Oude Spiegelstraat. Fu segretario del consiglio di amministrazione della Nederlandsch Onderwijsgenootschap (Società olandese per l'istruzione) dal 1859 fino alla sua morte, e commissario della Levensverzekeringsmaatschappij (Società di assicurazione sulla vita, 1863-1880) ad essa associata. Fu editore, tra l'altro, della Tijdschrift voor reken-, stel- en meetkunde e della Tijdschrift voor wis-, natuur- en werktuigkunde (due riviste di matematica, fisica e ingegneria). Tradusse anche libri didattici dal tedesco, come Einrichtungs- und Lehrplan für Dorfschulen di E.T. Goltzsch (1859).
$Bloem.nl_NL: Heertje Willem Bloem was een bekend onderwijzer uit Amsterdam. Jarenlang had hij daar een dagkostschool voor kinderen uit de gegoede burgerij, eerst op de Keizersgracht bij het Molenpad, later op de Heerengracht bij de Oude Spiegelstraat. Hij was secretaris van het hoofdbestuur van het Nederlandsch Onderwijsgenootschap van 1859 tot zijn dood en commissaris van de daaraan verbonden Levensverzekeringsmaatschappij (1863-1880). Voor o.a. het Tijdschrift voor reken-, stel- en meetkunde en het Tijdschrift voor wis-, natuur- en werktuigkunde was hij redacteur. Ook vertaalde hij onderwijskundige boeken uit het Duits, zoals E.T.Goltzsch' Einrichtungs- und Lehrplan für Dorfschulen (1859).

$Bonaparte.en_GB: The Emperor of the French Napoleon III, born Charles-Louis Napoléon Bonaparte, was the son of Louis Napoléon, king of Holland. From 1823 to 1831 he lived in Italy, where he became a member of the secret society the Carboneria and joined the rebellion in Forlì against papal authority (1831). After his exile in Switzerland and London, and several failed coup attempts (1836 and 1840) on the French throne, he was elected to the Assemblée of the Second French Republic (September 1848), which had been formed after the February revolution of 1848. In December 1848 he was elected president of the Assemblée, and in that capacity he sent an expeditionary army to Rome to restore papal authority, after the Roman Republic had been proclaimed in February 1849. On 2 December 1851, he committed a coup to extend his term as president; exactly a year later, he proclaimed the (Second) French Empire, thereby crowning himself. During the Second Italian War of Independence (1859) he led the French army into an alliance with the Kingdom of Sardinia-Piedmont against Austria. Paradoxically, at the same time he maintained a contingent of French troops in Rome (until August 1870) to protect the Papal State against Italian claims. The French defeat at the Battle at Sedan, during the French-Prussian War, led to the end of the French Empire (4 September 1870). Napoleon died in 1873, while in exile in England.
$Bonaparte.it_IT: L'imperatore dei Francesi Napoleone III, nato Carlo Luigi Napoleone Bonaparte, era figlio di Luigi Napoleone, re d'Olanda. Dal 1823 al 1831 visse in Italia, dove divenne membro della società segreta della Carboneria e si unì alla ribellione di Forlì contro l'autorità papale (1831). Dopo il suo esilio in Svizzera e a Londra, e diversi tentativi di colpo di stato falliti (1836 e 1840) per il  trono di Francia, fu eletto nell'Assemblea della Seconda Repubblica francese (settembre 1848), che si era formata dopo la rivoluzione di febbraio del 1848. Nel dicembre 1848 fu eletto presidente dell'Assemblea e in tale veste inviò un esercito di spedizione a Roma per restaurare l'autorità papale, dopo la proclamazione della Repubblica Romana nel febbraio 1849. Il 2 dicembre 1851 compì un colpo di stato per prolungare il suo potere  di mandato come presidente; esattamente un anno dopo, proclamò il (Secondo) Impero francese, incoronandosi così. Durante la Seconda Guerra d'Indipendenza Italiana (1859) guidò l'esercito francese nell'alleanza con il Regno di Sardegna-Piemonte contro l'Austria. Paradossalmente mantenne allo stesso tempo un contingente di truppe francesi a Roma (fino all'agosto 1870) per proteggere lo Stato Pontificio dalle pretese italiane. La sconfitta francese nella battaglia di Sedan, durante la guerra franco-prussiana, portò alla fine dell'Impero francese (4 settembre 1870). Napoleone morì nel 1873, mentre era in esilio in Inghilterra.
$Bonaparte.nl_NL: Keizer Napoleon III, geboren als Karel Lodewijk Napoleon Bonaparte, was de zoon van Lodewijk Napoleon, koning van Holland. Hij leefde van 1823 tot 1831 in Italië, waar hij lid werd van het geheime genootschap de Carboneria en deelnam aan de opstand in Forlì tegen het pauselijk gezag (1831). Na een ballingschap in Zwitserland en Londen en enkele vergeefse couppogingen (1836 en 1840) om de Franse troon te heroveren, werd hij in september 1848 gekozen in de Assemblée van de Tweede Franse Republiek, die na de Februarirevolutie van 1848 was ontstaan. Hij werd in december gekozen als president van de Assemblée en stuurde in die capaciteit een expeditieleger naar Rome om de paus in zijn macht te herstellen, nadat in februari 1849 de Romeinse Republiek was uitgeroepen. Op 2 december 1851 pleegde hij een staatsgreep om zijn termijn als president te kunnen verlengen; precies een jaar later riep hij het (Tweede) Franse Keizerrijk uit waarmee hij zichzelf kroonde. Tijdens de Tweede Italiaanse Onafhankelijkheidsoorlog (1859) leidde hij het Franse leger in een alliantie met het Koninkrijk Sardinië-Piemonte tegen Oostenrijk. Tegelijkertijd hield hij tot augustus 1870 een contingent Franse troepen in Rome om de Pauselijke Staat te beschermen tegen de Italiaanse aanspraken. De Franse nederlaag bij de Slag bij Sedan, tijdens de Frans-Pruisische Oorlog, betekende op 4 september 1870 het einde van het Franse Keizerrijk. Napoleon III stierf in 1873 in ballingschap in Engeland.

$Boni.en_GB: Filippo de Boni was an Italian writer and politician. After studying at the seminary in Padua, he moved to Venice even before he took his vows. There he began a journalistic career and fell under the spell of democratic ideals. Because of suspicions by the Austrian police, he made his way to Florence, where he worked for the Mondo contemporaneo. When he also had to leave Tuscany, he went to Genoa and then to Switzerland. In 1848 he participated as a mazzinian in the uprisings in Milan, Genoa, Florence and Rome. In the latter city he founded the journal Il Tribuno, in which he criticized the executive committee of the Roman Republic of 1849, which then sent him as its diplomatic representative to the Swiss Confederation. Even after the fall of the Roman Republic, he remained in Switzerland. Only in 1860 did he return to Italy, where he collaborated in Naples on the Partito d'Azione's party newspaper, Popolo d'Italia. In 1861 he was elected deputy for the Sinistra (Left), where he distinguished himself as one of the fiercest anticlericals.
$Boni.it_IT: Filippo de Boni fu uno scrittore e uomo politico italiano. Dopo aver studiato in seminario a Padova, prima di prendere i voti si trasferì a Venezia, iniziando la carriera giornalistica e aderendo alle idee democratiche. Diventato elemento sospetto per la polizia austriaca, passò a Firenze, dove collaborò al Mondo contemporaneo. Costretto a lasciare la Toscana, nel 1846 si trasferì a Genova e poi in Svizzera. Durante il 1848 fu a Milano, Genova, Firenze e Roma, partecipando, nelle file mazziniane, alle insurrezioni e alle sollevazioni che in quelle città si svolsero. A Roma fondò un periodico intitolato Il Tribuno, in cui criticò gli atti del comitato esecutivo del nuovo governo della Repubblica, il quale, per liberarsi dell'irruento contestatore, lo inviò come suo rappresentante presso la Confederazione svizzera. Qui si fermò anche dopo la caduta della Repubblica romana. Tornò in Italia nel 1860 e a Napoli collaborò al Popolo d'Italia, organo del Partito d'azione. Nel 1861 venne eletto deputato, nelle file della Sinistra, e fu tra i maggiori sostenitori della battaglia anticlericale.
$Boni.nl_NL: Filippo de Boni was een Italiaans schrijver en politicus. Na zijn studie aan het seminarie in Padova, verhuisde hij naar Venetië nog voordat hij zijn geloften kon afleggen. Daar begon hij een journalistieke carrière en raakte in de ban van democratische idealen. Vanwege verdenkingen bij de Oostenrijkse politie begaf hij zich naar Florence, waar hij meewerkte voor de Mondo contemporaneo. Toen hij ook Toscane moest verlaten, ging hij naar Genua en vervolgens naar Zwitserland. In 1848 nam hij als mazziniaan deel aan de opstanden in Milaan, Genua, Florence en Rome. In die laatste stad stichtte hij het blad Il Tribuno, waarin hij kritiek uitte op het uitvoerend comité van de Romeinse Republiek van 1849, dat hem vervolgens uitzond als diplomatiek vertegenwoordiger bij de Zwitserse Confederatie. Ook na de val van de Romeinse Republiek bleef hij in Zwitserland. Pas in 1860 keerde hij naar Italië terug, waar hij in Napels meewerkte aan het partijblad van de Partito d'Azione, Popolo d'Italia. In 1861 werd hij gekozen als gedeputeerde voor de Sinistra (Links), waar hij zich onderscheidde als een van de felste antiklerikalen.

$Boot.en_GB: Johan Cornelis Gerard Boot was a Dutch classicist. He was the older brother of Mr. C.H.B. Boot, mayor of Amsterdam and minister of (among other things) Justice (1858-1860). J.C.G. Boot studied Law and Latin in Leiden, where he also received his doctorate. In 1851 he was appointed professor of Greek, Latin, History and Antiquities at the Athenaeum Illustre (1851-1870), which continued as the University of Amsterdam. At the latter institution, Boot was again extraordinary professor from 1877-1881, this time with a chair in Latin. His particular interest was in Neolatin authors, as evidenced by his editions of the elegies of Heinsius (1872) and the Latin letters of Constantijn Huygens (1873). In 1836, 1871 and 1882, he traveled to Italy, a country for which he held a lifelong admiration. Boot corresponded with the Italian poets Giosuè Carducci and Giovanni Pascoli, with Cavour and with members of the Italian royal family. In the Netherlands he was secretary of the literature section of the Royal Academy of Sciences from 1863; in Italy he was a member of the Accademia dei Lincei, for which he gave a lecture in Italian at the Capitol during his 1882 trip.
$Boot.it_IT: Johan Cornelis Gerard Boot fu un classicista olandese. Era il fratello maggiore di C.H.B. Boot, sindaco di Amsterdam e ministro della Giustizia (1858-1860). J.C.G. Boot studiò legge e latino a Leida, dove conseguì anche il dottorato. Nel 1851 fu nominato professore di greco, latino, storia e antichità presso l'Athenaeum Illustre (1851-1870), che continuò come Università di Amsterdam. Presso quest'ultima istituzione, Boot fu nuovamente professore straordinario dal 1877 al 1881, questa volta con una cattedra di latino. Il suo particolare interesse era rivolto agli autori neolatini, come testimoniano le sue edizioni delle elegie di Heinsius (1872) e delle lettere latine di Constantijn Huygens (1873). Nel 1836, nel 1871 e nel 1882 viaggiò in Italia, un Paese per il quale nutrì un'ammirazione che durò tutta la vita. Boot fu in corrispondenza con i poeti italiani Giosuè Carducci e Giovanni Pascoli, con Cavour e con i membri della famiglia reale italiana. Nei Paesi Bassi fu segretario della sezione di letteratura dell'Accademia Reale delle Scienze dal 1863; in Italia fu membro dell'Accademia dei Lincei, per la quale tenne una conferenza in italiano al Campidoglio durante il viaggio del 1882.
$Boot.nl_NL: Johan Cornelis Gerard Boot was een Nederlands classicus. Hij was de oudere broer van Mr. C.H.B. Boot, burgermeester van Amsterdam en minister van (o.a.) Justitie (1858-1860). J.C.G. Boot studeerde Rechten en Latijn in Leiden, waar hij ook promoveerde. In 1851 werd hij benoemd tot hoogleraar Grieks, Latijn, Geschiedenis en Antiquiteiten aan het Athenaeum Illustre (1851-1870), dat werd voortgezet als Universiteit van Amsterdam. Aan die laatste instelling was Boot van 1877-1881 opnieuw buitengewoon hoogleraar, dit maar met de leeropdracht Latijn. Zijn belangstelling ging in het bijzonder uit naar Neolatijnse auteurs, zoals blijkt uit zijn edities van de elegieën van Heinsius (1872) en de Latijnse brieven van Constantijn Huygens (1873). In 1836, 1871 en 1882 reisde hij naar Italië, een land waarvoor hij een levenslange bewondering koesterde. Boot correspondeerde met de Italiaanse dichters Giosuè Carducci en Giovanni Pascoli, met Cavour en met leden van het Italiaanse koninklijk huis. In Nederland was hij vanaf 1863 secretaris van de afdeling Letterkunde van de Koninklijke Academie van Wetenschappen; in Italië was hij lid van de Accademia dei Lincei, waarvoor hij tijdens zijn reis in 1882 op het Capitool een voordracht in het Italiaans hield.

$Borgatti.en_GB: Francesco Borgatti was an Italian politician and magistrate. He graduated in law from the University of Bologna in 1842. Afterwards, he worked as a lawyer in Bologna and Rome, where he became involved in politics. After contributing to the newspaper 'Il Panorama', he became the editor of the political newspaper 'La Speranza' in 1848. In 1848, he was nominated Secretary-General of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, a position he held during the Roman Republic of 1849. After the fall of the republic and the entry of the French in Rome, Borgatti was forced to leave the city. He then returned to Bologna, where he devoted himself to the practice of law. When the papal government there fell in 1859, Borgatti became involved in politics once again. In 1860, he was elected to the Chamber of Deputies and was re-elected in all subsequent elections until 1871. As a friend of Marco Minghetti and Bettino Ricasoli, Borgatti was a representative of moderate thinking in the Emilia region. In 1866, he became Minister of Justice. In that position, he continued to advocate that relations between state and church should be regulated by the common law of the state. He was elected senator and served as vice-president of the Senate from 1876 onwards.
$Borgatti.it_IT: Francesco Borgatti fu un politico e magistrate Italiano. Si laureò in Diritto a Bologna nel 1842. Fece pratica legale a Bologna e a Roma, dove incominciò ad impegnarsi nella vita politica. Dopo aver collaborato a 'Il Panorama', e diresse dal 1848 il giornale politico 'La Speranza'. Nel 1848 divenne Segretariato generale del ministero degli Affari Esteri secolari,anche durante La Repubblica Romana del 1849. Dopo l'ingresso dei Francesi in Roma, fu costretto ad abbandonare la città e ritornò a Bologna, dedicandosi alla professione forense. Caduto il potere pontificio nel 1859, s'impegnò nella vita politica. Eletto deputato nel 1860, venne confermato in tale incarico in tutte le successive elezioni fino 1871. Amico di Marco Minghetti e di Bettino Ricasoli, fu esponente del moderatismo emiliano. Nel 1866  divenne ministro di Grazia e Giustizia  e anche successivamente sostenne che i rapporti tra Stato e Chiesa dovevano essere regolati dal diritto comune dello Stato. Eletto al Senato fu dal 1876 vicepresidente del Senato.
$Borgatti.nl_NL: Francesco Borgatti was een Italiaans politicus en magistraat. Hij studeerde in 1842 af in de rechten in Bologna. Daarna werkte hij als advocaat in Bologna en Rome, waar hij zich politiek begon te engageren. Na zijn medewerking te hebben verleend aan de krant “Il Panorama”, gaf hij vanaf 1848 leiding aan de politieke krant “La Speranza”. In 1848 werd hij secretaris-generaal van het ministerie van Buitenlandse Zaken, een functie die hij behield tijdens de Romeinse Republiek van 1849. Na de val van de republiek en de intocht van de Fransen in Rome moest Borgatti de stad verlaten en keerde hij terug naar Bologna, waar hij zich toelegde op de advocatuur. Toen het pauselijke gezag daar in 1859 ten val kwam, raakte hij opnieuw betrokken bij de politiek. In 1860 werd hij in het Huis van Afgevaardigden gekozen, en in alle daaropvolgende verkiezingen tot 1871 werd hij in die functie bevestigd. Als vriend van Marco Minghetti en Bettino Ricasoli was Borgatti een vertegenwoordiger van het gematigde denken in de regio Emilia. In 1866 werd hij minister van Justitie. Ook in die functie bleef hij bepleiten dat de betrekkingen tussen staat en kerk moesten worden gereguleerd door het gemeen recht van de staat. Hij werd verkozen tot senator en was vanaf 1876 vicevoorzitter van de Senaat.

$Borromeo.en_GB: Edoardo Borromeo Arese was a cardinal from Milan, born to a family that had produced no less than six cardinals, one of them cardinal-secretary of state, later canonized, Carlo Borromeo (1538-1584). Pope Pius IX named Eduardo Borromeo his chief chamberlain (30 March 1850) and subsequently majordomo and prefect of the Apostolic Palaces (16 June 1856). In 1868, Borromeo Arese was elevated to the cardinalate, and in 1872, he was named archpriest of Saint Peter's and prefect of the Fabric of Saint Peter's.
$Borromeo.it_IT: Edoardo Borromeo Arese era un cardinale di Milano, nato da una famiglia che aveva dato i natali a ben sei cardinali, uno dei quali cardinale-segretario di stato, poi canonizzato, Carlo Borromeo (1538-1584). Papa Pio IX nominò Eduardo Borromeo suo primo camerlengo (30 marzo 1850) e successivamente maggiordomo e prefetto dei Palazzi Apostolici (16 giugno 1856). Nel 1868 Borromeo Arese fu elevato al rango cardinalizio e nel 1872 fu nominato arciprete di San Pietro e prefetto della Fabbrica di San Pietro.
$Borromeo.nl_NL: Edoardo Borromeo Arese was een kardinaal uit Milaan afkomstig uit een familie die liefst zes kardinalen voortbracht, onder wie kardinaal-staatssecretaris en heiligverklaarde Carlo Borromeo (1538-1584). Paus Pius IX maakte hem zijn hoofd kamerheer (30 maart 1850) en benoemde hem vervolgens tot majordomus en prefect van de Apostolische Paleizen (16 juni 1856). In 1868 werd Borromeo Arese tot kardinaal gewijd, en in 1872 aartspriester van Sint Pieter en prefect van de Fabriek van Sint Pieter.

$Bouillet.en_GB: Marie-Nicolas Bouillet was a French writer, lexicographer, teacher and schools inspector. After being educated at the École Normale Superieure and studying philosophy with Victor Cousin and others, he began a career as a teacher at various collèges in Rouen and Paris. From 1837 he was active in various inspection bodies for the Ministry of Education, until finally, in 1861, he succeeded Alfred de Wailly as Inspector General of Secondary Education (Letters). After the February Revolution of 1848, he was sidelined as a 'compromised' official, but was rehabilitated in 1849. In addition to his public service, he contributed to many encyclopedic works. He himself was the compiler of, among others, the Dictionnaire classique de l'antiquité sacrée et profane (1827), the Dictionnaire universel des sciences, des lettres et des arts (1854) and the Atlas universel d'histoire et de géographie (1865). His best-known work was the 20-volume Dictionnaire universel d'histoire et de géographie (1842), also known as 'Le Bouillet,' which went through 34 editions until 1914. Some controversy i was caused by the changes made to the 1854 edition, which caused the Dictionnaire to be removed by church authorities from the Index of banned books on which it had been placed in 1852.
$Bouillet.it_IT: Marie-Nicolas Bouillet fu uno scrittore, lessicografo, insegnante e ispettore scolastico francese. Dopo essersi formato all'École Normale Superieure e aver studiato filosofia con Victor Cousin e altri, iniziò la carriera di insegnante in vari collegi di Rouen e Parigi. Dal 1837 fu attivo in vari organi di controllo del Ministero dell'Istruzione, finché nel 1861 succedette ad Alfred de Wailly come ispettore generale dell'istruzione secondaria (Lettere). Dopo la Rivoluzione di febbraio del 1848, fu emarginato come funzionario “compromesso”, ma fu riabilitato nel 1849. Oltre al suo servizio pubblico, contribuì a molte opere enciclopediche. Egli stesso fu il compilatore, tra gli altri, del Dictionnaire classique de l'antiquité sacrée et profane (1827), del Dictionnaire universel des sciences, des lettres et des arts (1854) e dell'Atlas universel d'histoire et de géographie (1865). La sua opera più nota fu il Dictionnaire universel d'histoire et de géographie (1842), in 20 volumi, noto anche come “Le Bouillet”, che ebbe 34 edizioni fino al 1914. Alcune polemiche vennero sollevate a causa delle modifiche apportate all'edizione del 1854, che hanno fatto sì che il Dictionnaire venisse rimosso dalle autorità ecclesiastiche dall'Indice dei libri proibiti in cui era stato inserito nel 1852.
$Bouillet.nl_NL: Marie-Nicolas Bouillet was een Franse schrijver, lexicograaf, docent en onderwijsinspecteur. Na een opleiding aan de École Normale Superieure en een studie filosofie bij o.a. Victor Cousin begon hij een carrière als onderwijzer aan verschillende collèges in Rouen en Parijs. Vanaf 1837 was hij actief voor verschillende inspectieorganen voor het ministerie van Onderwijs, tot hij ten slotte in 1861 Alfred de Wailly als inspecteur-generaal secundair onderwijs (letteren) opvolgde. Na de Februarirevolutie van 1848 werd hij als 'gecompromitteerd' ambtenaar op een zijspoor gezet, maar in 1849 werd hij gerehabiliteerd. Naast zijn overheidsdienst droeg hij bij aan vele encyclopedische werken. Zelf was hij de samensteller van onder meer het Dictionnaire classique de l'antiquité sacrée et profane (1827), het Dictionnaire universel des sciences, des lettres et des arts (1854) en de Atlas universel d'histoire et de géographie (1865). Zijn bekendste werk was het 20-delige Dictionnaire universel d'histoire et de géographie (1842), ook bekend als 'Le Bouillet', die tot 1914 liefst 34 edities kende. Enig opzien baarden daarbij de wijzigingen die in de editie van 1854 werden doorgevoerd, die ervoor zorgden dat het Dictionnaire door de kerkelijke autoriteiten van de Index van verboden boeken werd gehaald waar het in 1852 op was gezet.

$BourbonCL.en_GB: Born as heir to the throne of the Duchy of Parma, the young Carlo Ludovico di Borbone-Parma was given the demanding title of King of Etruria at the age of four. His childhood was troubled by the Napoleonic wars and, separated from his mother, he was entrusted to his maternal grandparents. He was a man of lively intelligence and wide cultural interests. In 1817, he moved to Lucca and in 1820 he married Maria Teresa of Savoy, daughter of Victor Emmanuel I. Succeeding his mother on the throne of the Duchy of Lucca in 1824, Carlo Lodovico preferred to spend his time abroad, especially in Vienna, Dresden and Berlin, residing in Lucca only for short periods and leaving the government to his ministers. His brief conversion to Protestantism and the numerous unsavoury characters at his court made him the subject of much gossip in Europe. He was a tolerant and mild-mannered man, even welcoming political émigrés to Lucca. Prodigal to excess, he accumulated enormous debts, which partly led him to hand over the Duchy of Lucca to the Grand Duchy of Tuscany. By virtue of the agreements of the Congress of Vienna in 1847, he regained possession of the Duchy of Parma under the name of Charles II. However, the revolutionary events of 1848 led him to abdicate in favour of his son. He spent the rest of his life between Paris, the area around Lucca and Nice, where he died.
$BourbonCL.it_IT: Nato come erede al trono del Ducato di Parma, il piccolo Carlo Ludovico di Borbone-Parma all'età di quattro anni portava l'impegnativo titolo di Re d'Etruria. La sua infanzia fu turbata dalle vicende napoleoniche e separato dalla madre fu affidato ai nonni materni. Fu uomo di vivace intelligenza e vasti interessi culturali. Nel 1817 si trasferì a Lucca e nel 1820 sposò Maria Teresa di Savoia figlia di Vittorio Emanuele I. Succeduto alla madre sul trono del Ducato di Lucca, nel 1824, Carlo Lodovico preferì dedicarsi ai soggiorni all'estero soprattutto a Vienna, Dresda e Berlino, dimorando a Lucca solo per brevi periodi e lasciando il governo del ducato ai ministri. Una sua effimera conversione al protestantesimo e i numerosi personaggi sconvenienti della sua corte ne fecero un personaggio molto chiacchierato in Europa. Fu uomo tollerante e mite tanto da accogliere a Lucca emigrati politici. Prodigo fino all'eccesso, accumulò enormi debiti a causa dei quali consegnò anticipatamente il Ducato di Lucca al Granducato di Toscana. In virtù degli accordi del Congresso di Vienna nel 1847 rientrò in possesso del Ducato di Parma con il nome di Carlo II. Ma gli eventi rivoluzionari del 1848 lo portarono ad abdicare in favore del figlio; trascorse il resto della sua vita fra Parigi, la Lucchesia e Nizza dove morì.
$BourbonCL.nl_NL: De kleine Carlo Ludovico van Bourbon-Parma, geboren als troonopvolger van het hertogdom Parma, droeg op vierjarige leeftijd reeds de titel van koning van Etrurië. Zijn jeugd werd verstoord door de Napoleontische woelingen en hij werd gescheiden van zijn moeder en toevertrouwd aan zijn grootouders van moederskant. Hij was een man met een levendige intelligentie en brede culturele interesses. In 1817 verhuisde hij naar Lucca en in 1820 trouwde hij met Maria Teresa van Savoia, dochter van Vittorio Emanuele I. Carlo Lodovico volgde in 1824 zijn moeder op de troon van het Hertogdom Lucca, maar hij gaf de voorkeur aan verblijven in het buitenland, vooral in Wenen, Dresden en Berlijn. Slechts gedurende korte periodes verbleef hij in Lucca; het bestuur van het hertogdom liet hij over aan zijn ministers. Door zijn kortstondige bekering tot het protestantisme en de vele onaangepaste figuren in zijn hofhouding werd hij in heel Europa een veelbesproken persoon. Hij was een tolerant en zachtmoedig man, die in Lucca ook politieke ballingen opnam. Door zijn verkwisting bouwde hij enorme schulden op; mede daardoor moest hij het hertogdom Lucca voortijdig aan het groothertogdom Toscane afstaan. Op grond van de akkoorden van het Congres van Wenen in 1847 kwam hij weer in het bezit van het hertogdom Parma onder de naam Carlo II. Maar de revolutionaire gebeurtenissen van 1848 brachten hem ertoe ten gunste van zijn zoon af te treden. Hij bracht de rest van zijn leven door in Parijs, de omgeving van Lucca en Nice, waar hij stierf.

$BourbonFeI.en_GB: Ferdinand I of Bourbon was King of the Two Sicilies. He was born as the third son of Charles of Bourbon, King of Naples and Sicily, and Maria Amalia of Saxony. In 1759, he ascended the throne and began a reign that would last for many decades. When he turned eighteen in 1767, Ferdinand acquired full power. The first decision he made was to expel the Jesuits from his kingdom. In the same year, his engagement to Maria Carolina of Austria was sealed, and they married in 1768. As a result, the kingdom's foreign policy took a pro-Austrian and pro-English turn. In 1775, the heir to the throne, Carlo Francesco, was born. Two sisters -  Maria Teresa and Luisa Amalia – had preceded him. The events of the French Revolution prompted Ferdinand to put an end to the enlightened absolutist policy. He thus began a long reactionary reign with repressive domestic politics, in which he constantly sought anti-French alliances. Napoleon Bonaparte's Italian campaign forced him to conclude an armistice with the French troops in 1796. However, the arrival of the English admiral Nelson in Naples in 1798 led him to the decision to declare war on France. This proved to be a failure and Ferdinand was soon forced to flee to Sicily. With the help of the so-called Sanfedist movement, in which Cardinal Fabrizio Ruffo (1844-1827) raised a Catholic and anti-republican resistance army, Ferdinand returned to Naples and began a powerful Counter-Revolution. In 1799, he attempted to occupy the Papal States, but failed. Two years later (1801), the French army, led by Napoleon's brother-in-law Joachim Murat, advanced on Naples. Murat would soon occupy the Kingdom, marking the beginning of a long period of French rule over southern Italy. The king's flight from Naples to Palermo contributed to an even stronger English control over that island. Ferdinand's reign was restored when Murat's government fell in 1815. Ferdinando thus returned to the Neapolitan throne and, in 1816, once again assumed the title of King of the Kingdom of the Two Sicilies, in accordance with the dictates of the Congress of Vienna.  A few years later, he was again confronted with liberal uprisings urging for a constitution (1820), with Guglielmo Pepe as their leading figure. He managed to weather this storm as well. Ferdinand died in Naples in 1825.
$BourbonFeI.it_IT: Ferdinando I Di Borbone fu Re delle Due Sicilie. Nacque come terzo figlio di Carlo di Borbone re di Napoli e di Sicilia e di Maria Amalia di Sassonia. Nel 1759 salì al trono iniziando un lunghissimo regno. Nel 1767, Ferdinando acquisì pieni poteri e il primo atto che siglò fu l'espulsione dei gesuiti dal Regno. Nello stesso anno si concluse il suo fidanzamento con Maria Carolina d'Austria che sposò nel 1768, spostando l'asse della politica estera in direzione austrofila e anglofila. Nel 1775 nacque l'erede al trono Carlo Francesco, preceduto da due femmine - Maria Teresa e Luisa Amalia. Gli eventi della Rivoluzione francese spinsero Ferdinando a porre fine alla politica illuministica; aveva così inizio una lunga fase reazionaria che lo portò a ricercare alleanze in chiave antifrancese in un clima repressivo. Nel 1796 la campagna d'Italia di Napoleone Bonaparte lo vide costretto a concludere un armistizio con le forze francesi. L'arrivo a Napoli dell'ammiraglio inglese Nelson, nel 1798, determinò la decisione di scendere in guerra contro la Francia che si rivelò un fallimento causando la fuga di Ferdinando in Sicilia. Attraverso le truppe sanfediste affidate al cardinale Ruffo, Ferdinando ritornò a Napoli, iniziando una forte reazione. Nel 1799 tentò l'occupazione dello Stato romano, che si rivelò un fallimento. Nel 1801 l'esercito guidato da Murat avanzò verso i del Regno che in seguito avrebbe occupato iniziando un lungo periodo di dominio francese sul Mezzogiorno. La fuga di Ferdinando da Napoli a Palermo intensificò il controllo inglese sull'isola. Dopo alterne vicende il regno di Ferdinando trovò una sua risoluzione in seguito al fallimento del governo di Murat nel 1815, che lo portarono nuovamente sul trono napoletano. Seguendo i dettami del congresso di Vienna nel 1816 Ferdinando assunse il nome di re del Regno delle Due Sicilie.  Pochi anni dopo Ferdinando si trovò nuovamente a fronteggiare moti rivoluzioni per l'ottenimento della costituzione (1820) che videro protagonista Guglielmo Pepe che furono represse. Ferdinando morì a Napoli nel 1825.
$BourbonFeI.nl_NL: Ferdinand I van Bourbon was koning der Beide Siciliën. Hij werd geboren als derde zoon van Karel van Bourbon, koning van Napels en Sicilië, en Maria Amalia van Saksen. In 1759 besteeg hij de troon en begon bewind dat vele decennia zou duren. Als achttienjarige verwierf Ferdinand in 1767 de volledige macht. Het eerste besluit dat hij nam was de verdrijving van de jezuïeten uit zijn koninkrijk. In datzelfde jaar werd zijn verloving bezegeld met Maria Carolina van Oostenrijk, met wie hij in 1768 trouwde. Als gevolg hiervan nam het buitenlands beleid van het koninkrijk een pro-Oostenrijkse en pro-Engelse wending. In 1775 werd de troonopvolger Carlo Francesco geboren, nadat al eerder twee dochters waren geboren: Maria Teresa en Luisa Amalia. De gebeurtenissen van de Franse Revolutie zetten Ferdinand ertoe aan een einde te maken aan het verlicht-absolutistische beleid; zo begon een lange reactionaire fase met een repressieve binnenlandse politiek, waarbij hij voortdurend zocht naar anti-Franse allianties. De Italiaanse veldtocht van Napoleon Bonaparte dwong hem in 1796 tot het sluiten van een wapenstilstand met de Franse troepen. De komst van de Engelse admiraal Nelson naar Napels in 1798 leidde tot het besluit om aan Frankrijk de oorlog te verklaren. Dat bleek een mislukking en Ferdinand was spoedig gedwongen naar Sicilië te vluchten. Met behulp van de zogenaamde Sanfedistische beweging, waarbij kardinaal Fabrizio Ruffo (1844-1827) een katholiek en antirepublikeins verzetsleger op de been bracht, keerde Ferdinand terug naar Napels en begon hij een krachtige Reactie. In 1799 probeerde hij de Kerkelijke Staten te bezetten, maar dat mislukte. Twee jaar later (1801) rukte het Franse leger onder leiding van Napoleons zwager Joachim Murat op naar Napels. Murato zou het Koninkrijk spoedig bezetten, waarmee een lange periode van Franse overheersing over Zuid-Italië begon. De vlucht van Ferdinand van Napels naar Palermo droeg bij aan een nog sterkere Engelse controle over dat eiland. Uiteindelijk werd het koningschap van Ferdinand hersteld nadat de regering van Murat in 1815 was gevallen. Hij kwam opnieuw op de Napolitaanse troon en kreeg in 1816  opnieuw de titel van koning van het Koninkrijk der Beide Siciliën aan, in navolging van de dictaten van het Congres van Wenen. Enkele jaren later kreeg hij opnieuw te maken met liberale opstanden die hem moesten dwingen een grondwet toe te staan (1820), met Guglielmo Pepe als hoofdrolspeler. Ook deze storm wist hij te doorstaan. Ferdinand stierf in Napels in 1825.

$BourbonFeII.en_GB: Ferdinand II of Bourbon was king of the Two Sicilies from 1830 to 1859. As a ruler he initially seemed to commit to progressive promises made, but his regime proved to be a repressive one, and he mercilessly squashed liberal rebellions. He mournfully watched pope Pius IX ascend to the papal throne and set a liberal and reformist course of government. After the revolutions of 1848 took place, having started in January in Sicily, Ferdinand proclaimed a constitution and also gave in to the liberal demand to declare war on Austria (7 April 1848), feeling forced to do so in order to maintain power. The idea that his power was increasingly being curtailed drove him back to a regime of rigid absolutism. In April 1849 he definitively disbanded the parliament in Naples; in May he called his men back from their march on Austria and also cut a violent end to the rebellion that took place in Sicily, which had been an independent kingdom since March 1848. In the meantime, he declared war on the Roman Republic and marched across Roman borders with 8.500 men. Since November 1848, he offered Pius IX protection in Gaeta, and later did the same for the Grand Duke of Tuscany, Leopold II. After 1849, his reign was characterized by a hardening of reactionary repression, diplomatic isolation and a hopelessly outdated mercantile policy.
$BourbonFeII.it_IT: Ferdinando II di Borbone fu re delle Due Sicilie dal 1830 al 1859. Come sovrano inizialmente sembrò impegnarsi a mantenere le promesse progressiste fatte, ma il suo regime si rivelò repressivo e represse senza pietà le ribellioni liberali. Osservò con apprensione papa Pio IX salire al soglio pontificio e stabilire un corso di governo liberale e riformista. Dopo i moti rivoluzionari del 1848, iniziati nel gennaio in Sicilia, Ferdinando proclamò una costituzione e cedette anche alla richiesta liberale di dichiarare guerra all'Austria (7 aprile 1848), sentendosi costretto a farlo per mantenere il potere. L'idea che il suo potere potesse diminuire lo riportò ad un regime di rigido assolutismo. Nell'aprile 1849 sciolse definitivamente il parlamento di Napoli; nel maggio richiamò i suoi uomini dalla marcia contro l'Austria e pose fine violentemente anche alla ribellione scoppiata in Sicilia, regno indipendente dal marzo 1848. Nel frattempo dichiarò guerra alla Repubblica Romana e marciò oltre i confini romani con 8.500 uomini. Dal novembre 1848 offrì protezione a Gaeta a Pio IX, e successivamente fece altrettanto per il Granduca di Toscana Leopoldo II. Dopo il 1849, il suo regno fu caratterizzato da un inasprimento della repressione reazionaria, dall'isolamento diplomatico e da una politica mercantile irrimediabilmente superata.
$BourbonFeII.nl_NL: Ferdinand II van Bourbon was koning der Beide Siciliën van 1830 tot 1859. Hij leek als vorst progressieve beloften in te lossen, maar hij voerde een repressief bewind en drukte liberale opstanden genadeloos te kop in. Met lede ogen zag hij in 1846 de troonsbestijging aan van paus Pius IX, die aanvankelijk een liberaal en hervormingsgezind bewind voerde. De revolutie van 1848, in januari begonnen op Sicilië, deed Ferdinand uit machtsbehoud een grondwet afkondigen en toegeven aan de liberale eis Oostenrijk de oorlog te verklaren (7 april 1848). Het inzicht dat zijn macht allengs werd ingeperkt deed hem echter terugkeren tot een rigide absolutisme. In april 1849 stuurde hij het parlement in Napels naar huis; in mei riep hij zijn troepen terug uit de oorlog met Oostenrijk. Daarnaast een bloedig einde aan de opstand op Sicilië, dat sinds maart 1848 een onafhankelijk koninkrijk was geweest. Intussen verklaarde hij de oorlog aan de Romeinse Republiek en trok met 8.500 man de Romeinse grenzen over. Sinds november 1848 bood hij in Gaeta bescherming aan de uit Rome gevluchte Pius IX, en later ook aan de groothertog van Toscane, Leopold II. Zijn beleid na 1849 werd gekenmerkt door een verharding van de reactionaire repressie, een diplomatiek isolement en een hopeloos achterhaald mercantilisme.

$BourbonIsa.en_GB: Maria Isabella II of Bourbon was Queen of Spain, daughter of Ferdinand VII and Maria Christina of the Two Sicilies. She ascended the throne in 1833, under the regency of her mother. As a result, a civil war broke out in Spain between her supporters and those of her paternal uncle, Don Carlos, who had been driven from the throne. The civil war lasted from 1833 to 1840 and ended with the victory of the troops supporting Isabella. To counter the liberal uprisings, a quadruple defensive alliance was formed with England, France and Portugal (22 April 1833). At the same time, attempts were made to steal the liberal's thunder by establishing a constitution and a bicameral system. After Madrid and Barcelona rebelled, the regent Maria Christina fled to France. The regime then fell into the hands of a military dictatorship (1843), which pursued an anti-liberal policy. In 1846, Isabella married her cousin Maria Ferdinando Francesco d'Assisi, who was given the title of King. After attempts at liberal reforms and an assassination attempt on Isabella (3 February 1852), an army uprising led by Leopoldo O'Donnell in 1854 forced the queen to form a liberal cabinet. In 1867, the uprisings against the monarchy flared up again, until a decisive uprising led to the formation of a provisional republican government and Isabella's flight to France (30 September 1868). In March 1870, she abdicated the throne in favour of her son Alfonso XII.
$BourbonIsa.it_IT: Maria Isabella II di Borbone fu regina di Spagna. Figlia di Ferdinando VII e di Maria Cristina delle Due Sicilie. Salì al trono nel 1833, con la reggenza della madre. Iniziò così in Spagna una guerra civile tra i suoi sostenitori e quelli dello zio paterno Don Carlos, escluso dal trono. La guerra civile durò dal 1833 al 1840 terminando con la vittoria delle forze che sostenevano la regina. Per fronteggiare le rivolte  dei liberali, venne sottoscritta una quadruplice alleanza difensiva con l'Inghilterra, la Francia e il Portogallo (22 aprile 1833), accordando una costituzione e istituendo due camere. Dopo che Madrid e Barcellona si sollevarono, la reggente Maria Cristina fuggì in Francia. La tutela passò ad una la dittatura militare (1843), che iniziò una politica antiliberale. Nel 1846 Isabella sposò il cugino Maria Ferdinando Francesco d'Assisi, che ebbe il titolo di re. Dopo tentativi di riforme liberali e dopo un attentato a Isabella (3 febbraio 1852), nel 1854 un'insurrezione dell'esercito capeggiata da Leopoldo O'Donnell, portò la regina alla formazione di un gabinetto di carattere liberale. Nel 1867 si riaccesero i moti insurrezionali ostili alla monarchia, finché una rivolta decisiva portò alla formazione di un governo provvisorio repubblicano e alla fuga di Isabella in Francia (30 settembre 1868). Nel marzo 1870  abdicò a favore del figlio Alfonso XII.
$BourbonIsa.nl_NL: Maria Isabella II van Bourbon was koningin van Spanje. Ze was de dochter van Ferdinand VII en Maria Christina der Beide Siciliën. Ze besteeg de troon in 1833, onder het regentschap van haar moeder. Als gevolg daarvan brak in Spanje een burgeroorlog uit tussen haar aanhangers en die van haar oom van vaderskant, Don Carlos, die van de troon was verdreven. De burgeroorlog duurde van 1833 tot 1840 en eindigde met de overwinning van de troepen die Isabella steunden. Om de opstanden van de liberalen het hoofd te bieden, werd een viervoudig defensief bondgenootschap gesloten met Engeland, Frankrijk en Portugal (22 april 1833). Tegelijkertijd werd gepoogd de liberale de wind uit de zeilen te nemen door een grondwet en een tweekamerstelsel in te stellen. Nadat Madrid en Barcelona in opstand waren gekomen, vluchtte de regentes Maria Christina naar Frankrijk. Het bewind kwam daarop in handen van een militaire dictatuur (1843), die een antiliberaal beleid voerde. In 1846 trouwde Isabella met haar neef Maria Ferdinando Francesco d'Assisi, die de titel van koning kreeg. Na pogingen tot liberale hervormingen en na een aanslag op Isabella (3 februari 1852) noopte een opstand van het leger onder leiding van Leopoldo O'Donnell in 1854 de koningin tot de vorming van een liberaal kabinet. In 1867 laaiden de opstanden tegen de monarchie opnieuw op, totdat een beslissende opstand leidde tot de vorming van een voorlopige republikeinse regering en de vlucht van Isabella naar Frankrijk (30 september 1868). In maart 1870 deed zij afstand van de troon ten gunste van haar zoon Alfonso XII.

$BourbonKF.en_GB: Carlo Ferdinando di Borbone was an Italian prince of the Royal House of Bourbon-Two Sicilies. As the second son of Francesco I of the Kingdom of Naples, he soon started a military career. In 1829, he was a candidate to the throne of Greece, and in 1831 to that of Belgium. Having fallen in love with the Irish woman Penelope Smith, he was forced to leave the Kingdom of Naples because of the strong opposition of the king, who tried in every way to prevent their marriage. Nevertheless, he marriage was celebrated, in Scotland. Thus began a nomadic life that took him to England, Prussia, Belgium, France, Spain and Malta. The enduring conflict with the King of Naples, now the young Francis II, led Carlo to seek rapprochement with the new Italian government in 1860. After the Italian Unification, Victor Emmanuel II of Savoia consented to his return to Italy and, upon arriving in Turin, he died there on 22 April 1862.
$BourbonKF.it_IT: Carlo Ferdinando di Borbone fu un principe Italiano della Reale Casa di Borbone-Due Sicilie. secondogenito di Francesco I del Regno di Napoli, iniziò una carriera militare. Nel 1829 fu candidato al trono greco e nel 1831 al trono belga. Invaghitosi dell'irlandese Penelope Smith, abbandonò il Regno di Napoli a seguito dell'opposizione del re che tentò in ogni modo di impedire che fosse celebrato il loro matrimonio, che venne celebrato in Scozia. Iniziò così una vita nomade che lo portò in Inghilterra, in Prussia, in Belgio, in Francia, in Spagna e a Malta. Il contrasto con il giovane re Francesco II  lo portò ad  aderire nel 1860 al nuovo governo italiano. Vittorio Emanuele II acconsentì al suo ritorno in patria e, giunto a Torino, vi morì il 22 aprile 1862.
$BourbonKF.nl_NL: Karel Ferdinand van Bourbon was een Italiaanse prins van het koninklijk huis Bourbon-Beide Siciliën. Als tweede zoon van Francesco I van het Koninkrijk Napels begon hij al snel een militaire carrière. In 1829 was hij kandidaat voor de Griekse troon en in 1831 voor die van het jonge België. Nadat hij verliefd was geworden op de Ierse Penelope Smith, moest hij het Koninkrijk Napels verlaten, omdat de koning grote bewaren tegen de relatie had en op alle mogelijke manieren probeerde een huwelijk te verhinderen. Niettemin werd het huwelijk voltrokken, in Schotland. Zo begon een nomadisch leven dat Karel naar Engeland, Pruisen, België, Frankrijk, Spanje en Malta voerde. Het voortslepende conflict met de koning van Napels, nu de jonge Frans II, bracht hem ertoe in 1860 toenadering te zoeken tot de nieuwe Italiaanse regering. Na de Italiaanse eenwording gaf Victor Emmanuel II van Savoye goedkeuring aan zijn terugkeer naar Italië. Na  aankomst in Turijn stierf Karel van Bourbon daar, op 22 april 1862.

$Bourguignon.en_GB: Alfred Bourguignon was of Swiss descent and a cousin of the Meuricoffre brothers Oscar and Tell. He was a partner of their bank and trading office in foodstuffs (oil, grain) and hemp, among others, the Ditta Meuricoffre & C in Naples. For this company, Bourguignon was head of accounts. Under Tell Meuricoffre's consulate-general for the Kingdom of the Netherlands, Bourguignon was vice-consul. He was also a collector and dealer of antiquities and a corresponding member of the Instituto di Corrispondenza Archeologica in Rome, later the Deutsches Archäologisches Institut. His archaeological involvement is evident, for example, in mentions in the letters of some of the most famous German archaeologists of his time, including Heinrich Schliemann. Bourguignon collected and sold, among other things, vases (e.g. from Orvieto), glassware (e.g. from Cumae) and terracotta reliefs and ornaments from the necropolis of Santa Maria Capua Vetere, objects that were then not infrequently described, especially in German archaeological journals, such as the Jahrbuch of the Instituto and the Rheinisches Museum für Philologie. At the beginning of the 20th century, he ran out of money. After Tell Meuricoffre's death (1900), B. was accused of financial malpractice and fraud in the accounts of the Meuricoffre bank. To repay his debt, much of B.'s collection was auctioned in Paris in 1901, but his financial situation remained problematic until his death in September 1904. Presumably he retained his position as the Dutch vice-consul until then (his name still appears in the 1907 Almanach de Gotha as the Dutch vice-consul). The remainder of his collection ended up at the Historisches Museum of Frankfurt am Main in 1907, later the Archäoligisches Museum, and the Liebighaus.
$Bourguignon.it_IT: Alfred Bourguignon era di origine svizzera e cugino dei fratelli Meuricoffre Oscar e Tell. Fu socio della loro banca e ufficio commerciale di prodotti alimentari (olio, grano) e canapa, tra gli altri, la Ditta Meuricoffre & C di Napoli. Per questa società, Bourguignon era responsabile della contabilità. Sotto il consolato generale di Tell Meuricoffre per il Regno dei Paesi Bassi, Bourguignon fu vice-console. Fu anche collezionista e commerciante di antichità e membro corrispondente dell'Istituto di Corrispondenza Archeologica di Roma, poi Deutsches Archäologisches Institut. Il suo impegno archeologico è evidente, ad esempio, nelle citazioni contenute nelle lettere di alcuni dei più famosi archeologi tedeschi del suo tempo, tra cui Heinrich Schliemann. Bourguignon raccolse e vendette, tra l'altro, vasi (ad esempio da Orvieto), vasellame in vetro (ad esempio da Cumae) e rilievi e ornamenti in terracotta provenienti dalla necropoli di Santa Maria Capua Vetere, oggetti che all'epoca venivano descritti non di rado, soprattutto nelle riviste archeologiche tedesche, come lo Jahrbuch dell'Instituto e il Rheinisches Museum für Philologie. All'inizio del XX secolo, rimase senza soldi. Dopo la morte di Tell Meuricoffre (1900), B. fu accusato di negligenza finanziaria e di frode nei conti della banca Meuricoffre. Per ripagare il suo debito, gran parte della collezione di B. fu messa all'asta a Parigi nel 1901, ma la sua situazione finanziaria rimase problematica fino alla sua morte, avvenuta nel settembre 1904. Presumibilmente mantenne la sua posizione di viceconsole olandese fino ad allora (il suo nome compare ancora nell'Almanacco di Gotha del 1907 come viceconsole olandese). Il resto della sua collezione finì nel 1907 all'Historisches Museum di Francoforte sul Meno, poi all'Archäoligisches Museum e al Liebighaus.
$Bourguignon.nl_NL: Alfred Bourguignon was van Zwitserse oorsprong en een neef van de gebroeders Meuricoffre. Hij was vennoot van hun bank en handelskantoor in o.a. levensmiddelen (olie, graan) en hennep, de Ditta Meuricoffre & C. Voor deze onderneming was Bourguignon het hoofd van de boekhouding. Onder het consultaat-generaal van Tell Meuricoffre was Bourguignon vice-consul. Hij was eveneens een verzamelaar van en handelaar in oudheden en corresponderend lid was van het Instituto di Corrispondenza Archeologica in Rome, het latere Deutsches Archäologisches Institut. Zijn archeologische bemoeienissen blijken bijvoorbeeld uit de brieven van enkele van de beroemdste Duitse archeologen van zijn tijd, onder wie Heinrich Schliemann. Bourguignon verzamelde en verkocht onder meer vazen (uit o.a. Orvieto), glaswerk (bv. uit Cumae) en terracottareliëfs en ornamenten uit de necropool van Santa Maria Capua Vetere, objecten die vervolgens niet zelden werden beschreven in vooral Duitse archeologische tijdschriften, zoal het Jahrbuch van het Instituto en het Rheinisches Museum für Philologie. Aan het begin van de twintigste eeuw raakte hij in geldnood. Na de dood van Tell Meuricoffre werd B. beschuldigd van financiële malversaties en fraude met de boekhouding van de bank Meuricoffre. Om zijn schuld te kunnen inlossen werd een groot deel van B.'s collectie in 1901 in Parijs geveild, maar hij hield problemen tot aan zijn dood in september 1904. Vermoedelijk behield hij tot die tijd zijn functie als de Nederlandse vice-consul (zijn naam duikt in de Almanach de Gotha van 1907 nog steeds op als de Nederlandse vice-consul). Het restant van zijn collectie kwam in 1907 terecht in het Historische Museum van Frankfurt am Main, later het Archäoligisches Museum en het Liebighaus.

$Bouteneff.en_GB: Apollinary Petrovič Bouteneff (also called Butenev, Buteniev, Butenyov, in Cyrillic Бутенев) was born in the Russian village of Gridenki near present-day Belarus and Ukraine, the son of the large landowner Pyotr Semyonovič B. (1751-1817). In 1802 he moved to St Petersburg, where from 1804 he worked at the Foreign Ministry, first as a translator, then as secretary to Deputy Minister A.N. Saltykov. The latter placed him in the department for Eastern and Southern Europe in 1810. During the war with Napoleon, he worked for General Pyotr Bagration's diplomatic service until the Battle of Borodino (1812). From 1816-1821, Bouteneff was secretary at the Russian embassy in Constantinople. During the Russo-Turkish War of 1828-1829, he headed the secretariat of Karl Count von Nesselrode, the Russian foreign minister, after which he was appointed chargée d'affaires in Constantinople. A year later, he was promoted ambassador to the 'Sublime Porte' (the Ottoman court), a post he held until 1843. During this period, he was an absolute key figure in Russian diplomacy. He contributed to stable Turkish-Russian relations, most notably through his role in bringing about the Treaty of Hünkâr İskelesi (1833), which indirectly resulted from Russian military support to the Ottomans against Muhammed Ali Pasha of Egypt, thus sidelining the Western powers. Among other things, it earned him an appointment as private counsel to Tsar Nicholas I. In 1843, Bouteneff was appointed envoy to the Holy See, a position he held until 1855. In Rome, he played an important role in the complicated relations between the Holy See and Russia. In previous years, Tsar Nicholas I had increasingly restricted the liberties of Catholics in Poland and Russia, by openly pursuing the conversion of Eastern Catholics to the Russian Orthodox Church, restricting the permitted number of regular Catholic clergy and secularising Catholic properties. Pope Gregory XVI's futile opposition to this had culminated in the allocution Haerentem diu (22 July 1842). In response, the tsar wanted to increase repression of Catholics, but his minister Nesselrode insisted on a policy of détente. As part of this policy, was the experienced and moderate Bouteneff was appointed as envoy to Rome. Through B.'s efforts, Nicholas I's visit to Rome on 13 December 1845 took place, after which a phase of negotiations between the two powers began. Relations however remained troubled. On the papal side, Cardinal L. Lambruschini acted as head of delegation even after the election of pope Pius IX; Russia was represented by former interior minister Dmitry Bludov and Bouteneff. Finally, a provisional concordat was signed on 3 August 1847. It meant only a partial agreement, which soon proved fragile in the years to come, especially as Slavophile influences grew in Russia from the 1860s onwards. Nevertheless, for the first time since the early 18th century, there was a clear break in Russian policy towards 'Rome', which until then had been characterised by unilateralism. Working relations between B. And the Papal court were probably good, as he followed the pope to Gaeta during the Roman Republic of 1849. Bouteneff remained in Rome until 1855. In 1856, after the end of the Crimean War, he was again sent to Constantinople, where as council of state he successfully restored diplomatic relations with Turkey. Later in life, he became almost completely blind and deaf. He travelled through Western Europe to take cures and died of a stroke on 18 April 1866 in Paris, where he was buried in the Montmartre cemetery. His daughter Aleksandrina (1825-1851) passed away during the family's sojourn in Rome. Her gravestone can still be seen there in the wall of the Protestant cemetery of Pyramide, although her remains were repatriated a year after her demise.
