In seguito partecipò all'intervento francese che pose fine alla rivolta liberale e alla guerra civile in Spagna nel 1823 e, nel 1832, con l'Armée du Nord, all'assedio della cittadella di Anversa, costringendo l'esercito olandese alla ritirata. Nel 1849 venne nominato comandante superiore di tutte le truppe. Nel 1852 divenne senatore. Morì a Sens nel 1868.
$Gemeau.nl_NL: Auguste Pierre Walbourg Gemeau werd in 1790 in Parijs geboren. Na de militaire school aldaar te hebben doorlopen maakte hij een snelle carrière in het leger door. Hij nam deel aan Napoleons veldtochten in Duitsland (1809), Spanje (1810-1812) en diende in het Grande Armée tijdens de invasie van Rusland. Later nam hij deel aan de Franse interventie die in 1823 een einde maakte aan de liberale opstand en burgeroorlog in Spanje, en 1832 met het Armée du Nord aan de belegering van de citadel van Antwerpen, waardoor het Nederlandse leger zich moest terugtrekken. In 1849 werd hij benoemd tot opperbevelhebber van alle Franse troepen. In 1852 werd hij senator. Hij stierf in Sens in 1868.

$Gerra.en_GB: Luigi Gerra was born in Compiano (Parma) in 1829. In 1849 he graduated in Law and in 1859 obtained the chair of Civil Law at the University of Parma. Of liberal ideas, he became secretary of the provisional government of the provinces of Parma in 1859. In 1861 he was appointed deputy attorney-general of the Italian king at the Court of Appeal in Bologna and in 1862 he joined the Council of State. An appointment as Prefect of Ascoli Piceno followed in 1865. A year later, he was transferred to the Prefecture of Salerno. In 1868 he was entrusted with the role of Secretary General of the Ministry of the Interior and was elected deputy. When Rome was taken by the army of the Kingdom of Italy in September 1870, Gerra joined General Cadorna in directing the public administration of the new capital. In 1873, he was again Secretary General at the Ministry of the Interior; in 1875, he was sent to Palermo as Prefect. He abandoned his political career in 1876 and died in Rome on 31 July 1882.
$Gerra.it_IT: Luigi Gerra nacque a Compiano (Parma) nel 1829. Nel 1849 si laureò in Legge e dal 1859 ottenne all'Università di Parma la cattedra di Codice civile. Di idee liberali, nel 1859, divenne segretario del governo provvisorio delle province parmensi. Nel 1861 fu nominato come sostituto procuratore generale del re presso la Corte d'Appello di Bologna ed entrò nel 1862 nel Consiglio di Stato. Nel 1865 fu nominato prefetto di Ascoli Piceno. Nel 1866 fu trasferito alla Prefettura di Salerno. Nel 1868 gli venne affidato il ruolo di Segretario generale del Ministero dell'Interno e fu eletto deputato. Dopo la presa di Roma, nel 1870, affiancò il generale Cadorna alla direzione dell'amministrazione pubblica della Capitale. Nel 1873 fu nuovamente segretario generale del Ministero dell'Interno. Nel 1875 venne inviato come Prefetto a Palermo. Abbandonata la carriera politica fin dal 1876, morì a Roma il 31 luglio 1882.
$Gerra.nl_NL: Luigi Gerra werd in 1829 geboren in Compiano (Parma). In 1849 studeerde hij af in de Rechten en vanaf 1859 bekleedde hij de leerstoel Burgerlijk Recht aan de universiteit van Parma. Hij koesterde liberale ideeën en werd in 1859 secretaris van de voorlopige regering van de provincies Parma. In 1861 werd hij benoemd tot plaatsvervangend procureur-generaal van de Italiaanse koning bij het Hof van Beroep in Bologna en in 1862 werd hij lid van de Raad van State. Een benoeming tot prefect van Ascoli Piceno volgde in 1865. Een jaar later werd hij overgeplaatst naar de prefectuur van Salerno. In 1868 kreeg hij de functie van secretaris-generaal van het Ministerie van Binnenlandse Zaken en werd hij tot afgevaardigde gekozen. Na de inname van Rome door de troepen van het Koninkrijk Italië in september 1870 gaf Gerra samen met generaal Cadorna leiding aan het openbaar bestuur van de nieuwe hoofdstad. In 1873 was hij opnieuw secretaris-generaal aan het Ministerie van Binnenlandse Zaken; in 1875 werd hij als prefect naar Palermo gestuurd. Hij gaf zijn politieke carrière op in 1876 en stierf in Rome op 31 juli 1882.

$Geuns.en_GB: Albert van Geuns was a Dutch banker, merchant and shipowner. He was born in Amsterdam in 1806 to a family of Mennonites, many of whose exponents were pastors, lawyers, doctors or merchants. He initially founded the firm Schmöle & Van Geuns, which Gulian Nolthenius later joined as partner, and still later Johannes Luden. The firm of Luden & Van Geuns held offices on Amsterdam's Keizersgracht near the Leidsestraat. Their activities as bankers lasted at least until the early 1870s; the firm is documented from at least 1836, when they bought their first of a total of seven (documented) sailing ships for long-haul trade. From 1859 to 1877, Van Goens was also a member of the Provincial States of North Holland on behalf of Amsterdam. On 17 June 1864, he was appointed Royal Commissioner at the Nederlandsche Bank by royal decree.
$Geuns.it_IT: Albert van Geuns fu un banchiere, commerciante e armatore olandese. Nacque ad Amsterdam nel 1806 da una famiglia di mennoniti, di cui molti esponenti erano pastori, avvocati, medici o commercianti. Fondò inizialmente la ditta Schmöle & Van Geuns, alla quale poi si unirono come soci Gulian Nolthenius e successivamente Johannes Luden. Lo studio Luden & Van Geuns aveva uffici sul Keizersgracht di Amsterdam, vicino alla Leidsestraat. La loro attività di banchieri durò almeno fino all'inizio degli anni settanta dell'Ottocento; l'azienda è documentata fin dal 1836, quando acquistarono la prima di un totale di sette velieri (documentati) per il commercio a lungo raggio. Dal 1859 al 1877 Van Goens fu anche membro degli Stati provinciali dell'Olanda Settentrionale per conto di Amsterdam. Il 17 giugno 1864 fu nominato con decreto reale commissario reale presso la Nederlandsche Bank.
$Geuns.nl_NL: Albert van Geuns was een Nederlandse bankier, koopman en reder. Hij werd in 1806 in Amsterdam geboren in een familie van Mennonieten, waarvan veel exponenten dominee, jurist, arts of koopman waren. Hij richtte aanvankelijk de firma Schmöle & Van Geuns op, waartoe later Gulian Nolthenius toetrad, en nog later Johannes Luden. De firma Luden & Van Geuns hield kantoor aan de Amsterdamse Keizersgracht ter hoogte van de Leidsestraat. Hun activiteiten als bankiers duurden ten minste tot begin jaren 1870; de firma is vanaf tenminste 1836 gedocumenteerd, toen ze hun eerste van in totaal 7 gedocumenteerde zeilschepen voor de grote vaart kochten. Van 1859 tot 1877 was Van Goens ook lid van de Provinciale Staten van Noord-Holland namens Amsterdam. Op 17 juni 1864 werd hij per Koninklijk Besluit benoemd tot Koninklijk Commissaris bij de Nederlandsche Bank.

$Gevers.en_GB: Daniël Theodoor Gevers van de Endegeest was a Dutch lawyer and politician, born in Rotterdam. In 1819, after finishing his study in Law, he travelled to Italy, a country to which he soon developed a life-long attachment. Upon his return to the Netherlands, he worked as senior officer at the department of Foreign Affairs, until he was elected to the Dutch House of Representatives, where he would represent various constituencies for twenty years (1838-1858, with a short interlude in 1849-1850, when he was elected to the Senate). From in 1842 to 1855 he also served as chairman of the House. In the cabinet Van der Brugghen, he was minister of Foreign Affairs from 1856 to 1858. After the fall of this cabinet, he governed the Dutch water authority (Hoogheemraadschap) in de Rijnland region, served as a board member of the University of Leiden and dedicated himself to the administration of his estates (Endegeest and later Oegstgeest and Poelgeest). Gevers van de Endegeest was a conservative and supported the governmental principles put forward by the Dutch king Willem I, which is why he struggled to come to terms with the changes brought on by the year 1848.
$Gevers.it_IT: Daniël Theodoor Gevers van de Endegeest fu un avvocato e politico olandese, nato a Rotterdam. Nel 1819, dopo aver terminato gli studi in Giurisprudenza, si recò in Italia, paese con il quale si creò presto un legame che durò tutta la vita. Al suo ritorno nei Paesi Bassi, lavorò come alto funzionario presso il dipartimento degli Affari esteri, finché fu eletto alla Camera dei rappresentanti olandese, dove rappresentò varie circoscrizioni elettorali per vent'anni (1838-1858, con una breve parentesi nel 1849 -1850, quando fu eletto al Senato). Dal 1842 al 1855 fu anche presidente della Camera. Nel gabinetto Van der Brugghen fu ministro degli Affari esteri dal 1856 al 1858. Dopo la caduta di questo gabinetto, governò l'autorità olandese per l'acqua (Hoogheemraadschap) nella regione del Rijnland, fu membro del consiglio dell'Università di Leida e si dedicò all'amministrazione dei suoi possedimenti (Endegeest e successivamente Oegstgeest e Poelgeest). Gevers van de Endegeest era un conservatore e sosteneva i principi governativi proposti dal re olandese Guglielmo I, motivo per cui lottò per modificare i cambiamenti introdotti nel 1848.
$Gevers.nl_NL: Daniël Theodoor Gevers van de Endegeest was een Nederlands advocaat en politicus, geboren in Rotterdam. In 1819, na het afronden van zijn studie Rechten, reisde hij naar Italië, een land waaraan hij erg gehecht raakte. Na zijn terugkeer in Nederland werd hij hoofdambtenaar bij Buitenlandse Zaken, waarna hij tussen 1838 en 1858 gedurende twintig jaar vrijwel onafgebroken lid was van de Tweede Kamer (behalve in 1849-1850, toen hij een zetel kreeg in de Eerste Kamer). Tussen 1842 en 1855 fungeerde hij in de Tweede Kamer ook als voorzitter. Van 1856 tot 1858 was hij vervolgens minister van Buitenlandse Zaken in het kabinet-Van der Brugghen. Na de val van deze regering trok hij zich terug uit de politiek en richtte hij zich op het waterschap Rijnland, het curatorium van de Leidse Hogeschool en het beheer van zijn landgoederen (Endegeest en later Oegstgeest en Poelgeest). Gevers was een conservatief politicus en aanhanger van de regeringsbeginselen van koning Willem I; hij had dan ook moeite zich te verzoenen met de veranderingen die het jaar 1848 met zich meebracht.

$Gioberti.en_GB: Vincenzo Gioberti was a catholic-liberal theologist, philosopher, writer and patriot. From 1833 onwards, he spent years in exile in Brussels and in Paris, where he wrote some of his most important work. In Del primato civile e morale degli italiani (1843), he formed the so-called Neo-Guelphist ideology, which maintained the pope should be the natural leader of an Italian confederacy that was to be instated. In his Gesuita moderno (1846-1848), he criticised abuses in the Church and the growing influence of the Jesuits, which landed the book on the Index of forbidden books. In 1848, Gioberti returned to Italy to urge the revolutionaries to political moderation. In Turin, he became chairman of the House of Representatives of the Kingdom of Sardinia, and from December 1848 to February 1849, president of the Council of Ministers. When king Carlo Alberto left the political arena shortly afterwards, Gioberti was also forced to retreat. He spent several months as ambassador in Paris before he abandoned public life and devoted himself to writing (Del rinnovamento civile d'Italia, 1851).
$Gioberti.it_IT: Vincenzo Gioberti fu un teologo, filosofo, scrittore e patriota cattolico-liberale. Dal 1833 passò anni in esilio a Bruxelles e a Parigi, dove scrisse alcune delle sue opere più importanti. Nel “Del primato civile e morale degli italiani” (1843), egli formulò la cosiddetta ideologia neoguelfa, che sosteneva che il papa dovesse essere il leader naturale di una confederazione italiana che si stava instaurando. Nel suo “Gesuita moderno” (1846-1848) criticò gli abusi nella Chiesa e la crescente influenza dei gesuiti, che inserirono il libro nell'Indice dei libri proibiti. Nel 1848 Gioberti tornò in Italia per esortare i rivoluzionari ad una posizione politica più moderata. A Torino divenne presidente della Camera dei Rappresentanti del Regno di Sardegna e, dal dicembre 1848 al febbraio 1849, presidente del Consiglio dei ministri. Quando, poco dopo, il re Carlo Alberto lasciò la scena politica, anche Gioberti fu costretto a ritirarsi. Trascorse diversi mesi come ambasciatore a Parigi prima di abbandonare la vita pubblica e dedicarsi alla scrittura (“Del rinnovamento civile d'Italia”, 1851).
$Gioberti.nl_NL: Vincenzo Gioberti was een katholiek-liberale theoloog, filosoof, schrijver en patriot. Vanaf 1833 verbleef hij jarenlang in ballingschap in Brussel en Parijs, waar hij ook zijn belangrijkste werken schreef. In Del primato civile e morale degli italiani (1843) lanceerde hij de zogenaamde neowelfische ideologie, waarin werd bepleit dat de paus de natuurlijke leider van een nieuw te vormen Italiaanse statenbond diende te zijn. In zijn Gesuita moderno (1846-1848) trok hij van leer tegen misstanden in de kerk en tegen de groeiende invloed van de jezuïeten, waarna het boek op de Index van verboden boeken kwam te staan. In 1848 keerde Gioberti naar Italië terug en maande hij de revolutionairen tot gematigdheid. In Turijn werd hij parlementsvoorzitter van het Koninkrijk Sardinië-Piemonte en van december 1848 tot februari 1849 voorzitter van de ministerraad. Toen koning Carlo Alberto even later van het toneel verdween, moest ook Gioberti het veld ruimen. Hij sleet enkele maanden als ambassadeur in Parijs en wijdde zich daarna aan het schrijverschap (Del rinnovamento civile d'Italia, 1851).

$Girardin.en_GB: Émile Girardin, the 'Napoléon of the press', is often considered as one of the forefathers of modern day media. In 1828, he founded the magazine Le Vouleur, in 1829 La Mode and in 1836 the journal La Presse. The latter is still one of the two largest newspapers in France. With La Presse, Girardin introduced a new concept: by raising funds through paid advertisements, he was able to offer the paper at a strongly reduced price. This was such a success that Armand Carrel, editor the rivalling newspaper National, felt so threatened he challenged Girardin to a duel. Carrel did not survive (22 July 1836). Later, Girardin became editor of the popular newspaper Le Petit Journal and of La France. In 1878, Girardin chaired the committee which prepared the French Law on the Freedom of Press (29 July 1881).
$Girardin.it_IT: Émile Girardin, il “Napoléon della stampa”, è stato spesso considerato uno degli antenati dei media moderni. Nel 1828 fondò la rivista “Le Vouleur”, nel 1829 “La Mode” e nel 1836 la rivista “La Presse”. Quest'ultima è ancora uno dei due giornali più diffusi della Francia. Con “La Presse”, Girardin introdusse un nuovo metodo: raccogliendo fondi attraverso inserzioni a pagamento, poteva proporre il giornale a un prezzo fortemente ridotto. Il successo fu tale che Armand Carrel, direttore del giornale rivale “National”, si sentì così minacciato che sfidò Girardin a duello. Carrel non sopravvisse (22 luglio 1836). Più tardi, Girardin divenne redattore del popolare quotidiano “Le Petit Journal” e di “La France”. Nel 1878 Girardin presiedette il comitato che preparò la legge francese sulla libertà di stampa (29 luglio 1881).
$Girardin.nl_NL: Émile Girardin, de 'Napoléon van de pers', staat bekend als een van de voorvaderen van de moderne media. In 1828 richtte hij het tijdschrift Le Vouleur op, in 1829 La Mode en in 1836 de krant La Presse. De laatste is nog steeds een van de twee grootste dagbladen van Frankrijk. Met La Presse kwam Girardin met een nieuw concept: hij kon de krant aanbieden voor een sterk gereduceerde prijs, door de benodigde gelden op te halen met betaalde advertenties. Dieze werkwijze was zo succesvol dat ze hem op een duel kwam te staan met Armand Carrel, hoofdredacteur van het concurrerende blad National. Carrel overleefde de confrontatie niet (22 juli 1836). Girardin werd later redacteur van de populaire krant Le Petit Journal en van La France. In 1878 was Girardin voorzitter van de commissie die de Franse Wet op persvrijheid van 29 juli 1881 voorbereidde.

$Girometti.en_GB: Giuseppe Girometti was born in Rome in 1780 to Clementina Patrizi and Lorenzo Girometti. He learned drawing and sculpture at the San Michele Institute and later entered the studio of the sculptor Vincenzo Pacetti, and he won four prizes in sculpture at the Accademia di S. Luca (1795, 1796, 1799, 1801). He then executed works for religious and private commissioners. With great success he devoted himself to engraving in (semi-precious) hardstones, mainly cameos, and to numismatic art, in which he was one of the protagonists of his time. In 1820 he became a member of the Academy of Fine Arts in Florence. In 1822, he was appointed engraver at the Papal Mint, where he executed the medal commissioned by President Massimiliano Laboureur on behalf of the Accademia di S. Luca, to be issued on the occasion of the funeral of Antonio Canova, celebrated in Rome in 1823. Girometti's production of numismatic art, much appreciated at an international level, was very prolific: he executed medals for Popes Pius VII, Leo XII, Pius VIII, Gregory XVI and Pius IX, as well as for numerous private commissioners and public institutions. His production in semi-precious (hard)stones was also rich, and consisted almost exclusively of large cameos, with mythological subjects or portraits. Girometti received numerous recognitions: in 1826, he became a member of the Royal Academy of Antwerp; in 1831, of the Congregazione dei Vistuosi al Pantheon. He was appointed as honorary member to the academies of Berlin (1833), Bologna (1837), and Perugia (1842). In 1847, during the pontificate of Pius IX, he was a member of the Capitoline Council for the administration of the city of Rome. He died in 1851 and was buried in the church of S. Maria del Popolo, where his son Pietro had a monument erected for him. His works are now in the collections of many major international museums.
$Girometti.it_IT: Giuseppe Girometti nacque a Roma nel 1780 da Clementina Patrizi e da Lorenzo Girometti. Apprese le prime nozioni di disegno e scultura presso l'Istituto di San Michele e successivamente entrò nello studio dello scultore Vincenzo Pacetti. Vinse quattro premi in scultura presso l'Accademia di S. Luca (1795, 1796, 1799, 1801). Eseguì quindi opere per committenze religiose e private. Si dedicò con grande successo all'incisione in pietre dure, prevalentemente cammei, e alla medaglistica nella quale fu uno fra i grandi protagonisti del suo tempo. Nel 1820 divenne socio dell'Accademia di belle arti di Firenze. Nel 1822 fu nominato incisore camerale presso la Zecca pontificia e eseguì su incarico del presidente Massimiliano Laboureur la medaglia dell'Accademia di S. Luca da distribuirsi in occasione delle solenni onoranze funebri di Antonio Canova celebrate a Roma nel 1823. La sua produzione medaglistica, molto apprezzata a livello internazionale, fu molto prolifica: eseguì medaglie per i pontefici Pio VII, Leone XII, Pio VIII, Gregorio XVI e Pio IX, oltre a quelle per numerose committenze private e pubbliche istituzioni. Ricchissima fu anche la produzione in pietre dure, quasi esclusivamente grandi cammei, con soggetti mitologici o con ritratti. Girometti ebbe numerosi riconoscimenti: nel 1826 divenne socio della R. Accademia di Anversa; nel 1831, membro della Congregazione dei Virtuosi al Pantheon; nel 1833, socio onorario dell'Accademia di Berlino; nel 1837, di quella di Bologna; nel 1842, di quella di Perugia. Nel 1847, durante il pontificato di Pio IX, fu tra i consiglieri della Consulta capitolina per l'amministrazione. Morì a Roma nel 1851 e fu sepolto in S. Maria del Popolo dove il figlio Pietro gli fece erigere un monumento. Sue opere sono oggi presenti nelle collezioni molti grandi musei internazionali.
$Girometti.nl_NL: Giuseppe Girometti werd in 1780 in Rome geboren als zoon van Clementina Patrizi en Lorenzo Girometti. Hij leerde tekenen en beeldhouwen aan het San Michele Instituut en ging later werken in het atelier van beeldhouwer Vincenzo Pacetti. Hij won vier prijzen in de beeldhouwkunst aan de Accademia di S. Luca (1795, 1796, 1799, 1801). Daarna werkte hij voor verschillende opdrachtgevers, binnen de kerk en daarbuiten. Met veel succes wijdde hij zich aan het graveren van (halfedele) hardsteen, voornamelijk cameeën, en aan de penningkunst, waarvan hij een van de belangrijkste exponenten van zijn tijd was. In 1820 werd hij lid van de Academie voor Schone Kunsten in Florence; een jaar later werd hij benoemd tot kamergraveur bij de Pauselijke Munt. Ook maakte hij in opdracht van president Massimiliano Laboureur van de Accademia di S. Luca de medaille die werd uitgegeven ter gelegenheid van de begrafenis van Antonio Canova in 1823. Zijn productie van medailles, internationaal zeer gewaardeerd, was indrukwekkend: hij maakte ze voor de pausen Pius VII, Leo XII, Pius VIII, Gregorius XVI en Pius IX, maar ook voor talrijke particuliere opdrachtgevers en openbare instellingen. Zijn productie in halfedelstenen was ook zeer rijk en bestond bijna uitsluitend uit grote cameeën met mythologische onderwerpen of portretten. Girometti ontving talrijke onderscheidingen: in 1826 werd hij lid van de Koninklijke Academie van Antwerpen; in 1831 van de Congregazione dei Virtuosi al Pantheon; in 1833 erelid van de Academie van Berlijn; in 1837 van die van Bologna; in 1842 van die van Perugia. Onder het pontificaat van Pius IX was hij in 1847 een van raadsheren van de Consulta Capitolina van de stad Rome. Hij stierf in 1851 in Rome en werd begraven in S. Maria del Popolo, waar zijn zoon Pietro een monument voor hem liet oprichten. Zijn werken bevinden zich nu in de collecties van vele grote internationale musea.

$Gizzi.en_GB: Tommaso Pasquale Gizzi was cardinal Secretary of State under pope Pius IX from 8 August 1846 until 5 July 1847. He was popular because of his reputation as a reformer, partly due to the appraisal he received from the prominent liberal Massimo D'Azeglio in Degli ultimi casi di Romagna (1846). Gizzi's appointment as Secretary of State by pope Pius IX (8 August 1846) contributed to the idea that the new pope was a liberal. On 17 July 1848 however, Gizzi resigned, in the aftermath of the allocution of Pius IX of 29 April 1848, in which the pope withdrew from the First Italian War of Independence against Austria. Nevertheless, Gizzi remained somehow involved in the politics of the Papal States, as he followed the pope from Rome to his exile in Gaeta at the end of 1848. Not much later, Gizzi retreated to the town of Lenola in the hinterland of Gaeta, where he died in 1849.
$Gizzi.it_IT: Tommaso Pasquale Gizzi fu cardinale segretario di Stato sotto papa Pio IX dall'8 agosto 1846 al 5 luglio 1847. Fu popolare per la sua fama di riformatore, anche per l'apprezzamento che ricevette dal noto liberale Massimo d'Azeglio in “Degli ultimi casi di Romagna” (1846). La nomina di Gizzi a Segretario di Stato da parte di papa Pio IX (8 agosto 1846) contribuì a far credere che il nuovo papa fosse un liberale. Il 17 luglio 1848 Gizzi si dimise però, all'indomani dell'allocuzione di Pio IX del 29 aprile 1848, con la quale il papa si ritirava dalla Prima Guerra d'Indipendenza italiana contro l'Austria. Ciononostante Gizzi rimase in qualche modo coinvolto nella politica dello Stato Pontificio, poiché seguì il papa da Roma fino al suo esilio a Gaeta alla fine del 1848. Non molto tempo dopo, Gizzi si ritirò nella città di Lenola, nell'entroterra di Gaeta, dove morì nel 1849.
$Gizzi.nl_NL: Tommaso Pasquale Gizzi was kardinaal-staatssecretaris onder paus Pius IX van 8 augustus 1846 tot 5 juli 1847. Hij was populair vanwege zijn reputatie als hervormer, die onder andere te danken was aan de loftuitingen door de prominente liberaal Massimo D'Azeglio in Degli ultimi casi di Romagna (1846). De benoeming tot staatssecretaris van de 'liberaal' Gizzi door Pius IX droeg bij aan de indruk dat ook de nieuwe paus een liberaal was. Op 17 juli 1848 trad Gizzi echter alweer af, in de nasleep van de allocutie van Pius IX van 29 april, waarmee de paus zich had teruggetrokken uit de Eerste Italiaanse Onafhankelijkheidsoorlog tegen Oostenrijk. Toch bleef Gizzi nog deels betrokken bij de politiek van de Pauselijke Staat, en volgde hij de paus ook toen deze eind 1848 uit Rome naar Gaeta vluchtte. Vervolgens trok G. zich terug in Lenola in het achterland van Gaeta, waar hij in 1849 overleed.

$Godefroi.en_GB: Michel Henry Godefroi was a prominent lawyer, liberal and Minister of Justice in the cabinet Van Zuylen van Nijevelt/Van Heemstra (1861-1862). He was also the first Jewish minister in the Netherlands. From 1849 until his death in 1881, he served almost without interruption as  a member of parliament. Furthermore, he acted as president of the General Committee for Israelite Affairs, and in that capacity in 1859 he appealed to the Dutch Minister of Foreign Affairs, baron Jan Karel van Goltstein, and to the ambassador in Rome, count Louis du Chastel, to protest against the decision taken by pope Pius IX to take away a child in Bologna from its parents after it had been baptized by a maidservant (the so-called Mortara affair). Godefroi also played a role in several important administrative and judicial reforms in the Netherlands, including the adoption of a new Law for the Council of State (1861) and of the Dutch Criminal Code (1881). After 1870, he was frequently absent due to the illness of his wife, although he stayed involved in politics until his death.
$Godefroi.it_IT: Michel Henry Godefroi fu un importante avvocato, liberale e ministro della Giustizia nel gabinetto Van Zuylen van Nijevelt/Van Heemstra (1861-1862). Fu anche il primo ministro ebreo nei Paesi Bassi. Dal 1849 fino alla sua morte nel 1881 prestò servizio quasi ininterrottamente come membro del parlamento. Inoltre, fu presidente del Comitato generale per gli affari israeliti, e in tale veste nel 1859 fece appello al ministro degli affari esteri olandese, barone Jan Karel van Goltstein, e all'ambasciatore a Roma, conte Louis du Chastel, per protestare contro la decisione presa da papa Pio IX di togliere ai genitori a Bologna un bambino dopo che era stato battezzato da una servitrice (affare Mortara). Godefroi svolse anche un ruolo importante in diverse riforme amministrative e giudiziarie nei Paesi Bassi, inclusa quella per l'adozione di una nuova legge per il Consiglio di Stato (1861) e del codice penale olandese (1881). Dopo il 1870 fu spesso assente a causa della malattia della moglie, ma rimase impegnato nella politica fino alla morte.
$Godefroi.nl_NL: Michel Henry Godefroi was een vooraanstaand advocaat, liberaal en minister van Justitie in het kabinet-van Zuylen van Nijevelt/Van Heemstra (1861-1862). Ook was hij de eerste Joodse minister van Nederland. Van 1849 tot zijn dood in 1881 was hij bijna onafgebroken lid van de Tweede Kamer. Daarnaast was hij president van de Hoofdcommissie tot de Zaken der Israëlieten. In deze hoedanigheid deed hij in 1857 beroep op o.a. de Nederlandse minister van Buitenlandse Zaken, baron Jan Karel van Goltstein, en graaf Louis du Chastel, ambassadeur te Rome, om protest aan te tekenen tegen het besluit van paus Pius IX om een kind uit Bologna bij zijn Joodse ouders weg te halen, nadat het door de dienstmeid gedoopt was (de zogenaamde Mortara-affaire). Godefroi was betrokken bij enkele belangrijke bestuursrechtelijke hervormingen in Nederland, waaronder de totstandkoming van de Wet op de Raad van State (1861) en van het Wetboek van Strafrecht (1880). Hij was na 1870 veel afwezig vanwege de ziekte van zijn vrouw, maar bleef desondanks tot zijn dood betrokken bij de politiek.

$Goes.en_GB: Louis Napoleon van der Goes van Dirxland was a Dutch court dignitary and conservative politician. His father Maarten was Minister of Foreign Affairs from 1806-1808 under King Louis Napoleon, after whom he named his son. From 1841 Van der Goes was chamberlain to Prince Frederick of the Netherlands, second son of King Willem I, from 1848-1850 member of the Provincial States of Holland on behalf of the Knightage, member of the Supreme Council of the Nobility and the Agricultural Society. Out of the blue, in January 1861 prime minister Van Hall approached him to succeed Van Zuylen van Nijevelt as Minister of Foreign Affairs. Van der Goes hesitated but eventually yielded. During his short ministry (14 January 1861-14 March 1861) he never addressed parliament and was treated with derision by the liberals. Among his duties was the tricky task to disprove the circular his predecessor had sent to all Dutch missions shortly before his resignation, stating that government had lost its credibility. When, eventually, the cabinet collapsed after Van Hall had stepped down and dissension had arisen over the colonial policy, Van der Goes took up his office as court dignitary again. He successively served as grandmaster and chamberlain in extraordinary service (1861-1875), and treasurer and chief cup-bearer (1875-1881) to King Willem III.
$Goes.it_IT: Louis Napoleon van der Goes van Dirxland fu un dignitario della corte olandese e politico conservatore. Suo padre Maarten fu ministro degli Affari esteri dal 1806 al 1808 sotto il re Luigi Napoleone, da cui prese il nome suo figlio. Dal 1841 Van der Goes fu ciambellano del principe Federico dei Paesi Bassi, secondo figlio del re Guglielmo I, dal 1848 al 1850 membro degli Stati provinciali d'Olanda per conto del Cavalierato, membro del Consiglio supremo della nobiltà e della Società agricola . All'improvviso, nel gennaio 1861, il primo ministro Van Hall gli si avvicinò per succedere a Van Zuylen van Nijevelt come ministro degli Affari esteri. Van der Goes esitò ma alla fine cedette. Durante il suo breve ministero (14 gennaio 1861-14 marzo 1861) non si rivolse mai al Parlamento e fu trattato con disprezzo dai liberali. Tra i suoi compiti c'era quello di confutare la circolare che il suo predecessore aveva inviato a tutte le missioni olandesi poco prima delle sue dimissioni, affermando che il governo aveva perso credibilità. Quando, alla fine, il governo crollò dopo che Van Hall si era dimesso e si era verificato un dissenso sulla politica coloniale, Van der Goes riprese il suo incarico di dignitario di corte. Successivamente prestò servizio come gran maestro e ciambellano in servizio straordinario (1861-1875), tesoriere e capo coppiere (1875-1881) del re Guglielmo III.
$Goes.nl_NL: Louis Napoleon van der Goes van Dirxland was een Nederlandse hofdignitaris en conservatief politicus. Zijn vader Maarten was van 1806-1808 minister van Buitenlandse Zaken onder koning Lodewijk Napoleon, naar wie hij zijn zoon vernoemde. Van der Goes was vanaf 1841 kamerheer van prins Frederik der Nederlanden en van 1848-1850 namens de Ridderschap lid van de provinciale staten van Holland, lid van de hoge raad van adel en van de maatschappij van landbouw. Uit het niets vroeg minister-president Van Hall hem in januari 1861 om de vertrokken Van Zuylen van Nijevelt op te volgen als minister van Buitenlandse Zaken. Van der Goes aarzelde over zijn geschiktheid, maar liet zich overhalen. Tijdens zijn korte ministerschap (14 januari 1861 tot 14 maart 1861) sprak hij nooit in de Staten-Generaal en was de hoon van de liberalen zijn deel. Hij kreeg de netelige taak om een circulaire te ontzenuwen waarmee zijn voorganger vlak voor diens aftreden alle gezantschappen had geschreven dat de regering haar geloofwaardigheid had verloren. Toen uiteindelijke het kabinet viel door het terugtreden van Van Hall en onenigheid over het koloniale beleid, nam Van der Goes zijn ambt van hofdignitaris weer op en diende achtereenvolgens als grootmeester en kamerheer in buitengewone dienst (1861-1875), en thesaurier en opperschenker (1875-1881) van koning Willem III.

$Goltstein.en_GB: Baron Jan Karel van Goltstein was a Dutch jurist and minister, born in Arnhem. After finishing his degree in Law (1811), he settled as a lawyer in Utrecht. After the Battle of Waterloo (1815) he went to Paris with the Compagnie Vrijwillige Jagers der Utrechtsche Studenten ('Company of Voluntary Chasseurs of Utrecht Students'), after which he visited the foremost universities in Germany and travelled to Britain. Between 1840 and 1858, he represented the constituency of Utrecht in the Dutch Lower House; he was also curator at the Utrechtse Hoogeschool (1841-1859). From 12 March 1858 tot 23 February 1860 he served as minister of Foreign Affairs in the cabinet Rochussen-van Bosse. From 1860 to 1869, he returned to the Lower House as representative of the constituency of Amersfoort, and from 1870 until his death in 1872, he was a senator. Goltstein was a moderate liberal for part of his career, and argued in favor of public control over state finances, and independence of the judicial authority in Suriname. Over time, he became more conservative, especially during his ministry. Goltstein married Adolphine Warnardine, baronness of Pallandt (d. 1853).
$Goltstein.it_IT: Il barone Jan Karel van Goltstein fu un giurista e ministro olandese, nato ad Arnhem. Dopo aver conseguito la laurea in giurisprudenza (1811), si stabilì come avvocato a Utrecht. Dopo la battaglia di Waterloo (1815) andò a Parigi con la Compagnie Vrijwillige Jagers der Utrechtsche Studenten ('Compagnia di cacciatori volontari degli studenti di Utrecht'), successivamente visitò le principali università della Germania e viaggiò in Gran Bretagna. Tra il 1840 e il 1858 rappresentò il collegio elettorale di Utrecht nella Camera bassa olandese; si occupò anche della Utrechtse Hoogeschool (1841-1859). Dal 12 marzo 1858 al 23 febbraio 1860 prestò servizio come ministro degli Affari esteri nel gabinetto Rochussen-van Bosse. Dal 1860 al 1869 tornò alla Camera bassa come rappresentante del collegio elettorale di Amersfoort e dal 1870 fino alla sua morte nel 1872 fu senatore. Goltstein fu un liberale moderato per gran parte della sua carriera e si espresse a favore del controllo pubblico sulle finanze statali e dell'indipendenza dell'autorità giudiziaria in Suriname. Col tempo divenne più conservatore, soprattutto durante il suo ministero. Goltstein sposò Adolphine Warnardine, baronessa di Pallandt (morta nel 1853).
$Goltstein.nl_NL: Baron Jan Karel van Goltstein was een Nederlands jurist en minister, geboren te Arnhem. Na het afronden van zijn opleiding Rechten (1811) vestigde hij zich als advocaat in Utrecht. Na de Slag bij Waterloo (1815) trok hij naar Parijs met de Compagnie Vrijwillige Jagers der Utrechtsche Studenten, waarna hij ook de voornaamste universiteiten in Duitsland bezocht en naar Engeland reisde. Tussen 1840 en 1858 vertegenwoordigde hij Utrecht in de Tweede Kamer; daarnaast bekleedde hij de post van curator bij de Utrechtse Hoogeschool (1841-1859). Van 12 maart 1858 tot 23 februari 1860 was hij minister van Buitenlandse Zaken in het kabinet-Rochussen-van Bosse. Tussen 1860 en 1869 keerde hij terug naar de Tweede Kamer voor het district Amersfoort; van 1870 tot zijn dood was hij lid van de Eerste Kamer. Goltstein was lange tijd een gematigd liberaal, en pleitte onder andere voor meer publiek toezicht op de staatsfinanciën en de onafhankelijkheid van de rechterlijke macht in Suriname. Hij werd echter steeds conservatiever, met name tijdens zijn ministerschap. Goltstein trouwde met Adolphine Warnardine, barones van Pallandt (d. 1853).

$Gramont.en_GB: Antoine X Alfred Agénor, Count of Gramont and Guiche, Prince of Bidache, was a French diplomat and politician, originally from Paris. During the French Revolution of 1848, also called the February Revolution, he was a first lieutenant in a company of the Garde Nationale and defended the Notre-Dame and the Tuileries Palace, where King Louis Philippe ('the Citizen King' of the July Monarchy) resided. After the declaration of the Second French Republic, Antoine X left for England, where he married Emma Mac-Kinnon in December 1848. When President of the Republic Louis Napoleon Bonaparte (Napoleon III) staged a coup d'état (20-21 Dec 1851), putting an end to the Second French Republic, Antoine X embarked on a diplomatic career: he was successively ambassador at Hesse-Cassel (1851), Stuttgart (1852), Turin (1853), Rome (1857) and Vienna (1861). From May to August 1870, he was also foreign minister in the cabinet of Ollivier. His ministry was marked by his hostile attitude towards Prussia, something that may have contributed to the Emser Depesche of Prussian chancellor Otto von Bismarck. It was also Gramont who announced to the Senate, on 15 July 1870, that France had declared war on Prussia. Gramont's two brothers were both generals who were seriously wounded in the Franco-Prussian War (15 Jul 1870-28 Jan 1871); the war also marked the end of the Second French Empire. During his retirement, Gramont published several reflections on the policies he pursued during his ministry, particularly relating to the Franco-Prussian war. He also wrote under the pseudonym Andreas Memor.
$Gramont.it_IT: Antoine X Alfred Agénor, conte di Gramont e Guiche, principe di Bidache, è stato un diplomatico e politico francese, originario di Parigi. Durante la Rivoluzione francese del 1848, detta anche Rivoluzione di febbraio, fu primo luogotenente di una compagnia della Garde Nationale e difese Notre-Dame e il palazzo delle Tuileries, dove risiedeva il re Luigi Filippo (“il re cittadino” della Monarchia di luglio). Dopo la dichiarazione della Seconda Repubblica francese, Antoine X partì per l'Inghilterra, dove sposò Emma Mac-Kinnon nel dicembre 1848. Quando il Presidente della Repubblica Luigi Napoleone Bonaparte (Napoleone III) fece un colpo di Stato (20-21 dicembre 1851), ponendo fine alla Seconda Repubblica francese, Antoine X intraprese la carriera diplomatica: fu successivamente ambasciatore in Assia-Cassel (1851), Stoccarda (1852), Torino (1853), Roma (1857) e Vienna (1861). Dal maggio all'agosto 1870 fu anche ministro degli Esteri nel gabinetto di Ollivier. Il suo ministero si contraddistinse per l'atteggiamento ostile nei confronti della Prussia, cosa che potrebbe aver contribuito all'Emser Depesche del cancelliere prussiano Otto von Bismarck. Fu anche Gramont ad annunciare al Senato, il 15 luglio 1870, che la Francia aveva dichiarato guerra alla Prussia. I due fratelli di Gramont erano entrambi generali che furono gravemente feriti nella guerra franco-prussiana (15 luglio 1870-28 gennaio 1871); la guerra segnò anche la fine del Secondo Impero francese. Durante il suo ritiro, Gramont pubblicò diverse riflessioni sulle politiche perseguite durante il suo ministero, in particolare per quanto riguarda la guerra franco-prussiana. Scrisse anche con lo pseudonimo di Andreas Memor.
$Gramont.nl_NL: Antoine X Alfred Agénor, graaf van Gramont en Guiche, prins van Bidache, was een Frans diplomaat en politicus, afkomstig uit Parijs. Hij vocht tijdens de Franse Revolutie van 1848, ook wel de zgn. Februarirevolutie, als eerste luitenant in een compagnie van de Garde Nationale en verdedigde de Notre-Dame en het Tuilerieënpaleis, waar koning Lodewijk Filips (“de Burgerkoning” van de Julimonarchie) vertoefde. Nadat de Tweede Franse Republiek werd uitgeroepen, vertrok Antoine X naar Engeland, waar hij in december 1848 trouwde met Emma Mac-Kinnon. Toen president van de Republiek Lodewijk Napoleon Bonaparte (Napoleon III) een staatsgreep pleegde (20-21 dec. 1851) en het met de Tweede Franse Republiek gedaan was, begon voor Antoine X een carrière als diplomaat: hij was achtereenvolgens ambassadeur te Hesse-Cassel (1851), Stuttgart (1852), Turijn (1853), Rome (1857) en Wenen (1861). Van mei tot augustus 1870 was hij ook minister van Buitenlandse Zaken in kabinet-Ollivier; zijn ministerschap werd gekenmerkt door zijn vijandige houding tegenover Pruisen, iets wat wellicht een aandeel heeft gehad in het Emser Depesche van Pruisische kanselier Otto von Bismarck. Het was ook Gramont die op 15 juli 1870 aan de Senaat te kennen gaf dat Frankrijk de oorlog had verklaard aan Pruisen. Gramonts twee broers waren beiden generaals die ernstig gewond raakten in de Frans-Pruisische Oorlog (15 jul. 1870-28 jan. 1871); de oorlog luidde ook het eind in van het Tweede Franse Keizerrijk. Tijdens zijn pensioen publiceerde Gramont nog meerdere reflecties op het beleid dat hij voerde tijdens zijn ministerschap. Hij schreef ook onder het pseudoniem Andreas Memor.

$Gremla.en_GB: K. van Kremla or Gremla worked for the Dutch consulate in Ancona, at least during the time when Gaspare Stienen served as consul (1866-1869), and was also active for the bank of Le Mesurier & Co, also based in Ancona. He offered his services to the Dutch resident minister in the Kingdom of Italy, Maurice Heldewier, to temporarily take over the position of consul after Stiene's demise (6 May 1869). Their exchange of letters suggests Heldewier initially accepted the offer, but in a letter to the Dutch Minister of Foreign Affairs Roest van Limburg, he later admitted to having mistaken Van Gremla for Herman van Bremen. Indeed, soon thereafter Van Bremen was appointed as the next Dutch consul in Ancona (in 1869).
$Gremla.it_IT: K. van Kremla o Gremla lavorò per il consolato olandese ad Ancona, almeno durante il periodo in cui Gaspare Stienen fu console (1866-1869) e fu impegnato anche per la banca di Le Mesurier & Co, anch'essa con sede ad Ancona. Offrì i suoi servizi al ministro olandese residente nel Regno d'Italia, Maurice Heldewier, per assumere temporaneamente la carica di console dopo la morte di Stiene (6 maggio 1869). Il loro scambio di lettere suggerisce che Heldewier inizialmente abbia accettato l'offerta, ma in una lettera al ministro degli Affari esteri olandese Roest van Limburg, ha poi ammesso di aver scambiato per errore Van Gremla per Herman van Bremen. Infatti, subito dopo Van Bremen fu nominato come nuovo console olandese ad Ancona (nel 1869).
$Gremla.nl_NL: K. van Kremla of Gremla werkte voor het Nederlands consulaat in Ancona, in elk geval in de periode waarin Gaspare Stienen als consul diende (1866-1869), en was daarnaast werkzaam voor de bank Le Mesurier & Co, ook gevestigd te Ancona. Hij bood de Nederlandse zaakgelastigde in Rome, minister-resident Maurice Heldewier, zijn diensten aan om na de dood van Stienen (6 May 1869) diens functie van consul over te nemen. De briefwisseling tussen Heldewier en Van Kremla suggereert dat Heldewier dit aanbod aanvankelijk aannam, maar in een brief van Heldewier aan de Nederlandse minister van Buitenlandse Zaken Roest van Limburg, geeft Heldewier aan een fout te hebben gemaakt, en Van Kremla te hebben verward met Herman van Bremen. Van Bremen werd hierop (1869) aangewezen als de volgende Nederlandse consul in Ancona.

$Grooff.en_GB: Jacobus Grooff was a Dutch Roman Catholic priest. He was ordained a priest in Munster in 1825, and appointed pastor in the Dutch colony of Suriname in the same year. Subsequently, he became apostolic prefect (1827), and apostolic vicar and pastor in Batavia (1842). He returned briefly to the Netherlands to be ordained bishop (of Canéa), before resuming his post in Batavia. Once he had returned there, he came into conflict with some of the local clergy, including H.J. Cartenstat, vice-prefect at Batavia, A. Grube, pastor at Semarang, and J.A. Van Dijk, vice-pastor at Batavia. Grooff believed these men exhibited behaviour most unbecoming of the clergy, and tried to reprimand and then suspend them. This the local colonial administration did not allow, and the result was that Grooff himself was suspended and exiled by the Governor-General of the Dutch Indies, J.J. Rochussen, on 19 Jan 1846. Grooff protested, on the grounds that he was answerable only to the Holy See, but he was nevertheless forced to return to the Netherlands. The affair led to an exchange of letters between the Holy See and the Netherlands. Pope Pius IX named Grooff apostolic visitator on 1 Dec 1846, while the Dutch king William II also vindicated Grooff by royal decree. Cartenstat was dismissed and left Batavia for Rome; Grooff himself left for Suriname again in May 1847 and worked in Paramaribo until his death on 29 April 1852.
$Grooff.it_IT: Jacobus Grooff era un prete cattolico olandese. Fu ordinato sacerdote a Munster nel 1825 e nominato parroco nella colonia olandese del Suriname nello stesso anno. Successivamente, divenne prefetto apostolico (1827) e vicario apostolico e parroco a Batavia (1842). Tornò brevemente nei Paesi Bassi per essere ordinato vescovo (di Canéa), prima di riprendere il suo incarico a Batavia. Una volta tornato lì, entrò in conflitto con alcuni membri del clero locale, tra cui H.J. Cartenstat, viceprefetto a Batavia, A. Grube, parroco a Semarang, e J.A. Van Dijk, viceparroco a Batavia. Grooff riteneva che questi uomini avessero un comportamento decisamente sconveniente per il clero e cercò di rimproverarli e poi sospenderli. L'amministrazione coloniale locale non lo permise, e il risultato fu che Grooff stesso fu sospeso ed esiliato dal Governatore Generale delle Indie Olandesi, J.J. Rochussen, il 19 gennaio 1846. Grooff protestò, sostenendo di dover rispondere solo alla Santa Sede, ma fu comunque costretto a tornare nei Paesi Bassi. La vicenda portò a uno scambio di lettere tra la Santa Sede e i Paesi Bassi. Papa Pio IX nominò Grooff visitatore apostolico il 1° dicembre 1846, mentre il re olandese Guglielmo II lo scagionò con decreto reale. Cartenstat fu destituito e lasciò Batavia per Roma; Grooff stesso partì nuovamente per il Suriname nel maggio 1847 e lavorò a Paramaribo fino alla sua morte, avvenuta il 29 aprile 1852.
$Grooff.nl_NL: Jacobus Grooff was een Nederlands Rooms-Katholiek priester. Hij werd in 1825 in Munster als priester gewijd, en in datzelfde jaar als pastoor aangesteld in de Nederlandse kolonie Suriname. Hij werd daar vervolgens in 1827 apostolisch prefect, en in 1842 apostolisch vicaris en pastoor te Batavia. Hij keerde kortstondig terug naar Nederland om tot bisschop (van Canéa) te worden geweid, alvorens zijn post in Batavia te hervatten. Hij kwam daar al snel in conflict met enkele geestelijken, waaronder H.J. Cartenstat, vice-prefect te Batavia, A. Grube, pastoor te Semarang, en J.A. Van Dijk, onderpastoor te Batavia. Grooff was van mening dat deze geestelijken zich misdroegen, en trachtte ze te schorsen. Dit liet het lokale koloniale bestuur niet toe, en het gevolg was dat Grooff zelf geschorst en verbannen werd door de Gouverneur-Generaal van Indië, J.J. Rochussen, op 19 jan. 1846. Grooff protesteerde, op grond van het feit dat hij alleen de Heilige Stoel verantwoording schuldig was, maar hij zag zich desondanks genoodzaakt naar Nederland terug te keren. Deze affaire leidde tot een uitwisseling van brieven tussen de Heilige Stoel en Nederland. Paus Pius IX benoemde Grooff apostolisch visitator te Suriname op 1 dec. 1846; ook de Nederlandse koning Willem II stelde Grooff in het gelijk bij koninklijk besluit. Cartenstat werd hierop ontslagen en vertrok naar Rome; Grooff zelf verliet Nederland in mei 1847 en werkte in Paramaribo tot zijn dood op 29 april 1852.

$Grovestin.en_GB: Eduard Grovestin was a Dutch diplomat and minister from Rotterdam. He worked for the ministry of Foreign Affairs from his twentieth year. Though not Catholic himself, after a stay in Brussels he became interested in the Roman Catholic Church. Upon his return to the Hague (around 1820), he therefore converted to Catholicism and devoted himself to the study of the religion with the help of French priests Francis Raynal (chaplain of the Chapel of the Spanish embassy in The Hague) and Charles Sulpice Flament (librarian of the Royal Library). From 1832, he worked as secretary at the Dutch legations in Lisbon and Berlin. The following year, he was stationed in Madrid as resident ambassador, a post he retained for thirty-two years. During that time, Queen Isabella of Spain granted him the title of Marquis of Casa Sirtema. In 1863, during the cabinet Thorbecke II, Grovestin was removed from office without a further explanation. In spite of criticism he had received after his conversion to catholicism, also from King William I, Grovestin never questioned his decision. He spent his last years in The Hague, writing down his memoirs, before his death in 1871.
$Grovestin.it_IT: Eduard Grovestin fu un diplomatico e ministro olandese di Rotterdam. Lavorò al Ministero degli Affari Esteri dall'età di vent'anni. Sebbene non fosse cattolico, dopo un soggiorno a Bruxelles si occupò della Chiesa cattolica romana. Al suo ritorno all'Aia (intorno al 1820), si convertì quindi al cattolicesimo e si dedicò allo studio della religione con l'aiuto dei sacerdoti francesi Francis Raynal (cappellano della Cappella dell'ambasciata spagnola all'Aia) e Charles Sulpice Flament (bibliotecario della Biblioteca Reale). Dal 1832 lavorò come segretario presso le legazioni olandesi a Lisbona e Berlino. L'anno successivo fu di stanza a Madrid come ambasciatore residente, incarico che mantenne per trentadue anni. In quel periodo la regina Isabella di Spagna gli concesse il titolo di marchese di Casa Sirtema. Nel 1863, durante il governo Thorbecke II, Grovestin fu rimosso dall'incarico senza ulteriori spiegazioni. Nonostante le critiche ricevute dopo la sua conversione al cattolicesimo, anche da parte del re Guglielmo I, Grovestin non mise mai in dubbio la sua decisione. Trascorse i suoi ultimi anni all'Aia, scrivendo le sue memorie, prima della sua morte nel 1871.
$Grovestin.nl_NL: Eduard Grovestin was een Nederlands diplomaat en minister, afkomstig uit Rotterdam. Op zijn twintigste trad hij in dienst bij het ministerie van Buitenlandse Zaken en vertrok voor enige tijd naar Brussel. Hoewel zelf geen katholiek, ontwikkelde hij daar een bijzondere belangstelling voor de Roomse Kerk. Bij terugkeer in Den Haag (ca. 1820) liet hij zich daarom bekeren en werd hij onderwijzen in de godsdienst door de Franse priesters Franciscus Raynal (kapelaan van de kapel bij de Spaanse ambassade in Den Haag) en Charles Sulpice Flament (bibliothecaris van de Koninklijke Bibliotheek). Vanaf 1832 werkte Grovestin als secretaris bij de Nederlandse gezantschappen in Lissabon en Berlijn, daarna werd hij ambassadeur in Madrid. Hij vervulde deze post tweeëndertig jaar en ontving van Koningin Isabella van Spanje de titel van Markies van Casa Sirtema. In 1863, tijdens het kabinet-Thorbecke II, werd hij zonder opgaaf van reden uit zijn functie ontheven. Grovestin kreeg na zijn bekering tot het katholicisme veel kritiek, onder meer van de Nederlandse koning Willem I, maar twijfelde nooit aan zijn beslissing. Zijn laatste jaren bracht Grovestin door in Den Haag, waar hij voor zijn dood in 1871 zijn memoires schreef.

$Guerrazzi.en_GB: Francesco Domenico Guerrazzi was an Italian novelist and radical democratic patriot, originally from Livorno. From the 1820's he made his name as a journalist and author of historical novels, like La Bataglia di Benevento (1828) and L'Assedio di Firenze (1836). Guerrazzi played an important part in the revolution of 1848-1849 in Tuscany. When, following pope Pius IX, Grand Duke Leopold II had also fled to Gaeta, Guerrazzi formed a provisional government with Giuseppe Montanelli and Giuseppe Mazzoni (9 February 1849). Soon thereafter, because of growing public unrest, Guerrazzi was proclaimed dictator (27 March). After the restauration of the grand-ducal power, he was sentenced to fifteen years of prison, later converted into exile, which he spent on the island of Corsica. In 1859, he was elected to the parliament of the Kingdom Piedmont-Sardinia, and from 1861-1870, to the parliament of Italy. When his re-election failed, he retreated from public life and devoted himself to writing.
$Guerrazzi.it_IT: Francesco Domenico Guerrazzi fu un romanziere e patriota democratico radicale italiano, originario di Livorno. Dagli anni venti dell'Ottocento si affermò come giornalista e autore di romanzi storici, come “La Battaglia di Benevento” (1828) e “L'Assedio di Firenze” (1836). Guerrazzi ebbe un ruolo importante nella rivoluzione del 1848-1849 in Toscana. Quando, al seguito di papa Pio IX, anche il granduca Leopoldo II era fuggito a Gaeta, Guerrazzi costituì un governo provvisorio con Giuseppe Montanelli e Giuseppe Mazzoni (9 febbraio 1849). Poco dopo, a causa dei crescenti disordini popolari, Guerrazzi fu proclamato dittatore (27 marzo). Dopo la restaurazione del potere granducale, fu condannato a quindici anni di carcere, poi convertiti in esilio, che trascorse nell'isola della Corsica. Nel 1859 fu eletto al Parlamento del Regno Piemonte-Sardegna e, dal 1861 al 1870, al Parlamento d'Italia. Quando la sua rielezione fallì, si ritirò dalla vita pubblica e si dedicò alla scrittura.
$Guerrazzi.nl_NL: Francesco Domenico Guerrazzi was een Italiaans romancier en radicaaldemocratisch patriot, afkomstig uit Livorno. Vanaf de jaren 1820 maakte hij naam als journalist en auteur van historische romans als La Bataglia di Benevento (1828) en L'Assedio di Firenze (1836). Hij had een belangrijk aandeel in de revolutie in Toscane van 1848-1849. Nadat, in navolging van paus Pius IX, ook groothertog Leopold II naar Gaeta was gevlucht, vormde Guerrazzi samen met Giuseppe Montanelli en Giuseppe Mazzoni in Florence een voorlopige regering (9 februari 1849). Omdat de publieke onvrede in Toscane toenam, werd Guerrazzi vervolgens op 27 maart tot dictator uitgeroepen. Na het herstel van de groothertogelijke macht kreeg hij vijftien jaar gevangenisstraf, later omgezet in ballingschap op Corsica. In 1859 kwam hij in het parlement van het Koninkrijk Sardinië-Piemonte; van 1861-1870 in dat van Italië. Daarna werd hij niet meer herkozen en richtte hij zich op zijn literaire werk.

$Hall.en_GB: Floris Adriaan van Hall was a jurist from Amsterdam, who became a baron in 1860. In 1842, he replaced Felix van Maanen as minister of Justice, and in 1843, he was minister of Finances. By the end of 1847 he resigned because he felt proposal for constitutional reforms were not drastic enough; in 1848 he voted in favour of the new constitution. When the so-called 'April Movement' of 1853 – which protested against the restoration of episcopal hierarchy in the Netherlands – had led to the fall of the cabinet Thorbecke I, Van Hall came to guide a new (conservative) cabinet. For a few months, he also replaced the minister for Roman Catholic Affairs Leonardus Antonius Lightenvelt, who had been sent to Rome as a special envoy. Van Hall succeeded in appeasing the April protesters, while at the same time maintaining the restauration of episcopal hierarchy. During the Crimean War (1853-1856), he was minister of Foreign Affairs and safeguarded Dutch neutrality. In 1860, he was again named minister of Finances, and devised plans for the construction of state railroads. He stepped down in 1861 and left politics to dedicate himself to the study of history. Van Hall was known as an able man and jurist with liberal views; he often appeared in satirical cartoons because of his reddish features.
$Hall.it_IT: Floris Adriaan van Hall era un giurista di Amsterdam, che nel 1860 ottenne il titolo di barone. Nel 1842 sostituì Felix van Maanen come ministro della Giustizia; nel 1843 divenne ministro delle Finanze. Si dimise alla fine del 1847 perché riteneva che le proposte di revisione della Costituzione non fossero sufficientemente ambiziose; nel 1848 votò a favore della nuova Costituzione. Dopo che nel 1853 il Movimento di aprile, che protestava contro il ripristino della gerarchia episcopale nei Paesi Bassi, aveva fatto cadere il governo Thorbecke I, Van Hall guidò un nuovo governo (conservatore). In tale occasione sostituì per alcuni mesi il ministro del Culto cattolico romano, Leonardus Antonius Lightenvelt, che era stato inviato a Roma come inviato speciale. Van Hall riuscì a placare gli animi del Movimento di aprile e allo stesso tempo mantenne il ripristino della gerarchia episcopale. Durante la guerra di Crimea (1853-1856) fu ministro degli Affari Esteri e fece in modo che i Paesi Bassi rimanessero neutrali. Nel 1860 fu nuovamente ministro delle Finanze e elaborò piani per la costruzione delle ferrovie statali. Si dimise nel 1861 e lasciò la politica per dedicarsi allo studio della scienza storica. Van Hall era noto come uomo competente e giurista di idee liberali. A causa del suo colorito rosso, era un soggetto molto amato dai caricaturisti.
$Hall.nl_NL: Floris Adriaan van Hall was een jurist uit Amsterdam, die in 1860 de titel van baron kreeg. In 1842 verving hij Felix van Maanen als minister van Justitie; in 1843 werd hij minister van Financiën. Hij nam eind 1847 ontslag omdat hij de voorstellen tot Grondwetsherziening niet ver genoeg vond gaan; in 1848 stemde hij voor de nieuwe grondwet. Nadat in 1853 de Aprilbeweging – die protesteerde tegen het herstel van de bisschoppelijke hiërarchie in Nederland – het kabinet-Thorbecke I ten val had gebracht, leidde Van Hall een nieuw (conservatief) kabinet. Hij verving daarin ook enkele maanden de minister van Rooms-Katholieke Eredienst, Leonardus Antonius Lightenvelt, die als speciaal gezant naar Rome was gezonden. Van Hall wist de gemoederen van de Aprilbeweging tot bedaren te brengen en hield tegelijkertijd het herstel van de bisschoppelijke hiërarchie in stand. Tijdens de Krimoorlog (1853-1856) was hij minister van Buitenlandse Zaken en zag erop toe dat Nederland afzijdig bleef. In 1860 werd hij nogmaals minister van Financiën, en maakte hij plannen voor de aanleg van staatsspoorwegen. Hij trad af in 1861 en verliet de politiek om zicht aan de historische studie te wijden. Van Hall stond bekend als een kundig man en jurist met liberale opvattingen. Vanwege zijn rode gelaatskleur was hij een geliefd onderwerp voor spotprenten.

$Heeckeren.en_GB: Jacob Derk Burchard Anne baron van Heeckeren tot Enghuizen, also known as Van Heeckeren tot Beverweerd, was a Dutch nobleman, military officer and diplomat. In 1813, he was given the title baron l'Empire during the French Empire. He was first a naval officer and then followed a diplomatic career of almost 50 years. Among other things, he was secretary of the Dutch legations in Lisbon (1814), Stockholm (1815-1817) and Berlin (1817-1822), then acting chargé d'affaires (1822-1823) and, from 1823, extraordinary envoy and minister plenipotentiary in St Petersburg. From Russia, he was recalled to the Netherlands in 1837 after the son he had adopted with the permission of King William I - George Charles baron d'Anthès (b. Colmar, 1812-1895), who was a captain in the Imperial Guard on horseback in Russia - had killed his Russian father-in-law, the poet Alexander Puschkin, in a duel on 10 February 1837. Van Heeckeren held no office from 1837-1842, but fulfilled special diplomatic missions, including some to the French court. In March 1842, he was appointed extraordinary envoy and minister plenipotentiary in Vienna, a post he held from 15 June 1842 to October 1875. One of the secondary positions he held in Vienna was that of vice-president of the international jury of the Agricultural Exhibition of 1873. After returning to the Netherlands, he was minister of state until 28 September 1884, even though he lived in Paris. Meanwhile, his son D'Anthès had emerged in French politics, from 1852 as a senator, as one of the staunchest advocates of the absolute power of Napoleon III and of the secular power of the pope, with the result that his public role would be exhausted after 1870.
$Heeckeren.it_IT: Jacob Derk Burchard Anne barone van Heeckeren tot Enghuizen, noto anche come Van Heeckeren tot Beverweerd, fu un nobile, ufficiale militare e diplomatico olandese. Nel 1813 gli fu conferito il titolo di barone dell'Impero durante l'Impero francese. Fu prima ufficiale di marina e poi seguì una carriera diplomatica durata quasi 50 anni. Fu tra l'altro segretario delle legazioni olandesi a Lisbona (1814), Stoccolma (1815-1817) e Berlino (1817-1822), poi incaricato d'affari ad interim (1822-1823) e, dal 1823, inviato straordinario e ministro plenipotenziario a San Pietroburgo. Dalla Russia, fu richiamato nei Paesi Bassi nel 1837 dopo che il figlio che aveva adottato con il permesso del re Guglielmo I - George Charles barone d'Anthès (nato a Colmar, 1812-1895), che era un capitano a cavallo della guardia imperiale in Russia - aveva ucciso in duello il suocero russo, il poeta Alexander Puschkin, il 10 febbraio 1837. Van Heeckeren non ricoprì alcuna carica dal 1837-1842, ma svolse speciali missioni diplomatiche, tra cui alcune presso la corte francese. Nel marzo 1842 fu nominato inviato straordinario e ministro plenipotenziario a Vienna, carica che mantenne dal 15 giugno 1842 all'ottobre 1875. Uno degli incarichi secondari che ricoprì a Vienna fu quello di vicepresidente della giuria internazionale dell'Esposizione agricola del 1873. Ritornato nei Paesi Bassi, fu ministro di Stato fino al 28 settembre 1884, anche se viveva a Parigi. Nel frattempo, suo figlio D'Anthès era emerso nella politica francese, dal 1852 come senatore, come uno dei più convinti sostenitori del potere assoluto di Napoleone III e del potere laico del papa, tanto che il suo ruolo pubblico si sarebbe esaurito dopo il 1870.
$Heeckeren.nl_NL: Jacob Derk Burchard Anne baron van Heeckeren tot Enghuizen, ook wel Van Heeckeren tot Beverweerd, was een Nederlandse edelman, militair en diplomaat. In 1813 kreeg hij tijdens het Franse Keizerrijk de titel baron l'Empire. Hij was eerst zeeofficier en doorlieop daarna een diplomatieke carrière van bijna vijftig jaar. Hij was onder meer secretaris van de Nederlandse legaties in Lissabon (1814), Stockholm (1815-1817) en Berlijn (1817-1822), vervolgens waarnemend zaakgelastigde (1822-1823) en vanaf 1823 buitengewoon gezant en gevolmachtigd minister in Sint Petersburg. Vanuit Rusland werd hij in 1837 teruggeroepen naar Nederland nadat de zoon die hij met toestemming van koning Willem I had geadopteerd, George Charles baron d'Anthès (geb. Colmar, 1812-1895), die in Rusland kapitein bij de keizerlijke garde te paard was, op 10 februari 1837 in een duel diens Russische schoonvader, de dichter Alexander Puschkin, had gedood. Van Heeckeren was van 1837-1842 officieel ambteloos, maar vervulde bijzondere diplomatieke missies, onder andere naar het Franse hof. In maart 1842 werd hij aangesteld als buitengewoon gezant en gevolmachtigd minister te Wenen, een functie die hij van 15 juni 1842 tot oktober 1875 bekleedde. Een van de nevenfuncties die hij in Wenen had, was die van vicevoorzitter van de internationale jury van de landbouwtentoonstelling te Wenen in 1873. Na terugkeer in Nederland was hij tot 28 september 1884 minister van Staat, ook al woonde hij in Parijs. Zijn zoon D'Anthès had zich intussen in de Franse politiek, vanaf 1852 als senator, ontpopt tot een van de meest geharnaste pleitbezorgers van de absolute macht van Napoleon III en van de wereldlijke macht van de paus, met als gevolg dat zijn publieke rol na 1870 was uitgespeeld.

$HeldewierI.en_GB:
Albert W.M.L. Heldewier was a Dutch diplomat, born into a family from Leiden, where his father Daniël Michiel Gijsbrecht (1753-1822) was mayor from 1810-1822. Albert married Johanna Jacoba Maria Slicher (1800-1851), heiress of the Swanenburg country estate on Walcheren, in 1824. By Royal Decree of
3 August 1835, he was raised to the peerage, after which he held the title of baron. Among other things, he was Commander in de Order van de Dutch Lion and Knight Grand Cross with Grand Collar in the Order of Mauritius and Lazarus of the Kingdom of Sardinia. His wife and later his daughter Sophie were ladies-in-waiting of the Queen of the Netherlands.
Albert Heldewier began his career in diplomacy from 21 August 1823 to 5 August 1829 as chargé d'affaires in the Grand Duchy of Baden. He was then transferred to Turin, where he succeeded the Dutch chargé d'affaires F.A. Count van Limburg Stierum. Heldewier held the position of chargé d'affaires from August 1829 to October 1835; thereafter he was first minister-resident (October 1835-September 1837) and finally envoy, until he was recalled home by Royal Decree of 13 September 1844. As envoy, he played an important role in the establishment of the Trattato di navigazione or Treaty of Navigation concluded between the kingdoms of Sardinia and the Netherlands on 24 January 1842, with his counterpart Count Clemente Solaro della Margherita, the Sardinian minister of Foreign Affairs. The treaty, which regulated shipping on the basis of equality and reciprocity and was valid for six years, was published in the Almanacco nautico (1844, pp. 122-125), among others. Heldewier also had an important role in the so-called 'questione valdese', the Waldensian question in the years 1841-1844, on which he corresponded intensely with the Dutch Foreign minister Huysssen van Kattendijke. The greater freedoms this Protestant mountain community had enjoyed during the French era and the Restoration came under pressure after 1830 by doing of an intransigent Catholic faction, led by Andrea Charvaz, from 1834 bishop of Pinerolo, an area where many Waldensians lived, and later also under the influence of Rodolphe de Maistre, aide-de-camp to the king and governor of Nice. The main issue at stake was whether the Waldensians should be allowed land ownership outside their valleys. Especially in the municipality of Lusernetta, the Waldensians had acquired agricultural land in the previous years. Charvaz wanted to proceed to forced sale or else expropriation, but found himself facing the consuls of the United Kingdom (Ralph Abercromby,2nd Baron Dunfermline), the Netherlands (Heldewier) and especially Prussia (Truchsess von Waldburg). The latter had previously established a Protestant chapel at his own legation in Turin, led by a Waldensian pastor, Amedeo Bert, for whom Heldewier had also applied to the Dutch king for financial aid. The three diplomats carefully balanced between the interests of their brother in faith and diplomatic interests of their respective countries, which in any case came under strain, partly because in August 1842 the British government and Queen had expressed to the Sardinian envoy in London their concern regarding the treatment of the Waldenses. In this diplomatic balancing act, Heldewier was usually the more cautious of the three. Initially, King Carlo Alberto was quite irritated by the foreign interference and things did not look good for the Waldensians. During a joint meeting with the Sardinian king in February 1843, during which the three envoys presented a request to at least postpone the impending forced sale of the lands, Carlo Alberto again reproached them for invoking Queen Victoria in this internal affair. But then his tone softened; it appeared he did not to want to risk losing face with the courts of northwestern Europe and chose to settle the matter. The outcome, which took hold in the spring of 1843, was that almost all 225 cases of property acquired by Waldensians since 1831 were retrospectively condoned. In all of this, Heldewier had also provided a legal way out, by pointing out that under the legislation and international agreements in force, foreign Protestants in Sardinia enjoyed rights to purchase property which were about to be denied to Protestant subjects of the kingdom. The concession to the Waldensians and the turbulence the issue had caused among Italian liberals were the impetus for the legislation by which Carlo Alberto would grant full civil rights, first to the Waldensians (17 February 1848) and later to other religious communities, including the Jews (29 March 1848). Not long after the 'Waldensian issue', Heldewier was recalled to the Netherlands, when the Dutch legations in Turin and Rome merged for economic reasons. After 15 years in Turin, he had his last audience with the king on 29 May 1844; on 2 June he bade farewell to Queen Maria Teresa and the Duke of Savoy Victor Emanuel, among others. Shortly after he left office, even before he could travel to the Netherlands, a very thorny issue arose. It involved 'freule' Carolina Heldewier (1825-1893), the envoy's 19-year-old daughter. She had allegedly fallen for the charms of what we would now call a 'loverboy', the young lawyer Giuseppe Cumietti, who was in reality after an inheritance that awaited her. When Carolina seemed willing to embrace Catholicism for him and he secretly sought advice on the legal - civil and ecclesiastical - side of things, the intransigent Catholics in Turin saw their chance to settle an outstanding account with Heldewier. Among those reportedly involved in the intrigue were police chief Michele Cavour, arch-Catholic minister Solaro della Margherita and archbishop Luigi Fransoni. On 8 June 1844, after the Heldewier family, at the invitation of the king, had made their appearance at the festivities celebrating the birth of Prince Umberto, and Heldewier had been awarded the supreme honour, the Knighthood Grand Cross with Grand Collar in the Order of Sts Mauritius and Lazarus, everyone but Carolina returned to the Hotel Feder where the family had temporarily moved in. Instead, she was taken to the convent of the Sister of Santa Croce by an acquaintance of Cumietti and Cavour's agents in disguise. When Heldewier found out where his daughter was hiding, he asked in vain to the authorities to bring her back to him. Not only did the police and minister Solaro (who were in the plot) not help him; also King Carlo Alberto, with whom Heldewier requested and received an audience on 12 June, hid behind the argument that, according to ancient canon law, no power in the world could force Carolina to leave the convent unless she herself changed her mind, reghardless of the fact that she was still a minor (according to Dutch law, the limit was 23). Heldewier's successor, the Catholic but liberal-minded Count Liedekerke de Beaufort, came up against the same walls when, in his first weeks as envoy in June 1844, he had temporarily left Rome for Turin. After returning to Rome, even Pope Gregory XVI, in the audience Liedekerke received on 18 October, appeared decidedly unwilling to overrule his archbishop. This much is clear from the dépèches Liedekerke wrote to foreign minister De La Sarraz in The Hague on 14 and 18 October 1844. By then, the affair had already totally escalated and many courts and embassies in Europe, including some catholic countries, were outraged by the intransigent attitude of the Piedmontese authorities. The newspapers were full of it, not only in the Netherlands but also in a French liberal journal like the Journal des Débats (3 July 1844). For Heldewier and his family, however, there was no alternative but to leave for the Netherlands without Carolina. Meanwhile, understanding that this plot could not have taken place without the knowledge of King Carlo Alberto, Heldewier returned his royal decoration to the court in Turin as soon as he had crossed the border of the Kingdom of Sardinia - an gesture he was technically allowed to make, since he had received the badge of honour when he no longer represented the Dutch king. Nevertheless, the government in The Hague, unaware of all the details and out of state interests, disapproved of this affront to Carlo Alberto. Meanwhile, the king of Sardinia seemed to recognise that the affair could cause him serious damage and urged his envoy in The Hague, Marquis Alberto Ricci, to normalise the strained relations. Moreover, he had Cumietti arrested and forced to serve in a free corps on the island of Sardinia. For Carolina, the king finally staged a marriage to a 'good match': the son of his own councillor Count Antonio Piola, Luigi Piola Caselli (1820-1890), later a legal secretary at the Council of State in Turin. After their marriage on 28 April 1846, the couple even went on their honeymoon to the Netherlands. Later, Carolina became a seen figure in Torinese high society and an ardent sympathizer of the Italian Risorgimento.Albert Heldewier's career in public service was over after his experiences in Turin. He was reportedly still approached in October 1849 to become foreign minister in the first Thorbecke cabinet, but declined the honour (C.B. Wels, 'The formation of the first Thorbecke ministry', Bijdragen en Mededelingen van het historische Genootschap 76 (1962) 263-317, ivi 286).) He died on 18 November 1870 in The Hague and was buried at Eik en Duinen.

Albert WML Heldewier fu un diplomatico olandese, nato in una famiglia di Leida, dove suo padre Daniël Michiel Gijsbrecht (1753-1822) fu sindaco dal 1810 al 1822. Albert sposò nel 1824 Johanna Jacoba Maria Slicher (1800-1851), erede della tenuta di campagna di Swanenburg a Walcheren. Con decreto reale del 3 agosto 1835 fu elevato al titolo nobiliare, dopo di che mantenne il titolo di barone. Fu, tra l'altro, Comandante nell'Ordine del Leone d'Olanda e Cavaliere di Gran Croce con Gran Collare nell'Ordine di Maurizio e Lazzaro del Regno di Sardegna. Sua moglie e poi sua figlia Sophie erano dame di compagnia della regina dei Paesi Bassi.
Albert Heldewier iniziò la sua carriera diplomatica dal 21 agosto 1823 al 5 agosto 1829 come incaricato d'affari nel Granducato di Baden. Fu poi trasferito a Torino, dove succedette all'incaricato d'affari olandese F.A., conte van Limburg Stierum. Heldewier ricoprì la carica di incaricato d'affari dall'agosto 1829 all'ottobre 1835; fu poi primo ministro residente (ottobre 1835-settembre 1837) e infine inviato, finché fu richiamato in patria con Regio Decreto del 13 settembre 1844. Come inviato, ebbe un ruolo importante nella stesura del Trattato di navigazione concluso tra i regni di Sardegna e dei Paesi Bassi il 24 gennaio 1842, con il suo omologo conte Clemente Solaro della Margherita, ministro sardo della Affari Esteri. Il trattato, che regolava la navigazione su base di uguaglianza e reciprocità ed aveva validità sei anni, fu pubblicato, tra gli altri, nell'Almanacco nautico (1844, pp. 122-125).
Heldewier ebbe un ruolo importante anche nella cosiddetta “questione valdese” degli anni 1841-1844, sulla quale mantenne un'intensa corrispondenza con il ministro degli Esteri olandese Huysssen van Kattendijke. Le maggiori libertà di cui questa comunità montana protestante aveva goduto durante l'epoca francese e la Restaurazione furono messe a dura prova dopo il 1830 ad opera di una fazione cattolica intransigente, guidata da Andrea Charvaz, dal 1834 vescovo di Pinerolo, zona dove vivevano molti valdesi, e più tardi anche sotto l'influenza di Rodolphe de Maistre, aiutante di campo del re e governatore di Nizza. La principale questione in gioco era se ai Valdesi dovesse essere concesso il possesso di terre al di fuori delle loro valli. Soprattutto nel comune di Lusernetta i valdesi avevano acquistato negli anni precedenti terreni agricoli. Charvaz voleva procedere alla vendita forzata oppure all'esproprio, ma si trovò di fronte ai consoli del Regno Unito (Ralph Abercromby, 2° barone Dunfermline), dei Paesi Bassi (Heldewier) e soprattutto della Prussia (Truchsess von Waldburg). Quest'ultimo aveva precedentemente fondato una cappella protestante presso la propria legazione a Torino, guidata da un pastore valdese, Amedeo Bert, per il quale Heldewier aveva anche chiesto aiuti finanziari al re olandese. I tre diplomatici bilanciarono attentamente gli interessi del fratello di fede e gli interessi diplomatici dei rispettivi paesi, che comunque erano messi a dura prova, anche perché nell'agosto 1842 il governo britannico e la regina avevano espresso all'inviato sardo a Londra la loro preoccupazione per il trattamento dei valdesi. In questo equilibrio diplomatico, Heldewier era solitamente il più cauto dei tre. Inizialmente il re Carlo Alberto fu piuttosto irritato dalle ingerenze straniere e le cose non si misero bene per i Valdesi. Nel corso di un incontro congiunto con il re sardo nel febbraio 1843, durante il quale i tre inviati presentarono la richiesta di almeno rinviare l'imminente vendita forzata delle terre, Carlo Alberto li rimproverò nuovamente di aver invocato la regina Vittoria in questa vicenda interna. Ma poi il suo tono si addolcì; sembrava che non volesse rischiare di perdere la faccia con i tribunali dell'Europa nordoccidentale e scelse di risolvere la questione.
Il risultato, che si verificò nella primavera del 1843, fu che quasi tutti i 225 casi di proprietà acquisite dai valdesi a partire dal 1831 furono condonati retroattivamente. A tutto ciò Heldewier aveva fornito anche una via d'uscita legale, sottolineando che secondo la legislazione e gli accordi internazionali vigenti, i protestanti stranieri in Sardegna godevano di diritti di acquisto di beni che stavano per essere negati ai sudditi protestanti del regno. La concessione ai valdesi e le turbolenze che la questione aveva suscitato tra i liberali italiani furono lo stimolo per la legislazione con la quale Carlo Alberto avrebbe concesso pieni diritti civili, prima ai valdesi (17 febbraio 1848) e poi ad altre comunità religiose, compresi gli ebrei (29 marzo 1848).
Non molto tempo dopo la “questione valdese”, Heldewier fu richiamato nei Paesi Bassi, quando le legazioni olandesi a Torino e Roma si unirono per ragioni economiche. Dopo 15 anni trascorsi a Torino, ebbe la sua ultima udienza dal re il 29 maggio 1844; il 2 giugno salutò, tra gli altri, la regina Maria Teresa e il duca di Savoia Vittorio Emanuele. Poco dopo aver lasciato l'incarico, ancor prima che potesse recarsi nei Paesi Bassi, eraemersa una questione molto spinosa. Si trattava della “freule” Carolina Heldewier (1825-1893), la figlia diciannovenne dell'inviato. Si sarebbe innamorata di quello che oggi chiameremmo un 'amante', il giovane avvocato Giuseppe Cumietti, che in realtà era alla ricerca dell'eredità che le sarebbe  spettata. Quando Carolina sembrò disposta ad abbracciare per lui il cattolicesimo ed egli cercò segretamente consigli sul piano giuridico - civile ed ecclesiastico -, gli intransigenti cattolici torinesi videro l'occasione di regolare un conto in sospeso con Heldewier. Tra coloro che sarebbero coinvolti nell'intrigo c'erano il capo della polizia Michele Cavour, il ministro arcicattolico Solaro della Margherita e l'arcivescovo Luigi Fransoni. L'8 giugno 1844, dopo che la famiglia Heldewier, su invito del re, si era presentata ai festeggiamenti per la nascita del principe Umberto, e Heldewier era stato insignito dell'onorificenza suprema, del Cavalierato di Gran Croce con Gran Collare dell'Ordine dei Santi Maurizio e Lazzaro, tutti tranne Carolina tornarono all'Hotel Feder dove la famiglia si era temporaneamente trasferita. Fu invece condotta al convento delle Suore di Santa Croce da un conoscente di Cumietti e gli agenti di Cavour sotto mentite spoglie. Quando Heldewier scoprì dove si nascondeva sua figlia, chiese invano alle autorità di riportargliela. Non solo la polizia e il ministro Solaro (che erano complici del complotto) non lo aiutarono; ma anche il re Carlo Alberto, al quale Heldewier chiese e ottenne udienza il 12 giugno, si nascose dietro l'argomento che, secondo l'antico diritto canonico, nessun potere al mondo poteva costringere Carolina a lasciare il convento a meno che lei stessa non cambiasse idea, indipendentemente dal fatto che fosse ancora minorenne (secondo la legge olandese il limite era 23). Il successore di Heldewier, il conte Liedekerke de Beaufort, cattolico ma di mentalità liberale, si scontrò con gli stessi muri quando, nelle sue prime settimane da inviato, nel giugno 1844, aveva temporaneamente lasciato Roma per Torino. Ritornato a Roma, anche papa Gregorio XVI, nell'udienza ricevuta da Liedekerke il 18 ottobre, si mostrò decisamente poco disposto a prevalere sul suo arcivescovo. Ciò emerge chiaramente dai dépèches che Liedekerke scrisse al ministro degli Esteri De La Sarraz all'Aja il 14 e 18 ottobre 1844.
