Naast zijn politieke carrière, bleef hij ook op wetenschappelijk vlak actief en gaf hij tussen 1868-1872 Geschiedenis der Nederlandsche Letterkunde uit, wat een belangrijk werk werd binnen het vakgebied van de Nederlandse taalkunde. Hoewel Jonckbloet bij wet de zoon was van een hoffourier van koning Willem II, was hij vermoedelijk een bastaardzoon van laatstgenoemde.

$Jongh.en_GB:
William Daniel De Yongh, sometimes William, Guillaume or Guglielmo, also De Jongh, was a British merchant and banker in Livorno, who was also consul, later consul-general on behalf of the Kingdom of the Netherlands. He was appointed by Royal Decree of 10 August 1814 (Nederlandsche Staatscourant, 11 August 1814). When he was honorably discharged on 12 February 1853 and succeeded by Heukensfeldt, he was granted the title of honorary consul general (Nederlandsche Staatscourant, 5 March 1853).
He initially sent his reports on trade and shipping (also) to the Directorate of Levantine Trade and Navigation in the Mediterranean, a body that had overseen ship equipment and taxation since 1625 and represented the interests of traders in the Levant. To this end, it also maintained correspondence with the Dutch representatives in the 'ports of call' in Italy, among others. Like other consuls, De Jongh was informed, for example, about a new law, which, as of 1 January 1818, required all incoming ships coming from ports in the (new!) southern provinces of the Netherlands to pay export duties. De Jongh and his colleagues had to ensure compliance. Conversely, De Yongh also informed the board, at least every six months, about ship movements in merchant shipping between Livorno and Dutch ports. 
In the 1820s these showed a downward trend, to De Jongh's regret. In July 1825, he wrote to the board that he had not even welcomed a single ship under the Dutch flag in the previous six months; six months later, the tally still stood at zero. De Yongh saw the consequence with sorrow: foreign competitors were taking over the trade.
De Yongh's later six-monthly reports to the minister only made the national newspapers occasionally. In August 1849, he reported on the numbers of incoming ships from Dutch ports (carrying sugar, coffee, cheese) and outgoing ones (potash, marble, oil) to the Netherlands. Compared to the last six months of 1848, when trade visibly benefited from the relative calm in the Netherlands compared to countries where revolutions had raged, volumes had again declined somewhat. 'The Dutch ships here have a good reputation,' said De Yongh. However, the opportunities offered by this reputation were insufficiently exploited; the consul-general therefore advised Dutch captains and shipowners to come down to Livorno with lower cargoes, so that the number of Dutch ships with opportunities for good return cargoes would increase (Nederlandsche Staatscourant, 28 August 1849).
Besides consul, De Yongh was also a partner in the trading house Bell, De Yongh & Co, together with James C.C. Bell, George Frederick Darby and Robert Grant. The firm was probably the city's most important importer of colonial goods - and Livorno was considered one of the Mediterranean's most important ports. Bell, De Yongh & Co played an important role in lobbying for Livorno traders, through the local Chamber of Commerce, towards the Ministry of Commerce in Florence. The aim was to relax fiscal and other regulations so that trade would flourish again, something for which merely restoring Livorno's status as a free port in 1814 had not been enough. The damage the firm had suffered from complex and inflexible rules gives an idea of the impressive volumes and global scale of their trade in coffee from Santo Domingo, among others. The same goes for two lawsuits involving the firm against trading partners in the United States, fought all the way to the Supreme Court there (1830 and 1839).
Apart from transporting merchandise, De Yongh also interfered in the trade and shipping of antiquities. In the archives of the Rijksmuseum van Oudheden in Leiden, founded by King Willem I in 1818, there are numerous letters by de De Yongh, as well as from vice-consul Callamand. These concern in particular the purchase of the Egyptian collections of Giovanni D'Anastasi, consul-general of Denmark in Alexandria, and those of a mysterious dr. Cimba. The purchase took place on the initiative of Jean Emile Humbert after mediation by the Dutch representatives. The firm Bell De Yongh & C. also arranged insurance and transport. The letters and bills can be seen in the RMO's digital collections. 
De Yongh also acted as host for Dutch travellers in Tuscany. On his Kunstreis through Europe, Hendrik Willem Cramer had the pleasure of dining in Livorno on 22 July 1834 with 'knight De Jongh, one of the most distinguished merchants of this merchant city'. In the autumn of 1839, the consul received Prince Hendrik 'De Zeevaarder' and some members of the equippage of his schip De Rhijn for dinner. 
Finally, De Yongh was closely involved with the church of the Dutch-German or Protestant congregation based there since 1622, which was above all an English affair in the nineteenth century. He was 'Trustee' of the church and in 1831, for example, in that capacity he signed a nomination for Rev Thomas Harvey as the new chaplain of the British community submitted to the British Secretary of State. Not surprisingly, De Yongh himself was interred in Livorno's 'English cemetery' (Via Pera) after his death in 1855.
$Jongh.it_IT:
William Daniel De Yongh, a volte William, Guillaume o Guglielmo, anche De Jongh, fu un mercante e banchiere britannico a Livorno;  fu anche console, poi console generale per conto del Regno dei Paesi Bassi. Fu nominato con Regio Decreto del 10 agosto 1814 (Nederlandsche Staatscourant, 11 agosto 1814). Quando fu congedato con onore il 12 febbraio 1853, e gli successe Heukensfeldt, gli fu concesso il titolo di console generale onorario (Nederlandsche Staatscourant, 5 marzo 1853).
Inizialmente inviò i suoi rapporti sul commercio e sulla navigazione anche alla Direzione del commercio e della navigazione levantina nel Mediterraneo, un organismo che aveva supervisionato l'equipaggiamento navale e la tassazione dal 1625 e rappresentava gli interessi dei commercianti nel Levante. A questo scopo intrattenne rapporti epistolari anche con i rappresentanti olandesi nei «porti di scalo» italiani. Come altri consoli, De Jongh fu informato, ad esempio, di una nuova legge che, a partire dal 1° gennaio 1818, imponeva a tutte le navi in ​​arrivo provenienti dai porti delle (nuove!) province meridionali dei Paesi Bassi di pagare dazi all'esportazione. De Jongh e i suoi colleghi dovevano garantire la conformità. Per contro, De Yongh informava il consiglio, almeno ogni sei mesi, anche sui movimenti delle navi nel traffico mercantile tra Livorno e i porti olandesi. Negli anni venti dell'Ottocento questi mostrarono una tendenza al ribasso, con rammarico di De Jongh. Nel luglio 1825 scrisse al consiglio di amministrazione di non aver accolto nemmeno una nave sotto bandiera olandese nei sei mesi precedenti; sei mesi dopo, il conteggio era ancora pari a zero. De Yongh vide con rammarico la conseguenza: i concorrenti stranieri stavano rilevando il settore. I successivi rapporti semestrali di De Yongh al ministro apparvero sui giornali nazionali solo occasionalmente. Nell'agosto 1849 riferì il numero di navi in ​​arrivo dai porti olandesi (che trasportavano zucchero, caffè, formaggio) e in uscita (potassa, marmo, petrolio) nei Paesi Bassi. Rispetto agli ultimi sei mesi del 1848, quando il commercio beneficiò visibilmente della relativa calma nei Paesi Bassi rispetto ai paesi in cui avevano imperversato le rivoluzioni, i volumi erano nuovamente leggermente diminuiti. 'Le navi olandesi qui hanno una buona reputazione', ha detto De Yongh. Tuttavia, le opportunità offerte da questa reputazione non furono sufficientemente sfruttate; il console generale consigliò quindi ai capitani e agli armatori olandesi di scendere a Livorno con carichi inferiori, così che aumentasse il numero delle navi olandesi con possibilità di buoni carichi di ritorno (Nederlandsche Staatscourant, 28 agosto 1849).
Oltre al console, De Yongh era anche socio della casa commerciale Bell, De Yongh & Co, insieme a James C.C. Bell, George Frederick Darby e Robert Grant. L'azienda era probabilmente il più importante importatore di merci coloniali della città e Livorno era considerato uno dei porti più importanti del Mediterraneo. Bell, De Yongh & Co svolsero un ruolo importante nell'attività di lobbying a favore dei commercianti livornesi, attraverso la locale Camera di Commercio, presso il Ministero del Commercio di Firenze. Lo scopo era quello di allentare le norme fiscali e di altro tipo in modo che il commercio potesse rifiorire, cosa per la quale il semplice ripristino dello status di porto franco di Livorno nel 1814 non era stato sufficiente. Il danno che l'azienda subì a causa di regole complesse e inflessibili dà un'idea dei volumi impressionanti e della scala globale del loro commercio, tra gli altri, di caffè proveniente da Santo Domingo. Lo stesso vale per due cause legali che coinvolsero l'azienda contro partner commerciali negli Stati Uniti, combattute fino alla Corte Suprema (1830 e 1839).
Oltre al trasporto di merci, De Yongh intervenne anche nel commercio e nella spedizione di antichità. Negli archivi del Rijksmuseum van Oudheden di Leida, fondato dal re Guglielmo I nel 1818, si trovano numerose lettere di de De Yongh, nonché del viceconsole Callamand. Si tratta in particolare dell'acquisto delle collezioni egiziane di Giovanni D'Anastasi, console generale di Danimarca ad Alessandria, e di quelle di un misterioso dott. Cimba. L'acquisto  avvenne su iniziativa di Jean Emile Humbert dopo la mediazione dei rappresentanti olandesi. La ditta Bell De Yongh & C. si occupò anche dell'assicurazione e del trasporto. Le lettere e le fatture sono visibili nelle collezioni digitali della RMO. De Yongh fungeva anche da ospite per i viaggiatori olandesi in Toscana. Nel suo Kunstreis attraverso l'Europa, Hendrik Willem Cramer ebbe il piacere di cenare a Livorno il 22 luglio 1834 con 'il cavaliere De Jongh, uno dei mercanti più illustri di questa città mercantile'. Nell'autunno del 1839 il console ricevette a cena il principe Hendrik 'De Zeevaarder' e alcuni membri dell'equipaggio della sua nave De Rhijn. Infine, De Yongh fu strettamente coinvolto con la chiesa della congregazione olandese-tedesca o protestante con sede lì dal 1622, che nel XIX secolo era soprattutto un affare inglese. Era il 'fiduciario' della chiesa e nel 1831, ad esempio, in tale veste firmò la nomina del reverendo Thomas Harvey a nuovo cappellano della comunità britannica presentata al Segretario di Stato britannico. Non sorprende che lo stesso De Yongh fu sepolto nel 'cimitero degli inglesi' di Livorno (Via Pera) dopo la sua morte nel 1855.
$Jongh.nl_NL:
William Daniel De Yongh, soms Willem, Guillaume of Guglielmo, ook De Jongh, was een Brits koopman en bankier in Livorno, die tevens consul, later consul-generaal namens het Koninkrijk der Nederlanden was. Hij werd per Koninklijk Besluit van 10 augustus 1814 benoemd (Nederlandsche Staatscourant, 11 augustus 1814). Toen hij op 12 februari 1853 eervol ontslag kreeg en door Heukensfeldt werd opgevolgd, werd hem de titel van honorair consul-generaal toegekend (Nederlandsche Staatscourant, 5 maart 1853).
Zijn rapportages over handel en scheepvaar stuurde hij aanvankelijk (ook) nog naar de Directie van de Levantse Handel en van de Navigatie op de Middellandse Zee, een college dat sinds 1625 toezicht hield op de uitrusting van de schepen en de belastingheffing en de belangen van de Levanthandelaars vertegenwoordigde. Daartoe onderhield het ook een correspondentie met de Nederlandse vertegenwoordigers in de 'aanloophavens' in onder meer Italië. Net als andere consuls werd De Jongh bijvoorbeeld geïnformeerd over een nieuwe wet, die per 1 januari 1818 alle binnengelopen schepen afkomstig uit havens van de (nieuwe!) zuidelijke provincies van de Nederlanden verplichtte uitvoerrechten te voldoen. De Jongh en zijn collega's moesten op naleving toezien. Omgekeerd informeerde De Yongh de directie ook, ten minste halfjaarlijks, over de scheepsbewegingen in de koopvaardij tussen Livorno en de Nederlandse havens. Die liet, tot De Jonghs spijt, in de jaren 1820 een neerwaartse trend zien. In juli 1825 schreef hij de directie in het voorgaande halfjaar zelfs geen enkel schip onder Nederlandse vlag te hebben verwelkomd; een half jaar later stond de teller nog altijd op nul. Het gevolg zag De Yongh met lede ogen aan: buitenlandse concurrenten namen de handel over.
Van De Yonghs latere halfjaarlijkse rapportages aan de minister haalde een enkel consulair bericht de landelijke kranten. In augustus 1849 berichtte hij over de aantallen inkomende schepen uit Nederlandse havens (met suiker, koffie, kaas) en de uitgaande (potas, marmer, olie, wijnsteen) naar Nederland. Vergeleken met het laatste semester van 1848, toen de handel zichtbaar profiteerde van de relatieve rust in Nederland vergeleken met landen waar de revoluties hadden gewoed, waren de volumes weer enigszins teruggelopen. 'De Nederlandsche schepen staan hier in eenen goeden roep', aldus De Yongh. De kansen die deze reputatie bood werden echter onvoldoende benut; de consul-generaal raadde Nederlandse kapiteins en reders daarom aan met lagere vrachten naar Livorno af te komen, zodat het aantal Nederlandse schepen met kansen op goede retourvrachten zou toenemen (Nederlandsche Staatscourant, 28 augustus 1849).
Behalve consul was De Yongh ook vennoot in het handelshuis Bell, De Yongh & Co, samen met James C.C. Bell, George Frederick Darby and Robert Grant. De firma was vermoedelijk de belangrijkste importeur van koloniale waren van de stad – en Livorno gold als een van de belangrijkste havens van de Middellandse Zee. Bell, De Yongh & Co speelden een belangrijke rol in de lobby die de Livornese handelaren, via de lokale Handelskamer, voerden richting het ministerie van Handel in Florence. Doel daarbij was om fiscale en andere regelgeving te versoepelen zodat de handel opnieuw zou floreren, iets waarvoor alleen het herstel van de status van Livorno als vrijhavenin 1814 niet genoeg was geweest. De schade die ze liepen door de complexe en inflexibele regels geeft een indruk van de indrukwekkende volumes en wereldschaal van de handel in onder meer koffie uit Santo Domingo. Hetzelfde geldt voor een tweetal rechtzaken waarbij de firma betrokken was tegen handelspartners in de Verenigde Staten, die tot aan het Supreme Court aldaar werden uitgevochten (1830 en 1839).
Behalve met het transport van handelswaar bemoeide De Yongh zich ook met de handele en het verschepen van oudheden. In het archief van het Rijksmuseum van Oudheden te Leiden, in 1818 gesticht door koning Willem I, bevinden zich talloze brieven de De Yongh, als ook van vice-consul Callamand. Die betreffen de aankoop van met name de Egyptische collecties van Giovanni D'Anastasi, consul-generaal van Denemarken te Alexandrië, en die van de mysterieuze dr. Cimba. De aankoop vond plaats op initiatief van Jean Emile Humbert na bemiddeling van de Nederlandse vertegenwoordigers. De firma Bell De Yongh & C. zorgde ook voor de verzekering en het transport. De brieven en rekeningen zijn in de digitale collecties van het RMO te zien. 
De Yongh trad ook op als gastheer van Nederlanders op reis in Toscane. Op zijn Kunstreis door Europa had Hendrik Willem Cramer op 22 juli 1834 het genoegen in Livorno te dineren met 'ridder De Jongh, een der wegezetenste kooplieden dezer handeldrijvende stad'. In het najaar van 1839 ontving de consul Prins Hendrik 'De Zeevaarder' en enkele leden van de equippage van diens De Rhijn voor een diner. 
Ten slotte was De Yongh nauw betrokken bij de kerk van de Nederlands-Duitse congregatie of protestantse gemeente die er sinds 1622 gevestigd was, en die in de negentiende eeuw bovenal een Engelse aangelegenheid was. Hij was 'Trustee' van de kerk en ondertekende in 1831 in die hoedanigheid bijvoorbeeld een voordracht voor Rev. Thomas Harvey als nieuwe 'chaplain' van de Britse gemeenschap bij de Britse Secretary of State. Het verbaast dan ook niet dat hij na zijn overlijden in 1855 op de 'Engelse begraafplaats' (Via Pera) van Livorno werd bijgezet.

$Kanzler.en_GB: Hermann [von] Kanzler was born in 1822 in Weingarten, Grand Duchy of Baden, to Maximilian and Maria Magdalene Krehmer. He entered the military college in Karlsruhe and started a military career; in 1841 he obtained the rank of lieutenant. In 1844, he resigned from the grand ducal army after refusing, for reasons of Catholic faith, to fight a duel with a fellow officer who had challenged him. He stayed for a few months in England and in 1845 he came to Rome, where he enlisted as a cadet in the Foreign Brigade of the papal troops. In 1848, he participated with his unit in the initial phase of the First Italian War of Independence in northern Italy, distinguishing himself during the defence of Vicenza. In 1849, he joined Pius IX in Gaeta after his flight from Rome, where soon afterwards the Roman Republic would be proclaimed. After the papal government had been fully restored in Rome (1850), in 1854 he was promoted tot he rank of major and, in 1855, to lieutenant-colonel. Between 1859 and 1860, he was among those responsible for reorganising the papal army, which had seen its territories considerably reduced after the end of the Second Italian War of Independence. In 1865, on general Lamoricière's death, Kanzler was promoted to lieutenant-general and also succeeded De Merode as (acting) Minister of Arms. Garibaldi's expedition in the autumn of 1867 found the papal army well prepared; the latter won, also thanks to the use of the railways, the Battle of Mentana. When, in 1870, the the Franco-Prussian caused the diplomatic isolation of the Holy See, Kanzler spoke out in favour of an all-out resistance tot he Italian claims and offensive. In the aftermath of 20 September 1870, when Rome was seized by the army of the Kingdom of Italy, he settled in the Vatican with his family. He died in 1888.
$Kanzler.it_IT: Hermann [von] Kanzler nacque nel 1822 a Weingarten, nel Granducato di Baden, da Maximilian e Maria Magdalene Krehmer. Entrò nel collegio militare di Karlsruhe e iniziò la carriera militare; nel 1841 ottenne i gradi di tenente. Nel 1844 si dimise dall'esercito granducale dopo essersi rifiutato, come cattolico, di battersi a duello con un collega che lo aveva sfidato. Soggiornò per alcuni mesi in Inghilterra e dal 1845 giunse a Roma dove si arruolò come cadetto della Brigata estera pontificia. Nel 1848 partecipò con il suo reparto alla fase iniziale della campagna nell'Italia settentrionale, distinguendosi nella difesa di Vicenza. Nel 1849 raggiunse Pio IX a Gaeta dopo la sua fuga da Roma, poco primadella proclamazione della Repubblica Romana. Dopo che, fin dal 1850, si era pienamente ristabilito il governo pontificio a Roma, nel 1854 fu promosso maggiore e, nel 1855, tenente colonnello. Tra il 1859 e il 1860 fu uno dei responsabili della riorganizzazione delle truppe dello Stato Pontificio che, dopo la fine della Seconda guerra d'Indipendenza, aveva visto notevolmente ridotti i suoi territori. Nel 1865, alla morte del generale Lamoricière, Kanzler fu promosso tenente generale e subentrò a De Merode nell'incarico di proministro delle Armi. La spedizione garibaldina dell'autunno 1867 non colse impreparato l'esercito pontificio che vinse, anche grazie all'uso della ferrovia, a Mentana. Quando, nel 1870, l'esito della guerra franco-prussiana, isolò la Santa Sede, Kanzler si pronunziò in favore di una resistenza a oltranza. All'indomani del 20 settembre 1870 e la presa di Roma da parte dell'esercito del Regno d'Italia, si stabilì con la famiglia in Vaticano. Morì nel 1888.
$Kanzler.nl_NL: Hermann [von] Kanzler werd in 1822 geboren in Weingarten in het Groothertogdom Baden, als zoon van Maximilian en Maria Magdalena Krehmer. Hij ging naar de militaire hogeschool in Karlsruhe en begon vervolgens zijn militaire loopbaan. In 1841 behaalde hij de rang van luitenant, maar in 1844 nam hij ontslag uit het groothertogelijke leger nadat hij, uit katholieke geloofsoverwegingen, had geweigerd een duel uit te vechten met een andere militair die hem had uitgedaagd. Hij verbleef een paar maanden in Engeland en kwam in 1845 naar Rome waar hij zich als cadet aanmeldde bij de Buitenlandse Brigade van het pauselijk leger. In 1848 nam hij met zijn eenheid deel aan de beginfase van de Eerste Italiaanse Onafhankelijkheidsoorlog in Noord-Italië; daarbij onderscheidde hij zich tijdens de verdediging van Vicenza. In 1849 voegde hij zich bij Pius IX in Gaeta na diens vlucht uit Rome, waar even later de Romeinse Republiek zou worden uitgeroepen. Nadat de pauselijke regering weer naar Rome was teruggekeerd (1850), werd hij in 1854 bevorderd tot majoor en in 1855 tot luitenant-kolonel. Tussen 1859 en 1860 was hij een van de verantwoordelijken voor de reorganisatie van de troepen van de Pauselijke Staat, waarvan het grondgebied aanzienlijk was verkleind na het einde van de Tweede Italiaanse Onafhankelijkheidsoorlog. In 1865, na de dood van generaal Lamoricière, werd hij bevorderd tot luitenant-generaal en volgde hij De Merode op als (waarnemend) minister van Oorlog. De expeditie van Garibaldi in de herfst van 1867 trof het pauselijke leger niet onvoorbereid; het laatste won, mede dankzij het gebruik van de spoorweg, de Slag bij Mentana. Toen in 1870 de Heilige Stoel vanwege de Frans-Duitse Oorlog geïsoleerd raakte, sprak Kanzler uit zich tot het laatst te willen blijven verzetten tegen de Italiaanse aanspraken. Na 20 september 1870, toen het leger van het Koninkrijk Italië Rome innam, vestigde hij zich met zijn gezin in het Vaticaan. Hij stierf in 1888.

$Kessels.en_GB: Mathieu (Matthijs, Matteo) Kessels was the most important neo-classical sculptor from the Southern Netherlands. After an apprenticeship at Joseph Carberlain's studio in St Petersburg (1806-1814), he settled in Rome in 1817. There he worked at Bertel Thorvaldsen's workshop until around 1819. His career took off when he won the sculpture competition of the Roman Accademia di San Luca in 1819, at the intercession of Antonio Canova. Among his best-known works are a Discus Thrower (1822) for William Cavendish, Duke of Devonshire, a Bust of Maarten Tromp (1823) for the Valhalla of Ludwig (crown prince) of Bavaria, a Resting Mars for King William I (1825) and the Funerary Monument for Countess De Celles (1832). In 1824, Kessels became a member of the royal academies of Antwerp and Amsterdam  and provisor of the San Giuliano dei Fiammingh in Rome; in 1829, he joined the Accademia di San Luca as professor. He died of tuberculosis on 3 March 1836. His friend and pupil Jan-Anthonie van der Ven designed a funerary monument for the San Giuliano dei Fiamminghi; a simple tombstone was placed instead. Kessels was a personal friend of Auguste Count de Liedekerke-Beaufort, ambassador of the (United) Kingdom of the Netherlands to the Holy See since 1829. After Kessels' death, the Belgian government bought all his (plaster) works in his workshop, which can still be seen today at the Royal Museum of Fine Arts in Brussels.
$Kessels.it_IT: Mathieu (Matthijs, Matteo) Kessels è stato il più importante scultore neoclassico dei Paesi Bassi meridionali. Dopo un apprendistato presso lo studio di Joseph Carberlain a San Pietroburgo (1806-1814), si stabilì a Roma nel 1817. Qui lavorò presso la bottega di Bertel Thorvaldsen fino al 1819 circa. La sua carriera decollò quando vinse il concorso di scultura dell'Accademia romana di San Luca nel 1819, per intercessione di Antonio Canova. Tra le sue opere più note ci sono un Lanciatore del disco (1822) per William Cavendish, duca di Devonshire, un busto di Maarten Tromp (1823) per il Valhalla di Ludwig (principe ereditario) di Baviera, un Marte in riposo per il re Guglielmo I (1825) e il monumento funebre per la contessa De Celles (1832). Nel 1824 Kessels divenne membro delle accademie reali di Anversa e Amsterdam e procuratore del San Giuliano dei Fiammingh a Roma; nel 1829 entrò come professore all'Accademia di San Luca. Morì di tubercolosi il 3 marzo 1836. Il suo amico e allievo Jan-Anthonie van der Ven progettò un monumento funebre per San Giuliano dei Fiamminghi; al suo posto fu posta una semplice lapide. Kessels era amico personale del conte Auguste de Liedekerke-Beaufort, ambasciatore del Regno (Unito) dei Paesi Bassi presso la Santa Sede dal 1829. Dopo la morte di Kessels, il governo belga acquistò tutte le sue opere (in gesso) nel suo laboratorio, che ancora oggi possono essere ammirate al Museo reale di belle arti di Bruxelles.
$Kessels.nl_NL: Mathieu (Matthijs, Matteo) Kessels was de belangrijkste Zuid-Nederlandse neo-classicistische beeldhouwer. Na een leertijd in het atelier van Joseph Carberlain in St.-Petersburg (1806-1814) streek hij in 1817 in Rome neer. Daar werkte hij tot ca. 1819 in het atelier Bertel Thorvaldsen. Zijn carrière nam een hoge vlucht toen hij in 1819, op voorspraak van Antonio Canova, het beeldhouwconcours van de Romeinse Accademia di San Luca won. Tot zijn bekendste werken behoren een Discuswerper (1822) voor William Cavendish, hertog van Devonshire, een Buste van Maarten Tromp (1823) voor het Walhalla van Ludwig (kroonprins) van Beieren, een Rustende Mars voor Koning Willem I (1825) en het grafmonument voor gravin De Celles (1832). In 1824 werd Kessels lid van de koninklijke academies van Antwerpen en Amsterdam en provisor van de San Giuliano dei Fiammingh in Rome; in 1829 trad hij aan als professor aan de Accademia di San Luca. Hij overleed op 3 maart 1836 aan tuberculose. Zijn vriend en leerling Jan-Anthonie van der Ven ontwierp een grafmonument voor de San Giuliano dei Fiamminghi; in plaats daarvan werd een eenvoudige zerk geplaatst. Kessels was persoonlijk bevriend met Auguste graaf de Liedekerke-Beaufort, sinds 1829 ambassadeur van het (Verenigd) Koninkrijk der Nederlanden bij de Heilige Stoel. Na Kessels dood kocht de Belgische overheid al zijn (gipsen) werken uit zijn atelier, die nu nog te zien zijn in het Koninklijk Museum voor Schone Kunsten in Brussel.

$King.en_GB: Rufus King was an American soldier, journalist and diplomat. King was born in New York City and entered West Point at age fifteen. In 1833 he went on to serve as an army engineer in Virginia, but he left the military to become the editor of the Albany Evening Journal. In 1845, King went to Milwaukee, where he would direct the Milwaukee Sentinel until 1861. President Lincoln, with whom King later became close friends, appointed him as ambassador to the Holy See in 1861. When King heard of the attack on Fort Sumter (near Charleston), however, he rushed back and spent the next two years in command of the regiments that would later be called the Iron Brigade. After his discharge from the military in 1863, King was reappointed ambassador to the Holy See. In 1865, he played a decisive role in capturing John Surratt, the suspected conspirator involved in Lincoln's assassination who had escaped to Europe. After returning to the United States in 1867, King worked as a tax collector in New York City, until his health failed him and he became an invalid.
$King.it_IT: Rufus King fu un soldato, giornalista e diplomatico americano. King nacque a New York City ed entrò a West Point all'età di quindici anni. Nel 1833 prestò servizio come ingegnere militare in Virginia, ma lasciò l'esercito per diventare redattore dell' Albany Evening Journal. Nel 1845, King andò a Milwaukee, dove avrebbe diretto la Milwaukee Sentinel fino al 1861. Il presidente Lincoln, con il quale King in seguito divenne amico intimo, lo nominò ambasciatore presso la Santa Sede nel 1861. Quando King seppe dell'attacco a Fort Sumter (vicino a Charleston) tornò di corsa e trascorse i due anni successivi al comando dei reggimenti che in seguito sarebbero stati chiamati la Brigata di Ferro. Dopo il suo congedo dall'esercito nel 1863, King fu riconfermato ambasciatore presso la Santa Sede. Nel 1865, giocò un ruolo decisivo nella cattura di John Surratt, il sospetto cospiratore coinvolto nell'assassinio di Lincoln che era fuggito in Europa. Dopo essere tornato negli Stati Uniti nel 1867, King lavorò come esattore delle tasse a New York City, finché la sua salute non venne meno e divenne invalido.
$King.nl_NL: Rufus King was een Amerikaans militair, journalist en diplomaat. King werd geboren in New York City en vertrok op zijn vijftiende naar West Point. In 1833 ging hij als ingenieur in Virginia werken, maar hij verliet het leger om redacteur te worden van het Albany Evening Journal. In 1845 vertrok hij naar Milwaukee, waar hij tot 1861 redacteur was van de Milwaukee Sentinel. President Lincoln, met wie King later goede vrienden werd, benoemde hem tot ambassadeur bij de Heilige Stoel in 1861. Toen King echter hoorde van de aanval op Fort Sumter (vlakbij Charleston), keerde hij terug en leidde in de daaropvolgende twee jaar de regimenten die later bekend kwamen te staan als de 'Iron Brigade'. Pas in 1863 nam hij zijn benoeming als ambassadeur in Rome weer op. Daarbij speelde hij in 1865 een belangrijke rol bij de opsporing van John Surratt, die werd verdacht van samenzwering tot de moord op president Lincoln en naar Europa was ontsnapt. Nadat King in 1867 naar de Verenigde Staten was teruggekeerd, werkte hij als belastinginner in New York City, tot hij door gezondheidsproblemen invalide werd.

$Koelman.en_GB: Johan (or Jan) Hendrik Koelman was born in The Hague as the son of a carpenter. As a young painter, he became an apprentice of Cornelis Kruseman and in 1839 he won the Prix de Rome awarded by the Academy of Fine Arts in Amsterdam. At the end of 1840, he traveled to Rome, together with painter and lithographer Adrianus Ehnle. There he turned to genre and portrait painting, much to the irritation of the Dutch ambassador in Rome count Liedekerke-de Beaufort and the council of the Amsterdam Academy. As a portraitist and miniaturist, he soon received commissions from the highest circles. Koelman exhibited his works in Rome at the Società degli Amatori e Cultori delle Belle Arti multiple times, while remained known in the Netherlands as well, thanks to reproductions in the Dutch art magazine Kunstkronijk. Except for a visit to the Netherlands in 1869 (ref.: visitor registry of the Dordrechts Museum 1869, p. 22), Koelman stayed in Rome until his death. He had already converted to catholicism buy the end of 1844 when he married the painter Enrichetta Fioroni. According to Liedekerke, Koelman was a fanatical supporter of the Roman Republic (1849). Whether or not he actually served in the Civic Guard, as his brother Johan Philip claims, is unclear.
$Koelman.it_IT: Johan (o Jan) Hendrik Koelman nacque a L'Aia, figlio di un falegname. Da giovane pittore, divenne allievo di Cornelis Kruseman e nel 1839 vinse il Prix de Rome assegnato dall'Accademia di Belle Arti di Amsterdam. Alla fine del 1840 si recò a Roma insieme al pittore e litografo Adrianus Ehnle. Qui si dedicò alla pittura di genere e al ritratto, con grande irritazione del conte Liedekerke-de Beaufort dell'ambasciatore olandese a Roma e del consiglio dell'Accademia di Amsterdam. Come ritrattista e miniatore, ricevette presto commissioni dai circoli più alti. Koelman espose più volte le sue opere a Roma presso la Società degli Amatori e Cultori delle Belle Arti, pur rimanendo conosciuto anche nei Paesi Bassi, grazie alle riproduzioni sulla rivista d'arte olandese Kunstkronijk. Fatta eccezione per una visita nei Paesi Bassi nel 1869 (rif.: registro dei visitatori del Museo di Dordrechts 1869, p. 22), Koelman rimase a Roma fino alla sua morte. Si era già convertito al cattolicesimo alla fine del 1844 quando sposò la pittrice Enrichetta Fioroni. Secondo Liedekerke, Koelman era un fanatico sostenitore della Repubblica Romana (1849). Non è chiaro se abbia effettivamente prestato servizio nella Guardia Civica, come sostiene suo fratello Johan Philip.
$Koelman.nl_NL: Johan (of Jan) Hendrik Koelman werd geboren in Den Haag als zoon van een timmerman. Hij ging als schilder in de leer bij Cornelis Kruseman en won in 1839 de Groote Prijs voor historieschilderkunst van de Amsterdamse academie. Met schilder en lithograaf Adrianus Ehnle reisde hij eind 1840 naar Rome, waar hij, tot ergernis van de Nederlandse ambassadeur graaf Liedekerke-de Beaufort en de raad van de academie, de weg van de genre- en portretkunst insloeg. Als portrettist en miniaturist kreeg hij weldra opdrachten uit de hoogste kringen. Hij exposeerde in Rome meermaals bij de Società degli Amatori e Cultori delle Belle Arti, en ook in Nederland bleef zijn werk bekend, dankzij reproducties in de Kunstkronijk. Met uitzondering van een bezoek aan Nederland in 1869 (bezoekersregister Dordrechts Museum 1869, p. 22) bleef Koelman tot zijn dood in Rome. Eind 1844 was hij al katholiek geworden en getrouwd met de schilderes Enrichetta Fioroni. Volgens Liedekerke was Koelman fanatiek sympathisant met de Romeinse Republiek (1849). Of hij inderdaad ook in de Romeinse burgerwacht diende, zoals zijn broer Johan Philip beweert, blijft onduidelijk.

$Kolb.en_GB: Karl von Kolb was a German who established a trading house and shipping firm in Rome in 1827-1828 (Via del Pozzo delle Cornacchie 63-64 and Piazza S. Luigi dei Francesi 34). That firm was eventually transformed into a bank. From 1833, Kolb was consul for the Kingdom of Württemberg and, on occasion, also for the grand duchies of Baden and Hessen. In 1841, he was promoted to envoy to the Holy See on behalf of Württemberg, even though he was a Protestant. In 1847, he sold a large collection of old Italian coins to the British Museum. Some of his official notices from Rome can be accessed online via the website of the Landesarchiv Baden-Württemberg. Kolb was buried at the non-Catholic cemetery near the Pyramid of Cestius in Rome.
$Kolb.it_IT: Karl von Kolb fu un tedesco che fondò una casa commerciale e una compagnia di spedizioni a Roma nel 1827-1828 (Via del Pozzo delle Cornacchie 63-64 e Piazza S. Luigi dei Francesi 34). Quella società fu successivamente trasformata in una banca. Dal 1833 Kolb fu console del Regno del Württemberg e, talvolta, anche dei granducati del Baden e dell'Assia. Nel 1841 fu promosso inviato presso la Santa Sede per conto del Württemberg, sebbene fosse protestante. Nel 1847 vendette una vasta collezione di antiche monete italiane al British Museum. Alcuni dei suoi comunicati ufficiali da Roma sono consultabili online tramite il sito del Landesarchiv Baden-Württemberg. Kolb fu sepolto nel cimitero acattolico vicino alla Piramide Cestia a Roma.
$Kolb.nl_NL: Karl von Kolb was een Duitser die in 1827-1828 een handelshuis annex expeditiefirma in Rome vestigde (Via del Pozzo delle Cornacchie 63-64 en Piazza S. Luigi dei Francesi 34). Die firma werd uiteindelijk omgevormd tot een bank. Vanaf 1833 was Kolb consul voor het Koninkrijk Württemberg en bij gelegenheid ook voor de groothertogdommen Baden en Hessen. In 1841 werd hij bevorderd tot gezant bij de Heilige Stoel namens Württemberg, ook al was hij protestant. In 1847 verkocht hij een grote hoeveelheid oude Italiaanse munten aan het British Museum. Sommige van zijn ambtsberichten uit Rome zijn online te raadplegen via de website van het Landesarchiv Baden-Württemberg. Kolb werd begraven op de niet-katholieke begraafplaats bij de Piramide van Cestius te Rome.

$Koningh.en_GB: John, also Iohannes de Koningh was a Dutch sculptor. His father was the painter Leendert de Koning(h) (1777-1849) from Dordrecht; John was born during his parents' stay in London (1801-1816, with interruptions). Like his sister and two brothers, he was taught by his father, continuing his studies as a sculptor at the Antwerp Academy from 1828-1830. He then travelled around Europe for a decade, maintaining himself with his art. In 1841, he won the Prix de Rome of the Royal Academy of Amsterdam. Via Paris, he travelled to the Eternal City, where he arrived on 2 January 1842. Unlike his predecessor in the Prix de Rome, Jan Hendrik Koelman, De Koningh did adhere to the new regulations for the Prix de Rome, and, in exchange for an annual fee of 1,200 guilders for four years, he regularly sent works to the exhibitions of Living Masters in Amsterdam and The Hague. This much is clear from the correspondence of the Academy Council with the Dutch envoy in Rome, count Liedekerke de Beaufort. De Koningh mainly made statues of saints and mythological figures. He died on 29 June 1845 in Genoa from the effects of a lung condition, during his return trip to the Netherlands. J.H. Koelman painted his portrait (c. 1843-1844), now unknown.
$Koningh.it_IT: John, anche Iohannes de Koningh fu uno scultore olandese. Suo padre era il pittore Leendert de Koning(h) (1777-1849) di Dordrecht; John nacque durante il soggiorno dei suoi genitori a Londra (1801-1816, con interruzioni). Come sua sorella e i suoi due fratelli, fu allievo del padre, continuando i suoi studi come scultore presso l'Accademia di Anversa dal 1828 al 1830. Viaggiò per l'Europa per un decennio, mantenendosi con la sua arte. Nel 1841 vinse il Prix de Rome della Royal Academy di Amsterdam. Da Parigi, si recò nella Città Eterna, dove arrivò il 2 gennaio 1842. A differenza del suo predecessore al Prix de Rome, Jan Hendrik Koelman, De Koningh aderì al nuovo regolamento del Prix de Rome e, in cambio di una quota annua di 1.200 fiorini per quattro anni, inviò regolarmente opere alle mostre di Living Masters ad Amsterdam e all'Aia. Ciò emerge chiaramente dalla corrispondenza del Consiglio dell'Accademia con l'inviato olandese a Roma, il conte Liedekerke de Beaufort. De Koningh realizzò principalmente statue di santi e figure mitologiche. Morì il 29 giugno 1845 a Genova per gli effetti di una malattia polmonare, durante il viaggio di ritorno nei Paesi Bassi. J.H. Koelman dipinse il suo ritratto (1843-1844 circa), ora di ubicazione ignota.
$Koningh.nl_NL: John, ook wel Iohannes de Koningh was een Nederlands beeldhouwer. Zijn vader was de schilder Leendert de Koning(h) (1777-1849), afkomstig uit Dordrecht; John werd geboren tijdens het verblijf van zijn ouders in Londen (1801-1816, met onderbrekingen). Net als zijn zus en twee broers kreeg hij les van zijn vader, om zich van 1828-1830 als beeldhouwer verder te bekwamen aan de Antwerpse academie. Daarna reisde hij een decennium Europa rond, zichzelf met zijn kunst onderhoudend. In 1841 won hij de Prix de Rome van de Koninklijke Academie van Amsterdam. Via Parijs reisde hij naar de Eeuwige Stad, waar hij op 2 januari 1842 aankwam. Anders dan zijn voorganger in de Romeprijs, Jan Hendrik Koelman, hield De Koningh zich wel aan het nieuwe reglement voor de Prix de Rome, en zond, in ruil voor een jaargeld à 1200,- gulden voor vier jaar, regelmatig werken naar de tentoonstellingen van Levende Meesters in Amsterdam en Den Haag. Zoveel blijkt ook uit de correspondentie van de Raad van de Academie met de gezant in Rome, graaf Liedekerke de Beaufort. De Koningh maakte vooral heiligenbeelden en mythologische figuren. Hij stierf op 29 juni 1845 in Genua aan de gevolgen van een longaandoening, tijdens zijn terugreis naar Nederland. J.H. Koelman schilderde zijn portret (ca. 1843-1844), nu helaas onbekend.

$Kruseman.en_GB: Jan Diederik Kruseman was a Dutch amateur painter, draughtsman and etcher from a family that produced several artists. He was the nephew of the better-known artist Cornelis Kruseman (1797-1857), whom - after studying (1841-1846) at the Hague Academy with J.E.J. van de Berg - he followed to Italy in 1847. There he stayed for about a year, notably in Rome and Trieste. Apart from cityscapes, his works include church interiors, portraits and genre pieces. From 1853, he was a member of the Hague Etching Club and from 1858 to 1862 he was secretary of the painterly society Pulchri Studio. From 1862 to 1811, he stayed in the Dutch East Indies to take over the directorship of his father's sugar factory (cf. his Reflections on the Sugar Crisis, 1886). In 1868, he was appointed consul for the Kingdom of Italy in Surabaya (Dutch East Indies); in 1875, he was awarded a knighthood in the Order of the Crown of Italy. After his death, he left a collection of mainly Dutch seventeenth-century paintings, which was auctioned at Frederik Muller in Amsterdam in 1919 (catalogue published the same year).
$Kruseman.it_IT: Jan Diederik Kruseman fu un pittore dilettante, disegnatore e incisore olandese proveniente da una famiglia dalla quale vennero diversi artisti. Era il nipote del più noto artista Cornelis Kruseman (1797-1857), il quale - dopo aver studiato (1841-1846) all'Accademia dell'Aja con J.E.J. van de Berg – lo seguì in Italia nel 1847. Lì rimase per circa un anno, in particolare a Roma e Trieste. Oltre ai paesaggi urbani, le sue opere includono interni di chiese, ritratti e pezzi di genere. Dal 1853 fu membro del Club dell'Acquaforte dell'Aja e dal 1858 al 1862 fu segretario della società pittorica Pulchri Studio. Dal 1862 al 1811 soggiornò nelle Indie orientali olandesi per assumere la direzione dello zuccherificio del padre (cfr. Riflessioni sulla crisi dello zucchero, 1886). Nel 1868 fu nominato console del Regno d'Italia a Surabaya (Indie orientali olandesi); nel 1875 fu insignito del cavalierato dell'Ordine della Corona d'Italia. Dopo la sua morte lasciò una collezione di dipinti prevalentemente olandesi del XVII secolo, che fu messa all'asta da Frederik Muller ad Amsterdam nel 1919 (catalogo pubblicato lo stesso anno).
$Kruseman.nl_NL: Jan Diederik Kruseman was een Nederlandse amateurschilder, tekenaar en etser uit een familie die verschillende kunstenaars voortbracht. Hij was de oomzegger van de bekendere kunstenaar Cornelis Kruseman (1797-1857), die hij – na zijn studie (1841-1846) aan de Haagse academie bij J.E.J. van de Berg - in 1847 volgde naar Italië. Daar bleef hij ongeveer een jaar, met name in Rome en Triëst. Behalve stadsgezichten zijn van hem ook kerkinterieurs, portretten en genrestukken bekend. Vanaf 1853 was hij lid van de Haagsche Etsclub en van 1858 tot 1862 was hij secretaris van het schilderkunstig genootschap Pulchri Studio. Van 1862 tot 1811 verbleef hij in Nederlands-Indië om het directeurschap van de suikerfabriek van zijn vader over te nemen (vgl. zijn Beschouwingen over de suikercrisis, 1886). In 1868 werd hij benoemd tot consul voor het Koninkrijk Italië in Soerabaja; in 1875 werd hij onderscheiden als ridder in de orde van de Kroon van Italië. Na zijn dood liet hij een collectie van met name Nederlandse zeventiende-eeuwse schilderijen na, die in 1919 bij Frederik Muller in Amsterdam werd geveild (met catalogus).

$Lambruschini.en_GB: Luigi Lambruschini was archbishop from Genoa from 1819 onwards, and was elevated to the cardinalate in 1831 by pope Gregory XVI. He served as the pope's secretary of state from 1836 until Gregory's death in 1846. After the first voting round at the conclave of 1846, Lambruschini was considered 'papabile', but he was quickly soon surpassed by cardinal Giovanni Maria Mastai-Ferretti, the future Pius IX. The new pope did not reappoint the conservative Lambruschini as his secretary of state. However, once Pius IX had thrown his liberal sympathies overboard and pursued an increasingly reactionary line, Lambruschini regained influence on the Church policy. From 1848 to 1850, he stayed in the pope's entourage in Gaeta and served as head of the committee which prepared the Dogma of Immaculate Conception (proclaimed through the bull Ineffabilis Deus, 8 December 1854).
$Lambruschini.it_IT: Luigi Lambruschini fu arcivescovo di Genova dal 1819, e fu elevato al cardinalato nel 1831 da papa Gregorio XVI. Fu Segretario di stato del papa dal 1836 fino alla morte di Gregorio nel 1846. Dopo la prima votazione del conclave del 1846, Lambruschini fu considerato 'papabile', ma fu presto superato dal cardinale Giovanni Maria Mastai-Ferretti, il futuro Pio IX. Il nuovo papa non confermò il conservatore Lambruschini come suo segretario di Stato. Tuttavia, una volta che Pio IX ebbe ripudiato le sue simpatie liberali e perseguito una linea sempre più reazionaria, Lambruschini riacquistò influenza sulla politica della Chiesa. Dal 1848 al 1850 seguì il papa a Gaeta e fu a capo della commissione che preparò il dogma dell'Immacolata Concezione (proclamato con la bolla Ineffabilis Deus, 8 dicembre 1854).
$Lambruschini.nl_NL: Luigi Lambruschini was vanaf 1819 aartsbisschop van Genua en werd in 1831 tot kardinaal gewijd door paus Gregorius XVI, onder wie hij vanaf 1836 ook staatssecretaris (en daarmee regeringsleider) was. Na de dood van Gregorius in 1846 was Lambruschini bij de eerste stemming op het conclaaf nog favoriet voor het pausschap, maar weldra werd hij overvleugeld door kardinaal Giovanni Maria Mastai-Ferretti, de latere Pius IX. De nieuwe paus herbenoemde de aartsconservatieve Lambruschini niet als staatssecretaris. Nadat Pius IX evenwel zijn liberale sympathieën overboord had gegooid, kreeg Lambruschini opnieuw invloed op diens beleid, vooral toen de paus een toenemend reactionaire koers ging varen. Van 1848 tot 1850 verbleef hij in het gevolg van de paus in Gaeta en was hij onder meer actief als voorzitter van de commissie die de afkondiging van het Dogma van de Onbevlekte Ontvangenis voorbereidde (afgekondigd met de bul Ineffabilis Deus, 8 december 1854).

$Lansberge.en_GB: Johan Wilhelm van Lansberge was born the son of Reinhart Frans van Lansberge (1804-1873), governor of Curaçao (1856-1859) and Suriname (1859-1867), and Victoria Maria Rodriguez y Escobar (1806-1880). He attended grammar school in Zutphen and studied law in Leiden, before beginning his career as a diplomat in 1856. His posts included attaché in Paris and Madrid, where he also became envoy secretary. In that position, he was transferred to St Petersburg in 1857 and to Brussels in 1860. In 1864, he returned to Paris as Council of Legation before becoming resident minister there, a post he also held temporarily in London in 1871, before an appointment followed as plenipotentiary to the Belgian king. n that position, he advocated the legitimacy of the Dutch intention to dam the river Scheldt. On 17 December 1874, he was appointed governor-general of the Dutch East Indies, a post he retained until 1881. While he made a strong case for the further implementation of the abolition of slavery, established higher civil schools and agricultural schools on Java, his reign was also marked by wars against 'internal' resistance, on Sumatra, Celebes and especially in Aceh, where he tried in vain to bring the conflict to an end that had flared up shortly before he had taken office (1873). His portrait painted by A. van den Berg was intended for the governor-general's portrait gallery in the Rijswijk Palace in Jakarta.
$Lansberge.it_IT: Johan Wilhelm van Lansberge nacque come figlio di Reinhart Frans van Lansberge (1804-1873), governatore di Curaçao (1856-1859) e del Suriname (1859-1867), e Victoria Maria Rodriguez y Escobar (1806-1880). Frequentò il liceo classico a Zutphen e studiò legge a Leida, prima di iniziare la sua carriera diplomatica nel 1856. I suoi incarichi includevano quello di addetto a Parigi e Madrid, dove divenne anche segretario dell'inviato. In quella posizione, fu trasferito a San Pietroburgo nel 1857 e a Bruxelles nel 1860. Nel 1864, tornò a Parigi come parte del Consiglio di Legazione prima di diventarvi ministro residente, incarico che mantenne temporaneamente anche a Londra nel 1871, prima di essere nominato plenipotenziario del re belga. In quella posizione, sostenne la legittimità dell'intenzione olandese di costruire una diga sul fiume Schelda. Il 17 dicembre 1874 fu nominato governatore generale delle Indie orientali olandesi, carica che mantenne fino al 1881. Se da un lato sostenne con forza l'ulteriore attuazione dell'abolizione della schiavitù, dall'altro istituì scuole civili superiori e scuole agricole a Giava, il suo governo fu segnato anche da guerre contro la resistenza 'interna', a Sumatra, Celebes e soprattutto ad Aceh, dove cercò invano di porre fine al conflitto scoppiato poco prima della sua presa. ufficio (1873). Il suo ritratto dipinto da A. van den Berg era destinato alla galleria dei ritratti del governatore generale nel Palazzo Rijswijk a Giakarta.
$Lansberge.nl_NL: Johan Wilhelm van Lansberge werd geboren als zoon van Reinhart Frans van Lansberge (1804-1873), gouverneur van Curaçao (1856-1859) en Suriname (1859-1867), en Victoria Maria Rodriguez y Escobar (1806-1880). Hij bezocht het gymnasium in Zutphen en studeerde rechten in Leiden, voordat in 1856 zijn carrière als diplomaat een aanvang nam. Hij was onder meer attaché in Parijs en Madrid, waar hij ook gezantschapssecretaris werd. In die functie werd hij in 1857 overgeplaatst naar St. Petersburg en in 1860 naar Brussel. In 1864 keerde hij als Raad van Legatie naar Parijs terug, alvorens er minister-resident te worden, een functie die hij in 1871 ook tijdelijk in Londen bekleedde, voordat een benoeming als gevolmachtigd gezant bij de Belgische koning volgde. In die functie bepleitte hij de rechtmatigheid van het Nederlandse voornemen de Schelde af te dammen. Op 17 december 1874 werd hij tot gouverneur-generaal van Nederlands-Indië benoemd, een functie die hij tot 1881 behield. Hij maakte zich weliswaar sterk voor de verdere implementatie van de afschaffing van de slavernij, vestigde hogere burgerscholen en landbouwscholen op Java, maar zijn bewind werd ook gekenmerkt door oorlogen tegen 'binnenlands' verzet, op Sumatra, Celebes en vooral in Atjeh, waar hij vergeefs probeerde het conflict dat kort voor zijn aantreden was opgelaaid (1873) tot een einde te brengen. Het portret dat A. van den Berg van hem schilderde was bestemd voor de portrettengalerij van de gouveneurs-generaal in het paleis Rijswijk in Jakarta.

$Lanza.en_GB: Giovanni Lanza was born in Casale Monferrato in 1810. He graduated in medicine in 1832 in Turin, where he was one of the animators of the Agrarian Association, becoming one of the leading exponents of the Piedmontese liberal group. In 1848 he left as a volunteer for Lombardy to fight the Austrians during the First Italian War of Independence; in May that year he was elected as a deputy to the Parlamento Subalpino, the first parliamento of the Kingdom of Sardinia. His parliamentary career, which lasted uninterruptedly for fourteen legislatures, took a turn with his rapprochement with Cavour, with whom he collaborated during the preparation of the Piemontese participation in the Crimean War. He was called to lead the Ministry of Education (1855), then Finance (1858) and in 1860 he was elected President of the Chamber of Deputies. From that moment he became one of the most influential leaders of the Right. In 1864 he was Minister of the Interior and advocated the transfer of the capital to Rome. Because he was against the milling levy, he resigned in August 1865. He was President of the Italian Chamber (1867-68 and 1869), and was appointed Prime Minister in 1869. After the Capture of Rome (20 September 1870) relations between Italy and the Holy See were regulated by the Law of (Papal) Guarantees promoted by his department (1871), which became an important point of reference in Italian foreign policy. In June 1873, he resigned after the Chamber voted against certain financial measures proposed by Sella. From 1878 he was president of the Constitutional Association (Associazione costituzionale) in Turin. He died in Rome in 1882.
$Lanza.it_IT: Giovanni Lanza nacque a Casale Monferrato nel 1810. Si laureò in medicina nel 1832 a Torino dove fu uno degli animatori dell'Associazione agraria diventando uno dei maggiori esponenti del gruppo liberale piemontese. Nel 1848 partì come volontario in Lombardia per combattere gli austriaci durante la Prima guerra d'Indipendenza; nel maggio fu eletto deputato al Parlamento subalpino. La sua carriera parlamentare, che durò ininterrottamente per quattordici legislature, conobbe una svolta con l'avvicinamento a Cavour, con il quale iniziò a collaborare durante la preparazione della guerra di Crimea. Venne chiamato al ministero dell'Istruzione (1855), poi alle Finanze (1858) e nel 1860 fu eletto presidente della Camera. Divenne uno dei capi più autorevoli della Destra. Nel 1864 fu ministro dell'Interno e si pronunciò per il trasferimento della capitale a Roma. Si dimise nell'agosto 1865 perché contrario alla tassa sul macinato. Fu presidente della Camera (1867-68 e 1869), e venne nominato presidente del Consiglio nel 1869. Dopo la presa di Roma (20 settembre 1870) i rapporti tra l'Italia e la Santa Sede furono regolati dalla legge delle guarentigie promossa dal suo dicastero (1871) che divenne un punto di riferimento costante della politica estera italiana. Nel giugno 1873 si dimise dopo il voto contrario della Camera ad alcuni provvedimenti finanziari proposti da Sella. Dal 1878 fu presidente dell'Associazione costituzionale di Torino. Morì a Roma nel 1882
$Lanza.nl_NL: Giovanni Lanza werd in 1810 geboren in Casale Monferrato. Hij studeerde in 1832 af in de geneeskunde in Turijn, waar hij een van de initiatiefnemers van de Agrarische Vereniging (Associazione agraria) was en een van de belangrijkste exponenten van de Piemontese liberale groep werd. In 1848 vertrok hij als vrijwilliger naar Lombardije om tegen de Oostenrijkers te vechten tijdens de Eerste Italiaanse Onafhankelijkheidsoorlog; in mei van dat jaar werd hij gekozen als afgevaardigde in het Parlamento Subalpino, het eerste parlement van het Koninkrijk Sardinië. Zijn parlementaire carrière, die veertien zittingsperiodes onafgebroken duurde, nam een nieuwe wending na zijn toenadering tot Cavour, met wie hij begon samen te werken tijdens de voorbereiding van de Piemontese deelname aan de Krimoorlog. Hij werd benoemd tot minister van Onderwijs (1855), daarna  Financiën (1858) en in 1860 werd hij gekozen tot Voorzitter van de Kamer van Afgevaardigden. Vanaf dat moment werd hij een van de invloedrijkste leiders van rechts. In 1864 was hij minister van Binnenlandse Zaken en pleitte hij voor de verplaatsing van de hoofdstad naar Rome. Hij naam in augustus 1865 ontslag omdat hij tegen de belastingen op het gemaal was. Hij was Kamervoorzitter (1867-68 en 1869) en werd in 1869 tot premier benoemd. Na de inname van Rome (20 september 1870) werden de betrekkingen tussen Italië en de Heilige Stoel geregeld door de zogenaamde (Pauselijke) Garantiewet, die door zijn departement werd ontwikkeld (1871) en een belangrijke pijler van de Italiaanse buitenlandse politiek werd. In juni 1873 nam hij ontslag nadat de Kamer tegen bepaalde financiële maatregelen had gestemd die door Q. Sella waren voorgesteld. Vanaf 1878 was hij voorzitter van de Constitutionele Vereniging (Associazione costituzionale) van Turijn. Hij stierf in Rome in 1882.

$Larderel.en_GB: Francis de Larderel was born in Vienne, France, in 1789 to Abel Philibert and Marie Acloque. He moved to Livorno during the Napoleonic era and started a business selling trinkets. Around 1820, he started developing a business for the extraction and production of boric acid, eventually affirming himself as the largest entrepreneur in Grand Duchy of Tuscany. With other partners, he founded an industrial company and began to make frequent trips abroad, thereby establishing a network with European industrialists and scientists. In 1835, he succeeded in obtaining full ownership of the company and secured a monopoly on the production of boric acid, becoming a leading industrial player in Tuscany. Having obtained the title of count, he gained access to the grand ducal court, forging marriage ties with families of great prestige and the (Italian) nobility, such as the Rucellai, the Salviati and even the Savoia. He was Gonfaloniere of Livorno from February 1847 to May 1848, did his utmost to build the Teatro Leopoldo and developed a wide range of philanthropic initiatives. Larderel was a moderate liberal; he adhered to the programme for the emancipation of the Jews, supported the institution of the Civic Guard and advocated the freedom of the press. He died in Florence on 5 June 1858.
$Larderel.it_IT: Francesco de Larderel nacque a Vienne, in Francia, nel 1789 da Abel Philibert, e da Marie Acloque. Trasferitosi a Livorno in età napoleonica, iniziò una attività di 'chincagliere'. Intorno al 1820 promosse e sviluppò l'industria dell'acido borico, si impose così come il maggiore imprenditore della Toscana granducale. Fondò insieme al altri soci una società industriale e iniziò a fare frequenti viaggi per stringere contatti con industriali e scienziati europei. Nel 1835, il Lardel riuscì a ottenere la piena proprietà dell'impresa e si assicurò il monopolio della produzione di acido borico, divenendo un protagonista dell'industria in Toscana. Ottenuto il titolo nobiliare di conte ebbe accesso alla corte granducale stringendo legami matrimoniali con famiglie di grande prestigio e nobiltà, come i Rucellai e i Salviati e anche con i Savoia. Fu Gonfaloniere di Livorno dal febbraio 1847 al maggio 1848, e si prodigò per la costruzione del teatro Leopoldo oltre a continuare una intensa attività filantropica. Fu un liberale moderato; aderì al programma di emancipazione degli ebrei; sostenne l'istituzione della Guardia Civica e la libertà di stampa. Morì a Firenze il 5 giugno 1858.
$Larderel.nl_NL: Francis de Larderel werd in 1789 geboren in Vienne, Frankrijk, als zoon van Abel Philibert en Marie Acloque. Hij verhuisde naar Livorno tijdens de Napoleontische tijd en begon een handel in snuisterijen. Rond 1820 startte hij een onderneming voor de winning en productie van boorzuur, waarmee hij ten slotte de grootste industrieel in het Groothertogdom Toscane zou worden. Met andere partners richtte hij een bedrijf op en begon frequente buitenlandse reizen te maken om contacten te leggen met Europese industriëlen en wetenschappers. In 1835 slaagde Larderel erin om de volledige eigendom over het bedrijf te verwerven, waarmee hij een monopolie verwierf op de productie van boorzuur. Zo werd hij een belangrijke speler werd in de Toscaanse industrie. Nadat hij de adellijke titel van graaf had verkregen, kreeg hij toegang tot het groothertogelijke hof en smeedde hij huwelijksbanden met adellijke en andere vooraanstaande families, zoals de families Rucellai en Salviati, en ook met de Savoia's. Hij was Gonfaloniere van Livorno van februari 1847 tot mei 1848 en maakte zich hard voor de bouw van het Teatro Leopoldo. Ook ontwikkelde hij talloze filantropische initiatieven. Larderel was een gematigd liberaal; hij hield vast aan het programma voor de emancipatie van de Joden; steunde de instelling van een gewapende burgerwacht en de persvrijheid. Hij stierf in Florence op 5 juni 1858.

$Larrain.en_GB: José Rafael Larraín Moxó was a Chilean politician and diplomat. The son of José Toribio de Larraín y Guzmán and Dolores Moxó Fuertes, on 19 October 1839 he married Victoria Prieto Warnes, daughter of the President of the Republic of Chile José Joaquin Prieto Vial (1786-1854). In 1827, he travelled to Europe to further develop his knowledge of agriculture. Back in Chile, he took charge of his large estate near Viluco. On 20 May 1838, he co-founded the Sociedad Nacional de Agricultura (SNA), of which he was director and president from 1845-1847 and 1875-1893. On 5 September 1859, he and others founded the Banco de Chile. This bank would later merge into the Banco Nacional and that in turn into the Banco de Valparaíso; of the latter two Larraín became president from 1874. The banks eventually merged into what is today again called the Banco de Chile. Larraín was a member of the Conservative Party and its president from 1884-1885. An MP (1840-1849), he was also a member of the Permanent Committee on Education and Welfare, the Standing Committee on the Constitution, and the Committee on Petitions. In 1852, the government sent him to Rome as Chile's chargé d'affaires to the Holy See. Back in Chile, he became a senator (1855-1882); in that capacity, he was a member of the government's committees on Foreign Relations and Ecclesiastical Affairs. From 1 June 1864 to 3 June 1867, he was also president of the Senate. He participated in the Constituent Congress of 1870, which aimed to reform the 1833 Constitution. During his last term as senator (for Santiago) from 1876-1882, he was also a member of the Standing Committee on Finance and Industry. Among other public duties, he was appointed president of the Sociedad de Instrución Primaria and was (in 1875) vice-president of the International Agricultural Exhibition held in Chile.
$Larrain.it_IT: José Rafael Larraín Moxó fu un politico e diplomatico cileno. Figlio di José Toribio de Larraín y Guzmán e di Dolores Moxó Fuertes, il 19 ottobre 1839 sposò Victoria Prieto Warnes, figlia del presidente della Repubblica del Cile José Joaquin Prieto Vial (1786-1854). Nel 1827 si recò in Europa per approfondire le sue conoscenze in campo agricolo. Tornato in Cile, si occupò della sua grande tenuta vicino a Viluco. Il 20 maggio 1838 co-fondò la Sociedad Nacional de Agricultura (SNA), di cui fu direttore e presidente negli anni 1845-1847 e 1875-1893. Il 5 settembre 1859 fondò, insieme ad altri, il Banco de Chile. Questa banca si sarebbe poi fusa nel Banco Nacional e questo a sua volta nel Banco de Valparaíso; di questi ultimi due Larraín divenne presidente dal 1874. Le banche si fusero infine in quello che oggi si chiama nuovamente Banco de Chile. Larraín fu membro del Partito Conservatore e ne fu presidente dal 1884 al 1885. Deputato (1840-1849), fu anche membro della Commissione permanente per l'istruzione e il benessere, della Commissione permanente per la Costituzione e della Commissione per le petizioni. Nel 1852, il governo lo inviò a Roma come incaricato d'affari del Cile presso la Santa Sede. Tornato in Cile, divenne senatore (1855-1882); in tale veste, fu membro delle commissioni governative per le Relazioni Estere e per gli Affari Ecclesiastici. Dal 1° giugno 1864 al 3 giugno 1867 fu anche presidente del Senato. Partecipò al Congresso Costituente del 1870, che si proponeva di rifondare il sistema di governo.
$Larrain.nl_NL:
José Rafael Larraín Moxó was een Chileens politicus en diplomaat.
Hij was de zoon van José Toribio de Larraín y Guzmán en Dolores Moxó Fuertes en trouwde op 19 oktober 1839 met Victoria Prieto Warnes, dochter van de President van de Republiek Chili José Joaquin Prieto Vial. In 1827 reisde hij naar Europa om zijn kennis van de landbouw te perfectioneren. Terug in Chili nam hij de leiding over zijn grote landgoed bij Viluco. Op 20 mei 1838 was hij medeoprichter van de Sociedad Nacional de Agricultura (SNA), waarvan hij directeur en voorzitter was van 1845-1847 en 1875-1893. Op 5 september 1859 richtte hij samen met anderen de Banco de Chile op. Die zou later opgaan in de Banco Nacional en die weer in de Banco de Valparaíso; vanm de laatste twee werd Larraín vanaf 1874 president. De banken gingen uiteindelijk op in wat nu opnieuw de Banco de Chile heet. Larraín was lid van de Conservatieve Partij en voorzitter van 1884-1885. Als parlementslid (1840-1849) was hij tevens lid van het ermanent commissie voor onderwijs en welzijn, de permanente commissie voor de grondwet, de commissie voor verzoekschriften. In 1852 werd hij door de regering naar Rome gestuurd als zaakgelastigde van Chili bij de Heilige Stoel. Terug in Chili werd hij senator (1855-1882); in die hoedanigheid was hij lid van de regeringscommissies voor buitenlandse betrekkingen en kerkelijke aangelegenheden. Van 1 juni 1864 tot 3 juni 1867 was hij tevens voorzitter van de senaat. Hij nam deel aan het Constituerend Congres van 1870, dat als doel had om het de grondwet van 1833 te hervormen. Tijdens zijn laatste termijn als senator (voor Santiago) van 1876-1882 was hij tevens lid van de Permanente commissie voor Financiën en Industrie. Naast andere publieke taken werd hij benoemd tot voorzitter van de Sociedad de Instrucción Primaria en was hij (in 1875) vice-voorzitter van de Internationale Landbouwtentoonstelling die in Chili gehouden werd.

$Launay.en_GB: Claudio Gabriele De Launay was born into a noble family in Duingt, Savoy, in 1786. He embarked on a military career and served in the Austrian army. Returning home in 1815, he was a major in the Corps Guards. He then continued his career in the Piedmontese army, where he was promoted to colonel of cavalry in 1838, and then to major-general. In 1841, he was given command of the Savoia Brigade, followed by a promotion to lieutenant-general in 1843. In that capacity he was sent to the island of Sardinia as viceroy. He held this post until May 1848, gaining fame as an energetic and intelligent governor. In 1848, he was sent to command the military division in Genoa. The Perrone-Pinelli governement appointed him to army general and senator (7 December 1848). Shortly afterwards he returned to Turin. Following the failure of the 1848 uprisings, Victor Emmanuel II charged him with the difficult task of setting up a government to restore the order. He kept the Foreign Ministry for himself and asked Gioberti to assist him. Having restore peace and order, he started, after mediation by France and England, peace negotiations with Austria, leaving his post as head of government to Massimo d'Azeglio (7 May 1849). He died in Turin in 1850.
$Launay.it_IT: Claudio Gabriele De Launay nacque da una famiglia nobile a Duingt, nella Savoia, nel 1786. Intraprese la carriera militare e servì l'esercito austriaco. Tornato in patria nel 1815, fu maggiore delle Guardie del corpo e, nel 1837 fu promosso colonnello di cavalleria e maggior generale. Nel 1841 ebbe il comando della brigata di Savoia e, nel 1843, fu promosso tenente generale e andò come viceré in Sardegna. Tenne questo incarico sino al maggio del 1848, acquistando fama d'uomo energico e intelligente. Nello stesso anno fu mandato al comando della divisione militare di Genova. Il ministero Perrone-Pinelli lo nominò generale d'esercito e senatore (7 dicembre 1848). Poco dopo tornò a Torino e in seguito al fallimento delle rivolte del 1848, accettò da Vittorio Emanuele II il difficile incarico di costituire un governo che fronteggiasse gli eventi. Tenne per sé il ministero degli Esteri, chiedendo anche la collaborazione del Gioberti. Ristabilito l'ordine avviò, con la mediazione della Francia e dell'Inghilterra, le trattative di pace con l'Austria, lasciò il posto al d'Azeglio (7 maggio 1849). Morì a Torino nel 1850.
$Launay.nl_NL: Claudio Gabriele De Launay werd in 1786 geboren in een adellijke familie in Duingt, Savoie. Hij begon een militaire carrière en diende in het Oostenrijkse leger. Toen hij in 1815 naar huis terugkeerde, was hij majoor bij de keizerlijke Garde. Hij zette zijn carrière voort in het Koninkrijk Sardinië-Piemonte en werd in 1837 bevorderd tot kolonel der cavalerie en daarna tot generaal-majoor. In 1841 kreeg hij het bevel over de Brigade Savoia, gevolgd door een promotie tot luitenant-generaal in 1843. In die hoedanigheid werd hij als onderkoning naar het eiland Sardinië gestuurd. Deze post bekleedde hij tot mei 1848; in die periode verwierf hij faam als energiek en intelligent bestuurder. In 1848 werd hij naar Genua gestuurd om het bevel over de militaire divisie aldaar over te nemen. De regering Perrone-Pinelli benoemde hem daarna tot generale d'esercito (eq. veldmaarschalk) en senator (7 december 1848). Korte tijd later keerde hij terug naar Turijn, waar hij van Victor Emmanuel II de moeilijke taak kreeg om een regering te vormen die na de mislukte opstanden van 1848 orde op zaken zou stellen. Hij nam het Ministerie van Buitenlandse Zaken onder zijn hoede en vroeg ook om de medewerking van Gioberti aan een nieuw kabinet. Nadat hij de rust hersteld had, begon hij, na bemiddeling van Frankrijk en Engeland, vredesonderhandelingen met Oostenrijk en liet zijn taak als regeringsleider over aan Massimo d'Azeglio (7 mei 1849). Hij stierf in Turijn in 1850.

$Laureani.en_GB: Gabriele Laureani was born in Rome in 1788. He began his ecclesiastical career, studying at the Collegio Romano and the seminary, specialising in the study of classical languages. He was ordained a priest in 1812. In the following years he became a professor at various pontifical academies. In 1820 he joined the Accademia dell'Arcadia, becoming its custos-general in 1825. Pope Gregory XVI appointed him in 1831 as second custos of the Vatican Library, which he would direct as chioef librarian from 1838. In 1843 he became Consultor of the Congregation of the Index and in 1844 Apostolic Protonotary. Even during the period of the Roman Republic in 1849 he continued to work regularly as director of the Vatican Library. He died the same year. Laureani was buried in the Vatican Basilica.
$Laureani.it_IT: Gabriele Laureani nacque a Roma nel 1788. Iniziò la carriera ecclesiastica, studiando al Collegio Romano e al Seminario, specializzandosi nello studio delle lingue classiche. Fu ordinato sacerdote nel 1812. Negli anni successivi divenne professore presso varie accademie pontificie. Nel 1820 entrò a far parte dell'Accademia dell'Arcadia divenendone nel 1825 il custode generale. Nel 1831 venne nominato dal papa Gregorio XVI secondo custode della Biblioteca Vaticana e la diresse dal 1838. Nel 1843 divenne consultore della Congregazione dell'Indice e nel 1844 Protonotario apostolico. Anche durante il periodo della Repubblica Romana del 1849 continuò a operare regolarmente alla direzione della Biblioteca Vaticana, morendo in quell'anno. Fu seppellito nella basilica vaticana.
$Laureani.nl_NL: Gabriele Laureani werd in 1788 in Rome geboren. Hij begon zijn kerkelijke carrière met een studie aan het Collegio Romano en het seminarie, waar hij zich specialiseerde in de studie van de klassieke talen. In 1812 werd hij tot priester gewijd. In de daaropvolgende jaren werd hij docent aan verschillende pauselijke academies. In 1820 trad hij toe tot de Accademia dell'Arcadia, waarvan hij in 1825 custos-generaal werd. Paus Gregorius XVI benoemde hem in 1831 tot tweede custos van de Vaticaanse Bibliotheek, waarvan hij vanaf 1838 hoofdbibliothecaris werd. In 1843 werd hij Consultor van de Congregatie van de Index en in 1844 Apostolisch Protonotaris. Zelfs tijdens de periode van de Romeinse Republiek van 1849 zette hij zijn werkzaamheden als directeur van de Vaticaanse Bibliotheek voort. In datzelfde jaar overleed hij. Laureani werd begraven in de Vaticaanse Basiliek.

$Laves.en_GB: Georg Heinrich Wilhelm Laves was a German painter and etcher, originally from Hanover. He was the eldest of three sons of Georg Ludwig Friedrich Laves (1788-1864), famous architect and town planner at the court of the King of Hanover. In Hanover, he painted, among other things, the ceiling of the Hoftheater, a building designed by his father. From 17 November 1851 to 1854, he stayed in Rome, close to his wife's great-uncle, the archaeologist and art collector August Kestner (1777-1853) who had represented the Kingdom of Hanover to the Holy See in Rome as envoy until 1849 and had continued to live there. In 1853, Laves also drew his great-uncle's portrait. When Kestner died in 1853, Laves informed the Roman corps diplomatique. In 1855, he returned to Hanover, where he was a succesful history painter and from 1871 took charge, unpaid, of the Kestner Museum in his hometown, where his great-uncle's collection and memory are still kept today. In 1858, the Dutch painter Matthijs Maris painted Laves' portrait.
$Laves.it_IT: Georg Heinrich Wilhelm Laves fu un pittore e incisore tedesco, originario di Hannover. Era il maggiore dei tre figli di Georg Ludwig Friedrich Laves (1788-1864), famoso architetto e urbanista alla corte del re di Hannover. Ad Hannover dipinse, tra l'altro, il soffitto dell'Hoftheater, un edificio progettato dal padre. Dal 17 novembre 1851 al 1854 soggiornò a Roma, vicino al prozio della moglie, l'archeologo e collezionista d'arte August Kestner (1777-1853) che era stato il rappresentante del Regno di Hannover presso la Santa Sede a Roma  come inviato fino al 1849 e aveva continuato a vivere lì. Nel 1853, Laves disegnò anche il ritratto del prozio. Quando Kestner morì nel 1853, Laves informò il Corpo diplomatico romano. Nel 1855 tornò ad Hannover, dove ebbe successo come pittore di storia e dal 1871 si occupò, non retribuito, del Museo Kestner nella sua città natale, dove ancora oggi sono conservate l'importante collezione del prozio la cui memoria sopravvive ancora oggi. Nel 1858, il pittore olandese Matthijs Maris dipinse il ritratto di Laves.
$Laves.nl_NL: Georg Heinrich Wilhelm Laves was een Duitse schilder en etser, afkomstig uit Hannover. Hij was de oudste van drie zonen van Georg Ludwig Friedrich Laves (1788-1864), beroemd architect en stadsplanner aan het hof van de koning van Hannover. In Hannover schilderde hij onder meer het plafond van het door zijn vader ontworpen Hoftheater. Van 17 november  1851 tot 1854 verbleef hij in Rome, in de nabijheid van de oudoom van zijn vrouw, de archeoloog en kunstverzamelaar August Kestner, die tot 1849 als gezant het Koninkrijk Hannover bij de Heilige Stoel in Rome had vertegenwoordigd en er was blijven wonen. In 1853 tekende Laves ook het portret van zijn oudoom. Toen Kestner in 1853 overleed, informeerde Laves het Romeinse corps diplomatique. In 1855 keerde hij naar Hannover terug, waar hij successen vierde als historieschilder en vanaf 1871 onbezoldigd de leiding op zich nam over het Kestner Museum in zijn geboorteplaats, waar de verzameling en nagedachtenis van zijn oudoom nog altijd wordt bewaard. In 1858 schilderde Matthijs Maris Laves' portret.

$LeemansJa.en_GB: Jasper Andreus Adrianus Leemans was a Dutch jurist and politician, born in Zaltbommel. He studied Law in Leiden and was a student of the prominent liberal politician Johan Rudolph Thorbecke. After his studies, Leemans left for the Dutch Indies, where from 1842 he worked for the High Court and the Military Court in Batavia. From 1846, he was also a member of the Council of Justice in Semarang. During his leave in the Netherlands in 1852, he was elected to the House of Representatives for the constituency of Tiel (23 November 1852). In that capacity, he was rarely heard of, yet he was the only liberal to vote against the motion Van Doorn, which urged the government to take firmer action against the decision of pope Pius IX to restore the Dutch episcopal hierarchy (announced in the papal bull Ex Qua Die,4 March 1853). After further protests leading to the 'April movement' (1853) and to the fall of the cabinet Thorbecke, Leemans was not re-elected. He went to live in Amsterdam and withdrew from public affairs.
$LeemansJa.it_IT: Jasper Andreus Adrianus Leemans fu un giurista e politico olandese, nato a Zaltbommel. Studiò giurisprudenza a Leida e fu allievo del noto politico liberale Johan Rudolph Thorbecke. Dopo gli studi, Leemans partì per le Indie olandesi, dove dal 1842 lavorò per l'Alta Corte e il Tribunale Militare di Batavia. Dal 1846 fu anche membro del Consiglio di Giustizia di Semarang. Durante il suo congedo nei Paesi Bassi nel 1852, fu eletto alla Camera dei Rappresentanti per la circoscrizione elettorale di Tiel (23 novembre 1852). Di lui in tale veste si sentiva raramente parlare, eppure fu l'unico liberale a votare contro la mozione Van Doorn, che invitava il governo ad agire con più fermezza contro la decisione di papa Pio IX di restaurare la gerarchia episcopale olandese (annunciata nel pontificio bolla Ex Qua Die, 4 marzo 1853). Dopo ulteriori proteste che portarono al “movimento di aprile” (1853) e alla caduta del governo Thorbecke, Leemans non fu rieletto. Andò a vivere ad Amsterdam e si ritirò dagli affari pubblici.
$LeemansJa.nl_NL: Jasper Andreus Adrianus Leemans was een Nederlands jurist en politicus, geboren te Zaltbommel. Hij studeerde Rechten in Leiden en was een leerling van de vooraanstaande liberale politicus Johan Rudolph Thorbecke. Na zijn afstuderen vertrok Leemans naar Nederlands-Indië, waar hij vanaf 1842 werkte aan het Hooggerechtshof en het Militair Gerechtshof te Batavia; vanaf 1846 was hij ook lid van de Raad van Justitie te Semarang. In 1852 ging hij met verlof naar Nederland. Daar kwam hij vervolgens op 23 november in de Tweede Kamer voor het kiesdistrict Tiel. Hij liet zich weinig horen, maar stemde wel als enige liberaal tegen de motie-Van Doorn, waarin de regering werd opgeroepen hardere maatregelen te nemen tegen het besluit van paus Pius IX om de bisschoppelijke hiërarchie in Nederland te herstellen (met de pauselijke bul Ex Qua Die, 4 maart 1853). Verdere protesten hiertegen leidden tot de Aprilbeweging (1853) en de val van kabinet-Thorbecke, waarna Leemans niet werd herkozen. Hij ging in Amsterdam wonen en bemoeide zich niet meer met publieke zaken.

$Liedkerke.en_GB: Count Auguste Liedekerke-de Beaufort came from a noble family in the region of Namur, then part of the Austrian Netherlands. For about ten years, he was the Dutch envoy to the Swiss Confederation; subsequently, he became envoy to the Holy See, from 31 December 1829 until his death. Because of his experience, Liedekerke was a known figure in diplomatic circles, and because of that he was the doyen (or longest-residing) ambassador of the corps diplomatique in Rome. In Rome, he resided in the palazzi where the Legation was housed, mainly in Palazzo Negroni al Clementino (1832-1840) and in the Palazzo Valdambrini (1841-) both in the Via di Ripetta. He was reportedly a personal friend of pope Pius IX, and supported his initial reforms and liberal government (1846-1848) as surely as he disapproved of the pope's later shift to reactionary policies. After Pius IX fled Rome on 24 November 1848, Liedekerke followed him to Gaeta. He died on 27 September 1855 of cholera in Rocca di Papa, on the Roman countryside.
$Liedkerke.it_IT: Il conte Auguste Liedekerke-de Beaufort proveniva da una famiglia nobile della regione di Namur, allora parte dei Paesi Bassi austriaci. Per circa dieci anni fu inviato olandese presso la Confederazione Svizzera; successivamente, dal 31 dicembre 1829 fino alla morte, divenne inviato presso la Santa Sede. Grazie alla sua esperienza, Liedekerke era una figura nota negli ambienti diplomatici, e per questo motivo era l'ambasciatore decano (o più longevo) del corpo diplomatico a Roma. A Roma risiedette nei palazzi dove aveva sede la Legazione, principalmente nel Palazzo Negroni al Clementino (1832-1840) e nel Palazzo Valdambrini (1841-) entrambi in Via di Ripetta. Si dice che fosse un amico personale di papa Pio IX e sostenesse le sue riforme iniziali e il governo liberale (1846-1848); disapprovò quindi il successivo passaggio del papa a politiche reazionarie. Dopo che Pio IX fuggì da Roma il 24 novembre 1848, Liedekerke lo seguì a Gaeta. Morì il 27 settembre 1855 di colera a Rocca di Papa, nella campagna romana.
$Liedkerke.nl_NL: Graaf Auguste Liedekerke-de Beaufort was afkomstig uit een adellijk geslacht uit de omgeving van Namen, destijds de Oostenrijkse Nederlanden. Gedurende ongeveer tien jaar was hij de Nederlandse gezant bij de Confederatie van de Zwitserse Kantons; aansluitend was hij in Rome de Nederlandse gezant bij de Heilige Stoel, van 31 december 1829 tot zijn dood. Vanwege zijn ervaring was Liedekerke een geziene figuur in diplomatieke kringen en daarom jarenlang deken van het corps diplomatique in Rome.
