In Rome woonde hij in de palazzi waar ook de Legatie gehuisvest was, in deze periode hoofdzakelijk in het Palazzo Negroni al Clementino (1832-1840) en het Palazzo Valdambrini (vanaf 1841), beide aan de Via di Ripetta. Naar verluidt was Liedekerke een persoonlijke vriend van paus Pius IX, wiens aanvankelijke hervormingen (1846-1848) hij steunde, evengoed als hij diens latere reactionaire draai afkeurde. Nadat de paus op 24 november 1848 Rome was ontvlucht, volgde Liedekerke hem naar Gaeta. Liedekerke stierf op 27 september 1855 aan de cholera in Rocca di Papa, op het Romeinse platteland.

$Lightenvelt.en_GB: Leonardus Antonius Lightenvelt was a Dutch catholic lawyer and politician from Den Bosch. At the recommendation of the minister of Roman Catholic Affairs Van Son, on 25 March 1848 Lightenvelt was named as the latter's successor. In this capacity he faced unrest caused by a separatist movement in the region of Limburg. From 21 november 1848 to 1 november 1849 he was minister of Foreign Affairs in the cabinet De Kempenaer/Donker Curtius. During the following cabinet (Thorbecke) he did not hold a public office. When Thorbecke's government stepped down following the so-called April movement of 1853 (the unrest caused by the restauration of the Dutch episcopal hierarchy), Lightnevelt resumed the ministry of Roman Catholic Affairs in the moderate-conservative cabinet of Van Hall/Donker Curtius. Shortly thereafter, however, he was sent to Rome to (temporarily) replace the Dutch envoy, count Liedekerke-de Beaufort. By the end of 1853 he resigned and was appointed ambassador to the French court in Paris; where he would spend his winters ice skating on the lakes of Bois de Boulogne with the empress Eugénie. Lightenvelt was not a practicing catholic and married a protestant woman.
$Lightenvelt.it_IT: Leonardus Antonius Lightenvelt fu un avvocato e politico cattolico olandese di Den Bosch. Su raccomandazione del ministro degli Affari cattolici romani Van Son, il 25 marzo 1848 Lightenvelt fu nominato successore di quest'ultimo. In questa veste dovette affrontare i disordini causati da un movimento separatista nella regione del Limburgo. Dal 21 novembre 1848 al 1 novembre 1849 fu ministro degli Affari esteri nel gabinetto De Kempenaer/Donker Curtius. Durante il governo successivo (Thorbecke) non ricoprì cariche pubbliche. Quando il governo di Thorbecke si dimise in seguito al cosiddetto movimento di aprile del 1853 (i disordini causati dal ripristino della gerarchia episcopale olandese), Lightnevelt riprese il ministero degli affari cattolici romani nel gabinetto moderato-conservatore di Van Hall/Donker Curtius. Poco dopo, però, fu inviato a Roma per sostituire (temporaneamente) l'inviato olandese, il conte Liedekerke-de Beaufort. Alla fine del 1853 si dimise e fu nominato ambasciatore presso la corte francese a Parigi; dove trascorreva i suoi inverni pattinando sul ghiaccio sui laghi del Bois de Boulogne con l'imperatrice Eugenia. Lightenvelt non era cattolico praticante e sposò una donna protestante.
$Lightenvelt.nl_NL: Leonardus Antonius Lightenvelt was een Nederlands katholiek advocaat en politicus, afkomstig uit Den Bosch. Op aanbeveling van de minister van Rooms-Katholieke Eredienst Jan van Son werd hij op 25 maart 1848 aangewezen als diens (tijdelijke) opvolger. Als zodanig kreeg te maken met de beweging die Limburg wilde afscheiden van Nederland. Van 21 november 1848 tot 1 november 1849 was Lightenvelt vervolgens minister van Buitenlandse Zaken in het kabinet-de Kempenaer/Donker Curtius. Hij bleef buiten het daaropvolgende liberale kabinet-Thorbecke en hervatte zijn ministerschap van Rooms-Katholieke Eredienst in het gematigd conservatieve kabinet-Van Hall/Donker Curtius, dat aantrad nadat de zogeheten Aprilbeweging van 1853 Thorbecke I ten val had gebracht. Kort na zijn benoeming werd Lightenvelt naar Rome afgevaardigd, om de taken van de Nederlands gezant Liedekerke-de Beaufort waar te nemen. Eind 1853 werd hij buitengewoon gezant te Parijs, waar hij 's winters met keizerin Eugénie op de vijvers van het Bois de Boulogne schaatste. Lightenvelt praktiseerde zijn katholieke geloof niet; hij was getrouwd met een protestantse vrouw.

$Limburg.en_GB: Frederik Adriaan Count van Limburg Stirum, Lord of Pilchowitz (Upper Silesia), received a doctorate in Law from Utrecht University in 1825 and was a member of the Knighthood of Friesland since 1825. He began his career as a clerk at the Department of Foreign Affairs in The Hague (RD 11 May 1825 no 123) and was subsequently appointed secretary of the Dutch legation at the Court of Sardinia in Turin (RD 12 May 1826 no 104) under envoy Elias van der Hoeven, whose duties he temporarily assumed after the latter's honorable resignation (11 March 1828, RD no 128), until Van Limburg Stirum was appointed secretary of the Dutch legation to the Kingdom of Sweden on 3 March 1829 (RD no 52). However, he requested 'to be spared from his trip to Stockholm' and was instead temporarily placed at the ministry in The Hague, until an appointment as secretary of legation in Berlin followed (RD 8 Aug 1830 no 81), where he became council of legation a few years later (RD 13 Nov 1836 no 76). Van Limburg Stirum was chamberlain in extraordinary service to King William I, King William II and King William III.
$Limburg.it_IT: Frederik Adriaan conte van Limburg Stirum, signore di Pilchowitz (Alta Slesia), conseguì il dottorato in legge all'Università di Utrecht nel 1825 e fu membro del cavalierato di Frisia dal 1825. Iniziò la sua carriera come impiegato presso il Dipartimento degli Affari Esteri dell'Aia (RD 11 maggio 1825 n. 123) e successivamente fu nominato segretario della legazione olandese presso la Corte di Sardegna a Torino (RD 12 maggio 1826 n. 104) sotto l'inviato Elias van der Hoeven, le cui funzioni vennero assunte temporaneamente dopo le  dimissioni di quest'ultimo (11 marzo 1828, RD n. 128), fino a quando Van Limburg Stirum fu nominato segretario della legazione olandese presso il Regno di Svezia il 3 marzo 1829 (RD n. 52). Tuttavia, chiese di “essere risparmiato dal viaggio a Stoccolma” e fu invece collocato temporaneamente al ministero dell'Aia, fino a quando non fu nominato segretario di legazione a Berlino (RD 8 agosto 1830 n. 81), dove qualche anno più tardi entrò come consiglio di legazione (RD 13 novembre 1836 n. 76). Van Limburg Stirum fu ciambellano in servizio straordinario di re Guglielmo I, re Guglielmo II e re Guglielmo III.
$Limburg.nl_NL: Mr. Frederik Adriaan graaf van Limburg Stirum, heer van Pilchowitz (Opper- Silezië), promoveerde in 1825 in de Rechten aan de Utrechtse universiteit en was lid van de Ridderschap van Friesland sinds 1825. Hij begon zijn carrière als adjunct-commies aan het departement van Buitenlandse Zaken (KB 11 mei 1825 no. 123), werd vervolgens benoemd als secretaris van de Nederlandse legatie bij het Hof van Sardinië te Turijn (KB 12 mei 1826 no. 104) onder gezant Elias van der Hoeven, wiens taken hij na diens eervol ontslag (11 maart 1828, KB no. 128) tijdelijk waarnam, tot hij  op 3 maart 1829 (KB no. 52) werd benoemd als secretaris van de Nederlandse  legatie bij het Koninkrijk Zweden. Hij verzocht evenwel 'om van zijn reis naar Stockholm verschoond te blijven' en werd in plaats daarvan tijdelijk op het ministerie in Den Haag geplaatst, tot een benoeming als secretaris van legatie te Berlijn volgde (KB 8 aug. 1830 no. 81), waar hij enkele jaren later raad van legatie werd (KB 13 nov. 1836 no. 76). Van Limburg Stirum was kamerheer in buitengewone dienst van Koning Willem I, Koning Willem II en Koning Willem III.

$LimburgNoordwijk.en_GB: Count Wigbold Albert Willem van der Does van Limburg Stirum was a Dutch soldier and court official. In 1809, during the French occupation, as a conscript in Napoleons army he took part in the Spanish War of Independence (1808-1814) and fought in the Battle of Medellin (28 March 1809).  After the Spanish campaign he left the army and became maire (mayor) of Noordwijk, in what was then the department of the Delf, near Delft. Subsequently, he was a member of the provincial executive for the southern part of Holland (1820-1840) and a member of the Senate (1840-1849). Between 1835 and 1849, he also served as chaimberlain-master of ceremonies of the Dutch kings Willem I and Willem II. In 1848, count Van Limburg Stirum voted in favour of a liberal amendment of the constitution.
$LimburgNoordwijk.it_IT: Il conte Wigbold Albert Willem van der Does van Limburg Stirum fu un soldato e funzionario di corte olandese. Nel 1809, durante l'occupazione francese, come coscritto nell'esercito di Napoleone prese parte alla Guerra d'Indipendenza spagnola (1808-1814) e combatté nella battaglia di Medellin (28 marzo 1809). Dopo la campagna di Spagna lasciò l'esercito e divenne maire (sindaco) di Noordwijk, in quello che allora era il dipartimento del Delf, vicino a Delft. Successivamente fu membro dell'esecutivo provinciale per la parte meridionale dell'Olanda (1820-1840) e membro del Senato (1840-1849). Tra il 1835 e il 1849 fu anche maestro di cerimonie dei re olandesi Guglielmo I e Guglielmo II. Nel 1848 il conte Van Limburg Stirum votò a favore di un emendamento liberale alla costituzione.
$LimburgNoordwijk.nl_NL: Graaf Wigbold Albert Willem van der Does van Limburg Stirum was een Nederlands militair en hofdignitaris. In 1809, tijdens de Franse Tijd, nam hij als dienstplichtige in Napoleons legers deel aan de Spaanse Onafhankelijkheidsoorlog (1808-1814)  en vocht onder andere in de Slag bij Medellin (28 Maart 1809). Na het einde van de veldtocht werd hij uit de dienst ontslagen en werd hij maire (burgermeester) van Noordwijk. Vervolgens was hij van 1820 tot 1840 lid van de Gedeputeerde Staten van Holland namens het zuidelijk deel van die provincie, en van 1840 tot 1849 lid van de Eerste Kamer. Daarnaast bekleedde tussen 1835 en 1849 ook de hoffunctie van kamerheer-ceremoniemeester van de koning. Graaf Van Limburg Stirum stemde in 1848 voor de liberale grondwetsherziening.

$Lintz.en_GB: Jean Henri or Johan Hendrik Lintz was employed at the royal treasury (1831-1849) under the Dutch Kings William I, II and III, first as regular clerk and most recently as first clerk under treasurer David Ragay, whom he also replaced in his absence. From 1 October 1850, he joined Princess Marianne van Orange's household as her administrator; later, he also became her General Plenipotentiary in The Hague. In early 1857 he experienced the Roman carnival together with the painter Gerrit Postma, who also belonged to the circle around Marianne. Lintz' son Johan Hendrik (jr.) was appointed the princess' deputy administrator in March 1877.
$Lintz.it_IT: Jean Henri o Johan Hendrik Lintz fu impiegato presso la tesoreria reale (1831-1849) sotto i re olandesi Guglielmo I, II e III, prima come impiegato ordinario e successivamente come primo impiegato sotto il tesoriere David Ragay, che sostituì anche in sua assenza. Dal 1° ottobre 1850 entrò a far parte della famiglia della principessa Marianne van Orange in qualità di amministratore; in seguito divenne anche suo plenipotenziario generale all'Aia. All'inizio del 1857 partecipò al carnevale romano insieme al pittore Gerrit Postma, anch'egli appartenente alla cerchia di Marianna. Il figlio di Lintz, Johan Hendrik (jr.), fu nominato vice amministratore della principessa nel marzo 1877.
$Lintz.nl_NL: Jean Henri of Johan Hendrik Lintz was werkzaam bij de thesaurie (1831-1849) onder de koningen Willem I, II en III, eerst als gewoon klerk en laatstelijk als eerste klerk onder thesaurier David Ragay, die hij bij afwezigheid ook verving. Per 1 oktober 1850 trad hij in dienst van prinses Marianne als haar administrateur; later werd hij ook haar generaal-gevolmachtigde in Den Haag. In Rome maakte hij, o.a. samen met de schilder Gerrit Postma, ook uit Marianne's entourage, begin 1857 het Romeinse carnaval mee. Zijn zoon Johan Hendrik (jr.) werd in maart 1877 benoemd tot haar adjunct-administrateur.

$Lucidi.en_GB: From 1832 to 1843, Lorenzo Lucidi was a member of the Papal Family (or Household), which assists the pope as head of a juridical body wit hall his civil functions. Among other things, Lucidi was judge, bursar and secretary of the Reverenda Fabbrica di San Pietro (1837-1853). Furthermore, he was embassy secretary (1837-1843) and Canon of St. Peter's in the Vatican (1844-1856), and Deacon at masses in the Pontifical Chapel (1844-1856). From 1845-1856 he was Apostolic Protonotary; from 1854-1856 Assessor and Consultor to the Holy Office (1854-1856) and Consultor to the Sacred Congregation of Rites (1854-1856). He died in 1856.
$Lucidi.it_IT: Lorenzo Lucidi fu un membro della Famiglia pontificia dal 1832 al 1843. Giudice, economo e segretario della Reverenda Fabbrica di San Pietro (1837-1853). Fu segretario d'ambasciata (1837-1843) e Canonico di S. Pietro in Vaticano (1844-1856). Diacono alle messe della Cappella pontificia (1844-1856). Prelato protonotaro apostolico (1845-1856). Assessore e consultore del Sant'Uffizio (1854-1856) e consultore della Sacra Congregazione dei Riti (1854-1856). Morì nel 1856.
$Lucidi.nl_NL: Lorenzo Lucidi was van 1832 tot 1843 lid van de Pauselijke Familie, de groep functionarissen die de paus tevens in zijn hoedanigheid als wereldlijk vorst bijstaan. Hij was onder meer rechter, econoom en secretaris van de Reverenda Fabbrica di San Pietro (1837-1853). Hij was daarnaast onder meer ambassadesecretaris (1837-1843) en kanunnik van de Sint-Pieter in het Vaticaan (1844-1856), en diaken bij de missen in de Pauselijke Kapel (1844-1856). Van 1845-1856 was hij Apostolisch Protonotaris en van 1854-1856 Assessor en Consultor van het Heilig Officie en Consultor van de Heilige Congregatie van Riten (1854-1856). Hij stierf in 1856.

$Lunati.en_GB: Giuseppe Lunati was a jurist and politician. He was Minister of Finance in the cabinets Mamiani (4 May-3 August 1848) and Muzzarelli (16 November-23 December 1848). During the Roman Republic of 1849, Lunati, who was a moderate liberal, chose a role in the background as government commissioner at the Bank of Rome and a judge at the Court of Cassation. Afterwards he became conservatore (councillor) of Finance in the city government. After the fall of the Republic, Lunati was offered the post of Special Commissioner of Finances by the French commander-in-chief general Charles Oudinot. He risked banishment for this, but pope Pius IX allowed him to stay in Rome. On 29 November 1870, Lunati became the first (acting) mayor of Rome. In December 1870, he was named senator of the Kingdom of Italy.
$Lunati.it_IT: Giuseppe Lunati fu un giurista e politico. Fu ministro delle Finanze nei gabinetti Mamiani (4 maggio-3 agosto 1848) e Muzzarelli (16 novembre-23 dicembre 1848). Durante la Repubblica Romana del 1849, Lunati, che era un liberale moderato, scelse un ruolo secondario dapprima come commissario governativo del Banco di Roma e come giudice della Corte di Cassazione. Successivamente divenne “conservatore” (assessore) delle Finanze nel governo della città. Dopo la caduta della Repubblica, a Lunati venne offerto il posto di commissario straordinario alle finanze dal comandante in capo francese Charles Oudinot. Per questo rischiò l'esilio, ma papa Pio IX gli permise di restare a Roma. Il 29 novembre 1870 Lunati divenne il primo sindaco (ad interim) di Roma. Nel dicembre 1870 fu nominato senatore del Regno d'Italia.
$Lunati.nl_NL: Giuseppe Lunati was jurist en politicus. Hij was minister van Financiën in de kabinetten Mamiani (4 mei-3 augustus 1848) en Muzzarelli (16 november-23 december 1848). Als gematigde liberaal koos hij tijdens de Romeinse Republiek van 1849 voor een rol op de achtergrond, als regeringscommissaris bij de Bank van Rome en rechter aan het Hof van Cassatie. Daarnaast was hij conservatore (wethouder) van Financiën in het Romeinse stadsbestuur. Na de val van de republiek weigerde hij een commissariaat van Financiën dat hem door de Franse opperbevelhebber generaal Charles Oudinot werd aangeboden. Hij riskeerde een verbanning, maar paus Pius IX stond hem toch toe te blijven. Op 29 november 1870 werd hij de eerste (waarnemend) burgemeester van Rome. In december 1870 werd hij benoemd tot senator van het Koninkrijk Italië.

$Lutzow.en_GB: Rudolf von Lützow was the Austrian ambassador to the Kingdom of Sardinia from 1823-1825 and from 1825 (present in Rome from 1827) to 1848 he was the Austrian envoy to the Holy See, residing in Palazzo Venezia in Piazza Venezia. Because of the rebellious and anti-Austrian mood in Rome in spring 1848, the Roman government (in favour of sending Roman volunteers to the war against Austria) requested him to leave Rome to avoid escalation, which L. did on 16 May 1848. He died in Monza but was interred in the cemetery of S. Maria in Camposanto in the Vatican.
$Lutzow.it_IT: Rudolf von Lützow fu ambasciatore austriaco nel Regno di Sardegna dal 1823 al 1825 e dal 1825 (presente a Roma dal 1827) al 1848 fu inviato austriaco presso la Santa Sede, risiedendo a Palazzo Venezia in Piazza Venezia. A causa del clima ribelle e antiaustriaco che si respirava a Roma nella primavera del 1848, il governo romano (favorevole all'invio di volontari romani alla guerra contro l'Austria) gli chiese di lasciare Roma per evitare un'escalation, cosa che L. fece il 16 maggio 1848. Morì a Monza ma fu sepolto nel cimitero di S. Maria in Camposanto in Vaticano.
$Lutzow.nl_NL: Rudolf von Lützow was van 1823-1825 de Oostenrijkse ambassadeur in Turijn en van 1825 (ter plaatse vanaf 1827) tot 1848 de Oostenrijkse gezant bij de Heilige Stoel, met als residentie Palazzo Venezia op Piazza Venezia. Vanwege de opstandige en anti-Oostenrijkse stemming in Rome in het voorjaar van 1848 verzocht de Romeinse regering (voorstander van de deelname van Romeinse vrijwilligers aan de oorlog tegen Oostenrijk) hem Rome te verlaten om escalatie te voorkomen, wat L. op 16 mei 1848 deed. Hij stierf in Monza maar werd bijgezet op het kerkhof van de S. Maria in Camposanto in het Vaticaan.

$Maesen.en_GB: Paul Thérèse van der Maesen de Sombreff was a Dutch politician from Maastricht. In 1850 he obtained his doctorate in Law at Leiden University and in 1853 he became senator for Limburg. From 1862 to 1864, Maesen was Minister of Foreign Affairs in the cabinet of Thorbecke II. The elections of 1864 led to a political scandal, the so-dubbed “letter affair of Limburg”, which involved postponing tax raises in Limburg until after the elections. It caused Maesen to step down and also led to the resignation of the Minister of Finance, G.H. Betz. Maesen was re-elected two weeks after the affair, however, and stayed a member of the House of Representatives until 1873. Due to the rift that had grown between Dutch liberals and Catholics, he was not re-elected. Maesen himself was one of the last remaining liberal-Catholics. He was married to Emilia Louise Charlotte de Cava and had five children.
$Maesen.it_IT: Paul Thérèse van der Maesen de Sombreff fu un politico olandese di Maastricht. Nel 1850 conseguì il dottorato in giurisprudenza all'Università di Leida e nel 1853 divenne senatore del Limburgo. Dal 1862 al 1864 Maesen fu ministro degli Affari esteri nel gabinetto di Thorbecke II. Le elezioni del 1864 portarono ad uno scandalo politico, il cosiddetto “affare della lettera del Limburgo”, che comportò il rinvio dell'aumento delle tasse nel Limburgo a dopo le elezioni. Ciò causò le dimissioni di Maesen e portò anche alle dimissioni del ministro delle Finanze, G.H. Betz. Maesen fu rieletto due settimane dopo l'affare e rimase membro della Camera dei rappresentanti fino al 1873. A causa della spaccatura che si era creata tra liberali olandesi e cattolici, non fu rieletto. Lo stesso Maesen fu uno degli ultimi cattolici liberali rimasti. Sposato con Emilia Louise Charlotte de Cava aveva cinque figli.
$Maesen.nl_NL: Paul Thérèse van der Maesen de Sombreff was een Nederlands politicus uit Maastricht. In 1850 promoveerde hij in de Rechten aan de Universiteit Leiden en in 1853 werd hij senator voor Limburg. Vervolgens werd Maesen in 1862 minister van Buitenlandse Zaken in het kabinet-Thorbecke II. De verkiezingen van 1864 leidden tot de zogeheten Limburgse brievenaffaire, waarbij belastingverhoging in Limburg werd uitgesteld tot na de verkiezingen. Dit leidde ertoe dat Maesen zich terugtrok en dat de minister van Financiën, G.H. Betz, moest aftreden. Maesen werd twee weken daarop wel herkozen en bleef lid van de Tweede Kamer tot 1873. Ten gevolge van de breuk tussen de liberalen en katholieken werd hij in 1873 niet opnieuw herkozen. Maesen gold als een van de laatste katholiek-liberalen ('papo-liberalen'). Hij was getrouwd met Emilia Louise Charlotte de Cava en kreeg met haar vijf kinderen.

$Magrini.en_GB:
Paul Émile (Paolo Emilio) Magrini was employed, at least in the 1830s, by the Dutch envoy to the Holy See, Count Liedekerke de Beaufort, as private secretary, a position outside the Dutch diplomatic corps. That changed in 1836, when foreign minister Verstolk, at Liedekerke's request, submitted a request to King William I to grant M. the honorary title of chancellor at the Dutch legation, a title rarely granted - with the exception of the Duch mission in Constantinople. In Liedekerke's justification submitted by the minister to the King on 18 June 1836, it was written that Magrini 'always showed the most benevolence to Your Majesty's subjects in Rome and [was] of service to them by his relations, wherever he can'. In addition, Liedekerke pointed out that Romans were very sensitive to (honorary) titles and that a such a title would 'prove useful to M. in arranging a marriage with the daughter of a Roman Count' (Van Galen Last, 74-75). A later letter by Liedekerke to minister Van Hall (15 February 1855 no. 707, National Archives, Foreign Affairs 2.05.01, inv.no. 2157) suggests that Magrini had indeed succeeded in marrying into the Roman high society.
In 1839, his appointment as chancellor was followed by an even more unusual promotion to honorary attaché, and in addition (from 1845) an annual allowance, despite the fact that, King William I, following M.' recognition as honorary chancellor in 1836, had warned that it should never lead to any kind of official position at the legation. During the 1850s, however, concerns arose in the Dutch House of Representatives about the remuneration of chancellors and other local (honorary) staff at the embassies (apart from Rome, the same had occurred in Madrid, Berlin, Frankfurt and Brussels). On 16 Dec 1854, Minister Van Hall decided to strip Magrini of his title of honorary attaché and also to withdraw his annual allowance of 600 guilders. Liedekerke's unsuccessful attempt (letter dated 15 February 1855, cited above) to at least let M. keep his titles indicates once again that the man's main merits regarded 'touristes néerlandais', whom he introduced to the Roman high society.
On the contrary, the Dutch painter Jan Philip Koelman (1818-1893) claimed in his memoirs In Rome 1846-1851 (1869) that Magrini was respected by hardly anyone in the Eternal City, and that he made a complete fool of himself with the honorary titles he had written in curly letters on his business card. During the Roman Republic of 1849, when the Dutch envoy Count Liedekerke-De Beaufort had followed pope Pius IX in his exile in Gaeta, Magrini remained in Rome and tried to provide his superior with information. Koelman notes that the chancellor revealed himself as an outspoken sympathizer of the clerical faction during this period. Other testimonies point in the same direction. Nicola Roncalli reports in his Diario that Magrini was mentioned in the same breath with, among others, the papal police officer Giovanni Minardi, as a 'notorious spy' in a republican pamphlet found by the police (2 July 1851). Although Magrini did sign the protest by foreign diplomats in Rome calling on the French commander Charles Oudinot to spare the Roman monuments during the siege of Rome in 1849, he explicitly refrained from making a 'political' judgment. After the fall of the Roman Republic on 14 July 1849, Magrini was appointed to the commission that, by order of the same Oudinot, surveyed the war damage, and he endorsed its assessment that damage was little.
$Magrini.it_IT:
Paul Émile (Paolo Emilio) Magrini fu assunto, almeno negli anni Trenta dell'Ottocento, dall'inviato olandese presso la Santa Sede, il conte Liedekerke de Beaufort, come segretario privato, una posizione al di fuori del corpo diplomatico olandese. La situazione cambiò nel 1836, quando il ministro degli Esteri Verstolk, su richiesta di Liedekerke, presentò al re Guglielmo I una richiesta per conferire a M. il titolo onorifico di cancelliere presso la legazione olandese, un titolo concesso raramente, ad eccezione della missione olandese a Costantinopoli. Nella motivazione presentata dal ministro al re il 18 giugno 1836, Liedekerke scrisse che Magrini 'ha sempre mostrato la massima benevolenza nei confronti dei sudditi di Vostra Maestà a Roma e [è stato] al loro servizio grazie alle sue relazioni, ovunque potesse'. Inoltre, Liedekerke sottolineò che i romani erano molto sensibili ai titoli (onorifici) e che un titolo del genere sarebbe stato 'utile a M. per combinare un matrimonio con la figlia di un conte romano' (Van Galen Last, 74-75). Una lettera successiva di Liedekerke al ministro Van Hall (15 febbraio 1855 n. 707, Archivi Nazionali, Affari Esteri 2.05.01, n. inv. 2157) suggerisce che Magrini fosse effettivamente riuscito a sposarsi nell'alta società romana.
Nel 1839, alla sua nomina a cancelliere seguì una promozione ancora più insolita ad addetto onorario e, inoltre (dal 1845), un'indennità annuale, nonostante il fatto che il re Guglielmo I, dopo il riconoscimento di M. come cancelliere onorario nel 1836, avesse avvertito che ciò non avrebbe mai dovuto portare ad alcuna carica ufficiale presso la legazione. Durante gli anni '50 dell'Ottocento, tuttavia, alla Camera dei rappresentanti olandese sorsero preoccupazioni riguardo alla retribuzione dei cancellieri e di altro personale locale (onorario) presso le ambasciate (oltre che a Roma, lo stesso era accaduto a Madrid, Berlino, Francoforte e Bruxelles). Il 16 dicembre 1854, il ministro Van Hall decise di privare Magrini del titolo di addetto onorario e di revocargli anche l'indennità annuale di 600 fiorini. Il tentativo fallito di Liedekerke (lettera del 15 febbraio 1855, citata sopra) di consentire almeno a M. di conservare i suoi titoli indica ancora una volta che i principali meriti dell'uomo riguardavano i 'touristes néerlandais', che egli aveva introdotto nell'alta società romana.
Al contrario, il pittore olandese Jan Philip Koelman (1818-1893) affermò nelle sue memorie In Rome 1846-1851 (1869) che Magrini era rispettato da quasi nessuno nella Città Eterna e che si rendeva completamente ridicolo con i titoli onorifici che aveva scritto in caratteri ricci sul suo biglietto da visita. Durante la Repubblica Romana del 1849, quando l'inviato olandese conte Liedekerke-De Beaufort seguì papa Pio IX nel suo esilio a Gaeta, Magrini rimase a Roma e cercò di fornire informazioni al suo superiore. Koelman - repubblicano convinto - osserva che il cancelliere si rivelò un simpatizzante dichiarato della fazione clericale durante questo periodo. Altre testimonianze vanno nella stessa direzione. Nicola Roncalli riferisce nel suo Diario che Magrini era menzionato insieme, tra gli altri, all'ufficiale di polizia papale Giovanni Minardi, come 'famigerato spia' in un opuscolo repubblicano trovato dalla polizia (2 luglio 1851). Sebbene Magrini abbia firmato la protesta dei diplomatici stranieri a Roma che chiedevano al comandante francese Charles Oudinot di risparmiare i monumenti romani durante l'assedio di Roma nel 1849, si è esplicitamente astenuto dal dare un giudizio 'politico' sui danni causati dai bombardamenti. Dopo la caduta della Repubblica Romana il 14 luglio 1849, Magrini fu nominato membro della commissione che, per ordine dello stesso Oudinot, valutò i danni di guerra, e approvò la sua valutazione secondo cui i danni erano stati minimi.
$Magrini.nl_NL:
Paul Émile (Paolo Emilio) Magrini was ten minste in de jaren 1830 bij de Nederlandse gezant bij de Heilige Stoel, graaf Liedekerke de Beaufort, in dienst als particulier secretaris, een functie die buiten het Nederlandse corps diplomatique viel. Dat veranderde in 1836, toen minister van Buitenlandse Zaken Verstolk, op verzoek van Liedekerke, M. bij koning Willem I voordroeg voor de honoraire titel van kanselier bij het gezantschap, een titel die – met uitzondering van de missie in Constantinopel, zelden werd verleend. In de onderbouwing van Liedekerke die de minister op 18 juni 1836 aan de koning voorlegde was geschreven dat Magrini 'de onderdanen van Uwe Majesteit te Rome komen steeds de meeste welwillendheid [betoonde en hen] door zijn betrekkingen, daar waar hij kan, van dienst [was]'. Ook de wetenschap dat de Romeinen zeer gevoelig waren voor titulatuur en dat het toekennen van een titel 'zoude kunnen strekken tot het gemakkelijk maken van eene huwelijks verbindtenis van den Heer Magrini met den dochter van eenen Romeinschen Graaf ' (Van Galen Last, 74-75). Uit een latere brief van Liedekerke aan minister Van Hall (15 februiari 1855 no. 707, Nationaal Archief, Buitenlandse Zaken 2.05.01, inv.nr. 2157) valt op te maken dat Magrini er inderdaad in geslaagd was in de hoge kringen te trouwen. Op zijn benoeming tot kanselier volgde in 1839 zelfs een hoogste ongebruikelijk promotie tot attaché honorair, en daarnaast werd hem vanaf 1845 zelfs een vast jaarlijkse beloning toegekend, in weerwil van de kanttekening die koning Willem I had gemaakt bij M.'s benoeming tot honorair kanselier, namelijk dat die nooit tot enige vorm van aanstelling bij het gezantschap mocht leiden. In de loop van de jaren 1850 rezen echter bij de Tweede Kamer bedenkingen over de beloning van kanseliers en andere lokale (honaire) krachten bij de gezantschappen (behalve in Rome ook in Madrid, Berlijn, Frankfurt en Brussel). In 1854 besloot minister Van Hall op 16 dec. 1854 Magrini zijn titel van honorair attaché te ontnemen en tevens zijn jaarlijkse toelage van 600 gulden in te trekken. Uit de vergeefse poging van Liedekerke (dezelfde brief aan Van Hall d.d. 15 februari 1855) om M. tenminste zijn titels de laten behouden valt nog eens op te maken dat diens belangrijkste verdiensten de 'touristes néerlandais' betroffen, die hij introducties in de Romeinse society bezorgde.
De Nederlandse schilder Jan Philip Koelman (1818-1893) beweert in zijn memoires In Rome 1846-1851(1869) juist dat Magrini door weinigen in de Eeuwige Stad voor vol werd aangezien en dat hij zich met de eretitels die hij in gekrulde letters op zijn visitekaart liet zetten volstrekt belachelijk maakte. Tijdens de Romeinse Republiek van 1849, toen de Nederlandse gezant graaf Liedekerke-De Beaufortv in het kielzog van paus Pius IX naar Gaeta was uitgeweken, bleef Magrini in Rome en probeerde hij zijn superieur van informatie te voorzien. Koelman merkt op dat de kanselier zich in deze periode als een uitgesproken klerikaal liet kennen. Andere getuigenissen wijzen in dezelfde richting. Nicola Roncalli meldt in zijn Diario dat Magrini in één adem met onder meer de pauselijke politiefunctionaris Giovanni Minardi werd genoemd als een 'beruchte spion' in een door de politie gevonden republikeins pamflet (2 juli 1851). Magrini ondertekende weliswaar het protest waarmee het Romeinse corps diplomatique de Franse bevelhebber Charles Oudinot in 1849 opriep in zijn beleg op Rome de kunst en monumenten te sparen, hij onthield expliciet van een 'politiek' oordeel. Na de val van de Romeinse Republiek op 14 juli 1849 werd Magrini benoemd in de commissie die op last van diezelfde Oudinot de oorlogsschade in kaart bracht, en (ook Magrini) oordeelde dat die erg meeviel.

$Mamiani.en_GB: Terenzio Mamiani della Rovere, Count of Sant'Angelo in Lizzola, was a writer, philosopher, patriot and politician. He served under Pope Pius IX as Minister of the Interior and Prime Minister (4 May – 17 August 1848), and was appointed Minister of Foreign Affairs the day after his predecessor Pellegrino Rossi was assassinated, an office he held from 16 November to 23 December 1848. He resigned after the pope, who had fled Rome in November 1848, had installed a three-headed administration or Suprema Giunta di Stato that sought to appoint a provisional government without consulting parliament. Mamiani was then elected as deputy to the Constituent Assembly of the Roman States on 21 January 1849. When, on the night of 8-9 February, the Assembly voted on Quirico Filopanti's proposal to declare the Roman Republic, Mamiani voted against it and subsequently resigned his post. In the last government of the Kingdom of Sardinia-Piedmont (Cavour III), he was Minister of Education; after the proclamation of the Kingdom of Italy, he became a senator (from 1864). He resigned in 1867, but continued to play an important role as a political advisor, for instance at the time of the capture of Rome in 1870.
$Mamiani.it_IT: Terenzio Mamiani della Rovere, conte di Sant'Angelo in Lizzola, fu scrittore, filosofo, patriota e politico. Sotto il pontificato di Pio IX ricoprì la carica di Ministro degli Interni e di Primo Ministro (4 maggio - 17 agosto 1848) e fu nominato Ministro degli Affari Esteri all'indomani dell'assassinio del suo predecessore Pellegrino Rossi, carica che ricoprì dal 16 novembre al 23 dicembre 1848. Si dimise dopo che il Papa, fuggito da Roma nel novembre 1848, aveva insediato un'amministrazione a tre teste o Suprema Giunta di Stato che cercava di nominare un governo provvisorio senza consultare il Parlamento. Mamiani fu quindi eletto deputato all'Assemblea Costituente degli Stati Romani il 21 gennaio 1849. Quando, nella notte tra l'8 e il 9 febbraio, l'Assemblea votò sulla proposta di Quirico Filopanti di dichiarare la Repubblica Romana, Mamiani votò contro e successivamente si dimise dalla carica. Nell'ultimo governo del Regno di Sardegna-Piemonte (Cavour III), fu Ministro della Pubblica Istruzione; dopo la proclamazione del Regno d'Italia, divenne senatore (dal 1864). Si dimise nel 1867, ma continuò a svolgere un ruolo importante come consigliere politico, ad esempio al momento della presa di Roma nel 1870.
$Mamiani.nl_NL: Terenzio Mamiani della Rovere, graaf van Sant'Angelo in Lizzola, was schrijver, filosoof, patriot en politicus. Onder paus Pius IX was hij onder meer minister van Binnenlandse Zaken en premier (4 mei - 17 augustus 1848). Direct na de moord op Pellegrino Rossi (15 november 1848) werd hij benoemd tot de nieuwe minister van Buitenlandse Zaken (16 november - 23 december 1848). Hij bood zijn ontslag aan nadat de paus in november 1848 uit Rome was gevlucht en een driekoppig bestuur of Suprema Giunta di Stato was aangetreden, dat buiten het parlement om, een voorlopige regering wilde benoemen. Mamiani werd vervolgens op 21 januari 1849 als gedeputeerde in de Grondwetgevende Vergadering van de Romeinse Staten gekozen. Toen die vergadering in de nacht van 8-9 februari stemde over het voorstel van Quirico Filopanti om de Romeinse Republiek uit te roepen, stemde Mamiani tegen en legde vervolgens zijn functie neer. In de laatste regering van het Koninkrijk Sardinië-Piemonte (Cavour III) was hij minister van Onderwijs; na de proclamatie van het Koninkrijk Italië werd hij senator (vanaf 1864). Hij diende in 1867 zijn ontslag in, maar bleef een belangrijke rol vervullen als politiek adviseur, ook ten tijde van de inname van Rome in 1870.

$Manna.en_GB: Giovanni Manna was an Italian jurist, economist and patriot. He was born in Naples in 1813. He made his debut as a writer in 1839 with his Storia della giurisprudenza. In 1848, he took part in the liberal government of the Kingdom of the Two Sicilies as Minister of Finance and even after the Restoration he managed to retain some prestige at the Bourbon court. In the summer of 1860, he was once again Minister of Finance in Naples, but shortly afterwards he withdrew from politics to devote himself to university education. After the proclamation of the Kingdom of Italy, he was elected senator in 1862 and he became Minister of Industry and Trade. He died in 1865 in Naples.
$Manna.it_IT: Giovanni Manna fu un giurista, economista e patriota italiano. Nacque a Napoli nel 1813. Esordì come scrittore nel 1839 con una sua Storia della giurisprudenza. Nel 1848 partecipò, come Ministro delle Finanze, al governo liberale del Regno delle Due Sicilie e anche dopo la restaurazione riuscì a conservare del prestigio presso la corte borbonica. Fu nuovamente Ministro delle Finanze nell'estate del 1860. Dopo questa esperienza di governo si appartò dalla politica per dedicarsi all'insegnamento universitario. Dopo la proclamazione del Regno d'Italia, fu chiamato al Senato nel 1862 e gli fu affidato il ministero dell'Industria e del Commercio. Morì nel 1865 a Napoli.
$Manna.nl_NL: Giovanni Manna was een Italiaanse jurist, econoom en patriot. Hij werd in 1813 in Napels geboren. Met zijn Storia della giurisprudenza maakte hij in 1839 zijn debuut als schrijver. In 1848 nam hij deel aan de liberale regering van het Koninkrijk der Twee Siciliën als minister van Financiën; zelfs nadat de Bourbons alle liberale hervormingen hadden teruggedraaid wist hij enig aanzien te behouden aan het hof. In de zomer van 1860 was hij opnieuw minister van Financiën te Napels, maar korte tijd later trok hij zich terug uit de politiek om zich te wijden aan het universitair onderwijs. Na de proclamatie van het Koninkrijk Italië werd hij in 1862 gekozen als senator en werd hij minister van Industrie en Handel. Hij stierf in 1865 in Napels.

$Margarita.en_GB: Clemente Solaro Count of Margarita was born in Cuneo in 1792, the eldest son of Vittorio Luigi and Gabriella Galleani d'Agliano. He graduated in Law at the University of Turin in 1812. After the collapse of the Napoleonic Empire, Solaro entered diplomacy and was sent to Naples in 1816 as Secretary of the Sardinian legation. His activities were also supported by the 'Catholic Friendship' network, which had as its objectives the dissemination of the 'good press', obedience to the Church, and opposition to all manifestations of liberalism. In 1825 he was chargé d'affaires at the Sardinian legation in Madrid and from 1826 minister plenipotentiary in Spain. In 1835 he returned to Turin as Minister of Foreign Affairs. In European relations his work was unsuccessful; instead, he achieved notable results with the conclusion of numerous navigation and trade treaties, and with the opening of many new consulates between 1835 and 1846. Solaro's major activity was in ecclesiastical affairs, favouring the Church over the State in every way, going against the jurisdictionalist traditions and interests of the House of Savoy. When the liberal reform movement erupted in 1847, it signalled Solaro's downfall and he was soon forced to resign. He died in Turin in 1869.
$Margarita.it_IT: Clemente Solaro conte della Margarita nacque a Cuneo nel 1792, primogenito di Vittorio Luigi e di Gabriella Galleani d'Agliano. Si laureò in Legge all'Università di Torino nel 1812. Dopo il crollo dell'impero napoleonico e la Restaurazione, Solaro entrò in diplomazia e fin dal 1816 fu inviato a Napoli come Segretario della legazione sarda. La sua attività venne appoggiata anche grazie alla rete dell' “Amicizia cattolica”, che aveva come obiettivi la diffusione della 'buona stampa', l'obbedienza alla Chiesa, e l'opposizione a tutte le manifestazioni di liberalismo. Nel 1825 venne incaricato d'affari presso la legazione sarda di Madrid e dal 1826 ministro plenipotenziario in Spagna. Nel 1835 divenne ministro degli Esteri. Nelle relazioni europee il suo operato non ebbe successo; ottenne invece notevoli risultati con la stipula di numerosi trattati di navigazione e di commercio, e con l'apertura, tra il 1835 e il 1846, di molti nuovi consolati. La maggiore attività di Solaro fu rivolta agli affari ecclesiastici, favorendo in ogni modo la Chiesa al di sopra dello Stato e di combattere le tradizioni giurisdizionaliste sabaude. Di fronte all'esplodere del movimento per le riforme nel 1847, Solaro ne fu travolto e fu spinto alle dimissioni. Morì a Torino nel 1869.
$Margarita.nl_NL: Clemente Solaro Graaf van Margarita werd geboren in Cuneo in 1792, als oudste zoon van Vittorio Luigi en Gabriella Galleani d'Agliano. Hij studeerde af in de Rechten aan de universiteit van Turijn in 1812. Na de ineenstorting van het Napoleontische Rijk ging Solaro de diplomatie in; in 1816 werd hij naar Napels gestuurd als secretaris van de Legatie van het Koninkrijk Sardinië. Zijn activiteiten werden ook ondersteund door het netwerk van de 'Amicizia cattolica' ('Katholieke Vriendschap'), een genootschap dat zich ten doel stelde de 'goede pers' te verspreiden, en gehoorzaamheid aan de Kerk en verzet tegen alle uitingen van liberalisme te bevorderen. In 1825 was Solaro zaakgelastigde bij de Sardijnse legatie in Madrid; vanaf 1826 was hij gevolmachtigd minister in Spanje. In 1835 keerde hij terug naar Turijn als minister van Buitenlandse Zaken. In de Europese betrekkingen was zijn werk niet succesvol; in plaats daarvan bereikte hij opmerkelijke resultaten met het sluiten van talrijke navigatie- en handelsverdragen en met de opening van vele nieuwe consulaten tussen 1835 en 1846. Solaro hield zich vooral bezig met kerkelijke zaken, waarbij hij de kerk in alle opzichten boven de staat stelde en inging tegen de jurisdictie tradities en belangen van het Huis Savoia. Toen in 1847 de liberale hervormingsbeweging tot een uitbarsting kwam betekende dat Solaro's ondergang en moest hij weldra aftreden. Hij stierf in Turijn in 1869.

$Marini.en_GB: Pietro Marini was a Roman cardinal (from 1846 onwards). Marini entered the prelature under Leo XII and held various positions in the Church, including that of auditor of the tribunal of “Sacra Rota” (1826). In 1845, Gregory XVI named him governor of Rome. Although he had been accused of 'liberalism' earlier in his career, his time as governor gave him the reputation of being reactionary (according to D. Marini, neither of these accusations seem true). After naming Marini a cardinal-deacon, Pius IX appointed him apostolic legate to Forlì (1847). Marini left Forlì after the murder on Pellegrino Rossi (15 November 1848). He returned to Rome after the fall of the Roman Republic of 1849 and helped reform the Papal States. He held several other positions in the following years, including Prefect of the Congregation of Propaganda Fide and Prefect of the Tribunal of the “Segnatura Apostolica” (1858). Marini's godfather was Luigi Barnaba Chiaramonti, later pope Pius VII.
$Marini.it_IT: Pietro Marini è stato un cardinale romano (dal 1846). Marini entrò in prelatura sotto Leone XII e ricoprì diversi incarichi nella Chiesa, tra cui quello di uditore della tribunale della Sacra Rota (1826). Nel 1845 Gregorio XVI lo nominò governatore di Roma. Sebbene fosse stato accusato di “liberalismo” all'inizio della sua carriera, il suo periodo come governatore gli diede la reputazione di essere reazionario (secondo D. Marini, nessuna di queste accuse sembra vera). Pio IX, dopo aver nominato Marini cardinale-diacono, lo nominò legato apostolico a Forlì (1847). Marini lasciò Forlì dopo l'omicidio di Pellegrino Rossi (15 novembre 1848). Tornò a Roma dopo la caduta della Repubblica Romana del 1849 e contribuì a riformare lo Stato Pontificio. Negli anni successivi ricoprì diversi altri incarichi, tra cui Prefetto della Congregazione di Propaganda Fide e Prefetto del Tribunale della Segnatura Apostolica (1858). Il padrino di Marini fu Luigi Barnaba Chiaramonti, futuro papa Pio VII.
$Marini.nl_NL: Pietro Marini was een Romeinse kardinaal (vanaf 1846). Eerder was hij prelaat geworden onder Leo XII en bekleedde verschillende functies in de Kerk, waaronder die van auditor van de Romeinse Rota (1826). In 1845 stelde Gregorius XVI hem aan als gouverneur van Rome. Hoewel Marini eerder wel beschuldigd werd van 'liberalisme', kreeg hij in zijn tijd als gouverneur juist de reputatie van reactionair (D. Marini lijken geen van beide juist). Nadat hij kardinaal werd, benoemde Pius IX Marini tot apostolisch afgevaardigde te Forlì (1847). Marini verliet Forlì na de moord op Pellegrino Rossi (15 november 1848). Hij keerde na de val van de Romeinse Republiek van 1849 terug naar Rome en hielp hij met de pauselijke restauratie. Hij bekleedde nog enkele functies in de daaropvolgende jaren, waaronder prefect van de Congregatie van Propaganda Fide en van de Congregatie van de Rechtbank van de Apostolische Signatuur (1858). Marini's peetvader was Luigi Barnaba Chiaramonti, de latere paus Pius VII.

$Marmora.en_GB: Alfonso Ferrero della Marmora was a marquis, politician and general from Piedmont, whose military career took off during the First Italian War of Independence (1848-1849), when he was quickly promoted from major to general. In April 1849, the king of Piedmont-Sardinia Victor Emanuel II tasked him with quelling the moti di Genova (the popular uprisings following the armistice with Austria the king had signed). As minister of War (1849), Della Marmora reorganised the army of Piedmont-Sardinia; during the Crimean War of 1855-1856, he was supreme commander of the army. From 1864-1866, he was prime-minister of Italy, before reassuming the command of the army during the Third Italian War of Independence (1859), a post he eventually resigned from after the dramatic defeat Italy suffered at Custoza (1866). In the years until his death, he published several works about (military) events he was involved in, such as the revolts in Genova and the reorganisation of the army: Quattro discorsi del generale La Marmora ai suoi colleghi della Camera sulle condizioni dell'esercito italiano (1871) and Un episodio del Risorgimento italiano (1875).
$Marmora.it_IT: Alfonso Ferrero della Marmora fu un marchese, politico e generale piemontese, la cui carriera militare prese il via durante la Prima Guerra d'Indipendenza italiana (1848-1849), quando fu rapidamente promosso da maggiore a generale. Nell'aprile 1849 il re di Piemonte-Sardegna Vittorio Emanuele II lo incaricò di sedare i moti di Genova (i moti popolari seguiti all'armistizio con l'Austria firmato dal re). Come ministro della Guerra (1849), Della Marmora riorganizzò l'esercito del Piemonte-Sardegna; durante la guerra di Crimea del 1855-1856 fu comandante supremo dell'esercito. Dal 1864 al 1866 fu primo ministro italiano, prima di riassumere il comando dell'esercito durante la Terza Guerra d'Indipendenza italiana (1859), incarico dal quale si dimise dopo la drammatica sconfitta subita a Custoza (1866). Negli anni successivi fino alla morte pubblicò diversi lavori sugli eventi (militari) a cui fu coinvolto, come le rivolte di Genova e la riorganizzazione dell'esercito: Quattro discorsi del generale La Marmora ai suoi colleghi della Camera sulle condizioni dell'esercito italiano (1871) e Un episodio del Risorgimento italiano (1875).
$Marmora.nl_NL: Alfonso Ferrero della Marmora was een Piemontese markies, politicus en militair, die tijdens de Eerste Italiaanse Onafankelijkheidsoorlog (1848-1849) snel carrière maakte en van majoor ten slotte generaal werd. Door de koning van Sardinië-Piemonte Victor Emanuel II werd hij in april 1849 aangewezen om de moti di Genova de kop in te drukken (de volksopstanden die uitbraken nadat de koning een wapenstilstand met Oostenrijk had getekend). Als minister van Oorlog (1849) reorganiseerde Della Marmora het Piemontese leger, waarvan hij tijdens de Krimoorlog in 1855-1856 als bevelhebber optrad. Van 1864-1866 was hij premier van Italië, alvorens opnieuw het opperbevel over het leger te aanvaarden tijdens de Derde Italiaanse Onafhankelijkheidsoorlog (1859). Na de dramatische nederlaag bij Custoza (1866) moest hij die functie neerleggen. In de jaren tot zijn dood publiceerde hij nog enkele werken over de (militaire) gebeurtenissen waarin hij een aandeel had gehad, zoals de opstanden in Genua en de reorganisatie van het leger: Quattro discorsi del generale La Marmora ai suoi colleghi della Camera sulle condizioni dell'esercito italiano (1871) en Un episodio del Risorgimento italiano (1875).

$Martinez.en_GB:
Francisco de Paula Martínez de la Rosa y Berdejo was a Spanish writer and politician. A deputy in the Cortes of Cadiz that had promulgated an extremely liberal constitution in 1812, he was imprisoned by Ferdinand VIII for his liberal ideas (1814-20). In 1822 he became head of the government and was then in exile in France until 1831. Once again prime minister (1834-35), he was ambassador in Paris from 1844 to 1847, and 'Agente de Preces', formal representative of the Spanish government in Rome from 1848-1849. Although appointed in November 1847, Martinez de la Rosa did not arrive in the city until July 1848, when the 'liberal' phase of the flamboyant pontificate of the young Pope Mastai was at its height, after Pius' allocution Non Semel (29 April 1848) and shortly before the assassination of Count Peregrino Rossi in November. He followed the Pope in his exile to Gaeta during the Roman Republic of 1849 and witnessed his return to Rome, before he returned to Spain at the end of 1850. As a playwright, novelist and poet, he is now largely forgotten. Among his works, special mention deserves his play La conjuración de Venecia (“The Conspiracy of Venice”), written during his political exile in France and staged in Madrid shortly after he had become prime minister of the new government (1834). It was the first success of romantic theatre in Spain.
There he still played an important part in politics, among others as president of the Lower House between 1851 and 1857, and Minister of State and Overseas Territories (1857-1858), when he was dedicated to re-establishing a good understanding with Rome. His last position was that of president of the Congress of Deputies under prime minister Leopoldo O'Donnell.
$Martinez.it_IT:
Francisco de Paula Martínez de la Rosa y Berdejo fu uno scrittore e politico spagnolo. Deputato alle Cortes di Cadice, che nel 1812 avevano promulgato una costituzione estremamente liberale, fu imprigionato da Ferdinando VIII per le sue idee liberali (1814-20). Nel 1822 divenne capo del governo e fu poi in esilio in Francia fino al 1831. Nuovamente primo ministro (1834-35), fu ambasciatore a Parigi dal 1844 al 1847 e “Agente de Preces”, rappresentante formale del governo spagnolo a Roma dal 1848 al 1849. Benché nominato nel novembre 1847, Martinez de la Rosa arrivò in città solo nel luglio 1848, quando la fase “liberale” del pontificato del giovane Papa Mastai era al suo culmine, dopo l'allocuzione di Pio “Non Semel” (29 aprile 1848) e poco prima dell'assassinio del conte Peregrino Rossi in novembre. Seguì il Papa nel suo esilio a Gaeta durante la Repubblica Romana del 1849 e fu testimone del suo ritorno a Roma, prima di rientrare in Spagna alla fine del 1850. Come drammaturgo, romanziere e poeta, è oggi in gran parte dimenticato. Tra le sue opere, merita una menzione speciale la commedia La conjuración de Venecia (“La congiura di Venezia”), scritta durante il suo esilio politico in Francia e messa in scena a Madrid poco dopo essere diventato primo ministro del nuovo governo (1834). Fu il primo successo del teatro romantico in Spagna.
Qui svolse ancora un ruolo importante in politica, tra l'altro come presidente della Camera dei Deputati tra il 1851 e il 1857, e come Ministro di Stato e dei Territori d'Oltremare (1857-1858), quando si dedicò a ristabilire una buona intesa con Roma. La sua ultima carica fu quella di presidente del Congresso dei Deputati sotto il primo ministro Leopoldo O'Donnell.
$Martinez.nl_NL: Francisco de Paula Martínez de la Rosa y Berdejo was een Spaanse schrijver en politicus. Als afgevaardigde in de Cortes van Cádiz die in 1812 een extreem liberale grondwet hadden afgekondigd, werd hij door Ferdinand VIII gevangengezet vanwege zijn liberale ideeën (1814-20). In 1822 werd hij regeringsleider en verbleef vervolgens tot 1831 in ballingschap in Frankrijk. Hij was opnieuw premier (1834-35), was ambassadeur in Parijs van 1844 tot 1847 en 'Agente de Preces', formele vertegenwoordiger van de Sopanese regering in Rome van 1848-1849. Hoewel benoemd in november 1847, arriveerde Martinez de la Rosa pas in juli 1848 in de stad, toen de 'liberale' fase van het flamboyante pontificaat van de jonge paus Mastai op zijn hoogtepunt was, na Pius' toespraak Non Semel (29 april 1848) en kort voor de moord op graaf Peregrino Rossi in november. Hij volgde de paus in zijn ballingschap naar Gaeta tijdens de Romeinse Republiek van 1849 en was getuige van zijn terugkeer naar Rome, voordat hij eind 1850 terugkeerde naar Spanje. Daar speelde hij nog steeds een belangrijke politieke rol, onder andere als voorzitter van het Lagerhuis tussen 1851 en 1857, en minister van Staat en Overzeese Gebiedsdelen (1857-1858), toen hij zich inzette voor het herstel van een goede verstandhouding met Rome. Zijn laatste functie was die van voorzitter van het Congres van Afgevaardigden onder premier Leopoldo O'Donnell. Als toneelschrijver, romanschrijver en dichter is hij nu grotendeels vergeten. Een speciale vermelding verdient zijn toneelstuk La conjuración de Venecia (“De samenzwering van Venetië”), geschreven tijdens zijn politieke ballingschap in Frankrijk en opgevoerd in Madrid kort nadat hij premier van de nieuwe regering was geworden (1834). Het was het eerste succes van het romantische theater in Spanje.

$Martino.en_GB: Giacomo De Martino was born in Tunis in 1811 to Renato, consul representing the Kingdom of the Two Sicilies in that city, and Maddalena Soler. Initiated to a diplomatic career, he became consul himself in Tangier and from 1848 in Marseille. He was then appointed ambassador in Rio de Janeiro, but never managed to go there. In 1855 he was transferred to Rome as chargé d'affaires of the Kingdom of the Two Sicilies; he would remain at this post until 1859. Of liberal persuasion, in 1860, upon his return to Naples, he was one of the main architects of a new foreign policy, which sought to reach an agreement between the kingdoms of the Two Sicilies and Sardinia, and to obtain French support to halt the advance of Garibaldi's legion. He then devoted himself to business activities and only returned to political life in 1865, running for Parliament where he was elected continuously from the 9th to the 13th legislature (1865-1879). He was little involved in parliamentary activity, as he mainly devoted himself to the administration of the Società delle strade ferrate romane, one of the state-subsidised railway companies. He died near Pontedera (Pisa) in 1879.
$Martino.it_IT: Giacomo De Martino nacque a Tunisi nel 1811 da Renato, console borbonico in quella città, e da Maddalena Soler. Avviato alla carriera diplomatica, fu console a Tangeri e dal 1848 a Marsiglia. Nominato ambasciatore a Rio de Janeiro, riuscì a non recarvisi mai e a farsi trasferire nel 1855 a Roma, come incaricato d'affari del Regno delle Due Sicilie, dove rimase fino al 1859. Di matrice liberale, nel 1860, dopo il suo ritorno a Napoli, fu tra i principali artefici di una nuova politica estera, che cercava di realizzare un accordo col Piemonte e ad ottenere la protezione francese contro l'avanzata garibaldina. Si dedicò quindi alle attività commerciali e torno alla vita politica solo nel 1865 candidandosi al Parlamento dove fu eletto ininterrottamente dalla IX alla XIII legislatura. Si impegnò poco nell'attività parlamentare, poiché si dedicò principalmente all'amministrazione della Società delle strade ferrate romane, una delle compagnie ferroviarie sovvenzionate dallo Stato. Morì presso Pontedera (Pisa) nel 1879.
$Martino.nl_NL: Giacomo De Martino werd in 1811 in Tunis geboren als zoon van Renato, consul namens het Koninkrijk der Beide Siciliën in die stad, en Maddalena Soler. Hij begon een diplomatieke carrière en werd zelf consul in Tanger en vanaf 1848 in Marseille. Hij werd vervolgens benoemd tot ambassadeur in Rio de Janeiro, maar slaagde er nooit in daarheen te gaan. In 1855 werd hij overgeplaatst naar Rome als zaakgelastigde van het Koninkrijk der Beide Siciliën; tot 1859 zou hij op deze post blijven. In 1860, na zijn terugkeer naar Napels, was hij een van de architecten van een nieuw buitenlands beleid, dat erop gericht was een akkoord te bereiken tussen de koninkrijken van Napels en Sardinië, en Franse steun te verwerven om de opmars van Garibaldi te stuiten. Daarna wijdde hij zich aan zakelijke activiteiten. Pas in 1865 keerde hij in het politieke leven terug door zich kandidaat te stellen voor het parlement, waar hij vervolgens onafgebroken werd gekozen van de 9e tot de 13e zittingsperiode (1865-1879). Hij was weinig betrokken bij parlementaire activiteiten, omdat hij zich in deze periode voornamelijk toelegde op het bestuur van de Società delle strade ferrate romane, een van de door de staat gesubsidieerde spoorwegmaatschappijen. Hij stierf in de buurt van Pontedera (Pisa) in 1879.

$MarzanoA.en_GB: Alessandro Asinari di San Marzano was a Piedmontese prelate and archbishop of Efese from 1846 onwards. Shortly after his consecration in February of 1846, Marzano was sent as a nuncio to Belgium. He stayed there for two years and returned to Rome after the fall of the Roman Republic of 1849. Pius IX named him advisor to the Congregation of the Index and the Congregation of Bishops and Regulars (1851), and later custodian of the Vatican Library (1853), a post that Marzano retained until his death in 1876. He left his sizeable personal library to the Vatican Library.
$MarzanoA.it_IT: Alessandro Asinari di San Marzano fu un prelato piemontese e arcivescovo di Efeso dal 1846. Poco dopo la sua consacrazione, nel febbraio del 1846, Marzano fu inviato come nunzio in Belgio. Vi rimase due anni e ritornò a Roma dopo la caduta della Repubblica Romana nel 1849. Pio IX lo nominò consigliere della Congregazione dell'Indice e della Congregazione dei Vescovi e Regolari (1851) e poi conservatore della Biblioteca Vaticana (1853), incarico che Marzano mantenne fino alla sua morte nel 1876. Lasciò la sua cospicua biblioteca personale alla Biblioteca Vaticana.
$MarzanoA.nl_NL: Alessandro Asinari di San Marzano was een prelaat uit Piemonte en aartsbisschop van Efese vanaf 1846. Kort na zijn consecratie in februari 1846, werd Marzano als nuntius naar België gezonden. Hij bleef daar twee jaar en keerde na de val van de Romeinse Republiek van 1849 terug naar Rome. Pius IX benoemde hem toen tot adviseur van de Congregatie van de Index en de Congregatie van Bisschoppen en Leken (1851), en later tot huisbewaarder van de Vaticaanse Bibliotheek (1853). Deze functie behield Marzano tot zijn dood in 1876. Hij liet zijn aanzienlijke persoonlijke bibliotheek na aan de Vaticaanse Bibliotheek.

$Matteucci.en_GB: Antonio Matteucci was a cardinal from Fermo, who was elevated to the cardinalate in 1866 by Pius IX. After the fall of the Roman Republic of 1849 and the restauration of papal authority in Rome, Pius IX appointed Matteucci to the post of director general of the police (1852) and governor and vice-chamberlain (1853). Matteucci's elevation to the cardinalate in 1866 became a controversial matter: he received much criticism, not only for his tenure as governor of Rome, but also for his amorous relationships with women, including the married woman Nina. This also raised questions during the process of beatification of Pius IX much later (2000). Matteucci died a few weeks after he became a cardinal, in the presence of the pope.
$Matteucci.it_IT: Antonio Matteucci fu cardinale proveniente da Fermo, elevato al cardinalato nel 1866 da Pio IX. Dopo la caduta della Repubblica Romana nel 1849 e la restaurazione dell'autorità pontificia a Roma, Pio IX nominò Matteucci direttore generale della polizia (1852), Governatore e vice-ciambellano (1853). L'elevazione di Matteucci al cardinalato nel 1866 fu molto controversa: ricevette critiche, non solo per il suo mandato come Governatore di Roma, ma anche per i suoi rapporti amorosi con le donne, tra cui la sposata Nina. Ciò sollevò interrogativi anche successivamente durante il processo di beatificazione di Pio IX molto più tardi (2000). Matteucci morì poche settimane dopo essere diventato cardinale alla presenza del papa.
$Matteucci.nl_NL: Antonio Matteucci was afkomstig uit Fermo en werd in 1866 door Pius IX tot kardinaal benoemd. Na het herstel van het pauselijk gezag in Rome en de val van de Romeinse Republiek van 1849, stelde Pius IX hem aan als directeur-generaal van de politie (1852), en als gouverneur van Rome en vice-camerlengo (1853). Matteucci's promotie tot het kardinaalschap in 1866 deed veel stof opwaaien: hij had namelijk veel kritiek gekregen, niet alleen voor zijn optreden als gouverneur, maar ook vanwege zijn amoureuze relaties met vrouwen, in het bijzonder de getrouwde vrouw Nina. Dit werd ook ter discussie gebracht bij het latere proces van beatificatie van Pius IX (2000).  Matteucci stierf slechts enkele weken nadat hij kardinaal werd, in het bijzijn van de paus.

$Mattioli.en_GB: Giuseppe Camillo Mattioli was arrested in Bologna in 1844 for plotting a conspiracy against the papal authority. He was released in 1846 due to Pius' amnesty edict. The provisory government in 1849 in popeless Rome appointed Mattioli president of the province of Ancona in January of 1849, to replace Aurelio Saffi. He was witness to the anti-revolutionary rebellion that was suppressed by Felice Orsini, and then to the occupation of Austria (22 May-19 June 1849). When Ancona fell, Mattioli fled to Corfù. He returned to Italy in 1859 and joined Mazzini's Partito d'Azione. In 1868 he became a teacher in Italian literature, history and geography and started teaching at the R. Istituto Tecnico in Bologna, which he did until his death. He also stayed politically engaged on the municipal level and continued to promote his own patriotism and Mazzini's political ideals.
$Mattioli.it_IT: Giuseppe Camillo Mattioli fu arrestato a Bologna nel 1844 per aver ordito una congiura contro l'autorità pontificia. Fu rilasciato nel 1846 grazie all'editto di amnistia di Pio XII. Il governo provvisorio di Roma del 1849, in assenza del papa, nominò Mattioli presidente della provincia di Ancona nel gennaio 1849, in sostituzione di Aurelio Saffi. Fu testimone della rivolta antirivoluzionaria repressa da Felice Orsini, e poi dell'occupazione dell'Austria (22 maggio-19 giugno 1849). Caduta Ancona, Mattioli fuggì a Corfù. Ritornò in Italia nel 1859 e aderì al Partito d'Azione di Mazzini. Nel 1868 divenne insegnante di letteratura italiana, storia e geografia e iniziò l'insegnamento presso il Regio Istituto Tecnico di Bologna, cosa che mantenne fino alla morte. Rimase impegnato politicamente anche a livello comunale e continuò la sua attività patriottica e gli ideali politici di Mazzini.
$Mattioli.nl_NL: Giuseppe Camillo Mattioli werd in 1844 in Bologna gearresteerd wegens het beramen van een samenzwering tegen het pauselijk gezag. In 1846 kwam hij vrij dankzij de amnestieregeling van Pius IX. De voorlopige regering in het pausloze Rome wees hem in januari 1849 aan als president van de provincie Ancona, ter vervanging van Aurelio Saffi. Daar maakte hij eerst de antirevolutionaire opstand mee die door Felice Orsini werd onderdrukt, en daarna de belegering door de Oostenrijkers (22 mei-19 juni 1849). Toen Ancona viel, vluchtte Mattioli naar Corfù. In 1859 keerde hij terug naar Italië, waar hij toetrad tot Mazzini's Partito d'Azione. In 1868 werd hij docent Italiaanse literatuur, geschiedenis en geografie, en begon hij les te geven aan het R. Istituto Tecnico in Bologna, iets wat hij tot aan zijn dood zou doen. Hij bleef ook politiek geëngageerd op lokaal niveau en bleef opkomen voor zijn patriottische idealen en de politieke visies van Mazzini.

$Mattos.en_GB: Joseph Henri Texeira de Mattos was a scion of a Portuguese-Jewish family that settled in Amsterdam at the end of the 17th century. His father Samuel Teixeira de Mattos (1791-1865) founded a bank in 1852, which was taken over by his two sons Isaac Eduard (1832-1885) and Abraham Louis (1839-1908), creating the banking house (general partnership) 'Gebr. Teixeira de Mattos'. Their elder brother Joseph Henri was active as an agent of the Steam Navigation Company 'Nederland', among other things. On 26 December 1873 he was appointed consul for the Kingdom of the Netherlands in Venice, in 1880 he became consul-general there, and in 1889 and appointment as consul-general in Budapest followed, where he also died in 1898. Texeira de Mattos was elevated to the peerage on 27 November 1888 by royal decree and was allowed to call himself a squire from then on. He had been decorated as a Knight in Order of the Crown of Italy, in the Austrian Franz-Joseph Order and in the Dutch Order of the Oak Crown.
$Mattos.it_IT: Joseph Henri Texeira de Mattos fu il rampollo di una famiglia ebrea portoghese che si stabilì ad Amsterdam alla fine del XVII secolo. Suo padre Samuel Teixeira de Mattos (1791-1865) fondò nel 1852 una banca, che fu rilevata dai suoi due figli Isaac Eduard (1832-1885) e Abraham Louis (1839-1908), creando la società bancaria (società in nome collettivo) 'Gebr. Teixeira de Mattos'. Il loro fratello maggiore Joseph Henri era attivo, tra le altre cose, come agente della Steam Navigation Company 'Nederland'. Il 26 dicembre 1873 fu nominato console del Regno dei Paesi Bassi a Venezia, nel 1880 divenne console generale e nel 1889 seguì la nomina a console generale a Budapest, dove morì anche lui nel 1898. Texeira de Mattos fu elevato al titolo nobiliare il 27 novembre 1888 con decreto reale e da quel momento in poi gli fu permesso di chiamarsi scudiero. Venne decorato come Cavaliere nell'Ordine della Corona d'Italia, nell'Ordine austriaco di Francesco Giuseppe e nell'Ordine olandese della Corona di Quercia.
$Mattos.nl_NL: Joseph Henri Texeira de Mattos was een telg van een Portugees-Joods geslacht dat zich aan het einde van de zeventiende eeuw in Amsterdam vestigde. Zijn vader Samuel Teixeira de Mattos (1791-1865) stichtte in 1852 een bankierskantoor, dat in 1852 door zijn beide zoons Isaac Eduard (1832-1885) en Abraham Louis (1839-1908), werd overgenomen, waarmee het bankiershuis (vennootschap onder firma) Gebr. Teixeira de Mattos onstond. Hun oudere broer Joseph Henri was onder meer actief als agent van de Stoomvaartmaatschappij “Nederland”. Op 26 december 1873 werd hij benoemd tot consul voor het Koninkrijk der Nederlanden in Venetië, in 1880 werd hij consul-generaal, en in 1889 volgde en benoeming in dezelfde functie in Budapest, waar hij in 1898 ook overleed. Texeira de Mattos werd op 27 november 1888 bij KB in de adelstand verheven en mocht zich vanaf dat moment jonkheer noemen. Hij was gedecoreerd als Ridder in de Orde van de Italiaanse Kroon, de Oostenrijke Frans-Jozefs Orde en de Nederlandse Orde van de Eikenkroon.

$Mazel.en_GB: Jean Zacharia Mazel was born to a family originally from the Languedoc, France. At a young age his artistic talents emerged as a draughtsman, later engraver and etcher, which he further developed under the guidance of Carl Senefelder. Although he remained active as an artist and collector, he first focused his attention on a career as a civil servant. At the Ministry of Foreign Affairs he successively served as commissioner (1819-1823), head of department (1823-1841) and eventually secretary-general (1841-1863). His acceptance of the latter position coincided with his appointment as director of the Mauritshuis museum, a function he fulfilled until old age (1874). His prominent role in the art scene of his native The Hague was further apparent in his involvement in the foundation of a Museum of Modern Art (founded in 1866, today the 'Kunstmuseum'), together with H.F. baron van Zuylen van Nijevelt and several artists. In addition, Mazel was a member of the Royal Institute, Fourth Class (Fine Arts) and the society Arte et Amicitia in Amsterdam. In 1820, he had married Maria Frederika Steyn Parvé (1795-1884).
$Mazel.it_IT: Jean Zacharia Mazel nacque da una famiglia originaria della Linguadoca, in Francia. Già in giovane età era emerso il suo talento artistico come disegnatore, poi incisore e acquafortista, che sviluppò ulteriormente sotto la guida di Carl Senefelder. Sebbene fosse rimasto attivo come artista e collezionista, concentrò inizialmente la sua attenzione sulla carriera di funzionario pubblico. Al Ministero degli Affari Esteri ricoprì successivamente la carica di commissario (1819-1823), capo dipartimento (1823-1841) e infine segretario generale (1841-1863). L'accettazione di quest'ultimo incarico coincise con la sua nomina a direttore del museo Mauritshuis, funzione che svolse fino alla vecchiaia (1874). Il suo ruolo di primo piano nella scena artistica della sua nativa L'Aia fu ulteriormente evidente nel suo coinvolgimento nella fondazione di un Museo d'Arte Moderna (fondato nel 1866, oggi il 'Kunstmuseum'), insieme al barone H.F. van Zuylen van Nijevelt e diversi artisti . Inoltre, Mazel era membro del Royal Institute, Fourth Class (Belle Arti) e della società Arte et Amicitia di Amsterdam. Nel 1820 sposò Maria Frederika Steyn Parvé (1795-1884).
$Mazel.nl_NL: Jean Zacharia Mazel werd geboren in een geslacht dat oorspronkelijk uit de Languedoc afkomstig was. Op jonge leeftijd bleek zijn artistieke talent als tekenaar, later als graveur en etser, dat hij verder ontplooide als leerling van Carl Senefelder. Hoewel hij als kunstenaar en verzamelaar actief bleef, richtte hij zich aanvankelijk vooral op een carrière in de ambtenarij: bij het ministerie van Buitenlandse Zaken was hij achtereenvolgens werkzaam als commissaris (1819-1823), referendaris (1823-1841) en ten slotte secretaris-generaal (1841-1863). Vrijwel gelijktijdig met het aanvaarden van die laatste functie werd hij eveneens directeur van het Mauritshuis, een rol die hij tot op hoge leeftijd bleef vervullen (1874). Zijn prominente plaats in de Haagse kunstwereld bleek verder uit zijn betrokkenheid bij de oprichting van het Museum voor Moderne Kunst (1866, nu het Kunstmuseum), samen met o.a. H.F. baron van Zuylen van Nijevelt en meerdere kunstenaars. Verder was Mazel onder meer lid van het Koninklijk Instituut, vierde klasse (Schoone Kunsten) en van het Amsterdamse kunstgezelschap Arte et Amicitia. Mazel was in 1820 getrouwd met Maria Frederika Steyn Parvé (1795-1884).

$Mazzini.en_GB: Giuseppe Mazzini was an Italian politician and patriot, and is commonly considered as one of the spiritual fathers of the Italian state. As a young man, he was part of the secret society the Carboneria (1827-1830), before he founded his own movement Giovine Italia (1831). During his exile in England (from 1837 onwards), he tried to garner international interest in the Italian cause and founded the movement of Young Europe (in which Italian, German and Polish nationalists joined forces). He returned to Italy in 1848, and was elected on 29 March 1849 to the triumvirate that led the Roman Republic, along with Aurelio Saffi and Carlo Armellini. After the fall of this republic, he returned to exile in London and founded the Italian National Committee (1850), which through loans and insurgencies was supposed to inspire a national war of liberation. Meanwhile, however, many Italian patriots had placed their hope for national liberation in Piedmont, and moderate liberal monarchist patriotism had overtaken Mazzini's democratic republicanism. After the Italian unification, Mazzini continued to oppose the 'rise' of the Kingdom Sardinia-Piedmont and persevered in his republicanism. In the spring of 1870, he organised an expedition from Palermo to free Rome from the papal yoke, but was arrested even before departure. He spent his last years as an exile in London, Lugano and in Pisa (as dr. Brown), where he died on 10 March 1872.
$Mazzini.it_IT: Giuseppe Mazzini fu un politico e patriota italiano, ed è comunemente considerato uno dei padri spirituali dello Stato italiano. Da giovane fece parte della società segreta della Carboneria (1827-1830), prima di fondare il proprio movimento Giovine Italia (1831). Durante il suo esilio in Inghilterra (dal 1837 in poi), cercò di suscitare l'interesse internazionale per la causa italiana e fondò il movimento della Giovane Europa (nel quale si unirono nazionalisti italiani, tedeschi e polacchi). Ritornato in Italia nel 1848, fu eletto il 29 marzo 1849 nel triumvirato che guidò la Repubblica Romana, insieme ad Aurelio Saffi e Carlo Armellini. Dopo la caduta di questa repubblica, tornò in esilio a Londra e fondò il Comitato Nazionale Italiano (1850), che attraverso prestiti e insurrezioni avrebbe dovuto ispirare una guerra di liberazione nazionale. Nel frattempo, però, molti patrioti italiani avevano riposto in Piemonte la speranza della liberazione nazionale, e il patriottismo monarchico liberale moderato aveva preso il sopravvento sul repubblicanesimo democratico di Mazzini. Dopo l'Unità d'Italia, Mazzini continuò ad opporsi all' “ascesa” del Regno del Piemonte Savoia e perseverò nel suo pensiero repubblicano. Nella primavera del 1870 organizzò da Palermo una spedizione per liberare Roma dal giogo papale, ma fu arrestato ancor prima della partenza. Trascorse i suoi ultimi anni di esule a Londra, Lugano e a Pisa (come dottor Brown), dove morì il 10 marzo 1872.
$Mazzini.nl_NL: Giuseppe Mazzini was een Italiaans politicus en patriot en wordt algemeen beschouwd als een van de geestelijk vaders van de Italiaanse eenheidsstaat. Hij maakte als jonge man deel uit van het geheime genootschap de Carboneria (1827-1830), maar richtte spoedig zijn eigen beweging Giovine Italia (1831) op. Tijdens zijn ballingschap in Engeland (vanaf 1837) poogde hij in het buitenland sympathie voor de Italiaanse zaak aan te wakkeren, mede door de oprichting van Jong Europa (waarin Italiaanse, Duitse en Poolse nationalisten de krachten bundelden). Hij keerde in 1848 terug naar Italië en werd op 29 maart 1849 met Aurelio Saffi en Carlo Armellini in het driemanschap van de Romeinse Republiek benoemd. Na de val van die republiek ging Mazzini weer in ballingschap in Londen, en richtte daar in 1850 het Italiaans Nationaal Comité op, dat met leningen en opstanden de aanstoot tot een nationale bevrijdingsoorlog moest geven. Inmiddels was echter de hoop van veel patriotten gevestigd op Piemonte en kreeg een gematigd liberaal monarchistisch patriottisme de overhand over Mazzini's democratisch republikanisme. Na de Italiaanse eenwording bleef hij tegenstander van de 'Piemontisering' van Italië en volhardde in zijn republicanisme. In de lente van 1870 organiseerde hij vanuit Palermo een expeditie om Rome te bevrijden, maar werd voor vertrek gearresteerd. Hij sleet zijn laatste jaren als balling in Londen, Lugano en (als dr. Brown) in Pisa, waar hij op 10 maart 1872 overleed.

$MedicidO.en_GB: Francesco de' Medici d'Ottajano was a Neapolitan cardinal, from a noble dynasty of the princes of Ottajano. He was canon of the cathedral of Huesca in Spain before becoming prelate in 1831, at the age of twenty-three. Pope Gregory XVI appointed him successively vice-legate of Velletri (4 April 1832), auditor of the cardinal-camerlengo (12 February 1838) and principal chamberlain of the pope (24 January 1842). During the pontificate of Pius IX, De' Medici was subsequently promoted to his majordomus and prefect of the Apostolic Palaces (17 May 1850). On 16 June 1856, he was elevated to the cardinalate. He was also played a prominent role in the Congregations of the Discipline of Laity, the Church Factory of St Peter, the Apostolic Visitation and Indulgences. De' Medici died in Rome of apoplexy, on 11 October 1856.
$MedicidO.it_IT: Francesco de' Medici d'Ottajano fu un cardinale napoletano, di una nobile dinastia dei principi di Ottajano. Fu canonico della cattedrale di Huesca in Spagna prima di diventare prelato nel 1831, all'età di ventitré anni. Papa Gregorio XVI lo nominò, in successione, vicelegato di Velletri (4 aprile 1832), uditore del cardinale camerlengo (12 febbraio 1838) e camerlengo principale del papa (24 gennaio 1842). Durante il pontificato di Pio IX, De' Medici fu successivamente promosso a suo maggiordomo e prefetto dei Palazzi Apostolici (17 maggio 1850). Il 16 giugno 1856 fu elevato al cardinalato. Svolse anche un ruolo di primo piano nelle Congregazioni della Disciplina dei Laici, della Fabbrica della Chiesa di San Pietro, della Visitazione Apostolica e delle Indulgenze. De' Medici morì a Roma di apoplessia, l'11 ottobre 1856.
$MedicidO.nl_NL: Francesco de' Medici d'Ottajano was een Napolitaans kardinaal, afkomstig uit een adellijke dynastie van de prinsen van Ottajano. Hij was kanunnik van de kathedraal van Huesca in Spanje voordat hij in 1831, op drieëntwintigjarige leeftijd, prelaat werd. Paus Gregorius XVI benoemde hem achtereenvolgens tot vice-legaat van Velletri (4 april 1832), auditor van de kardinaal-camerlengo (12 februari 1838) en hoofdkamerheer van de paus (24 januari 1842). Tijdens het pontificaat van Pius IX werd De' Medici vervolgens bevorderd tot diens majordomus en tot prefect van de Apostolische Paleizen (17 mei 1850). Op 16 juni 1856 werd hij tot het kardinalaat verheven. Daarnaast was hij verbonden aan de Congregaties van de Discipline van Leken, de Kerkfabriek van Sint Pieter, de Apostolische Visitatie en Aflaten. De' Medici stierf in Rome aan apoplexie, op 11 oktober 1856.

$Melegari.en_GB: Luigi Amedeo Melegari, jurist and politician, was born in Castelnuovo di Sotto (Reggio Emilia) in 1805, the son of poor farmers. After graduating in law in Rome, he took part in the revolutionary uprisings in the Duchy of Parma in 1831 and, after their failure, he was forced into exile in Marseille. There, he affiliated with Mazzini's Giovine Italia. He took part in the attempted invasion of Savoy in February 1834 and signed the pact of brotherhood of Giovine Europa with Mazzini. After moving to Lausanne, he moved away from revolutionary action and obtained a teaching position at the university. Here, he was commissioned to compile the Criminal Code (1843) and the Civil Procedure Code. In 1846, he moved to Paris. Two years later he returned to Italy and was appointed professor of Constitutional Law at the University of Turin. He held this professorship until 1860, when he was appointed councillor of state. He was one of the  most influential constitutionalists of the Kingdom of Italy, for which he was a deputy from 1849 to 1862 and a senator. In March 1862, during the Rattazzi government, he was appointed Secretary General of the Interior. In 1867 Melegari was sent to Bern as Italy's Minister Plenipotentiary. From March 1876 to December 1877 he was Minister of Foreign Affairs. He died in Bern in 1881.
$Melegari.it_IT: Luigi Amedeo Melegari, giurista e uomo politico, nacque a Castelnuovo di Sotto (Reggio Emilia) nel 1805, figlio di poveri agricoltori. Conseguita la laurea in giurisprudenza a Roma,nel 1831 prese parte ai moti rivoluzionari nel ducato di Parma e, dopo il loro fallimento, fu costretto all'esilio a Marsiglia, dove si affiliò alla Giovine Italia. Partecipò al tentativo d'invasione della Savoia del febbraio 1834 e firmò con Mazzini il patto di fratellanza della Giovine Europa. Trasferitosi a Losanna, si allontanò dall'azione rivoluzionaria, ottenendo un insegnamento all'università. Fu incaricato di compilare il Codice penale (1843) e quello di Procedura civile. Nel 1846 si trasferì a Parigi. Due anni dopo tornò in Italia e fu nominato professore di Diritto costituzionale all'università di Torino.
