Conservò la cattedra fino al 1860, quando venne nominato consigliere di Stato. Fu uno dei più autorevoli costituzionalisti del Regno. Fu deputato dal 1849 al 1862 e senatore. Nel marzo del 1862 fu designato segretario generale all'Interno nel governo Rattazzi; nel 1867 venne inviato come ministro plenipotenziario a Berna. Dal marzo 1876 al dicembre 1877 fu ministro degli Esteri. Morì a Berna nel 1881.
$Melegari.nl_NL: Luigi Amedeo Melegari, jurist en politicus, werd in 1805 geboren in Castelnuovo di Sotto (Reggio Emilia) als zoon van arme boeren. Na zijn rechtenstudie in Rome nam hij in 1831 deel aan de revolutionaire opstanden in het hertogdom Parma. Toen die waren mislukt werd hij gedwongen uit te wijken naar Marseille, waar hij zich aansloot bij de Giovine Italia, het geheime genootschap van Mazzini. Melegari nam vervolgens in februari 1834  deel aan de poging om in de Savoie een gewapender inval te doen en een opstand te ontketenen. Hij was, met Mazzini, een van de ondertekenaars van het broederschapspact van de Giovine Europa. Nadat hij naar Lausanne was verhuisd, zei hij de revolutionaire actie vaarwel en kreeg hij een baan als docent aan de universiteit. Daar kreeg hij de opdracht om het wetboek van strafrecht (1843) en het wetboek van burgerlijke rechtsvordering op te stellen. In 1846 verhuisde hij naar Parijs. Twee jaar later keerde hij terug naar Italië, waar hij werd benoemd tot hoogleraar constitutioneel recht aan de universiteit van Turijn. Dat professoraat bekleede hij tot 1860, toen hij tot staatsraad werd benoemd. Melegari was een van de meest invloedrijke constitutionalisten van het Koninkrijk Italië. Hij was afgevaardigde van 1849 tot 1862 en senator. In maart 1862 werd hij tijdens de regering Rattazzi benoemd tot secretaris-generaal op het ministerie van Binnenlandse Zaken; in 1867 werd hij als gevolmachtigd minister namens Italië naar Bern gezonden. Hij was minister van Buitenlandse Zaken van maart 1876 tot december 1877 en stierf in Bern in 1881.

$Menabrea.en_GB: Luigi Federico Menabrea was born in Chambéry in 1809. He became officer in the Corps of Engineers and was a teacher at the Military Academy of Turin from 1839 to 1848, working in the field of construction science. In 1848 he was elected to the Parlamento Subalpino, the first parliament of the Kingdom of Sardinia; he held his seat until 1860. In 1859-1860, he received important military assignments, such as the flooding of the plain between the Dora and Sesia rivers in 1859, to hinder the Austrian advance. He was also put in charge of the sieges of Ancona and Gaeta. From 1860 he was a senator, Minister of the Navy (1861-1862), and then of Public Works (1862-1864). As the Italian representative at the negotiations and signing of the Peace of Vienna (3 October 1866), he was honoured with the Collar of the Order of the Santissima Annunziata, the highest decoration of the Royal House of Savoia. In 1867, Menabrea was president of the Italian Council of Ministers when the Battle of Mentana took place, in which Garibaldi's volunteer legion was defeated by a coalition of papal and French troops. Later, he was charged with extraordinary missions to Vienna (1870) and Stockholm (1873) and became ambassador in London (1876-82) and Paris (1882-92). Menabrea was appointed member of the Accademia dei Lincei in 1874. He died in Cassin, Chambéry, in 1896.
$Menabrea.it_IT: Luigi Federico Menabrea nacque a Chambéry nel 1809. Ufficiale del genio, fu dal 1839 al 1848 insegnante all'Accademia militare di Torino occupandosi di scienza delle costruzioni. Nel 1848 fu eletto deputato al Parlamento subalpino e vi rimase fino al 1860. Nel 1859-1860 ebbe anche importanti incarichi militari come l'inondazione della pianura tra la Dora e la Sesia nel 1859 fatta per ostacolare l'avanzata austriaca o la gestione dell'assedio di Ancona e Gaeta. Dal 1860 fu senatore, ministro della Marina (1861-1862), e poi dei Lavori pubblici (1862-1864). Plenipotenziario italiano per la Pace di Vienna del 3 ottobre 1866, ebbe in tale occasione l'onorificenza del Collare della Ss. Annunziata. Nel 1867 fu Presidente del Consiglio quando si verificò lo scontro di Mentana. Fu poi incaricato di missioni straordinarie a Vienna (1870) e a Stoccolma (1873); ambasciatore a Londra (1876-82) e a Parigi (1882-92). Venne nominato nel 1874 socio nazionale del'Accademia dei Lincei. Morì a Cassin, Chambéry, nel 1896.
$Menabrea.nl_NL: Luigi Federico Menabrea werd in 1809 geboren in Chambéry. Hij was officier bij het Korps Ingenieurs en van 1839 tot 1848 docent aan de Militaire Academie van Turijn, waar hij zich bezighield met constructiewetenschappen. In 1848 werd hij gekozen in het Parlamento Subalpino, het eerste parlement van het Koninkrijk Sardinië; hij behield zijn zetel tot 1860. In 1859-1860 verkreeg hij ook belangrijke militaire opdrachten, zoals het onder water zetten van de vlakte tussen de rivieren Dora en Sesia in 1859 om de Oostenrijkse opmars te belemmeren. Ook kreeg hij de leiding over de belegeringen van Ancona en Gaeta. Vanaf 1860 was hij senator, minister van Marine (1861-1862) en vervolgens van Openbare Werken (1862-1864). Voor zijn rol als Italiaans gevolmachtigde bij de onderhandelingen en ondertekening van de Vrede van Wenen van 3 oktober 1866 werd hij onderscheiden in de Orde van de Santissima Annunziata, de hoogste decoratie van het Huis Savoia. In 1867 was Menabrea voorzitter van de Italiaanse ministerraad toen de Slag bij Mentana plaatsvond, waarbij het vrijwilligerslegioen van Garibaldi door een colatie van pauselijke en Franse troepen werd verslagen. Later werd hij belast met buitengewone missies naar Wenen (1870) en Stockholm (1873); verder was hij onder meer ambassadeur in Londen (1876-82) en Parijs (1882-92). In 1874 werd hij benoemd tot lid van de Accademia dei Lincei. Hij stierf in Cassin, Chambéry, in 1896.

$MenthonBake.en_GB:
Mr Rudolph Willem Johan Cornelis de Menthon Bake (name change from Bake to De Menthon Bake by KB 17 May 1869, no. 22), studied law at Leiden University, applied unsuccessfully to the Royal Library in 1835, then became a sworn clerk at the Council of Justice in Surabaya (1838), clerk at the Supreme Court of the Dutch East Indies (1840), lawyer and procurator at Semarang (1842) and at Surabaya (1846), and finally procurator at the Supreme Court of the Dutch East Indies (1854-1860). He was also a captain in the militia of Surabaya. At his own request, he was appointed honorary consul at Leipzig (1860-1864); he subsequently became consul general for Prussia based in Berlin (RD 26 June 1867 no 65). When he had already taken up his work in Berlin, he was appointed consul general in Mannheim and also commissioner to the Central Commission for the Navigation of the Rhine (RD 1 Jan 1868 no 8). From this post he was honorably dismissed (RD 28 April 1871 no. 21) due to the dissolution of the consular post at Mannheim. 
Thereupon he became consul at Djeddah, part of the Ottoman Empire on the Arabian Peninsula (RD 7 Feb. 1872 no. 20). He left that post “without permission, but for reasons of health”, followed by a dishonourable discharge (RD 23 July 1873 no 74), also for charging pilgrims from the Dutch East Indies undue visa fees and had declared these costs for his own gain. Among other things, he published De doorgraving der landengte van Suez en hare gevolgen voor Nederland en zijne koloniën (Amsterdam 1857).
$MenthonBake.it_IT:
Rudolph Willem Johan Cornelis de Menthon Bake (cambio di nome da Bake a De Menthon Bake da KB 17 maggio 1869, no. 22), studiò legge all'Università di Leida, si iscrisse senza successo alla Biblioteca Reale nel 1835, poi divenne cancelliere giurato presso il Consiglio di Giustizia di Surabaya (1838), cancelliere presso la Corte Suprema delle Indie Orientali Olandesi (1840), avvocato e procuratore a Semarang (1842) e a Surabaya (1846), e infine procuratore presso la Corte Suprema delle Indie Orientali Olandesi (1854-1860). Fu anche capitano della milizia di Surabaya. Su sua richiesta, fu nominato console onorario a Lipsia (1860-1864); successivamente divenne console generale per la Prussia con sede a Berlino (RD 26 giugno 1867 n. 65). Quando aveva già preso servizio a Berlino, fu nominato console generale a Mannheim e anche commissario della Commissione centrale per la navigazione del Reno (RD 1 gennaio 1868 n. 8). Da questa carica fu congedato con onore (RD 28 aprile 1871 n. 21) a causa dello scioglimento della sede consolare di Mannheim.
Divenne quindi console a Gedda, parte dell'Impero Ottomano nella Penisola Arabica (RD 7 febbraio 1872 n. 20). Lasciò questo incarico “senza permesso, ma per motivi di salute”, seguito da un congedo con disonore (RD 23 luglio 1873 n. 74), anche per aver fatto pagare ai pellegrini delle Indie Orientali Olandesi tasse di visto non dovute e aver dichiarato questi costi per proprio tornaconto. Tra le altre cose, pubblicò De doorgraving der landengte van Suez en hare gevolgen voor Nederland en zijne koloniën (Amsterdam 1857).
$MenthonBake.nl_NL: Mr. Rudolph Willem Johan Cornelis de Menthon Bake (naamsvermeerdering Bake in De Menthon Bake bij KB 17 mei 1869, no. 22), studeerde Rechten te Leiden, solliciteerde in 1835 tevergeefs bij de Koninklijke Bibliotheek, werd daarna gezworen klerk bij de Raad van Justitie te Soerabaja (1838), klerk bij het Hooggerechtshof van Nederlands-Indië (1840), advocaat en procureur te Semarang (1842) en te Soerabaja (1846), procureur bij het Hooggerechtshof van Nederlands-Indië (1854–1860). Ook was hij kapitein bij de schutterij te Soerabaja. Op eigen verzoek werd hij benoemd tot honorair consul te Leipzig (1860–1864); vervolgens werd hij consul-gener$Bakeaal voor Pruisen met standplaats Berlijn (KB 26 juni 1867 no. 65). Toen hij al met zijn werk in Berlijn was begonnen werd hij benoemd tot consul generaal te Mannheim en tevens commissaris bij de Centrale commissie voor de Rijnvaart (KB 1 jan. 1868 no. 8). Uit deze functie werd hij eervol ontslagen (KB 28 april 1871 no. 21) vanwege de opheffing van de consulaire post te Mannheim. Daarop werd hij consul te Djeddah, deel van het Ottomaanse Rijk op het Arabisch Schiereiland (KB 7 febr. 1872 no. 20). Die post verliet hij 'zonder magtiging, doch om redenen van gezondheid', waarop oneervol ontslag volgde (KB 23 juli 1873 no. 74), ook wegens het ten eigen bate in rekening brengen van niet-verschuldigde visumkosten bij de pelgrims uit Nederlands-Indië. Hij schreef onder meer De doorgraving der landengte van Suez en hare gevolgen voor Nederland en zijne koloniën (Amsterdam 1857).

$Merle.en_GB: Jean-Henri Merle d'Aubigné was a Swiss Reformed theologian and church historian. He studied theology in Geneva and was ordained pastor in 1817, a position he subsequently held in Hamburg from 1818-1823. From 1823-1831, he was pastor to the Franco-German Protestant Church and also chaplain to King William I of the United Kingdom of the Netherlands in Brussels. The Evangelical Society founded in Geneva as part of the Reveil movement recruited him as rector of their new school for preachers, where he taught church history from 1832-1872. He wrote numerous pamphlets and a monumental Histoire de la Réformation (1835-1878). As spokesman for the Schweizerische Evangelische Allianz, he was an influential voice within Protestantism. In June 1859, he called for the establishment of a committee for the wounded of the Battle of Solferino, which would prove to be a forerunner of the Red Cross.
$Merle.it_IT: Jean-Henri Merle d'Aubigné fu un teologo e storico della Chiesa riformata svizzero. Studiò teologia a Ginevra e fu ordinato pastore nel 1817, incarico che ricoprì successivamente ad Amburgo dal 1818 al 1823. Dal 1823 al 1831 fu pastore della Chiesa protestante franco-tedesca e cappellano del re Guglielmo I del Regno Unito dei Paesi Bassi a Bruxelles. La Società evangelica fondata a Ginevra nell'ambito del movimento Reveil lo reclutò come rettore della sua nuova scuola per predicatori, dove insegnò storia della Chiesa dal 1832 al 1872. Scrisse numerosi opuscoli e una monumentale Histoire de la Réformation (1835-1878). Come portavoce della Schweizerische Evangelische Allianz, fu una voce influente all'interno del protestantesimo. Nel giugno 1859, chiese l'istituzione di un comitato per i feriti della battaglia di Solferino, che si sarebbe rivelato un precursore della Croce Rossa.
$Merle.nl_NL: Jean-Henri Merle d'Aubigné was een Zwitsers gereformeerd theoloog en kerkhistoricus. Hij studeerde theologie in Genève en werd in 1817 tot dominee gewijd, een functie die hij daarna van 1818-1823 in Hamburg vervulde. Van 1823-1831 was hij predikant aan de Frans-Duitse protestantse kerk en tevens kapelaan van koning Willem I in Brussel. De Evangelische Gesellschaft die in Genève als onderdeel van de Reveil-beweging werd opgericht, haalde hem als rector van de nieuwe school voor predikanten, waaraan hij van 1832-1872 kerkgeschiedenis onderwees. Hij schreef talrijke brochures en een monumentale Histoire de la Réformation (1835-1878). Als woordvoerder van de Schweizerische Evangelische Allianz was hij binnen het protestantisme een invloedrijke stem. In juni 1859 riep hij op tot de oprichting van een comité voor de gewonden van de Slag bij Solferino, dat een voorloper van het Rode Kruis zou blijken.

$MeuricoffreA.en_GB:
Auguste Meuricoffre was a businessman and diplomat active in Naples, from a family of Swiss origin (Mörikhofer) from the canton of Thurgau that had operated a bank in Naples since 1760. The son of Frédéric-Robert M. and opera singer Celeste Coltellini, Auguste continued the family business along with his brothers Achille (1793-1840) and Georges (1795-1858). Operated by five generations of Meuricoffre until the early twentieth century, the bank was among the most important in Naples and was the only major bank in that city to survive the Italian Unification, thanks in part to large investments in the lucrative monopolies on salt and tobacco. The firm also comprised a trading company in raw materials (hemp) and foodstuffs (especially oil, grain), which owned numerous warehouses on the port of Naples and several steam and sailing ships. 
The brothers Achille, Georges and Auguste were also known as patrons and collectors of contemporary art, including landscape painting of the so-called School of Posillipo, of which the Dutchman Anton Sminck (van) Pitlo(o) was the most important exponent. The family's residence on Via dei Fiorentini, as well as their villa ('La Fiorita' or 'Meuricoffre') functioned as salons for art-lovers and moderate liberals in Naples. Furthermore, the family supported the evangelical community in Naples, for which they would finance the first church building to be erected after the Italian Unification. In 1856, the family bought out its partner Sorvillo and Meuricoffre & Sorvillo continued as Meuricoffre & Co, with Achille's sons Oscar (1824-1880) and Tell (1826-1900) also joining the business. 
Besides being entrepreneurs, the Meuricoffre's were also active as diplomatic representatives for the Helvetic Federation - they had Swiss nationality - and for the Kingdom of the Netherlands. The Dutch Consulate-General in Naples, which they successively administered, also held the consulates of Messina and Palermo and the vice-consulates of Barletta, Bari, Brindisi, Gallipoli, Taranto, Crotone and Castellamare under it, all also in the Kingdom of the Both Sicilies. After his brother Georges had died in 1858, Auguste took over the offices of consul general for both Switzerland and the Netherlands, just as Georges had succeeded Achille earlier (1840). The consular representation to the Helvetic Republic passed to his nephew Oscar as early as 1859; however, Auguste continued to hold the consulate general for the Netherlands until his death in 1875, until his other nephew Tell took over (1875-1900). After the deaths of Achille and Georges, the bank and business empire was also run first by Auguste and then by Oscar and Tell . After the latter's death (1900), the business fell on hard times, eventually leading to the bankruptcy of Meuricoffre & Co and the takeover of the bank by the Credito Italiano in 1905. The last heir to the Meuricoffre family died in 1998.
$MeuricoffreA.it_IT:
Auguste Meuricoffre fu un uomo d'affari e diplomatico attivo a Napoli, proveniente da una famiglia di origine svizzera (Mörikhofer) del Canton Turgovia che gestiva una banca a Napoli dal 1760. Figlio di Frédéric-Robert M. e della cantante lirica Celeste Coltellini, Auguste continuò l'attività di famiglia insieme ai fratelli Achille (1793-1840) e Georges (1795-1858). Gestita da cinque generazioni di Meuricoffre fino all'inizio del XX secolo, la banca era tra le più importanti di Napoli e fu l'unica grande banca della città a sopravvivere all'Unità d'Italia, grazie anche ai grandi investimenti nei lucrosi monopoli del sale e del tabacco. L'azienda comprendeva anche una società di commercio di materie prime (canapa) e alimentari (soprattutto olio e grano), e possedeva anche numerosi magazzini sul porto di Napoli e diverse navi a vapore e a vela.
I fratelli Achille, Georges e Auguste erano anche noti come mecenati e collezionisti di arte contemporanea, tra cui la pittura di paesaggio della cosiddetta Scuola di Posillipo, di cui l'olandese Anton Sminck (van) Pitlo(o) era il più importante esponente. La residenza della famiglia in via dei Fiorentini, così come la loro villa (“La Fiorita” o “Meuricoffre”), fungevano da salotti per gli amanti dell'arte e i liberali moderati di Napoli. Inoltre, la famiglia sosteneva la comunità evangelica di Napoli, per la quale avrebbe finanziato il primo edificio di culto eretto dopo l'Unità d'Italia. Nel 1856, la famiglia rilevò il socio Sorvillo e la Meuricoffre & Sorvillo continuò come Meuricoffre & Co, con l'ingresso nell'attività dei figli di Achille, Oscar (1824-1880) e Tell (1826-1900).
Oltre che come imprenditori, i Meuricoffre furono attivi anche come rappresentanti diplomatici per la Federazione Elvetica - avevano la nazionalità svizzera - e per il Regno dei Paesi Bassi. Il Consolato generale olandese a Napoli, da loro successivamente amministrato, aveva sotto di sé anche i consolati di Messina e Palermo e i viceconsolati di Barletta, Bari, Brindisi, Gallipoli, Taranto, Crotone e Castellamare, tutti anche nel Regno delle Due Sicilie. Dopo la morte del fratello Georges, avvenuta nel 1858, Auguste assunse la carica di console generale per la Svizzera e per i Paesi Bassi, così come Georges era succeduto ad Achille (1840). La rappresentanza consolare presso la Repubblica Elvetica passò al nipote Oscar già nel 1859; tuttavia, Auguste continuò a mantenere il consolato generale per i Paesi Bassi fino alla sua morte, avvenuta nel 1875, finché non gli subentrò l'altro nipote Tell (1875-1900). Dopo la morte di Achille e Georges, anche l'impero bancario e commerciale fu gestito prima da Auguste e poi da Oscar e Tell. Dopo la morte di quest'ultimo (1900), l'attività si è arenata e ha portato al fallimento della Meuricoffre & Co e all'acquisizione della banca da parte del Credito Italiano nel 1905. L'ultimo erede della famiglia Meuricoffre è morto nel 1998.
$MeuricoffreA.nl_NL: Auguste Meuricoffre was een zakenman en diplomaat actief in Napels, afkomstig uit een van oorsprong Zwitserse familie (Mörikhofer) uit het kanton Thurgau die sinds 1760 in Napels een bank dreef. Als zoon van Frédéric-Robert M. en operazangeres Celeste Coltellini zette Auguste de familieonderneming voort, samen met zijn broers Achille (1793-1840) en Georges (1795-1858). De bank die tot begin twintigste eeuw door vijf generaties Meuricoffre werd gedreven, behoorde tot de belangrijkste van Napels en was de enige grote bank in Napels die de Italiaanse Eenwording overleefde, mede dankzij grote investeringen in o.a. het lucratieve monopolie op zout en tabak. Daarnaast bestond de firma uit een handelsmaatschappij in grondstoffen (hennep) en levensmiddelen (m.n. olie, graan), die talrijke pakhuizen aan de haven van Napels en enkele stoom- en zeilschepen bezat. De broers Achille, Georges en Auguste stonden ook bekend als opdrachtgevers en verzamelaars van eigentijdse kunst, onder meer landschapschilders van de zogenaamde School van Posillipo, waarvan de Nederlander Anton Sminck (van) Pitlo(o) de belangrijkste was. Het huis van de familie aan de Via dei Fiorentini, als ook hun villa (“La Fiorita” of “Meuricoffre”) fungeerde als salon voor kunstminnend en gematigd progressief Napels. Intussen zetten ze zich in voor de evangelische gemeenschap in Napels, waarvoor de Meuricoffre's na de Italiaanse Eenwording het eerste kerkgebouw zouden financieren. In 1856 kocht de familie haar vennoot Servillo uit en ging Meuricoffre & Sorvillo verder als Meuricoffre & Co, waarbij ook Achille's zonen Oscar (1824-1880) en Tell (1826-1900) tot het bedrijf toetraden. Behalve als ondernemers waren de Meuricoffre's ook actief als diplomatieke vertegenwoordigers voor de Helvetische Federatie – ze hadden ze Zwitserse nationaliteit - en voor het Koninkrijk der Nederlanden. Onder het Nederlandse consultaat-generaal in Napels dat ze achtereenvolgens bestierden, ressorteerden ook de consulaten van Messina en Palermo en de vice-consulaten van Barletta, Bari, Brindisi, Gallipoli, Taranto, Crotone en Castellamare, alle eveneens in het Koninkrijk de Beide Siciliën. Auguste nam het ambt van consul-generaal voor zowel Zwitserland als Nederland in 1858 over van zijn broer Georges na diens overlijden, net zoals Georges eerder (1840) Achille was opgevolgd. De consulaire vertegenwoordiging bij de Helvetische Republiek ging al in 1859 over op zijn neef Oscar; het consulaat-generaal voor Nederland bleef Auguste evenwel tot zijn dood in 1875 bekleden, totdat zijn andere neef Tell dat van hem overnam (1875-1900). Ook de bank en het zakenimperium werden na het overlijden van Achille en Georges eerst door Auguste geleid en vervolgens door Oscar en Tell. Na de dood van die laatste (1900) kwam de onderneming in zwaar weer, hetgeen uiteindelijk leidde tot het faillissement van de Meuricoffre & Co en de overname van de bank door het Credito Italiano in 1905. De laatste erfgenaam van de familie Meuricoffre overleed in 1998.

Georges Meuricoffre was a businessman and diplomat active in Naples, from a family of Swiss origin (Mörikhofer) from the canton of Thurgau, which had had a bank in Naples since 1760. Operated by five generations of Meuricoffre until the early 20th century, the bank was among the most important in Naples and was the only major bank in Naples to survive the Italian Unification, thanks in part to large investments in the lucrative salt and tobacco monopolies. The firm also consisted of a trading company in raw materials (hemp) and foodstuffs (especially oil, grain) and owned numerous warehouses on the port of Naples and several steam and sailing ships. The brothers Achille, Auguste and Georges were also known as patrons and collectors of contemporary art, including landscape painting of the so-called School of Posillipo, of which the Dutchman Anton Sminck (van) Pitlo(o) was the most important exponent. The family residence on Via dei Fiorentini, as well as their villa ('La Fiorita' or 'Meuricoffre') functioned as salons for art-lovers and moderate liberals in Naples. 
Furthermore, the Meuricoffre's supported the evangelical community in their city, for which the they would finance the first church building after the Italian Unification. In 1856, the family bought out its partner Servillo and Meuricoffre & Sorvillo continued as Meuricoffre & Co, with Achille's sons Oscar (1824-1880) and Tell (1826-1900) also joining the business. 
Besides being entrepreneurs, the Meuricoffre's were also active as diplomatic representatives for the Helvetic Federation - they held the Swiss nationality - and for the Kingdom of the Netherlands. The Dutch Consulate-General in Naples, which they successively ran, also held the consulates of Messina and Palermo and the vice-consulates of Barletta, Bari, Brindisi, Gallipoli, Taranto, Crotone and Castellamare under it, all in the Kingdom of the Two Sicilies. Georges M. assumed the role of consul general for both Switzerland and the Netherlands in 1840 following the death of his brother Achille, who had held the same position since 1819. 
Shortly after taking office as consul, Georges faced mounting tensions between the governments of the Kingdom of the Two Sicilies on the one hand and those of the Netherlands (and Belgium) on the other. The latter stepped up pressure to force access of their colonial goods to the southern Italian market. An escalation was prevented mainly through the actions of the Dutch consul-general; on 17 November 1847, a new treaty for trade and shipping was concluded between the chancelleries of the Netherlands and the Kingdom of the Two Sicilies, in the presence of Georges Meuricoffre. The consul and his nephew Tell M., chancellor at the Dutch consulate and later his uncle's successor as consul, had made a crucial contribution to that treaty. For his merits, Georges Meuricoffre was invested as Commander in the Order of Francis I by King Ferdinand II in April 1848. Until his death in 1858, Georges M. would remain on his post. 
He was first succeeded by his brother Auguste (1858-1875). His other brother Achille's sons, Oscar and Tell M., later took over as consul for Switzerland (1859-1890) and the Netherlands (1875-1900) respectively. The bank and business empire were continued first by Auguste and then by his cousins Oscar and Tell. After the latter's death (1900), the business fell on hard times, eventually leading to the bankruptcy of the firm Meuricoffre & Co and the takeover of the bank by the Credito Italiano in 1905. The last heir to the Meuricoffre family died in 1998. Georges M. was married to Emilie Bourguignon (1800-1867).

Per i suoi meriti, Georges Meuricoffre fu investito del titolo di Commendatore dell'Ordine di Francesco I dal re Ferdinando II nell'aprile 1848. Fino alla sua morte, avvenuta nel 1858, Georges M. rimase al suo posto.Gli successe dapprima il fratello Auguste (1858-1875). I figli dell'altro fratello Achille, Oscar e Tell M., gli succedettero in seguito come consoli rispettivamente per la Svizzera (1859-1890) e per i Paesi Bassi (1875-1900). La banca e l'impero commerciale furono portati avanti prima da Auguste e poi dai cugini Oscar e Tell. Dopo la morte di quest'ultimo (1900), l'attività si è arenata e ha portato al fallimento della Meuricoffre & Co e all'acquisizione della banca da parte del Credito Italiano nel 1905. L'ultimo erede della famiglia Meuricoffre è morto nel 1998. Georges M. era sposato con Emilie Bourguignon (1800-1867).
$MeuricoffreG.nl_NL:
Georges Meuricoffre was een zakenman en diplomaat actief in Napels, afkomstig uit een van oorsprong Zwitserse familie (Mörikhofer) uit het kanton Thurgau, die sinds 1760 in Napels een bank had. Als zoon van Frédéric-Robert M. en operazangeres Celeste Coltellini zette Georges de familieonderneming voort, samen met zijn broers Achille (1793-1840) en Auguste (1800-1875). De bank die tot begin twintigste eeuw door vijf generaties Meuricoffre werd gedreven, behoorde tot de belangrijkste van Napels en was de enige grote bank in Napels die de Italiaanse Eenwording overleefde, mede dankzij grote investeringen in het lucratieve monopolie op zout en tabak. Daarnaast bestond de firma uit een handelsmaatschappij in grondstoffen (hennep) en levensmiddelen (met name olie, graan), die talrijke pakhuizen aan de haven van Napels en enkele stoom- en zeilschepen bezat. De broers Achille, Auguste en Georges stonden ook bekend als opdrachtgevers en verzamelaars van eigentijdse kunst, onder meer van landschapschilders van de zogenaamde School van Posillipo, van wie de Nederlander Anton Sminck (van) Pitlo(o) de belangrijkste was. Het huis van de familie aan de Via dei Fiorentini, als ook hun villa (“La Fiorita” of “Meuricoffre”) fungeerden als salons voor kunstminnend en gematigd liberaal Napels. Intussen zetten ze zich in voor de evangelische gemeenschap in hun stad, waarvoor de Meuricoffre's na de Italiaanse Eenwording het eerste kerkgebouw zouden financieren. In 1856 kocht de familie haar vennoot Servillo uit en ging Meuricoffre & Sorvillo verder als Meuricoffre & Co, waarbij ook Achille's zonen Oscar (1824-1880) en Tell (1826-1900) tot het bedrijf toetraden. 
Behalve als ondernemers waren de Meuricoffre's ook actief als diplomatieke vertegenwoordigers voor de Helvetische Federatie – ze hadden de Zwitserse nationaliteit - en voor het Koninkrijk der Nederlanden. Onder het Nederlandse consultaat-generaal in Napels dat ze achtereenvolgens bestierden, ressorteerden ook de consulaten van Messina en Palermo en de vice-consulaten van Barletta, Bari, Brindisi, Gallipoli, Taranto, Crotone en Castellamare, alle eveneens in het Koninkrijk der Beide Siciliën. Georges M. nam in 1840 de rol van consul-generaal voor zowel Zwitserland als Nederland op zich na het overlijden van zijn broer Achille, die dezelfde positie sinds 1819 had bekleed. Kort na zijn aantreden als consul kreeg Georges te maken met oplopende spanningen tussen de regeringen van het Koninkrijk der Beide Siciliën enerijds en Nederland (en België) anderzijds. De laatsten voerden de druk op om de toegang van hun koloniale goederen tot de Zuid-Italiaanse markt te forceren. Vooral door toedoen van Georges M. werd een escalatie voorkomen; op 17 november 1847 werd tussen de kanselarijen van Nederland en het Koninkrijk der Beide Siciliën, in het bijzijn van Georges Meuricoffre, een nieuw verdrag voor handel en scheepvaart gesloten. De consul en zijn neef Tell M., kanselier bij het Nederlandse consulaat en later de opvolger van zijn oom als consul, hadden aan dat verdrag een cruciale bijdrage geleverd. Voor zijn verdiensten werd Georges Meuricoffre in april 1848 door koning Ferdinand II onderscheiden als Commandeur in de Orde van Frans I. Tot zijn dood in 1858 zou Georges M. op zijn post blijven. Hij werd opgevolgd eerst door zijn broer Auguste (1858-1875). De zoons van zijn andere broer Achille, Oscar en Tell M., namen later het ambt van consul over voor respectievelijk Zwitserland (1859-1890) en Nederland (1875-1900). Ook de bank en het zakenimperium werden na Georges' dood eerst door Auguste en daarna door de neven Oscar en Tell voortgezet. Na de dood van die laatste (1900) kwam de onderneming in zwaar weer, hetgeen uiteindelijk leidde tot het faillissement van de firma Meuricoffre & Co en de overname van de bank door het Credito Italiano in 1905. De laatste erfgenaam van de familie Meuricoffre overleed in 1998. Georges M. was getrouwd met Emilie Bourguignon (1800-1867).

$Mijnden.en_GB: Jan Conrad Hacke van Mijnden was a Dutch man of letters and italophile. After completing his studies (first theology, then letters), he travelled to Italy, and then, on his return to the Netherlands, he obtained his doctorate at Utrecht University with a thesis on Cardinal Bessarion. He then devoted himself to classical Italian literature: Petrarch, Tasso, Ariosto and especially Dante. After his marriage in 1845 to Janna Catharina Susanna Elias, he lived on the Eikenrode estate near Loosdrecht. Hacke was a warm advocate of the Italian freedom struggle. When he heard about Garibaldi's forthcoming expedition to Sicily, he immediately travelled to Genoa in the summer of 1860. He arrived too late to join the '1000', but did meet Garibaldi's brother in arms and friend Augusto Candido Vecchi, with whom Hacke became friends. Through Hacke, Vecchi gained access in the Netherlands to a small but fanatical core of Dutch garibaldinians. Vecchi corresponded not only with Hacke but also with his daughter Marie and wife Janna, to whom he also forwarded letters from Garibaldi himself. Besides his work as a Dantist, Hacke also translated Vecchi's Garibaldi e Caprera into Dutch (or. 1861, transl. 1862). His masterpiece is the translation of the Divina Commedia, which he completed in the year of his death.
$Mijnden.it_IT: Jan Conrad Hacke van Mijnden fu un letterato e italofilo olandese. Dopo aver completato gli studi (prima di teologia, poi di lettere), si recò in Italia e poi, tornato nei Paesi Bassi, conseguì il dottorato all'Università di Utrecht con una tesi sul cardinale Bessarione. Si dedicò quindi alla letteratura classica italiana: Petrarca, Tasso, Ariosto e soprattutto Dante. Dopo il matrimonio nel 1845 con Janna Catharina Susanna Elias, visse nella tenuta di Eikenrode, vicino a Loosdrecht. Hacke fu un caloroso sostenitore della lotta per la libertà italiana. Quando seppe dell'imminente spedizione di Garibaldi in Sicilia, si recò immediatamente a Genova nell'estate del 1860. Arrivò troppo tardi per unirsi ai “1000”, ma incontrò il fratello d'armi e amico di Garibaldi, Augusto Candido Vecchi, con il quale Hacke strinse amicizia. Attraverso Hacke, Vecchi ebbe accesso nei Paesi Bassi a un piccolo ma fanatico nucleo di garibaldini olandesi. Vecchi corrispondeva non solo con Hacke ma anche con la figlia Marie e la moglie Janna, alle quali inoltrava anche lettere dello stesso Garibaldi. Oltre alla sua attività di dantista, Hacke tradusse in olandese Garibaldi e Caprera di Vecchi (or. 1861, trad. 1862). Il suo capolavoro è la traduzione della Divina Commedia, che completò nell'anno della sua morte.
$Mijnden.nl_NL: Jan Conrad Hacke van Mijnden was een Nederlands letterkundige en italofiel. Na zijn studie (eerste theologie, toen letteren) reisde hij naar Italië, om vervolgens bij terugkeer in Nederland te promoveren op een proefschrift over kardinaal Bessarion. Daarna wijdde hij zich aan de klassieke Italiaanse literatuur: Petrarca, Tasso, Ariosto en vooral Dante. Na zijn huwelijk in 1845 met Janna Catharina Susanna Elias woonde hij op het landgoed Eikenrode bij Loosdrecht. Hacke was een warm pleitbezorger van de Italiaanse vrijheidsstrijd. Toen hij hoorde over Garibaldi's aanstaande expeditie naar Sicilië reisde hij in de zomer van 1860 meteen naar Genua. Hij kwam te laat om zich bij de '1000' aan te sluiten, maar ontmoette wel Garibaldi's secondant Augusto Candido Vecchi, met wie hij vriendschap sloot. Via Hacke kreeg Vecchi in Nederland toegang tot een kleine maar fanatieke kern Nederlandse garibaldisten. Vecchi correspondeerde niet alleen met Hacke maar ook met diens dochter Marie en vrouw Janna, aan wie hij ook brieven van Garibaldi doorstuurde. Naast zijn werk als Dantist vertaalde Hacke ook Vecchi's Garibaldi e Caprera naar het Nederlands (or. 1861, vert. 1862). Zijn meesterwerk is de vertaling van de Divina Commedia, die hij in het jaar van zijn dood voltooide.

$Milesi.en_GB: Giuseppe Milesi Pironi Ferretti was a cardinal, originally from Ancona. He was apostolic delegate in Ascoli (1843), Civitavecchia (1843), Macerata (1845-1848), Urbino and Pesaro (1849-1851) and Forlì (1852-1854). In 1854, Pius XI appointed Milesi as his Minister of Trade and Public Works, a position Milesi held until he was elevated to the cardinalate on 15 March 1858. He subsequently became legate in the city and province of Bologna. He was driven out of Bologna during the uprising of the Legates and the Romagna and returned to Rome on 15 July 1859. In Rome, he was appointed abbot of the church Santi Vincenzo e Anastasio a Trevi (26 September 1860) and camerlengo of the College of Cardinals (25 June 1869). On 21 March 1870, he was consecrated bishop of Porto and S. Rufina, a position he held until his death on 2 August 1873.
$Milesi.it_IT: Giuseppe Milesi Pironi Ferretti fu un cardinale originario di Ancona. Fu delegato apostolico ad Ascoli (1843), Civitavecchia (1843), Macerata (1845-1848), Urbino e Pesaro (1849-1851) e Forlì (1852-1854). Nel 1854, Pio XI nominò Milesi suo Ministro del Commercio e dei Lavori Pubblici, incarico che mantenne fino alla sua elevazione al cardinalato il 15 marzo 1858. Successivamente divenne legato nella città e provincia di Bologna. Fu cacciato da Bologna durante la rivolta dei Legati e della Romagna e tornò a Roma il 15 luglio 1859. A Roma, fu nominato abate della chiesa dei Santi Vincenzo e Anastasio a Trevi (26 settembre 1860) e camerlengo del Collegio Cardinalizio (25 giugno 1869). Il 21 marzo 1870 fu consacrato vescovo di Porto e S. Rufina, incarico che mantenne fino alla morte, avvenuta il 2 agosto 1873.
$Milesi.nl_NL: Giuseppe Milesi Pironi Ferretti was een kardinaal afkomstig uit Ancona. Hij was onder meer apostolisch afgevaardigde in Ascoli (1843), Civitavecchia (1844), Macerata (1845-1848), Urbino en Pesaro (1849-1851) en Forlì (1852-1854). In 1854 werd hij door paus Pius XI benoemd tot minister van Handel en Openbare Werken, een functie die hij bekleedde tot hij op 15 maart 1858 tot kardinaal werd verheven. Vervolgens werd hij legaat in de stad en provincie Bologna. Hij werd uit Bologna verdreven tijdens de opstand van de Legaten en de Romagna en keerde op 15 juli 1859 terug naar Rome. In Rome werd Milesi benoemd tot abt van de kerk Santi Vincenzo e Anastasio a Trevi (26 september 1860) en camerlengo van het College van Kardinalen (25 juni 1869). Op 21 maart 1870 werd hij tot bisschop van Porto en S. Rufina gewijd, een positie die hij bekleedde tot zijn dood op 2 augustus 1873.

$Mollerus.en_GB: Jhr. Henry (Hendrik) Marie baron (1855) Mollerus volunteered with the Corps of Chasseurs ('Jagers') of the University of Utrecht during the Belgian Revolt. A few years later (RD 7 July 1835 no 69), he became attaché to Dutch legation in Vienna, where his father Willem baron Mollerus (1783-1855) had been extraordinary envoy and minister plenipotentiary since 1831. When his father was sent as extraordinary envoy to the Russian court in St Petersburg in 1842, Henry Marie accompanied him. It was initially intended he would also fulfil the role of attaché there, but for some reason this appointment failed, and as a result also the salary he had received since 1839 (1,000 guilders a year) ended. From the third quarter of 1842, his post was considered 'wholly honorary and titular'. From 1843, M. was also honorary chamberlain to King William II. In 1844 (RD 5 Feb 1844 no 48), he was appointed 1st lieutenant 'à la suite' in the Hague militia, serving chamberlain (1849-1853), master of ceremonies (1853-1855) and chamberlain in extraordinary service (1855-) to Kings Willem II and Willem III, until his death.
$Mollerus.it_IT: Jhr. Henry (Hendrik) Marie baron (1855) Mollerus si arruolò come volontario nel corpo dei Chasseurs (“Jagers”) dell'Università di Utrecht durante la Rivolta del Belgio. Qualche anno dopo (RD 7 luglio 1835 n. 69), divenne addetto alla legazione olandese a Vienna, dove il padre Willem barone Mollerus (1783-1855) era stato inviato straordinario e ministro plenipotenziario dal 1831. Quando il padre andò come inviato straordinario alla corte russa di San Pietroburgo nel 1842, Enrico Maria lo accompagnò. Inizialmente era previsto che vi svolgesse anche il ruolo di addetto, ma per qualche motivo questa nomina non andò a buon fine e di conseguenza venne meno anche lo stipendio che percepiva dal 1839 (1.000 fiorini all'anno). Dal terzo trimestre del 1842, il suo incarico fu considerato “del tutto onorifico e titolare”. Dal 1843, M. fu anche ciambellano onorario del re Guglielmo II. Nel 1844 (RD 5 feb 1844 n. 48), fu nominato 1° luogotenente “à la suite” della milizia dell'Aia, ricoprendo il ruolo di ciambellano (1849-1853), maestro di cerimonie (1853-1855) e ciambellano in servizio straordinario (1855-) dei re Willem II e Willem III, fino alla sua morte.
$Mollerus.nl_NL: Jhr. Henry (Hendrik) Marie baron (1855) Mollerus was tijdens de Belgische Opstand vrijwilliger bij het Korps Jagers van de Utrechtse Hogeschool. Enkele jaren later (KB 7 juli 1835 no. 69) werd hij attaché bij het gezantschap te Wenen, waar zijn vader Willem baron Mollerus (1783-1855) sinds 1831 buitengewoon gezant en gevolmachtigd minister was. Toen zijn vader in 1842 als buitengewoon gezant naar het Russische hof in St.-Petersburg werd gestuurd vergezelde Henry Marie hem. De bedoeling was aanvankelijk dat hij ook daar de rol van attaché zou vervullen, maar deze aanstelling ging niet door, waardoor ook het tractement dat hij sinds 1839 ontving (1000 gulden per jaar) werd beëindigd. Vanaf het derde kwartaal van 1842 werd zijn betrekking als 'geheel honorair en titulair' beschouwd. Vanaf 1843 was M. ook honorair kamerheer van koning Willem II. In 1844 (KB 5 febr. 1844 no. 48) werd hij benoemd tot 1e luitenant 'à la suite' bij de schutterij in Den Haag, dienstdoend kamerheer (1849–1853), ceremoniemeester (1853–1855) en kamerheer in buitengewone dienst (1855–) van de koningen Willem II en Willem III, tot aan zijn overlijden.

$Morandi.en_GB: Giuseppe Morandi was a lawyer and monsignore, born the son of composer and organist Giovanni Morandi and soprano Maria Paolina Morolli. Like Pope Pius IX, he was from Senigallia. During the pontificate of Gregory XVI he was assigned as a lawyer to Giuseppe Galletti, who had bene given a life sentence because of his membership of the secret society Carboneria and his role in the 1831 uprisings in Emilia, until Pius IX granted him amnesty. In 1844-45, he had also assisted the glassmaker and patriot Ciro Santi from Rimini. On 17 July 1847, Morandi was appointed 'protogovernor' of Rome by Cardinal Secretary of State Gabriele Ferretti, a post he held until 15 November 1847. At the trial of participants in the 'Gregorian' or 'Sanfedist' conspiracy (a failed reactionary coup d'état in July 1847 to stem the tide of reform in Rome), Morandi acted as prosecutor.
$Morandi.it_IT: Giuseppe Morandi era un avvocato e monsignore, figlio del compositore e organista Giovanni Morandi e del soprano Maria Paolina Morolli. Come Papa Pio IX, era originario di Senigallia. Durante il pontificato di Gregorio XVI fu assegnato come avvocato a Giuseppe Galletti, condannato all'ergastolo per la sua appartenenza alla Carboneria e per il suo ruolo nei moti del 1831 in Emilia, finché Pio IX non gli concesse l'amnistia. Nel 1844-45, fu assistente anche del vetraio e patriota Ciro Santi di Rimini. Il 17 luglio 1847, Morandi fu nominato 'protogovernatore' di Roma dal cardinale segretario di Stato Gabriele Ferretti, incarico che mantenne fino al 15 novembre 1847. Al processo ai partecipanti alla cospirazione 'gregoriana' o 'sanfedista' (un fallito colpo di stato reazionario del luglio 1847 per arginare l'ondata di riforme a Roma), Morandi svolse la funzione di pubblico ministero.
$Morandi.nl_NL: Giuseppe Morandi was een jurist en monseigneur, geboren als zoon van de componist en organist Giovanni Morandi en de sopraan Maria Paolina Morolli. Net als paus Pius IX was hij afkomstig uit Senigallia. Hij werd tijdens het pontificaat van Gregorius XVI als advocaat toegewezen aan Giuseppe Galletti, die als lid van het geheime genootschap de Carboneria en vanwege zijn rol in de opstanden van 1831 in Emilia levenslang had gekregen, tot Pius IX hem amnestie gaf. In 1844-45 had hij ook de glazenmaker en patriot Ciro Santi uit Rimini bijgestaan. Op 17 juli 1847 werd Morandi door kardinaal-staatssecretaris Gabriele Ferretti benoemd tot 'protogouverneur' van Rome, een functie die hij hield tot 15 november 1847. Bij het proces tegen de deelnemers aan de 'Gregoriaanse' of 'Sanfedistische' samenzwering (een mislukte reactionaire coup d'état in juli 1847 het tij van hervormingen in Rome te keren) was Morandi de aanklager.

$Murray.en_GB: Edward Murray was a British subject, tried for the murders of Pacifico Angelucci, Nazzareno Bellomo and Alessandro Tittoni in Ancona. He was first arrested by Felice Orsini in 1849 on behalf of the republican authorities, later by the papal police. and eventually sentenced to death in Rome in 1851. In a debate of the British House of Commons in May 1852, Lord Dudley Stuart gives the following account of Murray: 'He was, strictly speaking, a British subject, born in a country under the rule of Her Majesty—namely, at Corfu, in 1823; and, it appeared that he was, with his father, travelling in Italy, about the year 1848. It seemed that he entered the service of the Government of Rome of that day, and was employed in the army there, and afterwards in the police; but he was suspected—as I understood from the noble Lord the Under Secretary for Foreign Affairs—of being implicated in the murder of some partisans of the Papal Government. He was arrested and sent to Rome, where he was tried, acquitted, and set at liberty. He afterwards proceeded to Ancona; but the Pope having been restored to his dominions subsequently, the unfortunate man was again arrested for the offence of which it had been rumoured he was guilty, and of which he had been acquitted, and was thrown into prison. There he remained for nearly three years.' Murray was sentenced to death on 17 December 1851. That sentence was commuted to life in prison on 3 August 1852 at the intercession of Pope Pius IX, followed by exile.
$Murray.it_IT: Edward Murray fu un suddito britannico, processato per gli omicidi di Pacifico Angelucci, Nazzareno Bellomo e Alessandro Tittoni ad Ancona. Fu arrestato prima da Felice Orsini nel 1849 per conto delle autorità repubblicane, poi dalla polizia pontificia e infine condannato a morte a Roma nel 1851. In un dibattito alla Camera dei Comuni britannica nel maggio 1852, Lord Dudley Stuart fornisce il seguente resoconto di Murray: “Era, in senso stretto, un suddito britannico, nato in un paese sotto il dominio di Sua Maestà, vale a dire a Corfù, nel 1823; e sembra che fosse, con suo padre, in viaggio in Italia, intorno all'anno 1848. Sembra che entrasse al servizio del governo di Roma di quel giorno, e fosse impiegato lì nell'esercito, e poi nella polizia; ma era sospettato - come ho capito dal nobile Signore Sottosegretario agli Esteri - di essere implicato nell'assassinio di alcuni partigiani del Governo Pontificio. Fu arrestato e mandato a Roma, dove fu processato, assolto e rimesso in libertà. Poi si recò ad Ancona; ma essendo poi il Papa restituito ai suoi domini, lo sventurato fu di nuovo arrestato per il delitto di cui si era creduto colpevole, e dal quale era stato assolto, e fu gettato in prigione. Lì rimase per quasi tre anni». Murray fu condannato a morte il 17 dicembre 1851. Tale condanna fu commutata in ergastolo il 3 agosto 1852 per intercessione di Papa Pio IX, seguita dall'esilio.
$Murray.nl_NL: Edward Murray was een Britse onderdaan, die in 1851 in Rome op beschuldiging van medeplichtigheid aan de moord op Pacifico Angelucci, Nazzareno Bellomo en Alessandro Tittoni in 1849 ter dood werd veroordeeld. Hij werd in 1849 in Ancona eerst gearresteerd door Felice Orsini namens de republikeinse autoriteiten, later opnieuw op gezag van de pauselijke autoriteiten. In het verslag van het parlementair debat van het Britse Lagerhuis dat plaatsvond in mei 1852, zegt Lord Dudley Stuart over hem het volgende: 'Hij was, strikt genomen, een Brits onderdaan, geboren in een land onder het bewind van Hare Majesteit, namelijk op Corfu, in 1823; en het bleek dat hij, met zijn vader, rond 1848 op reis was in Italië. Het lijkt erop dat hij toen in dienst trad van de toenmalige regering van Rome en daar in het leger en vervolgens bij de politie werkte; maar hij werd ervan verdacht - zo begreep ik van de edelachtbare staatssecretaris van Buitenlandse Zaken - betrokken te zijn bij de moord op enkele partizanen van de pauselijke regering. Hij werd gearresteerd en naar Rome gestuurd, waar hij werd berecht, vrijgesproken en op vrije voeten gesteld. Daarna ging hij naar Ancona; maar omdat de paus daarna weer in zijn macht werd hersteld, werd de ongelukkige man opnieuw gearresteerd voor het vergrijp waaraan hij volgens geruchten schuldig was en waarvan hij was vrijgesproken, en werd hij in de gevangenis gegooid. Daar bleef hij bijna drie jaar.' Ondanks de bemoeienis van de Britse consul in Ancona Moore en de Britse consul in Rome Freeborn werd Murray op 17 december 1851 ter dood veroordeeld. Die straf werd op 3 augustus 1852 op voorspraak van paus Pius IX omgezet in levenslang en vervolgens in ballingschap.

$Muzzarelli.en_GB: Monsignor Count Carlo Emanuele Muzzarelli was dean of the Roman Rota (the ecclesiastical court in the Curia) and a respected legal scholar. He was not ordained as a priest and was known as a moderate liberal. Following the flight of Pius IX from Rome in November 1848, Muzzarelli maintained his post. On 29 December 1848, he joined the three-member Suprema Giunta di Stato, the highest organ of power in the absence of the pope, before also joining the provisional government that the Suprema Giunta appointed (without consulting parliament). After the proclamation of the Roman Republic on February 9th 1849, he was appointed Minister of Education and President of the Council of Ministers, which after the fall of the Republic in 1849 and the restoration of papal power earned him a life of exile. In July 1849, he fled through Tuscany to Corsica and remained there for three years before traveling to Genoa. He died on 10 April 1856 at Villa Cristina nursing home, in Valle Lomellina (in the Italian province of Pavia).
$Muzzarelli.it_IT: Monsignor conte Carlo Emanuele Muzzarelli fu decano della Rota Romana (il tribunale ecclesiastico della Curia) e stimato giurista. Non fu ordinato sacerdote ed era conosciuto come un liberale moderato. Dopo la fuga di Pio IX da Roma nel novembre 1848, Muzzarelli mantenne il suo incarico. Il 29 dicembre 1848 entrò a far parte della Suprema Giunta di Stato composta da tre membri, il massimo organo del potere in assenza del papa, prima di entrare anche nel governo provvisorio nominato dalla Suprema Giunta (senza consultare il Parlamento). Dopo la proclamazione della Repubblica Romana, il 9 febbraio 1849, fu nominato Ministro della Pubblica Istruzione e Presidente del Consiglio dei Ministri, cosa che dopo la caduta della Repubblica nel 1849 e la restaurazione del potere pontificio gli valse una vita di esilio. Nel luglio 1849 fuggì attraverso la Toscana in Corsica e vi rimase tre anni prima di recarsi a Genova. Morì il 10 aprile 1856 nella casa di cura Villa Cristina, in Valle Lomellina (in provincia di Pavia).
$Muzzarelli.nl_NL: Monseigneur graaf Carlo Emanuele Muzzarelli was decaan van de Rota (de kerkelijke rechtbank in de Curie) en een gerespecteerd rechtsgeleerde. Hij was niet als priester gewijd en stond bekend als gematigd liberaal. Na de vlucht van Pius IX uit Rome in november 1848 bleef Muzzarelli op zijn post en trad bovendien op 29 december toe tot de driekoppige Suprema Giunta di Stato, het hoogste machtsorgaan in afwezigheid van de paus. Vervolgens trad hij ook toe tot de voorlopige regering die de Suprema Giunta buiten het parlement om aanstelde. Na de proclamatie van de Romeinse Republiek op 9 februari 1849 werd hij als minister van Onderwijs en voorzitter van de ministerraad benoemd, hetgeen hij na de val van de Republiek in 1849 en het herstel van de pauselijke macht met ballingschap moest bekopen. Hij vluchtte in juli 1849 via Toscane naar Corsica en bleef daar drie jaar, alvorens af te reizen naar Genua. Hij stierf op 10 april 1856 in het Villa Cristina verzorgingstehuis, in de Valle Lomellina (in de Italiaanse provincie Pavia).

$NagellAWC.en_GB: Baron Anne Willem Carel Nagell van Ampsen was Dutch minister of Foreign Affairs (16 Sep 1815-16 May 1824). After studying law in Leiden, he became mayor of Zutphen (before 1795) and ambassador to London (1787-1795). He was a supporter of (the last) Stadtholder of the Dutch Republic, William V of Orange, so when the latter, as a result of the French occupation of the Dutch Republic, fled to London (heralding the so-called Batavian-French era, 1795-1813), Nagell was relieved of his post. He continued supporting William V in London, and returned to his estate in the Netherlands (Ampsen) in 1803. After the return of the Orange family in 1813, Nagell was named president of the inaugural meeting in Amsterdam and helped to introduce the 1814 constitution. King William I then appointed him Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs (6 April 1814-16 September 1815) and, immediately afterwards, minister of Foreign Affairs. Nagell eventually requested his resignation due to his advanced age, which was granted in 1824; however, the king did instruct him to continue negotiations with Pope Pius VII on a concordat, which Nagell did (unsuccessfully). In the last years of his life, Nagell was mainly occupied with his estate at Ampsen and his art collection. He died at the age of 96 in his city of birth, The Hague, on 6 February 1851.
$NagellAWC.it_IT: Il barone Anne Willem Carel Nagell van Ampsen fu ministro degli Esteri olandese (16 settembre 1815 - 16 maggio 1824). Dopo aver studiato giurisprudenza a Leida, divenne sindaco di Zutphen (prima del 1795) e ambasciatore a Londra (1787-1795). Fu un sostenitore dell''ultimo Statolder della Repubblica Olandese, Guglielmo V d'Orange, così quando quest'ultimo, a seguito dell'occupazione francese della Repubblica Olandese, fuggì a Londra (annunciando la cosiddetta era batavo-francese, 1795-1813), Nagell fu sollevato dall'incarico. Continuò a sostenere Guglielmo V a Londra e tornò alla sua tenuta nei Paesi Bassi (Ampsen) nel 1803. Dopo il ritorno della famiglia Orange nel 1813, Nagell fu nominato presidente della riunione inaugurale ad Amsterdam e contribuì a introdurre la costituzione del 1814. Re Guglielmo I lo nominò Segretario di Stato per gli Affari Esteri (6 aprile 1814 - 16 settembre 1815) e, subito dopo, Ministro degli Affari Esteri. Nagell chiese infine le sue dimissioni a causa dell'età avanzata, che gli furono concesse nel 1824; tuttavia, il re gli diede istruzioni di proseguire i negoziati con Papa Pio VII per un concordato, cosa che Nagell fece (senza successo). Negli ultimi anni della sua vita, Nagell si dedicò principalmente alla sua tenuta di Ampsen e alla sua collezione d'arte. Morì all'età di 96 anni nella sua città natale, L'Aia, il 6 febbraio 1851.
$NagellAWC.nl_NL: Baron Anne Willem Carel Nagell van Ampsen was Nederlands minister van Buitenlandse Zaken (16 sep. 1815-16 mei 1824). Na zijn opleiding in de Rechten te Leiden, werd hij burgemeester van Zutphen (voor 1795) en was hij tevens ambassadeur te Londen (1787-1795). Hij was een aanhanger van (de laatste) erfstadhouder van de Republiek der Verenigde Nederlanden, Willem V van Oranje; toen deze, als gevolg van de Franse bezetting, naar Londen vluchtte (start van de zgn. Bataafs-Franse tijd, 1795-1813), werd hij dan ook uit zijn functie ontheven. Hij zette zich in Londen in voor Willem V, alvorens in 1803 terug te keren naar zijn landgoed in Nederland (Ampsen). Na terugkeer van de Oranje-familie in 1813, hielp hij om de grondwet van 1814 in te voeren als voorzitter van de inhuldigingsvergadering te Amsterdam. Koning Willem I benoemde hem vervolgens tot Secretaris van Staat voor Buitenlandse zaken (6 april 1814-16 september 1815) en direct hierop minister van Buitenlandse Zaken. Nagell verzocht uiteindelijk ontslag vanwege zijn gevorderde leeftijd, wat hem in 1824 werd verleend; wel droeg de koning hem op om de onderhandelingen met paus Pius VII over een concordaat voort te zetten, wat Nagell (zonder succes) deed. In de laatste jaren van zijn leven, hield Nagell zich vooral bezig met zijn landgoed te Ampsen en zijn kunstverzameling. Hij overleed op 96-jarige leeftijd in zijn geboortestad, Den Haag, op 6 februari 1851.

$Nagtglas.en_GB: Cornelis Johannes Marius Nagtglas was a Dutch colonial governor. He initially aspired to a military career, but as he did not get past the rank of non-commissioned officer, he resigned and ended up in Guinea, where he eventually became governor in 1857. Nagtglas adopted a relatively mild attitude towards the native population. In 1862, when he had actually already retired, he anonymously published the pamphlet 'What should the Netherlands do with its Possessions on the Coast of Guinea?', in which he highlighted the neglect of Guinea - both by the native population and the Dutch civil service. In 1865, he travelled to London, where he discussed idea to exchange territories in Guinea with A.A. Bentinck, who was the Dutch envoy to London at the time. After the change of boundaries, relations between the Dutch administration in Guinea and the indigenous population deteriorated to such an extent that Nagtglas was asked to return to replace Governor G.P. Boers. War broke out; Nagtglas did not wait for its end and returned to the Netherlands. In 1872, Guinea was ceded to the British Empire, with Nagtglas receiving an honourable discharge.
$Nagtglas.it_IT: Cornelis Johannes Marius Nagtglas fu un governatore coloniale olandese. Inizialmente aspirava alla carriera militare, ma poiché non riuscì a superare il grado di sottufficiale, si dimise e finì in Guinea, dove divenne governatore nel 1857. Nagtglas adottò un atteggiamento relativamente mite nei confronti della popolazione nativa. Nel 1862, quando in realtà era già in pensione, pubblicò in forma anonima l'opuscolo 'Cosa dovrebbero fare i Paesi Bassi con i loro possedimenti sulla costa della Guinea?', in cui sottolineava l'abbandono della Guinea, sia da parte della popolazione nativa che della pubblica amministrazione olandese. Nel 1865 si recò a Londra, dove discusse l'idea di scambiare territori in Guinea con A.A. Bentinck, che all'epoca era l'inviato olandese a Londra. Dopo il cambio di confini, i rapporti tra l'amministrazione olandese in Guinea e la popolazione indigena si deteriorarono a tal punto che a Nagtglas fu chiesto di tornare per sostituire il governatore G.P. Boeri. Scoppiò la guerra; Nagtglas aspettò fine e tornò nei Paesi Bassi. Nel 1872, la Guinea fu ceduta all'Impero britannico, con Nagtglas che ricevette un onorevole congedo.
$Nagtglas.nl_NL: Cornelis Johannes Marius Nagtglas was een Nederlands koloniaal gouverneur. Hij ambieerde aanvankelijk een militaire carrière, maar omdat hij niet voorbij de rank van onderofficier kwam, nam hij ontslag en belandde in Guinea, waar hij in 1857 uiteindelijk gouverneur werd. Nagtglas stelde zich mild op naar de inlandse bevolking. In 1862, toen hij eigenlijk al met pensioen was, publiceerde hij anoniem het pamflet 'Wat moet Nederland doen met zijn Bezittingen ter Kuste van Guinea?', waarin hij de verwaarlozing van Guinea – zowel door de inheemse bevolking als het Nederlandse ambtelijk bestel – onder de aandacht bracht. In 1865 reisde hij naar London, waar hij samen met A.A. Bentinck, die op dat moment de Nederlands gezant te Londen was, gebiedsruil in Guinea besprak. Na de verandering van de grenzen verslechterde de relatie tussen het Nederlandse bestuur in Guinea en de inheemse bevolking dusdanig dat Nagtglas werd gevraagd terug te keren om gouverneur G.P. Boers te vervangen. Er brak een oorlog uit; Nagtglas wachtte het einde daarvan niet af en keerde terug naar Nederland. In 1872 werd Guinea overgedragen aan het Britse Rijk, waarbij Nagtglas eervol ontslag kreeg.

$Nardoni.en_GB: Filippo Nardoni was a senior police officer during the pontificate of Gregory XVI, notorious for his hard-handed methods and direction of secret service espionage activities. He became so infamous that during the liberal government of pope Pius IX (1846-1848), he shaved his hair and moustache so as not to be recognized. After the failed reactionary coup of July 1847 (also called the 'Gregorian or 'Sanfedist' conspiracy), Nardoni fled to Sicily and Malta under the false name of Filippo Moraschi. After the fall of the Roman Republic of 1849 and the restoration of papal authority in Rome, he returned at the express request of Cardinal Antonelli, first as head of the secret service and later as colonel and commander of the papal gendarmerie. These appointments led to protest from Roman patriots, and on 19 July 1850, he survived an assassination attempt. He died in Rome on 26 August 1864.
$Nardoni.it_IT: Filippo Nardoni  fu un alto ufficiale di polizia durante il pontificato di Gregorio XVI, noto per i suoi metodi duri e la direzione delle attività di spionaggio dei servizi segreti. Divenne così famigerato che durante il governo liberale di papa Pio IX (1846-1848), si rase capelli e baffi per non essere riconosciuto. Dopo il fallito colpo di stato reazionario del luglio 1847 (chiamato anche congiura 'gregoriana' o 'sanfedista'), Nardoni fuggì in Sicilia e a Malta sotto il falso nome di Filippo Moraschi. Dopo la caduta della Repubblica Romana nel 1849 e la restaurazione dell'autorità pontificia a Roma, vi ritornò su espressa richiesta del cardinale Antonelli, prima come capo dei servizi segreti e poi come colonnello e comandante della gendarmeria pontificia. Queste nomine suscitarono la protesta di Roman patrioti e il 19 luglio 1850 sopravvisse ad un attentato. Morì a Roma il 26 agosto 1864.
$Nardoni.nl_NL: Filippo Nardoni was een hoge politiefunctionaris onder Gregorius XVI, berucht om zijn harde optreden en aansturing van spionageactiviteiten van de geheime dienst. Hij kreeg zo'n slechte naam dat hij na de troonsbestijging van Pius IX – tijdens de liberale fase van de paus (1846-1848) – zijn haar en snor liet afscheren om niet herkend te worden. Na de mislukte reactionaire coup  van juli 1847 (ook wel de 'Gregoriaanse of 'sanfedistische' samenzwering), vluchtte Nardoni onder de valse naam Filippo Moraschi naar Sicilië en Malta. Na de val van de Romeinse Republiek van 1849 en het herstel van de pauselijke autoriteit in Rome keerde hij op nadrukkelijk verzoek van kardinaal G. Antonelli terug, eerst als hoofd van de geheime dienst, later als kolonel en commandant van de pauselijke gendarmerie. Deze benoemingen leidden tot protest van Romeinse patriotten, en op 19 juli 1850 wist hij aan een moordpoging te ontkomen. Hij stierf in Rome op 26 augustus 1864.

$Nervegna.en_GB: Giuseppe Nervegna was an Italian merchant. His father Giuseppe was from Ortona and had settled in Brindisi in the early nineteenth century. The Nervegna's established a trading house in oil and other foodstuffs, which they traded to and from Trieste, Naples and Venice, among other places. Giuseppe became president of the Chamber of Commerce of the province of Terra d'Otranto (1869-1881), member of the Brindisi city council and deputy to the province of Terra d'Otranto. He was also a widely respected connoisseur and collector of antiquities, especially numismatics. From all over the former Magna Grecia area, he managed to acquire antique coins. In 1862, the Nervegna's acquired the palazzo Granafei, now Granafei-Nervegna, which came to house the archaeological collection as well as the family library, which can today be found in the local Biblioteca Annibale de Leo. Nervegna was also vice-consul for the German Empire, the British Empire and the Kingdom of the Netherlands (the latter from 4 February 1859). His son Ugo (1867-1919) succeeded him as vice-consul on 29 December 1894.
$Nervegna.it_IT: Giuseppe Nervegna fu un mercante italiano. Il padre Giuseppe era ortonese e si era stabilito a Brindisi agli inizi dell'Ottocento. I Nervegna fondarono una attività commerciale di olio e altri generi alimentari con Trieste, Napoli e Venezia, tra gli altre località. Giuseppe divenne presidente della Camera di Commercio della provincia di Terra d'Otranto (1869-1881), consigliere comunale di Brindisi e deputato alla provincia di Terra d'Otranto. Era anche un conoscitore e collezionista di antichità ampiamente rispettato, in particolare di numismatica. Da tutta l'area dell'ex Magna Grecia riuscì ad acquisire monete antiche. Nel 1862 i Nervegna acquistarono il palazzo Granafei, oggi Granafei-Nervegna, che divenne sede della collezione archeologica e della biblioteca di famiglia, oggi conservata nella locale Biblioteca Annibale de Leo. Nervegna fu anche viceconsole dell'Impero tedesco, dell'Impero britannico e del Regno dei Paesi Bassi (quest'ultimo dal 4 febbraio 1859). Gli succedette come viceconsole il figlio Ugo (1867-1919) il 29 dicembre 1894.
$Nervegna.nl_NL: Giuseppe Nervegna was een Italiaanse koopman. Zijn vader Giuseppe was afkomstig uit Ortona en had zich begin negentiende eeuw in Brindisi gevestigd. De Nervegna's vestigden een handelshuis in olie en andere levensmiddelen, die ze onder meer verhandelden van en naar Triëst, Napels en Venetië. Giuseppe werd onder meer president van de Handelskamer van de provincie van Terra d'Otranto (1869-1881), lid van de gemeenteraad van Brindisi en  gedeputeerde bij de provincie Terra d'Otranto. Daarnaast was hij een alom gerespecteerd kenner en verzamelaar van oudheden, met name numismatiek. Vanuit de gehele Magna Grecia wist hij antieke munsten te verwerven. In 1862 verwierven de Nervegna's het palazzo Granafei, tegenwoordig Granafei-Nervegna, waar de archeologische collectie werd ondergebracht en ook de boekerij, die zich thans in de plaatselijke Biblioteca Annibale de Leo bevindt. Nervegna was in Brindisi ook geruime tijd vice-consul van het Duitse Rijk, van Groot-Brittannië en voor het Koninkrijk der Nederlanden (dat laatste vanaf 4 februari 1859). Zijn zoon Ugo (1867-1919) volgde hem op 29 december 1894 als vice-consul op.

$Ney.en_GB: Napoléon Henri Edgar Ney, prince of La Moskowa, was a French military officer and a loyal supporter of L.N. Bonaparte. After L.N. Bonaparte was elected as president in December 1848, he appointed Ney as ordonnance officer and lieutenant colonel on his staff (1 March 1849). In the summer of 1849, Ney was sent on a mission to Rome, from where he reported to the president. On 19 August 1849, Bonaparte wrote to Ney his famous letter, which was soon deliberately circulated and which sought to limit reputational damage by outlining French liberal intentions that would serve as a condition for the restoration of papal power. The letter caused fierce debate in the Assembly. Ney was elected to the Constituent Assembly on 3 February 1850 and to the Senate in 1857, where he steadfastly defended imperialist rule. After participating in the Italian campaign of 1859, he was also promoted to the rank of general. He retired from politics in 1870 and died in Paris on 12 March 1882.
$Ney.it_IT: Napoleone Henri Edgar Ney, principe di La Moskowa, fu un ufficiale militare francese e un fedele sostenitore di L.N. Bonaparte. Dopo che L.N. Bonaparte fu eletto presidente nel dicembre 1848, nominò Ney ufficiale di ordinanza e tenente colonnello nel suo stato maggiore (1° marzo 1849). Nell'estate del 1849, Ney fu inviato in missione a Roma, da dove riferiva al presidente. Il 19 agosto 1849, Bonaparte scrisse a Ney la sua famosa lettera, che fu presto fatta circolare deliberatamente e che cercava di limitare il danno di reputazione delineando le intenzioni liberali francesi che sarebbero servite come condizione per la restaurazione del potere papale. La lettera causò un acceso dibattito nell'Assemblea. Ney fu eletto all'Assemblea Costituente il 3 febbraio 1850 e al Senato nel 1857, dove difese con fermezza il dominio imperialista. Dopo aver partecipato alla campagna d'Italia del 1859, fu anche promosso al grado di generale. Si ritirò dalla politica nel 1870 e morì a Parigi il 12 marzo 1882.
$Ney.nl_NL: Napoléon Henri Edgar Ney, prins van La Moskowa, was een Franse militair en een trouw aanhanger van L.N. Bonaparte, die hem na diens uitverkiezing tot president in december 1848 benoemde tot ordonnans-officier en luitenant-kolonel in zijn staf (1 maart 1849). In de zomer van 1849 werd Ney op een missie gestuurd naar Rome, vanwaar hij de president verslag uitbracht. Op 19 augustus 1849 schreef Bonaparte aan Ney zijn beroemde brief, weldra met opzet verspreid, waarmee hij imagoschade trachtte te beperken door de Franse liberale intenties uiteen te zetten die als voorwaarde zouden gelden voor het herstel van de pauselijke macht. De brief zorgde in de Assemblée voor een hevig debat. Ney werd op 3 februari 1850 gekozen in de grondwetgevende vergadering en in 1857 in de senaat, waar hij het imperiale regime standvastig verdedigde. Intussen was hij, na deelname aan de Italiaanse campagne van 1859, bevorderd tot generaal. Hij trok zich terug uit de politiek in 1870 en stierf in Parijs op 12 Maart 1882.

$Novelli.en_GB: Ettore Novelli was an Italian librarian, historian and poet. He studied at the seminary in Velletri, then moved to Rome to enrol in the Faculty of Law, which did not prevent him from embarking on a career as a man of letters. Novelli's rich bibliography testifies to a varied cultural background, ranging from texts written in Latin, unpublished works of various kinds, to erudite historical and philological treatises. His main interest, however, remained writing verse. In March 1846, he was elected as municipal librarian of Velletri. Alongside his commitment as a man of letters, his political activity was very intense, as evidenced by his participation in the revolutionary uprisings of 1848-1849, as well as his role in the attempted insurrection of 1867 for the occupation of Rome, which was nipped in the bud by the victory of the joined French and papal troops over Garibaldi's volunteers at Mentana. After the capture of Rome (1870) Novelli worked as a government commissioner in charge of the confiscation of the immense book heritage held by religious orders. He was among the eminent protagonists of the foundation of the National Central Library in Rome, which was inaugurated on 16 March 1876. His most important assignment, however, was the direction of the Angelica Library, confiscated from the Augustinians, which he held from 3 November 1873 until 15 May 1898.
$Novelli.it_IT: Ettore Novelli fu un bibliotecario, storico e poeta italiano. Studiò presso il Seminario di Velletri, poi si trasferì a Roma per iscriversi alla Facoltà di giurisprudenza, il ché non gli impedì di avviare una carriera di letterato. La ricca bibliografia del Novelli, testimonia una formazione culturale variegata che va da testi redatti in latino, opere inedite di vario genere, ai discorsi e trattati di erudizione storica e filologica; il suo principale interesse rimase però lo scrivere versi. Nel marzo del 1846 fu eletto bibliotecario comunale di Velletri. Unitamente all'impegno di letterato fu molto intensa l'attività politica, come testimonia la sua partecipazione ai moti rivoluzionari del 1848-1849, nonché alla tentata insurrezione del 1867 per l'occupazione di Roma, conclusasi a Mentana con la vittoria delle truppe franco-pontificie sui volontari garibaldini. Dopo la presa di Roma (1870) Novelli si adoperò come commissario governativo preposto al sequestro ed all'incameramento dello sterminato patrimonio librario in possesso degli ordini religiosi. Fu tra gli eminenti protagonisti della fondazione della Biblioteca nazionale centrale di Roma, inaugurata il 16 marzo 1876. L'incarico più importante fu però la direzione della Biblioteca Angelica, confiscata agli Agostiniani, che tenne dal 3 novembre 1873 fino al 15 maggio 1898.
$Novelli.nl_NL: Ettore Novelli was een Italiaanse bibliothecaris, historicus en dichter. Hij studeerde aan het seminarie in Velletri en verhuisde daarna naar Rome om zich in te schrijven aan de rechtenfaculteit, wat hem niet weerhield van een carrière als letterkundige. Novelli's rijke bibliografie getuigt van een brede culturele achtergrond, variërend van teksten in het Latijn, ongepubliceerde werken van allerlei soort, tot erudiete historische en filologische traktaten. Zijn belangrijkste interesse bleef echter het schrijven van verzen. In maart 1846 werd hij gekozen tot gemeentebibliothecaris van Velletri. Naast zijn inzet als letterkundige was hij ook politiek actief, zoals blijkt uit zijn deelname aan de revolutionaire opstanden van 1848-1849 en zijn rol in het anti-pauselijke verzet dat in 1867 Rome wilde bezetten, een plan dat in de kiem werd gesmoord door de overwinning van de Frans-pauselijke troepen op de vrijwilligers van Garibaldi bij Mentana. Na de inname van Rome (1870) werkte Novelli als regeringscommissaris die verantwoordelijk was voor de inbeslagname van het immense boekenerfgoed van religieuze ordes. Hij was een van de hoofdrolspelers bij de oprichting van de Nationale Centrale Bibliotheek in Rome, die op 16 maart 1876 werd ingewijd. Zijn belangrijkste verdienst was echter het beheer van de Angelica Bibliotheek, die geconfisqueerd was van de Augustijnen en die hij beheerde van 3 november 1873 tot 15 mei 1898.

$OranjeWI.en_GB: William Frederick, prince of Orange-Nassau, was sovereign prince of the United Netherlands from 1813-1815 and king of the Netherlands, grand duke of Luxembourg and duke of Limburg from 1815 until his abdication in 1840. He secured the addition of Belgium to his kingdom at the Congress of Vienna in 1815 and organised a strong central government. As a 'king merchant' or 'canal king', he invested heavily in the restoration of prosperity and the rise of industry. To the working class, he paid little attention. In the southern part of his kingdom in particular, dissatisfaction with his autocratic and capitalist style of government led to resistance and eventually to Belgium's secession in 1830. It was only in 1839 (Treaty of London) that the king acquiesced; a little later, a new constitution also significantly curtailed his power. For these reasons, William decided to abdicate his throne on 7 October 1840. He left for Berlin, where he died three years later.
$OranjeWI.it_IT: Guglielmo Federico, principe di Orange-Nassau, fu principe sovrano dei Paesi Bassi Uniti dal 1813 al 1815 e re dei Paesi Bassi, granduca di Lussemburgo e duca di Limburgo dal 1815 fino alla sua abdicazione nel 1840. Si assicurò l'aggiunta del Belgio al suo regno al Congresso di Vienna nel 1815 e organizzò un forte governo centrale. In qualità di 're commerciante' o 're dei canali', investì molto nel ripristino della prosperità e nella crescita dell'industria. Alla classe operaia prestava poca attenzione. Nella parte meridionale del suo regno, in particolare, l'insoddisfazione per il suo stile di governo autocratico e capitalista portò alla resistenza e infine alla secessione del Belgio nel 1830. Fu solo nel 1839 (Trattato di Londra) che il re acconsentì; poco dopo, anche una nuova costituzione ridusse significativamente il suo potere. Per questi motivi Guglielmo decise di abdicare al trono il 7 ottobre 1840. Partì per Berlino, dove morì tre anni dopo.
$OranjeWI.nl_NL: Willem Frederik, prins van Oranje-Nassau, was van 1813-1815 soeverein vorst der Verenigde Nederlanden en van 1815 tot zijn abdicatie in 1840 koning der Nederlanden, groothertog van Luxemburg en hertog van Limburg. Hij bewerkstelligde in 1815 op het Congres van Wenen dat België aan zijn koninkrijk werd toegevoegd enorganiseerde een sterk centraal bestuur. Als 'koning kooppman' of 'kanalenkoning' investeerde hij flink in het herstel van de welvaart en de opkomst van de industrie. Voor de arbeidersklasse had hij nauwelijks aandacht. Met name in het zuiden leidde ontevredenheid over de autocratische en kapitalistische regeerstijl tot verzet en uiteindelijk in 1830 tot de afscheiding van België. Pas in 1839 (Verdrag van Londen) legde de koning zich daarbij neer; even later werd met een nieuwe grondwet ook zijn macht aanzienlijk ingeperkt. Om deze redenen besloot Willem op 7 oktober 1840 afstand te doen van zijn troon. Hij vertrok naar Berlijn, waar hij drie jaar later overleed.

$OranjeWII.en_GB: William Frederick George Louis, prince of Orange-Nassau (1792- 1849) was king of the Netherlands, grand duke of Luxembourg and duke of Limburg from 1840 until his death in 1849. In 1815, he fought in the Battle of Waterloo under the Duke of Wellington. In 1816, he married Anna Paulowna (1795-1865), daughter of Tsar Paul of Russia. Although, like his father William I, he opposed democratic reforms, he abruptly changed his mind after the outbreak of the revolutions in Germany and France in 1848. At first unbeknownst to the incumbent moderately conservative cabinet, he appointed a constitutional commission headed by liberal politician Johan Rudolf Thorbecke. William II died at his palace in the city of Tilburg on 17 March 1849, a few months after the promulgation of the new constitution (3 November 1848), which had curtailed the king's power enforced the powers of parliament. William II was known as a great art lover and collector. He was succeeded by his son Willem III.
$OranjeWII.it_IT: William Frederick George Louis, principe di Orange-Nassau (1792- 1849) fu re dei Paesi Bassi, granduca di Lussemburgo e duca di Limburgo dal 1840 fino alla sua morte nel 1849. Nel 1815 combatté nella battaglia di Waterloo sotto il duca di Wellington. Nel 1816 sposò Anna Paulowna (1795-1865), figlia dello zar Paolo di Russia. Sebbene, come suo padre Guglielmo I, si opponesse alle riforme democratiche, cambiò improvvisamente idea dopo lo scoppio delle rivoluzioni in Germania e Francia nel 1848. Inizialmente all'insaputa del governo moderatamente conservatore in carica, nominò una commissione costituzionale guidata dal politico liberale Johan Rudolf Thorbecke. Guglielmo II morì nel suo palazzo nella città di Tilburg il 17 marzo 1849, pochi mesi dopo la promulgazione della nuova costituzione (3 novembre 1848), che aveva ridotto il potere del re rafforzando i poteri del parlamento. Guglielmo II era conosciuto come un grande amante e collezionista d'arte. Gli successe il figlio Guglielmo III.
$OranjeWII.nl_NL: Willem Frederik George Lodewijk, prins van Oranje-Nassau (1792- 1849) was van 1840 tot zijn dood in 1849 koning der Nederlanden, groothertog van Luxemburg en hertog van Limburg. In 1815 vecht hij mee in de Slag bij Waterloo onder de hertog van Wellington. Hij trouwt in 1816 met Anna Paulowna (1795-1865), de dochter van Tsaar Paul van Rusland. Hoewel hij, net als zijn vader Willem I, geen democratische hervorming wenste, veranderde hij abrupt van gedachten na het uitbreken van revoluties in Duitsland en Frankrijk in 1848. Hij stelde, eerst buiten weten van het zittende, gematigd conservatieve kabinet, een grondwetscommissie aan die werd geleid door de liberale politicus Johan Rudolf Thorbecke. Willem II stierf op 17 maart 1849 in zijn paleis in de stad Tilburg, een paar maanden na de afkondiging van de nieuwe grondwet (3 november 1848), die de macht van de koning had ingeperkt en de parlementaire bevoegdheden aanzienlijk had uitgebreid. Willem II stond bekend als een groot kunstliefhebber- en verzamelaar. Hij werd opgevolgd door zijn zoon Willem III.

$Orengo.en_GB: Paolo Orengo was born in Ventimiglia in 1828 to Marquis Pietro and Carolina Preti of the Marquises of Saint-Ambroise. In 1842 he was educated at the Naval School in Genoa and in 1848 he took part as an ensign in the First Italian War of Independence. After other naval missions, he took part in the Crimean War as a second lieutenant. In 1855 he transported supplies to the Sardinian troops in the Black Sea, while in 1856 he helped repatriate the troops. He was promoted to lieutenant-lieutenant in 1858, at the beginning of the Second Italian War of Independence. Orengo took part in the Sardinian Navy's activities during the Expedition of Garibaldi's 'Thousand' in 1860 and, shortly afterwards, played a leading role in the siege of Ancona. In August 1861 he obtained his first naval command. As captain of a frigate, in 1864 he received his first shore-based position with the Italian Navy department in Genoa, at the office of the Adjutant General. From 1865 he was transferred to the Ministry of the Navy in Florence as Chief of Cabinet until 1866, when he left to take part in the Third Italian War of Independence, also fighting at the Battle of Lissa. Four years later, he took part in the operations that led to the conquest of Civitavecchia. Important were Orengo's duties as director of personnel at the Ministry of the Navy between 1872 and 1876.
