$Rignano.en_GB: Mario Massimo, duke of Rignano, was a politician who was the Minister of Trade and Public Works in the Mamiani cabinet (4 May-3 August 1848). Besides being known as a minister, Mamiani was also known as a mathematician and astronomer, and one can in fact see his observatory at the Via del Teatro Marcello 2 in Rome today. Massimo was also president of the Pontifical Academy of Sciences (also called “the new Lincei”), Commissary General of the Papal Railway and municipal councillor. After 1870, he was a member of parliament.
$Rignano.it_IT: Mario Massimo, duca di Rignano, fu un politico che coprì anche l'incarico di ministro del Commercio e dei Lavori Pubblici nel governo Mamiani (4 maggio-3 agosto 1848). Oltre che ministro, Mamiani fu conosciuto anche come matematico e astronomo, tanto che oggi è possibile vedere il suo osservatorio in Via del Teatro Marcello 2 a Roma. Massimo fu anche presidente della Pontificia Accademia delle Scienze (detta anche “i nuovi Lincei”), commissario generale delle Ferrovie Pontificie e consigliere comunale. Dopo il 1870 fu membro del parlamento.
$Rignano.nl_NL: Mario Massimo, hertog van Rignano, was een politicus die in het kabinet-Mamiani (4 mei-3 augustus 1848) minister van Handel en Openbare Werken was. Behalve als minister was hij vooral bekend als wiskundige en astronoom. Zo is in Rome aan de Via del Teatro Marcello 2 nog het torentje van zijn observatorium te zien. Massimo was verder president van de pauselijke academie van wetenschappen (ook wel de 'nieuwe Lincei'), commissaris-generaal van de pauselijke spoorwegen, gemeenteraadslid in Rome en, na 1870, parlementslid.

$Roest.en_GB: Theodorus Martinus Roest van Limburg studied Law in Liège, Ghent and Leiden, where he also obtained a doctorate with his mentor Thorbecke (1831). Additionally, he learned Italian, as appears from his translations, such as Machiavelli's The Prince (1834). In 1835 he started his career as a critical liberal journalist with the Arnhemsche Courant. To draw his teeth, in 1841 he was secretly appointed as counsellor of legation at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, and from 1843-1846 at the Dutch legation in Vienna. In 1846 he refused a position as chargé d'affaires in Athens. His attempts to force a better offer out of the government by threatening to reveal secret agreements eventually succeeded in 1851, when he was appointed as chargé d'affaires in Lisbon. Later he became envoy in Washington (1856-1868). There he reported on the American Civil War and married Isabella Cass (1816-1879), daughter of the American Minister for Foreign Affairs Lewis Cass and sister of the US ambassador to the Holy See (1849-1858) Lewis Cass jr. Upon Roest's return to Europe in October 1867, to the amazement of many, he was appointed as (interim) Minister of Foreign Affairs in the liberal cabinet Van Bosse-Fock (in June 1868). In that role he promoted the Dutch neutrality during the Franco-Prussian War and the Dutch position concerning the demise of the Papal States. At his Ministry he was conspicuously absent; in parliament the vagueness of his responses caused general annoyance. In 1870, the prospect that parliament would reject his budget for 1871 led him to resign and eventually leave the country. Roest and his wife died in Florence.
$Roest.it_IT: Theodorus Martinus Roest van Limburg studiò giurisprudenza a Liegi, Gand e Leida, dove conseguì anche un dottorato con il suo mentore Thorbecke (1831). Inoltre, imparò l'italiano, come risulta dalle sue traduzioni, come Il Principe di Machiavelli (1834). Nel 1835 iniziò la sua carriera come giornalista liberale critico presso l'Arnhemsche Courant. Per farsi notare, nel 1841 fu segretamente nominato consigliere di legazione presso il Ministero degli Affari Esteri e dal 1843 al 1846 presso la legazione olandese a Vienna. Nel 1846 rifiutò l'incarico di incaricato d'affari ad Atene. I suoi tentativi di forzare un'offerta migliore al governo minacciando di rivelare accordi segreti alla fine ebbero successo nel 1851, quando fu nominato incaricato d'affari a Lisbona. Successivamente divenne inviato a Washington (1856-1868). Lì riferì sulla guerra civile americana e sposò Isabella Cass (1816-1879), figlia del ministro americano degli affari esteri Lewis Cass e sorella dell'ambasciatore americano presso la Santa Sede (1849-1858) Lewis Cass jr. Al ritorno di Roest in Europa nell'ottobre 1867, con stupore di molti, fu nominato ministro (ad interim) degli affari esteri nel gabinetto liberale Van Bosse-Fock (nel giugno 1868). In quel ruolo promosse la neutralità olandese durante la guerra franco-prussiana e la posizione olandese riguardo alla fine dello Stato Pontificio. Al suo Ministero era decisamente assente; in parlamento la vaghezza delle sue risposte causaroini un fastidio generale. Nel 1870, la prospettiva che il parlamento respingesse il suo bilancio per il 1871 lo portò a dimettersi e alla fine a lasciare il paese. Roest e sua moglie morirono a Firenze.
$Roest.nl_NL: Theodorus Martinus Roest van Limburg studeerde Rechten in Luik, Gent en Leiden, waar hij vervolgens bij zijn leermeester Thorbecke promoveerde (1831). Daarnaast leerde hij Italiaans, blijkens vertalingen zoals o.a. die van Machiavelli's De Vorst (1834). In 1835 begon hij zijn loopbaan als kritisch liberaal journalist bij de Arnhemsche Courant. Om hem onschadelijk te maken werd hij in 1841 in het geheim benoemd als raad van legatie bij Buitenlandse Zaken en twee jaar later bij de legatie in Wenen (1843-1846). In 1846 weigerde hij een baan als zaakgelastigde in Athene. Zijn pogingen een betere post af te dwingen door de regering te dreigen met openbaarmaking van geheime afspraken slaagden uiteindelijk in 1851, toen hij werd benoemd als zaakgelastigde in Lissabon. In 1856 werd hij gezant in Washington (1856-1868). Daar rapporteerde hij over de Amerikaanse Burgeroorlog en trouwde Isabella Cass (1816-1879), dochter van de Amerikaanse minister van Buitenlandse Zaken Lewis Cass en zus van de ambassadeur bij de Heilige Stoel (1849-1858) Lewis Cass jr. Na Roests terugkeer naar Europa in oktober 1867 werd hij tot veler verbazing in juni 1868 (interim) minister van Buitenlandse Zaken in het liberale kabinet Van Bosse-Fock. In die rol behartigde hij de Nederlandse neutraliteit in de Frans-Pruisische oorlog en het Nederlandse standpunt inzake het wegvallen van de Kerkelijke Staat. Op zijn ministerie liet hij zich echter weinig zien en in de Kamer wekte hij ergernis met zijn vage antwoorden. Het vooruitzicht dat zijn begroting voor 1871 zou worden geblokkeerd deed hem in 1870 ontslag nemen en ten slotte naar het buitenland vertrekken. Roest en zijn vrouw overleden in Florence.

$Rolandus.en_GB: Thomas Dolegius Govert Rolandus was born the son of Thomas Dolegius, captain, and Maria Johanna des H.R. Rijksbarones van Slingelandt. Rolandus was in charge of the Military Engineers on Curaçao as the 'oldest 1st lieutenant of Artillery', and was appointed consul-general to the commonwealths of Venezuela, New Grenada and Ecuador in 1858, based in Caracas (RD 9 Sept 1858 no 88). He also received the diplomatic title of 'political agent”' (RD 27 May 1860 no 61). Nine years later, revoking that earlier title simultaneously, he was appointed honorary chargé d'affaires at Caracas (RD 7 July 1869 no. 15). From the latter office he was honorably discharged on 12 May 1872 (RD no. 12), after which he was put on waiting pay. He married Josina Helena Esser (1830-1909) on Curaçao on 9 August 1848. From: Van Galen Last, Diplomaten, consuls en tolken, 736.
$Rolandus.it_IT: Thomas Dolegius Govert Rolandus era il figlio di Thomas Dolegius, capitano, e Maria Johanna des H.R. Rijksbarones van Slingelandt. Rolandus era a capo del Genio militare di Curaçao come il 'primo luogotenente di artiglieria più anziano' e fu nominato console generale presso i Commonwealth di Venezuela, Nuova Grenada ed Ecuador nel 1858, con sede a Caracas (RD 9 settembre 1858 n. 88). Ricevette inoltre il titolo diplomatico di “agente politico” (RD 27 maggio 1860 n. 61). Nove anni dopo, revocando simultaneamente quel titolo precedente, fu nominato incaricato d'affari onorario a Caracas (RD 7 luglio 1869 n. 15). Da quest'ultimo incarico venne dimesso con onore il 12 maggio 1872 (RD n. 12), dopodiché fu posto in attesa. Sposò Josina Helena Esser (1830-1909) a Curaçao il 9 agosto 1848. Da: Van Galen Last, Diplomaten, consuls en tolken, 736.
$Rolandus.nl_NL: Thomas Dolegius Govert Rolandus werd geboren als zoon van Thomas Dolegius, kapitein, en Maria Johanna des H.R. Rijksbarones van Slingelandt. Rolandus was als 'oudste 1e luitenant der Artillerie belast met het Departement der Genie op Curaçao', en werd in 1858 benoemd tot consul-generaal bij de gemenebesten Venezuela, Nieuw Grenada en Ecuador met standplaats Caracas (KB 9 sept. 1858 no. 88). Hij ontving tevens de diplomatieke titel van 'politiek agent' (KB van 27 mei 1860 no. 61). Negen jaar later werd hij, onder gelijktijdige intrekking van die eerdere titel, benoemd tot honorair zaakgelastigde te Caracas (KB 7 juli 1869 no. 15). Uit dat laatste ambt werd hij eervol ontslagen op 12 mei 1872  (KB no. 12), waarna hij op wachtgeld werd gezet. Hij trouwde op Curaçao op 9 augustus 1848 met Josina Helena Esser (1830-1909). Uit: Van Galen Last, Diplomaten, consuls en tolken, 736.

$Rollman.en_GB: Rollman was the wife of Gaspari Stienen, consul of the Netherlands in Ancona.
$Rollman.it_IT: Rollman era la moglie di Gaspari Stienen, console dei Paesi Bassi ad Ancona.
$Rollman.nl_NL: Rollman was de vrouw van Gaspari Stienen, consul van Nederland te Ancona.

$Rossi.en_GB: Pasquale de Rossi was a lawyer and professor of Roman Law at the Università La Sapienza in Rome. In the Mamiani cabinet (4 May-3 August 1848), he was Minister of Justice. Although he opposed anticlerical sentiment, during the Roman Republic of 1849 he gained prestige as captain ad honorem of the Bataglione Universitario Romano, the corps of Roman students. After the fall of the Roman Republic and the restoration of papal authority, De Rossi received a pardon from the Pope; even so, he was no longer allowed to teach and remained a person of interest in the eyes of the Church. A warrant for his arrest and search of his property was issued in May 1851, although he was released a few hours later. He spent his final years quietly and died on 18 December 1863.
$Rossi.it_IT: Pasquale de Rossi fu avvocato e professore di Diritto Romano all'Università La Sapienza di Roma. Nel governo Mamiani (4 maggio-3 agosto 1848), fu Ministro di Giustizia. Pur opponendosi al sentimento anticlericale, durante la Repubblica Romana del 1849 si guadagnò prestigio come capitano ad honorem del Bataglione Universitario Romano, il corpo degli studenti romani. Dopo la caduta della Repubblica Romana e la restaurazione dell'autorità pontificia, De Rossi ricevette la grazia dal Papa; ciononostante, non gli fu più permesso di insegnare e rimase una persona oggetto di attenzione agli occhi della Chiesa. Un mandato di arresto e la perquisizione dei suoi beni furono emessi nel maggio 1851, ma fu rilasciato poche ore dopo. Trascorse gli ultimi anni in silenzio e morì il 18 dicembre 1863.
$Rossi.nl_NL: Pasquale de Rossi was advocaat en hoogleraar Romeins Recht aan de Università La Sapienza in Rome. In het kabinet-Mamiani (4 mei-3 augustus 1848) was hij minister van Justitie. Hoewel hij tegenstander van de antiklerikale tendensen was, verwierf hij tijdens de Romeinse Republiek van 1849 aanzien als aanvoerder ad honorem van het Bataglione Universitario Romano, het korps van de Romeinse studenten. Na de val van de Romeinse Republiek en het herstel van de pauselijke macht ontving De Rossi een pardon van de paus; desalniettemin mocht hij geen les meer geven en bleef hij een verdacht type in de ogen van de Kerk. Zo werd in mei 1851 een arrestatie- en huiszoekingsbevel uitgevaardigd (al werd hij enkele uren later weer vrijgelaten). Hij trok zich tijdens zijn laatste jaren terug en stierf op 18 december 1863.

$RossiP.en_GB: Pellegrino Luigi Eduardo Rossi was an economist, jurist and politician. A native from Carrara, Rossi received the French nationality in 1834, when he was Professor of Economics at the Collège de France in Paris. Minister Guizot sent him to Gregory as a special envoy, to plead the case of the Jesuits in France. In 1845, Rossi was promoted to ambassador to the Holy See. When the February Revolution of 1848 put an end to the July monarchy in France, Rossi stayed in Rome as a private citizen until September 1848. Pius IX then named him minister of Internal Affairs and Finances in a moderate cabinet (the Soglia Ceroni cabinet), of which Rossi was in reality the leader. His first acts in his position did little to assuage the disappointment and anger that lived in radical circles with respect to the 'betrayal' of the pope to the liberal-national cause. On 15 November 1848, Rossi was killed in front of the Palazzo della Cancelleria by a dagger to his neck.
$RossiP.it_IT: Pellegrino Luigi Eduardo Rossi fu un economista, giurista e politico. Originario di Carrara, Rossi ricevette la nazionalità francese nel 1834, quando era professore di economia al Collège de France di Parigi. Il ministro Guizot lo inviò a papa Gregorio XVI come inviato speciale, per perorare la causa dei gesuiti in Francia. Nel 1845 Rossi fu promosso ambasciatore presso la Santa Sede. Quando i moti rivoluzionari di febbraio del 1848 misero fine alla monarchia di luglio in Francia, Rossi rimase a Roma come privato cittadino fino al settembre 1848. Pio IX lo nominò ministro degli Interni e delle Finanze in un gabinetto moderato (il gabinetto Soglia Ceroni), di cui Rossi era in realtà il leader. I suoi primi atti in carica non riuscirono a placare la delusione e la rabbia che vivevano negli ambienti radicali rispetto al “tradimento” del papa nei confronti della causa liberale-nazionale. Il 15 novembre 1848 Rossi fu ucciso davanti al Palazzo della Cancelleria con un pugnale al collo.
$RossiP.nl_NL: Pellegrino Luigi Eduardo Rossi was econoom, jurist en politicus. Hij kwam uit Carrara en kreeg als hoogleraar economie aan het Collège de France in Parijs in 1834 de Franse nationaliteit. Als speciaal gezant werd hij door de minister Guizot naar Rome gestuurd om bij Gregorius XVI de ontbinding van de Jezuïetenorde in Frankrijk te bepleiten. In 1845 promoveerde hij tot ambassadeur bij de Heilige Stoel. Toen in Frankrijk de Februarirevolutie van 1848 een einde maakte aan de Julimonarchie, bleef Rossi als ambteloos burger in Rome tot september 1848. Pius IX benoemde hem toen tot minister van Binnenlandse Zaken en Financiën in een gematigd liberaal kabinet (kabinet-Soglia Ceroni), waarvan Rossi feitelijk de leider was. Zijn eerste daden konden de teleurstelling en woede in radicale kringen over het 'verraad' van de paus aan de liberaal-nationale zaak niet wegnemen. Op 15 november 1848 werd Rossi voor het Palazzo della Cancelleria met een dolksteek in de hals om het leven werd gebracht.

$Rossum.en_GB: Johannes van Rossum was a Dutch court servant, from a working-class district of The Hague, who became known as the lover of Princess Marianne of Orange-Nassau, daughter of King William I and sister of William II. In 1836, Johannes succeeded his late father as one of William I's lackeys. Around 1844, he met Marianne, who soon employed him, after which he rose from being her equerry to librarian and private secretary. From 1845, he accompanied her on trips she undertook to Kamenz and Italy (Como, Rome, Naples) to escape her unhappy marriage to Prince Albert of Prussia. Around 1848, the extramarital affair with Johannes began - himself married until his wife's death in 1861. The tabloid press painted a pitch-black portrait of him, especially when news came out that Marianne was pregnant shortly after her divorce from Albrecht. Their illegitimate son Johannes Willem was born in Cefalù on 30 October 1849 during a trip to the Holy Land. From October 1850, Van Rossum and Marianne was again in Rome, where he signed the contract for the purchase of the Villa Celimontana on 7 June 1851. In February 1857, the couple left Rome permanently, to settle at Reinhartshausen castle in the Duchy of Nassau. Like his 12-year-old son (decd. 1861), Johannes would also die there. The grave in which he was reunited with Marianne in 1883 could not bear his name.
$Rossum.it_IT: Johannes van Rossum fu un servitore di corte olandese, originario di un quartiere operaio dell'Aia, che divenne noto come l'amante della principessa Marianne di Orange-Nassau, figlia del re Guglielmo I e sorella di Guglielmo II. Nel 1836, Johannes succedette al suo defunto padre come uno dei lacchè di Guglielmo I. Intorno al 1844 incontrò Marianne, che presto lo assunse, dopo di che passò da suo scudiero a bibliotecario e segretario privato. Dal 1845 l'accompagnò nei viaggi che intraprese a Kamenz e in Italia (Como, Roma, Napoli) per sfuggire al suo infelice matrimonio con il principe Alberto di Prussia. Intorno al 1848 iniziò la relazione extraconiugale con Johannes, lui stesso sposato fino alla morte della moglie nel 1861. La stampa scandalistica dipinse di lui un ritratto nero come la pece, soprattutto quando arrivò la notizia che Marianne era incinta poco dopo il divorzio da Albrecht. Il loro figlio illegittimo Johannes Willem nacque a Cefalù il 30 ottobre 1849 durante un viaggio in Terra Santa. Dall'ottobre 1850 Van Rossum e Marianne furono nuovamente a Roma, dove firmò il contratto per l'acquisto di Villa Celimontana il 7 giugno 1851. Nel febbraio 1857 la coppia lasciò definitivamente Roma, per stabilirsi nel castello di Reinhartshausen nel Ducato di Nassau. Come suo figlio dodicenne (dec. 1861), anche Johannes morì lì. La tomba in cui si riunì a Marianne nel 1883 non  portò il suo nome.
$Rossum.nl_NL: Johannes van Rossum was een Nederlandse hofdienaar, afkomstig uit een Haagse volkswijk, bekend geworden als geliefde van prinses Marianne van Oranje-Nassau, dochter van koning Willem I en zus van Willem II. In 1836 volgde Johannes zijn overleden vader op als lakei van Willem I. Rond 1844 ontmoette hij Marianne, die hem spoedig in dienst nam, waarna hij opklom van stalmeester tot bibliothecaris en secretaris. Vanaf 1845 vergezelde hij haar op reizen naar Kamenz en Italië (Como, Rome, Napels) om aan haar ongelukkige huwelijk met prins Albrecht van Pruisen te ontsnappen. Rond 1848 begon de buitenechtelijke relatie met Johannes –zelf getrouwd tot het overlijden van zijn vrouw in 1861. De roddelpers schetste een gitzwart portret van hem, vooral toen bleek dat Marianne in verwachting was, kort na haar scheiding van Albrecht. Hun buitenechtelijke zoon Johannes werd tijdens een reis naar het Heilig Land op 30 oktober 1849 in Cefalù geboren. Vanaf oktober 1850 was Van Rossum opnieuw met Marianne in Rome, waar hij op 7 juni 1851  tekende voor de koop van de Villa Celimontana. In februari 1857 verliet het stel Rome definitief, om zich te vestigen op kasteel Reinhartshausen in het hertogdom Nassau. Net als zijn twaalfjarige zoon Johannes Willem (1861) zou ook Johannes daar overlijden. Het graf waarin hij in 1883 met Marianne werd herenigd mocht zijn naam niet dragen.

$Rusconi.en_GB: Carlo Rusconi was a writer, translator, patriot and politician from Bologna, who also partook in the liberal uprising against papal authority in Bologna, 1831. Next to his political work, he made a career as an author of historical novels and an influential translator of Shakespeare, Schiller, Byron and Walter Scott. In 1849 he was elected during the Roman Constitutional Assembly, and after the proclamation of the Roman Republic, was appointed minister of External Affairs. Rusconi pleaded for the case of the Republic in London and in Paris, particularly after the arrival of the French troops (April 1849). When he had word of the Roman capitulation in July 1849, he went into exile in Belgium, Switzerland and finally in Genoa. He continued to combine his literary work with his strong political engagement. After Italian unification, he held several public functions, among which was the post of general secretary of the Council of State (1879). Rusconi published his memories of the events of 1848-1849 in La Repubblica Romana del 1849 (Turin, 1850-1851).
$Rusconi.it_IT: Carlo Rusconi fu uno scrittore, traduttore, patriota e politico bolognese, che partecipò anche alla rivolta liberale contro l'autorità papale a Bologna, nel 1831. Oltre alla sua attività politica, fu apprezzato come autore di romanzi storici e traduttore di Shakespeare, Schiller, Byron e Walter Scott. Nel 1849 fu eletto nell'Assemblea Costituente Romana e, dopo la proclamazione della Repubblica Romana, fu nominato ministro degli Affari Esteri. Rusconi difese la causa della Repubblica a Londra e a Parigi, soprattutto dopo l'arrivo delle truppe francesi (aprile 1849). Quando seppe della capitolazione romana nel luglio 1849, andò in esilio in Belgio, Svizzera e infine a Genova. Continuò a coniugare la sua attività letteraria con un forte impegno politico. Dopo l'Unità d'Italia ricoprì numerose funzioni pubbliche, tra cui quella di segretario generale del Consiglio di Stato (1879). Rusconi pubblicò le sue memorie degli avvenimenti del 1848-1849 ne “La Repubblica Romana del 1849” (Torino, 1850-1851).
$Rusconi.nl_NL: Carlo Rusconi was een schrijver, vertaler, patriot en politicus uit Bologna, waar hij in februari 1831 deelnam aan de liberale opstand tegen het pauselijk gezag. Intussen maakte hij carrière als auteur van historische romans en invloedrijk vertaler van o.a. Shakespeare, Schiller, Byron en Walter Scott. In 1849 werd hij gekozen in de Romeinse Grondwetgevende Vergadering; na de proclamatie van de republiek werd hij benoemd tot minister van Buitenlandse Zaken. Vooral na de landing van de Franse troepen (april 1849) behartigde hij de belangen van de Romeinse Republiek in Londen en Parijs, waar hem in juli 1849 het bericht van de Romeinse overgave bereikte. Daarop ging hij in ballingschap in België, Zwitserland en ten slotte in Genua. Hij bleef zijn literaire werk combineren met een sterk politiek engagement, dat na de Italiaanse Eenwording resulteerde in verschillende publieke functies, waaronder die van algemeen secretaris van de Raad van State (1879). Zijn herinneringen aan de gebeurtenissen van 1848-49 publiceerde Rusconi in La Repubblica romana del 1849 (Turijn 1850-51).

$Saliceti.en_GB: Aurelio Saliceti was a politician, patriot and jurist from Teramo, who worked as a professor of civil law from 1836 onwards and as a judge from 1838 onwards, both posts in Naples. After the proclamation of the new constitution of the Kingdom of the Two Sicilies by Ferdinando II (11 February 1848), Saliceti became intendant for the province of Salerno and then Minister of Justice. In the latter capacity he pleaded for the banishment of Jesuits, which ultimately led to his dismissal. He went on to write a programme for a more reformist government. As a consequence, he was suspected of republican and subversive activities, and so he fled to Rome on 15 May 1848. In Rome, Saliceti was elected in the Constitutional Assembly of 21 January and appointed to the executive committee of the Roman Republic, together with Montecchi and Armellini. On 1 July 1849, Saliceti formed the last formal Triumvirate together with Mariani and Calandrelli (until 4 July). Afterwards he fled to London and later Paris. He returned to Italy in 1860. Shortly before his death, Saliceti was elected to the Italian parliament (1861).
$Saliceti.it_IT: Aurelio Saliceti fu un politico, patriota e giurista teramano, che operò come professore di diritto civile dal 1836 e in successivamente, dal 1838,  come giudice,  a Napoli. Dopo la proclamazione della Costituzione del Regno delle Due Sicilie da parte di Ferdinando II (11 febbraio 1848), Saliceti divenne intendente della provincia di Salerno e poi Ministro della Giustizia. In quest'ultima veste chiese la soppressione e l'esilio dei gesuiti, cosa che portò alle sue dimissioni. Continuò a scrivere un programma per un governo più riformista. Sospettato di attività repubblicana ed eversiva, fuggì a Roma il 15 maggio 1848. A Roma Saliceti fu eletto nell'Assemblea Costituente del 21 gennaio 1849 e nominato membro del comitato esecutivo della Repubblica Romana, insieme a Montecchi e Armellini. Il 1° luglio 1849 Saliceti formò insieme a Mariani e Calandrelli l'ultimo triumvirato formale (fino al 4 luglio). Successivamente fuggì a Londra e poi a Parigi. Ritornò in Italia nel 1860. Poco prima della sua morte Saliceti fu eletto al Parlamento italiano (1861).
$Saliceti.nl_NL: Aurelio Saliceti was een politicus, patriot en jurist uit Teramo, die vanaf 1836 als universitair docent burgerlijk recht en vanaf 1838 als rechter in Napels werkte. Na de afkondiging van de grondwet van het Koninkrijk der Beide Siciliën door Ferdinando II (11 februari 1848) werd hij intendant van de provincie Salerno en vervolgens minister van Justitie. In die hoedanigheid pleitte hij o.a. voor de verbanning van de Jezuïeten, wat tot zijn ontslag leidde. Daarop schreef hij een programma voor een meer hervormingsgezinde regering. Hij werd hierdoor verdacht van republikeinse en staatsondermijnende activiteiten, en vluchtte op 15 mei 1848 naar Rome. Daar werd Saliceti op 21 januari in de Grondwetgevende Vergadering gekozen en vervolgens met Montecchi en Armellini in het uitvoerend comité van de Romeinse Republiek benoemd. Op 1 juli 1849 vormde hij met Mariani en Calandrelli het laatste, zuiver formele driemanschap (tot 4 juli). Hij vluchtte vervolgens naar Londen en later naar Parijs. In 1860 keerde hij naar Italië terug. Kort voor zijn dood werd Saliceti in het Italiaanse parlement gekozen (1861).

$Santucci.en_GB: Vincenzo Santucci was a cardinal from La Gorga, in the province of Rome. He began his career as a secretary of Cardinal Giacinto Placido Zurla, who helped jumpstart his career. Santucci first became a secretary at the papal Secretariate of State in 1832 and retained that function for twelve years. In the fall of 1841, he first became substitute for the secretary of state, replacing Francesco Capaccini who was on a diplomatic mission to Portugal. He continued in this function after Pius IX's return to Rome in April 1850, after the fall of the Roman Republic; Santucci also helped prepare the pope's return. During the papal restauration, Santucci was tasked with the reorganisation of ecclesiastic affairs in the territories of the Kingdom of Sardinia. After Pius IX elevated Santucci to the cardinalate in 1853, he became prefect to the Congregation of Studies (14 Nov. 1856), a post he retained until his death. During his life Santucci became an important part of the Papal apparatus, and could greatly influence the diplomatic positioning of the Papal States, also with respect to the Roman Question.
$Santucci.it_IT: Vincenzo Santucci fu un cardinale originario di Gorga, nei pressi di Roma. Iniziò la sua carriera come segretario del cardinale Giacinto Placido Zurla, che lo aiutò a fare carriera. Santucci divenne per la prima volta segretario presso la Segreteria di Stato pontificia nel 1832 e mantenne tale incarico per dodici anni. Nell'autunno del 1841 fu nominato sostituto della segreteria di Stato, al posto di Francesco Capaccini che era in missione diplomatica in Portogallo. Continuò in tale incarico anche dopo il ritorno di Pio IX a Roma nell'aprile 1850, dopo la caduta della Repubblica Romana, avendo anche contribuito a preparare il ritorno del papa. Durante la restaurazione pontificia, Santucci fu incaricato della riorganizzazione degli affari ecclesiastici nei territori del Regno di Sardegna. Dopo la sua nomina a cardinale nel 1853, divenne prefetto della Congregazione degli Studi (14 novembre 1856), incarico che mantenne fino alla morte. Durante la sua vita Santucci svolse un ruolo importante all'interno dell'amministrazione pontificia, influenzando il ruolo dello Stato Pontificio nelle vicende diplomatiche, anche rispetto alla Questione Romana.
$Santucci.nl_NL: Vincenzo Santucci was een kardinaal afkomstig uit La Gorga, in de provincie van Rome. Hij begon zijn carrière als secretaris van kardinaal Giacinto Placido Zurla, die hielp zijn carrière van de grond te krijgen. Santucci begon in 1832 als secretaris bij het pauselijk Staatssecretariaat, een functie die hij twaalf jaar bekleedde. In de herfst van 1841 werd hij voor het eerst plaatsvervangend staatssecretaris, ter vervanging van Francesco Capaccini die op diplomatieke missie in Portugal was. Hij nam deze functie opnieuw op kort na de terugkeer van Pius IX naar Rome in april 1850 na de val van de Romeinse Republiek; Santucci hielp deze terugkeer voor te bereiden. Tijdens de pauselijke restauratie werd Santucci gevolmachtigd om toe te zien op de reorganisatie van kerkelijke zaken in de gebieden van het Koninkrijk Sardinië. Nadat Pius IX hem in 1853 kardinaal maakte, werd hij onder andere Prefect van de Congregatie van Studies (14 nov. 1856), een functie die hij tot zijn dood aanhield. Tijdens zijn leven ontwikkelde Santucci zich tot een spil in het pauselijke bestuursstelsel en had hij grote invloed op de diplomatieke positionering van de Pauselijke Staat in de late negentiende eeuw, ook met betrekking tot de Romeinse Kwestie.

$Savelli.en_GB: Domenico Savelli was a cardinal, originally from Corsica. From 1833 to 1841, he was apostolic delegate in Rieti (1833), Frosinone (1834), Perugia (1838) and Macerata (1841). Pius IX promoted Savelli to the position of pro-governor of Rome and director-general of the Police (15 November 1847). When that position was abolished under the Ferretti-cabinet, Savelli became Minister of the Police. He held this position from 29 December 1847 to 9 February 1948, after which he resigned and followed the pope in his flight to Gaeta. After the fall of the Roman Republic in 1849, Savelli helped restore papal authority from Ancona, as extraordinary commissary. He returned to Rome in August, to become Minister of Internal Affairs and director-general of the Police. On 7 March 1853, he was elevated to the cardinalate, after which Pius named him president of the State Council for Finance (4 July 1853). Savelli resigned from this position on 14 December 1859, after clashing with the pope and the Cardinal Secretary of State G. Antonelli over expenses incurred by the Ministry of Arms. He quitted politics and died in Rome on 30 August 1864.
$Savelli.it_IT: Domenico Savelli era un cardinale, originario della Corsica. Dal 1833 al 1841, fu delegato apostolico a Rieti (1833), Frosinone (1834), Perugia (1838) e Macerata (1841). Pio IX lo promosse alla carica di pro-governatore di Roma e direttore generale della Polizia (15 novembre 1847). Quando tale carica fu abolita sotto il governo Ferretti, Savelli divenne Ministro della Polizia. Mantenne questo incarico dal 29 dicembre 1847 al 9 febbraio 1948, dopodiché si dimise e seguì il papa nella sua fuga a Gaeta. Dopo la caduta della Repubblica Romana nel 1849, Savelli contribuì a ripristinare l'autorità papale da Ancona, in qualità di commissario straordinario. Ritornò a Roma in agosto, per diventare Ministro degli Interni e direttore generale della Polizia. Il 7 marzo 1853 fu elevato al cardinalato, dopodiché Pio XII lo nominò presidente del Consiglio di Stato per le Finanze (4 luglio 1853). Savelli si dimise da questo incarico il 14 dicembre 1859, dopo uno scontro con il papa e il cardinale segretario di Stato G. Antonelli sulle spese sostenute dal Ministero delle Armi. Abbandonò la politica e morì a Roma il 30 agosto 1864.
$Savelli.nl_NL: Domenico Savelli was een kardinaal, afkomstig van Corsica. Van 1833 tot 1841 was hij apostolisch gedelegeerde in Rieti (1833), Frosinone (1834), Perugia (1838) en Macerata (1841). Pius IX benoemde Savelli tot pro-gouverneur van Rome en directeur-generaal van de politie (15 november 1847); toen deze functie onder het kabinet-Ferretti werd afgeschaft, werd Savelli minister van Politie. Hij bekleedde deze functie van 29 december 1847 tot 9 februari 1948, waarna hij ontslag nam en de paus volgde in zijn vlucht naar Gaeta. Na de val van de Romeinse Republiek in 1849 werkte Savelli vanuit Ancona bij aan het herstel van het pauselijk gezag, in de functie van buitengewoon commissaris. In augustus keerde hij terug naar Rome om minister van Binnenlandse Zaken te worden en directeur-generaal van de politie. Op 7 maart 1853 werd hij vervolgens verheven tot kardinaal, waarna Pius hem benoemde tot voorzitter van de Staatsraad voor Financiën (4 juli 1853). Savelli nam ontslag uit deze functie op 14 december 1859, na een conflict met de paus en de kardinaal staatssecretaris G. Antonelli over de uitgaven van het Ministerie van Wapens. Hij trok zich terug uit het politieke leven en stierf in Rome op 30 augustus 1864.

$SavoiaCE.en_GB: Charles Emmanuel of Savoy, future King Charles Emmanuel IV, was born in Turin in 1751 the eldest son of Victor Amadeus III of Savoy and Maria Antonia Ferdinanda of Bourbon. He was given the title of Prince of Piedmont. His educator was the Barnabite pedagogue Giacinto Gerdil, who favoured the young prince's religious, almost ascetic tendencies. Charles Emanuel married Maria Clotilde of Bourbon in 1775; the couple had no children. Physically and morally weak and unable to impose himself both at court and in political life, he ascended the throne in 1796, under very difficult circumstances. With the collapse of the Austrian power in Lombardy, Charles Emmanuel hoped to save his kingdom and dynasty by joining a French alliance against Austria, but the Treaty of Campoformio (17 October 1797) between France and Austria soon dashed all hopes. After he had been forced by the French to abdicate in December 1798, Charles Emmanuel and the royal family left for Livorno, and then sailed to Cagliari on the island of Sardinia. The political and military ups and downs that followed led to his abdication in 1802 in favour of his brother Victor Emmanuel I. He died in Rome on 6 October 1819.
$SavoiaCE.it_IT: Carlo Emanuele di Savoia, futuro re Carlo Emanuele IV, figlio primogenito di Vittorio Amedeo III di Savoia e di Maria Antonia Ferdinanda di Borbone, nacque in Torino nel 1751. Ebbe il titolo di Principe di Piemonte. Suo educatore fu il pedagogo barnabita Giacinto Gerdil che favorì le tendenze religiose, quasi ascetiche del giovane principe. Sposò nel 1775 Maria Clotilde di Borbone, ma non ne ebbe figli. Debole fisicamente e moralmente e incapace d'imporsi sia nella corte che nella vita politica, salì al trono nel 1796, in momenti difficilissimi. Crollata la potenza austriaca in Lombardia, Carlo Emanuele sperò di salvare regno e dinastia accettando l'idea di un'alleanza francese contro l'Austria; ma il trattato di Campoformio fece presto svanire ogni speranza. Nel dicembre 1798 Carlo Emanuele IV con la famiglia reale partì per Livorno, dopo essere stato costretto dai francesi all'abdicazione e salpò per Cagliari. Le alterne vicende politiche e militari che seguirono lo portarono nel 1802 all'abdicazione a favore del fratello Vittorio Emanuele I. Morì in Roma il 6 ottobre 1819.
$SavoiaCE.nl_NL: Karel Emanuel van Savoia, toekomstig koning Karel Emanuel IV, werd in 1751 in Turijn geboren als oudste zoon van Victor Amadeus III van Savoia en Maria Antonia Ferdinanda van Bourbon. Hij kreeg de titel Prins van Piemonte. Zijn leraar was de barnabieter pedagoog Giacinto Gerdil, die de religieuze, bijna ascetische neigingen van de jonge prins verder aanwakkerde. Karel Emanuel trouwde in 1775 met Maria Clothilde van Bourbon; het echtpaar kreeg geen kinderen. Fysiek en moreel zwak en niet in staat om zich zowel aan het hof als in de politiek te handhaven, besteeg hij de troon in 1796, in zeer moeilijke tijden. Met de ineenstorting van de Oostenrijkse macht in Lombardije hoopte Karel Emanuel zijn koninkrijk en dynastie te redden door akkoord te gaan met een Franse alliantie tegen Oostenrijk, maar het Verdrag van Campoformio (17 oktober 1797) tussen Frankrijk en Oostenrijk maakte al snel een einde aan alle hoop. In december 1798 vertrok Karel Emanuel met de koninklijke familie naar Livorno, nadat hij door de Fransen tot troonsafstand was gedwongen, en zeilde verder naar Cagliari op Sardinië. De politieke en militaire ups en downs die volgden leidden tot zijn troonsafstand in 1802, ten gunste van zijn broer Victor Emanuel I. Hij stierf in Rome op 6 oktober 1819.

$SavoiaCF.en_GB: Charles Felix of Savoy was the eleventh son of Victor Amadeus III and Maria Antonia Ferdinanda of Bourbon; he was born in Turin in 1765. In 1798, he followed his brother Charles Emmanuel IV to Sardinia after the latter's abdication; Charles Felix would rule the island as viceroy from 1799 to 1806. In 1807, he married Maria Christina of Sicily. In 1814, after the restoration, he returned to Piedmont with the king, his other brother Victor Emmanuel I. A year later, he resumed his duties as viceroy of Sardinia, where he remained until 1821. To avoid the suspicion of interfering with the affairs of the kingdom at the expense of the king's weaknesses, he preferred to stay at the small court of Francis IV of Modena, his cousin. After the abdication of Victor Emmanuel I (13 March 1821), Charles Felix had to ascend the throne and face the difficulties that had arisen in Piedmont after liberal uprisings had forced his brother to proclaim a constitutional charter. He quickly put an end to this brief period of reform, partly with the help of Austria. With the death of Victor Emmanuel I in 1824, Charles Felix's kingship was definitively sanctioned. During his reign, he improved public administration, the judicial system, agricultural societies and the chambers of commerce. In foreign policy, he defended Piedmontese independence against both Austria and France. Charles Felix concluded numerous trade agreements with Turkey and Morocco (1825) and opened numerous consulates along the African coast of the Mediterranean and in the ports of the Levant. In his final days, he was shaken by the Paris Revolution of July 1830 and the Italian uprisings of February 1831. He died on 27 April 1831.
$SavoiaCF.it_IT: Carlo Felice di Savoia fu l'undicesimo figlio di Vittorio Amedeo III e di Maria Antonia Ferdinanda di Borbone e nacque a Torino nel 1765. Nel 1798 seguì il fratello Carlo Emanuele IV in Sardegna dopo la sua abdicazione; Carlo Felice assunse come viceré il governo dell'isola dal 1799 al 1806. Nel 1807 sposò Maria Cristina di Sicilia. Nel 1814 tornò con il re in Piemonte, dopo la sua restaurazione e riprese dal 1815 l'incarico di vicerè di Sardegna che conservò sino al 1821. Affinché non si sospettasse ch'egli volesse intromettersi nelle cose del regno approfittando della debolezza di Vittorio Emanuele I, preferì soggiornare presso la piccola corte di Francesco IV di Modena, suo nipote. Si trovava a Modena quando, in seguito all'abdicazione di Vittorio Emanuele I (13 marzo 1821), dovette salire sul trono affrontando anche le difficoltà insorte in Piemonte a causa delle rivolte che avevano portato alla concessione della carta costituzionale. Fu questa una breve esperienza, subito sedata con l'aiuto dell'Austria. Nel 1824 con la morte Vittorio Emanuele I, Carlo Felice si considerò legittimamente re. Durante il suo regno migliorò l'amministrazione civile e giudiziaria; le società agricole e le Camere di commercio. Nella politica estera difese la propria indipendenza sia di fronte all'Austria che alla Francia, stringendo numerosi trattati commerciali con la Turchia e col Marocco (1825) e istituendo consolati lungo le coste mediterranee dell'Africa e negli scali del Levante. I suoi ultimi giorni furono rattristati dalla rivoluzione parigina del luglio 1830 e dai moti italiani del febbraio 1831. Morì il 27 aprile 1831.
$SavoiaCF.nl_NL: Karel Felix van Savoia was de elfde zoon van Victor Amadeus III en Maria Antonia Ferdinanda van Bourbon; hij werd geboren in Turijn in 1765. In 1798 volgde hij zijn broer Karel Emanuel IV na diens troonsafstand naar Sardinië; Karel Felix zou hier als onderkoning het bewind over het eiland voeren van 1799 tot 1806. In 1807 trouwde hij met Maria Christina van Sicilië. Met de koning, zijn andere broer Victor Emanuel I, keerde hij na de restauratie van 1814 terug naar Piemonte; in 1815 hervatte hij zijn taken als onderkoning van Sardinië, waar hij bleef tot 1821. Om de verdenking te vermijden dat hij zich wilde mengen in de aangelegenheden van het koninkrijk ten koste van de zwakheden van de koning, verbleef hij liever aan het kleine hof van Franciscus IV van Modena, zijn neef. Na de troonsafstand van Victor Emmanuel I (13 maart 1821) moest hij de troon bestijgen en de moeilijkheden het hoofd bieden die in Piemonte waren ontstaan nadat liberale opstanden zijn broer hadden gedwongen een constitutioneel charter af te kondigen. Aan die korte periode van hervormingen maakte Karel Felix spoedig een einde, mede met de hulp van Oostenrijk. Met de dood van Victor Emmanuel I in 1824 werd het koningschap van Karel Felix definitief gesanctioneerd. Tijdens zijn bewind verbeterde hij het openbaar bestuur en de rechtspraak, de landbouworganisaties en de Kamers van Koophandel. Op het gebied van de buitenlandse politiek verdedigde hij de Piemontese onafhankelijkheid tegenover zowel Oostenrijk als Frankrijk. Karel Felix sloot talrijke handelsverdragen met Turkije en Marokko (1825) en opende talrijke consulaten langs de Afrikaanse kusten van de Middellandse Zee en in de havens van de Levant. In zijn laatste dagen werd hij opgeschrikt door de Parijse revolutie van juli 1830 en de Italiaanse opstanden van februari 1831. Hij stierf op 27 april 1831.

$SavoiaVE.en_GB: Vittorio Emanuele II di Savoia succeeded his father Carlo Alberto as king of Sardinia-Piedmont from 1849 to 1861, and was king of Italy from 1861 onwards. Immediately after his accession to the throne on 24 March 1849 (a year after the start of the First Italian War of Independence), he negotiated an armistice with the Austrian general Joseph Radetzky (Vignale, 26 March 1849). During his reign, it was chiefly pragmatism and opportunism that inspired him to uphold the constitution (Statuto Albertino) his father had proclaimed. Similar calculations caused him to entrust his government to the liberal politician Camillo Cavour. When war with Austria broke out again in 1859 (Second Italian War of Independence), Vittorio Emanuele personally led his troops into battle. After the armistice of Villafranca (11 June 1859), his territories were expanded with the addition of Lombardy, in 1860 with Tuscany, Emilia-Romagna, and finally with the Marche and Umbria. By 'accommodating' the expedition of the “Mille” (Thousand) patriot Giuseppe Garibaldi in Southern Italy in name of the crown, Vittorio Emanuele smoothed the way to his proclamation as King of Italy, which followed on 17 March 1861. He was not known for his refined tastes, and preferred hunting and military matters to art. He was buried in the Pantheon in Rome in 1878.
$SavoiaVE.it_IT: Vittorio Emanuele II di Savoia succedette al padre Carlo Alberto come re di Sardegna-Piemonte dal 1849 al 1861, finchè dal 1861 divenne re del Regno d'Italia dal 1861. Subito dopo la sua ascesa al trono, il 24 marzo 1849 (un anno dopo l'inizio della Prima Guerra d'Indipendenza italiana), negoziò un armistizio con il generale austriaco Joseph Radetzky (Vignale, 26 marzo 1849). Durante il suo regno, furono soprattutto il pragmatismo e l'opportunismo a ispirarlo, sostenendo la costituzione (Statuto Albertino) proclamata da suo padre. Calcoli simili lo indussero ad affidare il suo governo al politico liberale Camillo Cavour. Quando nel 1859 scoppiò nuovamente la guerra con l'Austria (Seconda Guerra d'Indipendenza Italiana), Vittorio Emanuele guidò personalmente le sue truppe in battaglia. Dopo l'armistizio di Villafranca (11 giugno 1859), i suoi territori si ampliarono con l'aggiunta della Lombardia, nel 1860 con la Toscana, l'Emilia-Romagna, ed infine con le Marche e l'Umbria. Favorendo la spedizione”dei Mille” del patriota Giuseppe Garibaldi nel Sud Italia in nome della Corona, Vittorio Emanuele aprì la strada alla sua proclamazione a Re del Regno d'Italia, che seguì il 17 marzo 1861. Non era noto per i suoi gusti raffinati, e preferì caccia e questioni militari all'arte. Fu sepolto nel Pantheon a Roma alla sua morte nel 1878.
$SavoiaVE.nl_NL: Victor Emanuel II van Savoia volgde zijn vader Karel Albert van 1849 tot 1861 op als koning van Sardinië-Piemonte en was vanaf 1861 de eerste koning van Italië. Direct na zijn troonsbestijging (24 maart 1849, een jaar na het begin van de Eerste Italiaanse Onafhankelijkheidsoorlog) onderhandelde hij met de Oostenrijkse generaal Josef Radetzky over een wapenstilstand (Vignale, 26 maart 1849). Meer uit pragmatisme en opportunisme dan uit overtuiging behield hij vervolgens de grondwet (Statuto Albertino) die zijn vader in het leven had geroepen. Uit soortgelijke overwegingen vertrouwde hij in 1852 zijn regering toe aan liberaal staatsman Camillo Cavour. Toen in 1859 de oorlog met Oostenrijk wederom uitbrak (Tweede Italiaanse Onafhankelijkheidsoorlog), voerde hij persoonlijk zijn troepen aan. Na de wapenstilstand van Villafranca (11 juni 1859) zag hij zijn koninkrijk uitgebreid met Lombardije, in 1860 gevolgd door Toscane, Emilia-Romagna en ten slotte de Marken en Umbrië. Door de expeditie van patriot Giuseppe Garibaldi in Zuid-Italië onder de kroon te 'accommoderen' kon Victor Emanuel op 17 maart 1861 worden uitgeroepen tot koning van Italië. Hij stond niet bepaald bekend om zijn verfijnde smaak en manieren; in plaats van met kunst hield hij zich liever bezig met de jacht en militaire aangelegenheden. Hij werd begraven in het Pantheon in Rome.

$SchimmelpenninckOye.en_GB: Baron Willem Anne Schimmelpenninck van der Oye was a Dutch politician. During the Ten Day's Campaign against the Kingdom of Belgium (August 1831)  he served as captain of the civic guard the king had been force to conscript. After he had been elected to the Dutch House of Representatives on 7 July 1831, he soon came to the fore as a moderate liberal. His ministry of Internal Affairs (starting 1 June 1841) came to an end with his resignation on 15 February 1846, partly motivated by his disapproval of the increasingly conservative course cabinet and king were taking. As governor of Gelderland (1847-1853) he was well respected; therefore his (honourable) discharge in January of 1853 came as a surprise. It had been provoked – against the will of king Willem III – by the liberal prime minister Thorbecke, who considered Schimmelpenninck too conservative for the post. In the following years, Schimmelpenninck lived up to that stigma. He held several functions at the Dutch court and was president of the House of Representatives for some months in 1858. On 8 March 1860, he was elected to the Senate for the constituency of Gelderland, and kept that post until his death in 1872.
$SchimmelpenninckOye.it_IT: Il barone Willem Anne Schimmelpenninck van der Oye fu un politico olandese. Durante la campagna dei dieci giorni contro il Regno del Belgio (agosto 1831) prestò servizio come capitano della guardia civica che il re era stato costretto ad arruolare. Dopo essere stato eletto alla Camera dei rappresentanti olandese il 7 luglio 1831, si dimostrò presto un liberale moderato. Il suo ministero degli Affari interni (a partire dal 1 giugno 1841) terminò con le sue dimissioni il 15 febbraio 1846, in parte motivate dalla sua disapprovazione per il corso sempre più conservatore che il gabinetto e il re stavano seguendo. Come governatore della Gheldria (1847-1853) era molto rispettato; il suo congedo nel gennaio del 1853 fu una sorpresa. Era stato provocato – contro la volontà del re Guglielmo III – dal primo ministro liberale Thorbecke, che considerava Schimmelpenninck troppo conservatore per la carica. Negli anni successivi, Schimmelpenninck fu all'altezza di quello stigma. Ricoprì diverse funzioni presso la corte olandese e fu presidente della Camera dei rappresentanti per alcuni mesi nel 1858. L'8 marzo 1860 fu eletto al Senato per la circoscrizione elettorale di Gelderland e mantenne tale carica fino alla sua morte nel 1872.
$SchimmelpenninckOye.nl_NL: Baron Willem Anne Schimmelpenninck van der Oye was een Nederlands politicus. Tijdens de Tiendaagse Veldtocht tegen België (augustus 1831) diende hij als kapitein der schutterij, die de koning noodgedwongen had opgeroepen. Nadat hij op 7 juli 1831 in de Tweede Kamer was gekozen, trad hij al snel op de voorgrond als gematigd liberaal. Aan zijn ministerschap op Binnenlandse Zaken (benoeming 1 juni 1841) kwam een einde op 15 februari 1846, toen hij ontslag nam mede uit protest tegen de allengs conservatiever wordende kabinet en koning. Als gouverneur van Gelderland (1847-1853) was hij geliefd; zijn ontslag begin januari 1853 kwam dan ook als een verassing. Het was bewerkstelligd, tegen de zin van koning Willem III, door eerste minister Thorbecke, die Schimmelpenninck te conservatief vond. Dat stempel maakte Schimmelpenninck in de jaren daarna waar. Hij bekleedde nog enkele functies aan het hof en was in 1858 enkele maanden voorzitter van de Tweede Kamer. Op 8 maart 1860 werd hij door de Staten van Gelderland gekozen tot lid van de Eerste Kamer, wat hij bleef tot zijn overlijden in 1872.

$Sella.en_GB: Quintino Sella, one of the twenty children of Maurizio and Rosa Sella, was born at Sella di Mosso in 1827. He studied hydraulic engineering and graduated from the University of Turin in his early twenties. At the request of the Sardinian government, he was sent to the Ėcole des Mines in Paris; after completing these studies in 1851, he made several study trips to France, Germany and England. Upon his return to Turin in 1852, he was appointed professor of applied geometry and mineralogy, and temporary regent of the mining district of Savoy. In 1853, he was appointed substitute professor of mathematics at the University of Turin. Cavour's invitated hi mto run for parliament, where he was elected in the Chamber of Deputies for the Historic Right party in 1860. The following year he took office as Secretary General at the Ministry of Public Education; in 1862 he became Minister of Finance in the Rattazzi cabinet. As Minister, his aim was to balance the state budget by implementing budget cuts and unpopular taks raises, such as the milling levy (1865). He also dealt with the railways and political and economic relations with the Austro-Hungarian Empire. From December 1869 to July 1873 he was Minister of Finance in the Lanza-Sella cabinet; in that capacity in 1870 he opposed King Victor Emmanuel II's desire to assist France in the Franco-Prussian conflict. After the defeat of Napoleon III, Sella was among the most ardent supporters of the capture of Rome and, later, of the Law of Papal Guarantees. From 1876, when the Historic Right had been defeated in the general elections, Sella became the leader of the opposition until 1878. In the meantime, he had been appointment as president of the Accademia dei Lincei (1874) and called the most renowned scientists of the period to join it. Passionate about mountaineering he founded the Club Alpino Italiano (CAI) in 1863 and the Italian Geological Society in 1881. He died in Biella on 14 March 1884 and was buried at the monumental cemetery of Oropa.
$Sella.it_IT: Quintino Sella, uno dei venti figli di Maurizio e di Rosa Sella, nacque alla Sella di Mosso nel 1827. Indirizzato dal padre agli studi di ingegneria idraulica, si laureò appena ventenne presso l'Università di Torino. Su richiesta del governo sardo venne inviato a frequentare l Ėcole des Mines di Parigi e dopo aver conclusi questi studi nel 1851 e effettuò vari viaggi di studio in Francia, Germania e Inghilterra. Al suo rientro a Torino nel 1852 venne nominato professore di geometria applicata e mineralogia e reggente temporaneo del distretto minerario della Savoia. Nel 1853 venne nominato professore sostituto di matematica presso l'Università di Torino. Su invito di Cavour, nel 1860 venne eletto deputato alla Camera per il partito della Destra Storica. L'anno successivo assunse l'incarico di segretario generale del Ministero della Istruzione Pubblica e nel 1862 divenne Ministero delle Finanze nel Gabinetto Rattazzi. Il suo obiettivo fu arrivare al pareggio del bilancio statale attuando una politica di restrizioni economiche e di impopolari inasprimenti fiscali come l'imposta sul macinato (1865). Si occupò anche della questione ferroviaria e dei rapporti politici ed economici con l'Impero Austro-Ungarico. Dal dicembre 1869 al luglio 1873 fu ministro delle Finanze nel gabinetto Lanza-Sella e nel 1870 si oppose alla volontà del re Vittorio Emanuele II di intervenire a fianco della Francia contro la Germania nel conflitto franco-prussiano. Dopo la sconfitta di Napoleone III, fu tra i più accesi sostenitori della presa di Roma e, successivamente, della legge delle Guarentigie. Dal 1876, con la sconfitta del partito della Destra Storica alle elezioni politiche, Sella divenne il capo del partito di opposizione fino al 1878. In questi anni, a seguito della sua nomina a presidente dell'Accademia dei Lincei nel 1874 chiamò a farne parte i più conosciuti scienziati del periodo. Appassionato di alpinismo compì varie ascensioni e fondò nel 1863, a Torino, il Club Alpino Italiano e nel 1881 la Società Geologica Italiana. Morì a Biella il 14 marzo 1884 e il suo corpo venne sepolto al cimitero monumentale di Oropa.
$Sella.nl_NL: Quintino Sella, een van de twintig kinderen van Maurizio en Rosa Sella, werd in 1827 geboren in Sella di Mosso. Hij ging waterbouwkunde studeren aan de universiteit van Turijn en studeerde af toen hij begin twintig was. Op verzoek van de regering van het Koninkrijk Sardinië werd hij naar de Ėcole des Mines in Parijs gestuurd. Na het afronden van deze studie (1851) maakte hij verschillende studiereizen naar Frankrijk, Duitsland en Engeland. Toen hij terugkeerde naar Turijn in 1852 werd hij benoemd tot professor in de toegepaste meetkunde en mineralogie, en tijdelijk regent van het mijndistrict in de Savoie. In 1853 werd hij benoemd tot plaatsvervangend hoogleraar wiskunde aan de universiteit van Turijn. Op uitnodiging van Cavour werd hij in 1860 gekozen in de Kamer van Afgevaardigden voor de partij Historisch Rechts (Destra storica). Het jaar daarop werd hij secretaris-generaal van het ministerie van Onderwijs; in 1862 werd hij minister van Financiën in het kabinet Rattazzi. Daarbij werd zijn doel om de staatsbegroting in evenwicht te brengen door een beleid van besparingen en impopulaire belastingverhogingen, zoals die op het gemaal (1865). Hij hield zich ook bezig met de spoorwegkwestie en de politieke en economische relaties met het Oostenrijks-Hongaarse Rijk. Van december 1869 tot juli 1873 was hij opnieuw minister van Financiën, nu in het kabinet Lanza-Sella. In die hoedanigheid verzette hij zich in 1870 tegen de wens van Koning Victor Emanuel II om Frankrijk te hulp te komen in het Frans-Pruisische conflict. Na de nederlaag van Napoleon III behoorde Sella tot de meest fervente pleitbezorgers van de inname van Rome en later van de zogenaamde (Pauselijke) Garantiewet. Vanaf 1876, na de nederlaag van Historisch Rechts bij de parlementsverkiezingen, werd Sella de leider van de oppositie, tot 1878. Intussen was hij in 1874 voorzitter geworden van de Accademia dei Lincei, en in die rol riep hij de meest gerenommeerde wetenschappers van die tijd op om lid te worden. Als gepassioneerd bergbeklimmer richtte hij in 1863 in Turijn de Club Alpino Italiano (CAI); in 1881 stichtte hij de Italiaanse Geologische Vereniging. Sella stierf in Biella op 14 maart 1884; hij werd begraven op de monumentale begraafplaats van Oropa.

$Sismonda.en_GB: Eugenio Sismonda was an Italian geologist, lithologist, botanist and palaeontologist, brother of Angelo Sismonda, scholar of mineralogy and chemistry. Born in Corneliano on 29 April 1815, he studied philosophy and medicine, graduating on 24 April 1839. He was a member of the Turin Academy of Sciences from 3 December 1843, of which he became perpetual secretary of the physical and mathematical sciences class in 1859. He devoted himself above all to palaeontology, publishing numerous works on fossils, particularly those of the Tertiary period in the Piedmont region. At the University of Turin, he was assistant at the Museum of Mineralogy and then professor of mineralogy (1848). In the same year, however, he accepted a position as professor of natural history at the Regio Liceo del Carmine in Turin. During the 1861-62 school year, King Victor Emmanuel II appointed him private teacher of natural history of the princes Umberto and Amedeo. Sismonda was a member of various Italian and foreign academies and societies, and received numerous honours. Together with his brother, he played a key role in the preparation of the Frejus tunnel, which was started in 1857 and realised thanks to Cavour's support, and inaugurated on 17 September 1871.
$Sismonda.it_IT: Eugenio Sismonda fu un geologo, litologo, botanista e paleontologo italiano, fratello di Angelo Sismonda studioso di mineralogia e chimica. Nacque a Corneliano il 29 aprile 1815, studiò filosofia e medicina laureandosi il 24 aprile 1839. Fu socio dell'Accademia delle Scienze di Torino dal 3 dicembre 1843, di cui divenne segretario perpetuo della classe di scienze fisiche e matematiche nel 1859. Si dedicò sopratutto alla paleontologia pubblicando numerose opere sui fossili, in particolare quelli del Terziario nel territorio del Piemonte. All'università di Torino fu assistente presso il Museo di Mineralogia e poi professore di mineralogia (1848). Nello stesso anno, accettò però l'incarico di professore di storia naturale al Regio Liceo del Carmine di Torino. Nel corso dell'anno scolastico 1861-62 il re Vittorio Emanuele II lo nominò professore di storia naturale dei principi Umberto e Amedeo. Fu membro di diverse accademie e società sia italiane che estere, e ottenne numerosi riconoscimenti. Assieme al fratello ebbe un ruolo fondamentale nella preparazione del traforo del Frejus, iniziato nel 1857 e realizzato grazie anche al sostegno di Cavour, e inaugurato il 17 settembre del 1871.
$Sismonda.nl_NL: Eugenio Sismonda was een Italiaanse geoloog, litholoog, botanicus en paleontoloog, broer van Angelo Sismonda, en geleerde op het gebied van mineralogie en scheikunde. Hij werd op 29 april 1815 geboren in Corneliano en studeerde filosofie en geneeskunde. Hij studeerde af op 24 april 1839. Vanaf 3 december 1843 was hij lid van de Academie van Wetenschappen van Turijn, waar hij in 1859 permanent secretaris werd van de afdeling natuur- en wiskunde. Hij legde zich vooral toe op de paleontologie en publiceerde talrijke werken over fossielen, met name die uit de regio Piemonte tijdens het Tertiair. Aan de Universiteit van Turijn was hij assistent bij het Museum voor Mineralogie en vervolgens hoogleraar mineralogie (1848). In datzelfde jaar aanvaardde hij echter een aanstelling als hoogleraar natuurkunde aan het Regio Liceo del Carmine in Turijn. Tijdens het schooljaar 1861-1862 benoemde koning Victor Emmanuel II hem tot privéleraar natuurkunde van de prinsen Umberto en Amedeo. Sismonda was lid van verschillende Italiaanse en buitenlandse academies en verenigingen en ontving talrijke onderscheidingen. Samen met zijn broer speelde hij een sleutelrol bij de voorbereiding van de Frejus-tunnel, die in 1857 van start ging en dankzij de steun van Camillo Cavour werd gerealiseerd en op 17 september 1871 werd ingehuldigd.

$Soelen.en_GB: Johan Gijsbert Verstolk van Soelen was a Dutch diplomat and politician from Rotterdam. He spent the years 1795-1802 travelling through northern Europe and studied Law (in Göttingen and Kiel). On 13 December 1810 he was named prefect of the French department Frise, until Russian and Prussian troops invaded Friesland on 18 November 1813. After his refusal to obey the order of the Russian colonel Von Rosen to reassume his post, Verstolk spent several days in prison in Groningen. For some time in 1814-1815, he was commissioner-general of the southern regions of the Netherlands that had been recaptured from Napoleonic rule, before he was sent to Saint Petersburg, where he served as the Dutch envoy from October 1815 to 1823. By royal decree of 1 December 1825, he then became minister of Foreign Affairs, a post he held until 13 September 1841, when he resigned after a dispute with king Willem II, who refused to ratify the treaty on the accession of Luxembourg to the German Zollverein. Verstolk was known as a hardened conservative and a prominent supporter of king William I.
$Soelen.it_IT: Johan Gijsbert Verstolk van Soelen fu un diplomatico e politico olandese di Rotterdam. Trascorse gli anni 1795-1802 viaggiando attraverso il nord Europa e studiò giurisprudenza (a Gottinga e Kiel). Il 13 dicembre 1810 fu nominato prefetto del dipartimento francese della Frisia, finché le truppe russe e prussiane non invasero la Frisia il 18 novembre 1813. Dopo il suo rifiuto di obbedire all'ordine del colonnello russo Von Rosen di riprendere il suo incarico, Verstolk trascorse diversi giorni in prigione a Groninga. Per un certo periodo, nel 1814-1815, fu commissario generale delle regioni meridionali dei Paesi Bassi riconquistate dal dominio napoleonico, prima di essere inviato a San Pietroburgo, dove prestò servizio come inviato olandese dall'ottobre 1815 al 1823. Con un decreto reale del 1° dicembre 1825, divenne  ministro degli Affari esteri, incarico che mantenne fino al 13 settembre 1841, quando si dimise dopo una disputa con il re Guglielmo II, che rifiutò di ratificare il trattato di adesione del Lussemburgo allo Zollverein tedesc . Verstolk era conosciuto come un conservatore incallito e un importante sostenitore del re Guglielmo I.
$Soelen.nl_NL: Johan Gijsbert Verstolk van Soelen was een Nederlands diplomaat en politicus uit Rotterdam. In de jaren 1795-1802 reisde hij door Noord-Europa en studeerde Rechten in Göttingen en Kiel. Op 13 december 1810 werd hij prefect van het Franse departement Frise, tot op 18 november 1813 Russische en Pruisische troepen Friesland binnenvielen. Nadat hij het verzoek van de Russische kolonel Von Rosen om zijn ambt weer te hervatten had geweigerd, zat Verstolk enkele dagen gevangen in Groningen. In 1814-1815 was hij enige tijd commissaris-generaal van de op Napoleon veroverde Zuid-Nederlandse gewesten, alvorens hij als gezant naar Sint-Petersburg te worden uitgezonden. In die functie diende hij van oktober 1815 tot 1823. Bij Koninklijk Besluit van 1 december 1825 werd hij vervolgens minister van Buitenlandse Zaken, een functie die hij behield tot 13 september 1841, toen hij aftrad vanwege een conflict met koning Willem II, die weigerde het traktaat over de toetreding van Luxemburg tot de Zollverein te ratificeren. Verstolk gold als een verstokte conservatief en een belangrijke supporter van koning Willem I.

$Soglia.en_GB: Giovanni Soglia Ceroni was cardinal and Secretary of State under pope Pius IX, from 2 June to 29 November 1848. Between 1809 and 1810, after obtaining his law degree from the 'Sapienza' university in Rome, he accompanied pope Pius VII during his exile in Savona. As a consequence, he was imprisoned by the French for some months in 1810 in the fortress of Fenestrelle. By the end of 1814 he returned to Rome, where he became professor of canon law at the Sapienza, and held several offices in the administration of the Church. In 1826, pope Leo XIII appointed him as archbishop of Efese; in 1835 Gregory XVI assigned him to the post of Latin patriarch of Alexandria. Four years later he was elevated to the cardinalate, while also obtaining the dioceses of Osimo and Cingoli. His mandate as Secretary of State abruptly ended in November 1848; after the pope's secret flight from Rome, about which Soglia Ceroni had not been informed, he asked for his resignation. Thereby his public career came to an end.
$Soglia.it_IT: Giovanni Soglia Ceroni fu cardinale e segretario di Stato sotto papa Pio IX, dal 2 giugno al 29 novembre 1848. Tra il 1809 e il 1810, dopo aver conseguito la laurea in giurisprudenza presso l'Università 'Sapienza' di Roma, accompagnò papa Pio VII durante il suo esilio a Savona. Per questo motivo venne imprigionato dai francesi per alcuni mesi nel 1810 nella fortezza di Fenestrelle. Alla fine del 1814 ritornò a Roma, dove divenne professore di diritto canonico alla Sapienza, e ricoprì diversi incarichi nell'amministrazione della Chiesa. Nel 1826 papa Leone XIII lo nominò arcivescovo di Efeso; nel 1835 Gregorio XVI gli assegnò l'incarico di patriarca latino di Alessandria. Quattro anni dopo fu elevato al cardinalato, ottenendo anche le diocesi di Osimo e Cingoli. Il suo mandato di Segretario di Stato terminò bruscamente nel novembre 1848; dopo la fuga segreta del papa da Roma, della quale Soglia Ceroni non era stato informato; Pio IX  ne chiese le dimissioni. Così terminò la sua carriera pubblica.
$Soglia.nl_NL: Giovanni Soglia Ceroni was kardinaal-staatssecretaris onder paus Pius IX, van 2 juni tot 29 november 1848. Tussen 1809 en 1810, na het afronden van zijn rechtenstudie aan de Universiteit 'La Sapienza' te Rome, begeleidde hij paus Pius VII tijdens diens ballingschap in Savona. In 1810 werd Soglia Ceroni vervolgens enkele maanden door de Fransen gevangengezet in de vesting Fenestrelle. Hij keerde eind 1814 terug naar Rome, waar hij hoogleraar Canoniek Recht werd aan de Sapienza, en verschillende functies in het kerkelijk bestuur bekleedde. Paus Leo XII maakte hem in 1826 aartsbisschop van Efese; in 1835 volgde een benoeming door Gregorius XVI tot Latijns patriarch van Alexandrië. Vier jaar later werd hij kardinaal en kreeg hij ook de bisdommen van Osimo en Cingoli. Zijn Staatsscretariaat kwam in november 1848 tot een abrupt einde. Na de vlucht van Pius uit Rome, waarover Soglia Ceroni niet was ingelicht, vroeg hij om ontslag. Daarmee kwam een einde aan zijn publieke functies.

$Sonsbeeck.en_GB: Herman van Sonsbeeck was a Dutch lawyer and minister of Foreign Affairs and Affairs of Roman-Catholic Worship in the cabinet Thorbecke (1 November 1849 to 16 October 1852). He first worked as a lawyer in his birthplace Zwolle, until he was appointed to the Dutch Council of State and moved to The Hague (21 April 1842). During his ministries between 1849 and 1852, he faced the temporary disbandment of the Deutsche Bund (following the liberal revolutions of March 1848) and the following discussions in the Netherlands about the position of the region Limburg, which was also a member of the Bund. Furthermore, Van Sonsbeeck had to deal with the initiatives taken by pope Pius IX towards the restauration of the episcopal hierarchy in the Netherlands. As a minister he was unhappy, partly because of his lack of diplomatic experience, partly because of the fierce opposition from parliament. For these reasons, he resigned in 1852 and retreated from politics.
$Sonsbeeck.it_IT: Herman van Sonsbeeck fu un avvocato olandese e ministro degli affari esteri e degli affari del culto cattolico romano nel gabinetto Thorbecke (dal 1 novembre 1849 al 16 ottobre 1852). Inizialmente lavorò come avvocato nella sua città natale, Zwolle, finché non fu nominato membro del Consiglio di Stato olandese e si trasferì all'Aia (21 aprile 1842). Durante i suoi ministeri tra il 1849 e il 1852 dovette affrontare il temporaneo scioglimento del Deutsche Bund (in seguito alle rivoluzioni liberali del marzo 1848) e le successive discussioni nei Paesi Bassi sulla posizione della regione del Limburgo, che era anche membro del Bund. Van Sonsbeeck dovette fare i conti con le iniziative prese da papa Pio IX che desiderava ripristinare la gerarchia episcopale nei Paesi Bassi. Come ministro fu poco felice, in parte a causa della sua mancanza di esperienza diplomatica, in parte a causa della feroce opposizione del parlamento. Per questi motivi si dimise nel 1852 e si ritirò dalla politica.
$Sonsbeeck.nl_NL: Herman van Sonsbeeck was een Nederlands advocaat en minister van Buitenlandse Zaken en Rooms-Katholieke Eredienst in het kabinet Thorbecke (1 november 1849-16 oktober 1852). Als jonge advocaat vestigde hij zich in zijn geboortestad Zwolle, tot hij op 21 april 1842 lid van de Raad van State werd en naar Den Haag verhuisde. Tijdens zijn ministerschappen tussen 1849 tot 1852 kreeg hij te maken met de tijdelijke opheffing van de Duitse Bond (in navolging van de Maartrevoluties van 1848) en de discussies die dit in Nederland teweegbracht over de positie van Limburg, dat ook lid was van de Duitse Bond. Ook kwam Van Sonsbeeck in aanraking met het pauselijke initiatief om de bisschoppelijke hiërarchie in Nederland te herstellen (de invoering zou pas in 1853 volgen). Als minister was hij niet gelukkig, mede door een gebrek aan diplomatieke ervaring en de zware tegenwerking vanuit de Tweede Kamer. Hij diende daarom in 1852 zijn ontslag in en trok zich terug uit de politiek.

$Spakler.en_GB: Johannes Christoffel van der Masch Spakler (jr.) was the son of Susanna Harmina Scholten and Hendrik van der Masch Spakler, who, with J. Tetterode and three other associates, started a new sugar refinery in Amsterdam, located behind the Stadsschouwburg on the Lijnbaansgracht in 1854, on the site where a sugar refinery had already been established since the 18th century. His younger brother Willem (1839-1932) would later run the company for 50 years and became known as a philanthropist. J.C. Spakler must have made a trip to Italy in 1855-1856, because in 1855 he had evaded conscription for military service by travelling to Trieste, and then to Rome and Naples - to which, as his letter to envoy Du Chastel attests, he had his mail forwarded.
$Spakler.it_IT: Johannes Christoffel van der Masch Spakler (jr.) era il figlio di Susanna Harmina Scholten e Hendrik van der Masch Spakler, che, con J. Tetterode e altri tre soci, avviarono una nuova raffineria di zucchero ad Amsterdam, situata dietro lo Stadsschouwburg sul Lijnbaansgracht nel 1854, sul sito dove già dal XVIII secolo era stata fondata una raffineria di zucchero. Suo fratello minore Willem (1839-1932) avrebbe poi diretto l'azienda per 50 anni e divenne noto come filantropo. J.C. Spakler deve aver fatto un viaggio in Italia nel 1855-1856, perché nel 1855 era riuscito a sfuggire alla leva militare recandosi a Trieste, poi a Roma e Napoli - alla quale, come attesta la sua lettera all'inviato Du Chastel, aveva fatto inoltrare la posta.
$Spakler.nl_NL: Johannes Christoffel van der Masch Spakler (jr.) was de zoon van Susanna Harmina Scholten en Hendrik van der Masch Spakler, die in 1854 met J. Tetterode en drie andere vennoten een nieuwe suikerraffinaderij achter de Stadsschouwburg aan de Lijnbaansgracht begon, op de plek waar sinds de 18e eeuw reeds een suikerfabriek gevestigd was. Zijn jongere broer Willem (1839-1932) zou later het bedrijf gedurende 50 jaar leiden en bekendheid krijgen als filantroop. J.C. Spakler moet in 1855-1856 een reis naar Italië gemaakt hebben, want in 1855 had hij zich aan de oproep voor militaire dienst onttrokken door naar Triëst te reizen, en daarna naar Rome en Napels – waarheen hij, getuige zijn brief aan gezant Du Chastel, zijn post liet doorsturen.

$SpaurK.en_GB: Karl von Spaur was chargé d'affaires (1832-1838) and plenipotentiary ambassador for the Kingdom of Bavaria in Rome (1838-1854). From 1850 and 1851 onwards he was also the Bavarian ambassador at the courts of the kings of Piedmont-Sardinia and of the Two Sicilies. He was a confidante of Gregory XVI and afterwards of Pius IX, who became famous because he helped the latter flee Rome in disguise on 24 November 1848. Spaur died in 1854 in Florence, while returning to Bavaria.
$SpaurK.it_IT: Karl von Spaur fu agente d'affari (1832-1838) e ambasciatore plenipotenziario del Regno di Baviera a Roma (1838-1854). Dal 1850 al 1851 fu anche ambasciatore bavarese presso le corti del re di Sardegna e del re delle Due Sicilie. Fu fiduciario di Gregorio XVI e poi di Pio IX, divenuto famoso per aver aiutato quest'ultimo a fuggire sotto mentite spoglie da Roma il 24 novembre 1848. Spaur morì nel 1854 a Firenze, mentre tornava in Baviera.
$SpaurK.nl_NL: Karl von Spaur was chargé d'affaires (1832-1838) en gevolmachtigd gezant namens het Koninkrijk Beieren in Rome (1838-1854). Vanaf resp. 1850 en 1851 was hij daarnaast ambassadeur namens Beieren aan de hoven van de koningen van Piemonte-Sardinië Koninkrijk der Beide Siciliën. In 1854 stierf hij in Florence, tijdens een terugreis naar Beieren. Spaur was een vertrouweling van Gregorius XVI en daarna van Pius IX en werd beroemd omdat hij op 24 november de vermomde paus uit Rome hielp vluchten.

$Spinelli.en_GB: Gennaro Spinelli was born in Naples in 1780. He embarked on a military career and as a naval officer, he fought for the Parthenopean Republic in Naples in 1799. An officer under the King of Naples Joachim Murat, he took part in the Russian campaign, distinguishing himself at the Moskva (1812). In 1820 he was sent on a diplomatic mission to Paris and Vienna by the shortlived Neapolitan constitutional government, which had been established after Ferdinand I had granted a constitution. In 1848 he became Minister of Foreign Affairs and later that year Prime Minister as well, in which capacity he suppressed the revolt in Calabria. During his reign, he rejected an alliance with Piedmont, but refused to go along with a hardening of reactionary politics. Therefore, he resigned in 1849. He died in Naples in 1851.
$Spinelli.it_IT: Gennaro Spinelli nacque a Napoli nel 1780. Intraprese la carriera militare e come ufficiale di marina, nel 1799 si batté per la Repubblica napoletana. Ufficiale di ordinanza di Gioacchino Murat, partecipò alla campagna di Russia distinguendosi alla Moscova (1812). Nel 1820 fu inviato in missione diplomatica a Parigi e Vienna dal governo costituzionale napoletano. Nel 1848 divenne Ministro degli Esteri e nello stesso anno divenne Presidente del Consiglio reprimendo la rivolta in Calabria. Durante la sua carica respinse l'alleanza col Piemonte ma, contrario all'ulteriore inasprimento della reazione, si dimise nel 1849. Morì a Napoli nel 1851.
$Spinelli.nl_NL: Gennaro Spinelli werd in 1780 in Napels geboren. Hij begon een militaire carrière en vocht als marineofficier in 1799 voor de Parthenopeïsche Republiek in Napels. Als officier onder de koning van Napels Joachim Murat nam hij deel aan de Russische campagne, waarin hij zich onderscheidde bij de Moskva (1812). In 1820 werd hij door de kortstondige Napolitaanse constitutionele regering, aangetreden nadat Ferdinand I een grondwet had toegestaan, op diplomatieke missie naar Parijs en Wenen gestuurd. In 1848 werd hij minister van Buitenlandse Zaken en in hetzelfde jaar eveneens premier, in welke hoedanigheid hij de opstand in Calabrië de kop in drukte. Tijdens zijn heerschappij verwierp hij weliswaar een alliantie met Piemonte, maar hij weigerde mee te gaan in een verharding van de reactionaire politiek. Om die reden nam hij in 1849 ontslag. Hij stierf in Napels in 1851.

$SterbiniP.en_GB: Pietro Sterbini was an Italian politician and writer. After his studies, he worked as a doctor in Rome and started writing patriotic prose and poetry. As a member of the secret society the Carboneria, he moved general Giuseppe Sercognani into marching from the rebellious Legations on Rome in 1831, although they were stopped at Rieti. After his flight in July 1846, Sterbini was pardoned by Pius IX. He continued his activities as a radical-democratic journalist in Rome, and became one of the leaders of the Roman political club the Circolo Popolare Romano. After the murder of minister Pellegrino Rossi (15 December 1848), which some people suspected him to have committed, Sterbini became one of the lay ministers in the cabinets Muzzarelli I-III (Minister of Trade and Public Works). He had limited influence during the Roman Republic of 1849, in part because he wanted to make Garibaldi a dictator, at the expense of Mazzini. After the fall of the Republic, Sterbini went into exile in Paris, where he wrote Tredici giornate della rivoluzione romana (1862).
$SterbiniP.it_IT: Pietro Sterbini fu un politico e scrittore italiano. Dopo gli studi, lavorò come medico a Roma iniziando a scrivere componimenti patriottici. Come membro della società segreta della Carboneria, convinse il generale Giuseppe Sercognani a marciare dalle Legazioni ribelli su Roma nel 1831, finchè non venne fermato a Rieti. Dopo la sua fuga da Roma nel luglio 1846, Sterbini venne graziato da Pio IX. Continuò la sua attività di giornalista democratico radicale a Roma, e divenne uno dei protagonisti del circolo politico romano, il Circolo Popolare Romano. Dopo l'assassinio del ministro Pellegrino Rossi (15 dicembre 1848), di cui alcuni lo sospettavano, Sterbini divenne uno dei ministri laici nei gabinetti Muzzarelli I-III (Ministro del Commercio e dei Lavori Pubblici). Ebbe un ruolo minore durante la Repubblica Romana del 1849, anche perché voleva fare di Garibaldi un dittatore, a scapito di Mazzini. Dopo la caduta della Repubblica, Sterbini andò in esilio a Parigi, dove scrisse “Tredici giornate della rivoluzione romana” (1862).
$SterbiniP.nl_NL: Pietro Sterbini was een Italiaans politicus en schrijver. Na zijn studie vestigde hij zich als arts in Rome en begon daarnaast patriottische proza en poëzie te schrijven. Als lid van het geheime genootschap de Carboneria wist hij in 1831 generaal Giuseppe Sercognani vanuit de opstandige Legaties tot een mars op Rome te bewegen – al werd die bij Rieti tot staan gebracht. Na zijn vlucht kreeg hij in juli 1846 van Pius IX amnestie. Zijn activiteiten als radicaal-democratisch journalist zette hij in Rome voort; tegelijkertijd werd hij een van de leiders van de Romeinse politieke club de Circolo Popolare Romano. Na de moord op minister Pellegrino Rossi (15 december 1848), waarvan sommigen hem verdachten, werd Sterbini een van de lekenministers (Handel en Openbare Werken) in de regeringen Muzzarelli I-III. Tijdens de Romeinse Republiek van 1849 was zijn invloed beperkt, onder meer omdat hij Garibaldi dictator wilde maken, ten koste van Mazzini. Na de val van de republiek ging hij in ballingschap naar Parijs, waar hij onder meer Tredici giornate della rivoluzione romana (1862) schreef.

$Stover.en_GB: Johan Hendrik Stöver was a Dutch sculptor and student of the sculptor Louis Royer. In 1851 he went to Rome, along with the painters Laurens Lodewijk Kleijn and Karel Frans Philippeau. He formed part of the artists' society surrounding princess Marianne of Orange-Nassau, whom Stöver would continue to work for later. Stöver first lived at the Via de' Pontefici 55. After that, he worked at the Via Margutta 33 until 1872, and lived at the Via del Corso 504 and the Passeggiata di Ripetta 35 respectively. Stöver would remain in Rome until 1876, after which he settled in The Hague. In Rome, Stöver made the sculpture Angel with a dead child (1856) for the mortuary of the Diakonessenziekenhuis Hospital in Utrecht (currently it is in Centraal Museum Utrecht), as well as Mother with child (1859), bought by king Frederik III of Prussia for his wife Victoria, on the occasion of the birth of their son, later emperor Wilhelm II.
$Stover.it_IT: Johan Hendrik Stöver fu uno scultore olandese allievo dello scultore Louis Royer. Nel 1851 si recò a Roma, insieme ai pittori Laurens Lodewijk Kleijn e Karel Frans Philippeau. Fece parte della società degli artisti che circondava la principessa Marianna di Orange-Nassau, per la quale Stöver avrebbe continuato a lavorare in seguito.
