Stöver visse prima in Via de' Pontefici 55. Successivamente lavorò in Via Margutta 33 fino al 1872, e abitò rispettivamente in Via del Corso 504 e nella Passeggiata di Ripetta 35. Stöver rimase a Roma fino al 1876, dopodiché si stabilì all'Aia. A Roma Stöver realizzò la scultura “Angelo con bambino morto” (1856) per la camera mortuaria dell'ospedale Diakonessenziekenhuis di Utrecht (attualmente si trova al Centraal Museum Utrecht), e  “Madre con bambino” (1859), acquistata dal re Federico III di Prussia per la moglie Vittoria, in occasione della nascita del figlio, futuro imperatore Guglielmo II.
$Stover.nl_NL: Johan Hendrik Stöver was een Nederlandse beeldhouwer en leerling van de beeldhouwer Louis Royer. In 1851 trok hij in gezelschap van de schilders Laurens Lodewijk Kleijn en Karel Frans Philippeau naar Rome. Daar behoorde Stöver tot de kunstenaarskring rond prinses Marianne van Oranje-Nassau, voor wie hij ook later werkzaam zou blijven. Stöver nam eerst zijn intrek in de Via de' Pontefici 55. Daarna werkte hij tot 1872 aan de Via Margutta 33, en woonde respectievelijk aan de Via del Corso 504 en de Passeggiata di Ripetta 35. Hij zou tot 1876 in Rome blijven, waarna hij zich in Den Haag vestigde. In Rome maakte Stöver o.a. het beeld van een Engel met een dood kind (1856) voor het mortuarium van het Diakonessenhuis in Utrecht (nu het Centraal Museum) en een Moeder met kind (1859), gekocht door koning Frederik III van Pruissen voor zijn vrouw Victoria, ter gelegenheid van de geboorte van hun zoon, de latere keizer Wilhelm II.

$Streefkerk.en_GB: Jonkheer (Squire) Jean Gijsberto baron de Mey van Streefkerk (1782-1841), nicknamed “The Clock”, received his doctorate in both Roman and canonical law from Leiden University in 1802. He served as secretary to the Dutch ambassador to Paris from 1803, as cabinet secretary to Raadspensionaris (Grand Pensionary) R.J. Schimmelpenninck of the Batavian Republic from 1805, and subsequently as cabinet secretary to King Louis Napoleon (1805-1810), secretary to the Syndicate of Holland (1810-1813), secretary to the Department of the Interior (1813), secretary to the Council of State (1814), first secretary of the Cabinet of the King under William I (April 1815 - July 1816), Staatsraad (counselor of state) in special service, in charge of directing the state secretariat (1818-1823), secretary of state and secretary of the council of ministers (January 1823- November 1835) and finally minister of state from 1835 until his death.
$Streefkerk.it_IT: Jonkheer (Scudiero) Jean Gijsberto barone de Mey van Streefkerk (1782-1841), soprannominato “L'Orologio”, conseguì il dottorato in diritto romano e canonico presso l'Università di Leiden nel 1802. Servì come segretario dell'ambasciatore olandese a Parigi dal 1803, come segretario di gabinetto del Raadspensionaris (Grand Pensionario) R.J. Schimmelpenninck della Repubblica Batava dal 1805, e successivamente segretario di gabinetto del re Luigi Napoleone (1805-1810), segretario del Sindacato d'Olanda (1810-1813), segretario del Dipartimento degli Interni (1813), segretario del Consiglio di Stato (1814), primo segretario del Gabinetto del re sotto Guglielmo I (aprile 1815 - luglio 1816), Staatsraad (consigliere di Stato) in servizio speciale, incaricato di dirigere la segreteria di Stato (1818-1823), segretario di Stato e segretario del consiglio dei ministri (gennaio 1823-novembre 1835) e infine ministro di Stato dal 1835 fino alla morte.
$Streefkerk.nl_NL: Jonkheer Jean Gijsberto baron de Mey van Streefkerk (1782–1841), bijgenaamd 'De Klok', doctoreerde in zowel het Romeins als het canoniek recht aan de Leidse universiteit in 1802. Hij was werkzaam als secretaris van de Nederlandse ambassadeur te Parijs vanaf 1803, als kabinetssecretaris van Raadspensionaris R.J. Schimmelpenninck van de Bataafse Republiek vanaf 1805, en aansluitend kabinetssecretaris van koning Lodewijk Napoleon (1805-1810), secretaris van het  Syndicaat van Holland (1810-1813), secretaris van het departement van Binnenlandse Zaken (1813), secretaris van de Raad van State (1814), eerste secretaris van het Kabinet des Konings onder Willem I (april 1815 - juli 1816), staatsraad in bijzondere dienst, belast met de directie van de staatssecretarie (1818-1823), secretaris van staat en secretaris van de ministerraad (januari 1823- november 1835) en ten slotte minister van Staat van 1835 tot zijn dood.

$Strens.en_GB: Martin Pascal Hubert Strens was a Dutch lawyer and politician, born in Roermond. He was a supporter of the liberal leader Thorbecke, who appointed him as minister of Justice on 15 July 1852. Shortly afterwards (16 October 1852), he was also appointed as the temporary minister of the Affairs for the Roman-Catholic Worship. In that capacity he faced the unrest caused by the publication of the papal bull Ex Qua Die (4 March 1853), in which pope Pius IX announced the restauration of the episcopal hierarchy in the Netherlands. Protests against this decision prompted the so-called April movement, which eventually led to the fall of cabinet Thorbecke on 19 april 1853. In 1861-1862, Strens would return to the ministry of Roman Catholic Worship in the cabinet Van Zuylen van Nijevelt/Van Heemstra, when he also served as interim minister of Foreign Affairs, after Van Zuylen van Nijevelt had resigned from this post. Strens was appointed as attorney general in Limburg on 18 August 1865, a post he retained until his death in 1875.
$Strens.it_IT: Martin Pascal Hubert Strens fu un avvocato e politico olandese, nato a Roermond. Fu un sostenitore del leader liberale Thorbecke, che lo nominò ministro della Giustizia il 15 luglio 1852. Poco dopo (16 ottobre 1852) fu nominato anche ministro temporaneo degli Affari per il Culto Romano-Cattolico. In tale veste affrontò i disordini causati dalla pubblicazione della bolla papale Ex Qua Die (4 marzo 1853), in cui papa Pio IX annunciava il ripristino della gerarchia episcopale nei Paesi Bassi. Le proteste contro questa decisione innescarono il cosiddetto movimento di aprile, che alla fine portò alla caduta del gabinetto Thorbecke il 19 aprile 1853. Nel 1861-1862 Strens tornò al ministero del culto cattolico romano nel gabinetto Van Zuylen van Nijevelt/Van Heemstra, quando questi ricopriva anche la carica di ministro ad interim degli Affari esteri, dopo che Van Zuylen van Nijevelt si era dimesso da questo incarico. Strens fu nominato procuratore generale nel Limburgo il 18 agosto 1865, incarico che mantenne fino alla sua morte nel 1875.
$Strens.nl_NL: Martin Pascal Hubert Strens was een Nederlands advocaat en politicus, afkomstig uit Roermond. Hij behoorde tot de achterban van de liberale voorman Thorbecke en werd op 15 juli 1852 diens minister van Justitie, alvorens op 16 oktober ook tijdelijk het ministerschap van Rooms-Katholieke Eredienst op zich te nemen. In die hoedanigheid kreeg hij te maken met de ophef rondom de publicatie van de pauselijke bul Ex Qua Die (4 maart 1853), waarmee Pius IX het herstel van de bisschoppelijke hiërarchie in Nederland afkondigde. Protest hiertegen uitte zich in de zogeheten Aprilbeweging, die het kabinet-Thorbecke op 19 april 1853 ten val bracht. In 1861-1862 werd Strens in het kabinet-Van Zuylen van Nijevelt/Van Heemstra nog eens minister van Rooms-Katholieke Eredienst en eveneens korte tijd minister ad interim op Buitenlandse Zaken, na het vertrek van Van Zuylen van Nijevelt. Strens werd 18 augustus 1865 benoemd tot procureur-generaal in Limburg, een post die hij bekleedde tot zijn dood in 1875.

$Struth.en_GB: Emile or Emil Struth-Pferstorff was a German from Lauterbach (Hessen), born in Rotterdam, living in Milan for most of his life, where he was a merchant and banker, and Council of the Banca Nazionale del Regno d'Italia, from 1893 Banca d'Italia. From 1871, he was consul for the Kingdom of the Netherlands in Milan; his consulate was located on Via dell'Orso 16.  At some point he was owner and director of the bank Mack-Wiegel & Kreutzer (office on Via Brera 19). When the bank went bankrupt, he was subjected to an investigation for suspicion of fraud, partly related to a questionable life insurance policy through which he wanted to secure his capital for his heirs. He was decorated as a Knight in the Order of the Dutch Lion, in the Order of the Crown of Italy and in the Prussian Order of the Red Eagle IVth Class. Struth-Pferstorff was also active as an amateur painter, as evidenced by his presence at several art exhibitions in Milan in the 1880s.
$Struth.it_IT: Emile o Emil Struth-Pferstorff fu un tedesco di Lauterbach (Assia), nato a Rotterdam, vissuto per gran parte della sua vita a Milano, dove fu commerciante, banchiere e Consigliere della Banca Nazionale del Regno d'Italia, dal 1893 Banca d'Italia. Dal 1871 fu console del Regno dei Paesi Bassi a Milano; il suo consolato si trovava in Via dell'Orso 16. Per un certo periodo fu proprietario e direttore della banca Mack-Wiegel & Kreutzer (ufficio in Via Brera 19). Quando la banca fallì, fu sottoposto ad un'indagine per sospetta frode, in parte legata ad una discutibile polizza di assicurazione sulla vita attraverso la quale voleva garantire il suo capitale ai suoi eredi. Fu decorato Cavaliere nell'Ordine del Leone Olandese, nell'Ordine della Corona d'Italia e nell'Ordine Prussiano dell'Aquila Rossa di IV Classe. Struth-Pferstorff fu attivo anche come pittore dilettante, come testimonia la sua presenza a diverse mostre d'arte a Milano negli anni Ottanta dell'Ottocento.
$Struth.nl_NL: Emile of Emil Struth-Pferstorff was een Duitser uit Lauterbach (Hessen), geboren in Rotterdam, die het grootste deel van zijn leven in Milaan woonde, waar hij koopman en bankier was, en Raad van de Banca Nazionale del Regno d'Italia, vanaf 1893 Banca d'Italia. Vanaf 1871 was hij actief als consul voor het Koninkrijk der Nederlanden in Milaan; zijn consulaat was gevestigd aan de Via dell'Orso 16.  Op enig moment was hij eigenaar en directeur van de bank Mack-Wiegel & Kreutzer (gevestigd aan Via Brera 19). Toen die failliet ging werd hij onderworpen aan een onderzoek wegens verdenking van fraude, mede verband houdend met een discutabele levensverzekering waarmee hij zijn kapitaal voor zijn erfgenamen veilig wilde stellen. Hij was onderscheiden als Ridder in de Orde van de Nederlandse Leeuw, in de Orde van de Italiaanse Kroon en de Pruissische Orde van de Rode Adelaar IV. Klasse. Struth-Pferstorff was ook actief als amateurschilder, getuige zijn aanwezigheid op verschillende kunsttentoonstellingen in Milaan in de jaren 1880.

$Sturbinetti.en_GB: Francesco Sturbinetti was a successful Roman lawyer, whose political engagement started in the liberal period of pope Pius IX (1846-1848). He was captain of the Civic Guard and minister of Public Works and Justice, but resigned after the allocution of 29 April 1848, with which Pius withdrew from the First Italian War of Independence against Austria. Following Pius' flight from Rome, Stubinetti was elected in the Constitutional Assembly of January 1849 and voted for the proclamation of the Republic. In April 1849, he became senator of Rome, and was also promoted to General of the National Guard (formerly the Civic Guard) by triumvir of the republic Mazzini. After the fall of the Roman Republic, Sturbinetti led the commission that negotiated on behalf of the city of Rome with the French commander general Oudinot. He rejected the latter's demands and issued a proclamation calling for Rome's citizens to accept the French invasion. He then fled through Geneva to Genoa. Sturbinetti never received the papal pardon he wished for, but he did receive permission in 1857 to settle in Frascati, where he died in 1865.
$Sturbinetti.it_IT: Francesco Sturbinetti fu un avvocato romano di successo, il cui impegno politico iniziò nel periodo liberale di papa Pio IX (1846-1848). Fu capitano della Guardia Civica e ministro dei Lavori Pubblici e della Giustizia, ma si dimise dopo l'allocuzione del 29 aprile 1848, con la quale Pio XII si ritirò dalla Prima Guerra d'Indipendenza italiana contro l'Austria. Dopo la fuga del papa da Roma, Stubinetti fu eletto nell'Assemblea Costituente del gennaio 1849 e votò per la proclamazione della Repubblica. Nell'aprile 1849 divenne senatore di Roma e fu anche promosso generale della Guardia Nazionale (già Guardia Civica) dal triumviro della repubblica Mazzini. Dopo la caduta della Repubblica Romana, Sturbinetti guidò la commissione che negoziò per conto della città di Roma con il comandante francese generale Oudinot. Respinse le richieste di questi ultimi ed e emanò un proclama in cui invitava i cittadini di Roma ad accettare l'invasione francese. Poi fuggì attraverso Ginevra a Genova. Sturbinetti non ottenne mai il perdono papale desiderato, ma ebbe nel 1857 il permesso di stabilirsi a Frascati, dove morì nel 1865.
$Sturbinetti.nl_NL: Francesco Sturbinetti was een succesvol Romeins advocaat, wiens politieke engagement begon tijdens de liberale periode van paus Pius IX (1846-1848). Hij was o.a. kapitein in de burgerwacht en minister van Openbare Werken en Justitie, maar nam ontslag na de allocutie  van 29 april 1848, waarmee Pius zich had teruggetrokken uit de Eerste Italiaanse Onafhankelijkheidsoorlog tegen Oostenrijk. Na de vlucht van Pius uit Rome werd Sturbinetti in de Grondwetgevende Vergadering van januari 1849 verkozen, en stemde hij voor de proclamatie van de republiek. In april 1849 werd hij senator van de gemeente Rome en werd hij door triumvir van de republiek Mazzini tot generaal van de Nationale Garde (voorheen de burgerwacht) benoemd. Na de val van de Romeinse Republiek leidde Sturbinetti de commissie die namens de stad Rome onderhandelde met de Franse opperbevelhebber generaal Oudinot. Hij verwierp diens condities en gaf een proclamatie uit om de burgers op te roepen zich bij de Franse intocht neer te leggen. Zelf vluchtte hij en streek via Genève in Genua neer. Hij kreeg nooit de gewenste pauselijke absolutie, maar in 1857 wel toestemming zich in Frascati te vestigen, waar hij in 1865 stierf.

$Teerlink.en_GB: Abraham, in Italy 'Alessandro', Teerlink was a Dutch painter from Dordrecht. In 1807, together with P.R. Kleijn, he was the first apprentice artist who, even before the regulations of the Dutch Prix de Rome had been drawn up, received a grant from the French king Louis Napoleon. With this, he left for Paris, where he studied with J.-L. David. In 1808, he moved to Rome, where he remained for the rest of his life. At first he painted copies after the old masters, later mainly landscapes, with which he gained great prestige. He became a member of the Società degli Amatori e Cultori delle Belle Arti and taught at the Accademia di San Luca. There he was the teacher of painter Anna Muschi, who became his wife in 1836. Their studio and residence in Rome was located at Via Capo le Case 3 for many years. Although Teerlink lived in Rome, he continued to submit paintings for the exhibitions of “Levende Meesters” (Living Masters) in the Netherlands, and in 1839 he was appointed Knight of the Order of the Dutch Lion by Dutch King William I. Teerlink also wrote French poetry, including a long poem in praise of H. Vernet. His tomb can still be seen in San Carlo al Corso, Rome.
$Teerlink.it_IT: Abraham, in Italia 'Alessandro', Teerlink era un pittore olandese di Dordrecht. Nel 1807, insieme a P.R. Kleijn, fu il primo apprendista artista a ricevere una borsa di studio dal re francese Luigi Napoleone, ancor prima che fossero redatti i regolamenti del Prix de Rome olandese. Con questa, partì per Parigi, dove studiò con J.-L. David. Nel 1808 si trasferì a Roma, dove rimase per il resto della sua vita. Inizialmente dipinse copie di opere di grandi maestri, in seguito soprattutto paesaggi, con i quali ottenne grande prestigio. Divenne membro della Società degli Amatori e Cultori delle Belle Arti e insegnò all'Accademia di San Luca. Lì fu insegnante della pittrice Anna Muschi, che divenne sua moglie nel 1836. Il loro studio e residenza a Roma si trovava per molti anni in Via Capo le Case 3. Sebbene Teerlink vivesse a Roma, continuò a presentare dipinti alle mostre dei 'Levende Meesters' (Maestri Viventi) nei Paesi Bassi e nel 1839 fu nominato Cavaliere dell'Ordine del Leone d'Olanda dal re Guglielmo I. Teerlink scrisse anche poesie in francese, tra cui un lungo poema in lode di H. Vernet. La sua tomba è ancora visibile a San Carlo al Corso, a Roma.
$Teerlink.nl_NL: Abraham, in Italië 'Alessandro', Teerlink was een Nederlandse schilder uit Dordrecht. In 1807 was hij, met P.R. Kleijn, de eerste leerling-kunstenaar die, nog voor het reglement van de Hollandse Prix de Rome was opgesteld, een toelage kreeg van de Franse koning Lodewijk Napoleon. Daarmee vertrok hij naar Parijs, waar hij onder anderen bij J.-L. David studeerde. In 1808 verhuisde hij naar Rome, waar hij de rest van zijn leven bleef. Hij schilderde eerst vooral kopieën naar de oude meesters, later hoofdzakelijk landschappen, waarmee hij groot aanzien genoot. Hij werd lid van de Società degli Amatori e Cultori delle Belle Arti en docent aan de Accademia di San Luca. Daar gaf hij les aan de schilderes Anna Muschi, die in 1836 zijn vrouw werd. Hun atelier en woonhuis in Rome was jarenlang gevestigd aan Via Capo le Case 3. Hoewel Teerlink in Rome woonde, bleef hij schilderijen insturen voor de tentoonstellingen van Levende Meesters in Nederland, en werd hij in 1839 door de Nederlandse koning Willem I benoemd tot Ridder in de Orde van de Nederlandsche Leeuw. Teerlink schreef ook Franstalige poëzie, waaronder een lang lofdicht op H. Vernet. Zijn grafmonument is nog altijd te zien in de San Carlo al Corso, Rome.

$Tommaseo.en_GB: Niccolò Tommaseo was an Italian writer, linguist and patriot. He was born in the Dalmatian town of Sebenico/Šibenik, formerly under Venetian and Napoleonic and since 1815 under Habsburg rule. He studied in Padua and first lived in Milan and Florence, where he pursued activities as a journalist, Risorgimento activist and Philhellenic sympathiser. With his Nuovo Dizionario de' sinonimi della lingua italiana (1830), he made a name for himself as a lexicographer and linguist. After a diplomatic riot in Florence following an anti-Austrian article he wrote, he moved to Paris, where he wrote his political treatise Dell'Italia (1835) and the historical novel Il duca d'Atene (1837). After moving to Venice in 1840, he published his Canti popolari toscani, corsi, illirici and greci (1841-42). In 1847, he was arrested by the Habsburg authorities but freed from prison by a popular uprising. During the short-lived Venetian Republic, he was a member of the provisional government. After its collapse, he went into exile to Corfu and in 1854 moved to Turin, before finally settling in Florence. Tommaseo regretted the monarchist turn the Risorgimento had taken; earlier, his devout Catholicism had not prevented him from urging the pope to relinquish his secular authority in favour of Italian unification (Rome et le monde, 1851). He is best known for his monumental Dizionario della lingua italiana (1865-1879), published partly after his death.
$Tommaseo.it_IT: Niccolò Tommaseo fu uno scrittore, linguista e patriota italiano. Nacque nel 1802 nella cittadina dalmata di Sebenico/Šibenik, che era stata sotto il dominio veneziano e napoleonico e dal 1815 sotto il dominio asburgico. Studiò a Padova e visse prima a Milano e Firenze, dove svolse attività di giornalista, militante risorgimentale e simpatizzante filellenico. Con il Nuovo Dizionario de' sinonimi della lingua italiana (1830) si affermò come lessicografo e linguista. Dopo un tumulto diplomatico a Firenze in seguito a un articolo antiaustriaco da lui scritto, si trasferì a Parigi, dove scrisse il trattato politico Dell'Italia (1835) e il romanzo storico Il duca d'Atene (1837). Trasferitosi a Venezia nel 1840, pubblicò i Canti popolari toscani, corsi, illirici e greci (1841-42). Nel 1847 fu arrestato dalle autorità asburgiche ma liberato dal carcere grazie a una rivolta popolare. Durante la breve Repubblica di Venezia fu membro del governo provvisorio. Dopo il suo crollo, andò in esilio a Corfù e nel 1854 si trasferì a Torino, prima di stabilirsi definitivamente a Firenze. Tommaseo si rammaricava della svolta monarchica presa dal Risorgimento; in precedenza, il suo devoto cattolicesimo non gli aveva impedito di esortare il papa a rinunciare alla sua autorità secolare a favore dell'unificazione italiana (Rome et le monde, 1851). Oggi è noto soprattutto per il suo monumentale Dizionario della lingua italiana (1865-1879), pubblicato in parte dopo la sua morte (1874).
$Tommaseo.nl_NL: Niccolò Tommaseo was een Italiaanse schrijver, taalkundige en patriot. Hij werd geboren in de Dalmatische stad Sebenico/Šibenik, vroeger onder Venetiaans en Napoleontisch bewind en sinds 1815 onder Habsburgs bewind. Hij studeerde in Padua en woonde eerst in Milaan en Florence, waar hij actief was als journalist, Risorgimento activist en Filhelleense sympathisant. Met zijn Nuovo Dizionario de' sinonimi della lingua italiana (1830) maakte hij naam als lexicograaf en taalkundige. Na een diplomatieke rel in Florence naar aanleiding van een anti-Oostenrijks artikel dat hij schreef, verhuisde hij naar Parijs, waar hij zijn politieke verhandeling Dell'Italia (1835) en de historische roman Il duca d'Atene (1837) schreef. Nadat hij in 1840 naar Venetië was verhuisd, publiceerde hij zijn Canti popolari toscani, corsi, illirici en greci (1841-42). In 1847 werd hij gearresteerd door de Habsburgse autoriteiten, maar door een volksopstand uit de gevangenis bevrijd. Tijdens de kortstondige Venetiaanse Republiek was hij lid van de voorlopige regering. Na de val ervan ging hij in ballingschap naar Corfu en in 1854 verhuisde hij naar Turijn, voordat hij zich uiteindelijk in Florence vestigde. Tommaseo betreurde de monarchistische wending die het Risorgimento had genomen; eerder had zijn vroom katholicisme hem er niet van weerhouden de paus aan te sporen afstand te doen van zijn wereldlijke autoriteit ten gunste van de Italiaanse eenwording (Rome et le monde, 1851). Hij is het meest bekend om zijn monumentale Dizionario della lingua italiana (1865-1879), dat gedeeltelijk na zijn dood werd gepubliceerd.

$Tornielli.en_GB: Giuseppe Tornielli- Brusati, Count of Vergano, was an Italian diplomat. He was born in Novara in 1836 and graduated in Law in 1858. In 1859, he accompanied Massimo d'Azeglio on his mission to the Romagne and was secretary to the governor of Ferrara. In 1859, he began working as a volunteer at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, where he was trained at the State Secretariat in a 'Cavourian' climate, of which Emilio Visconti Venosta and Costantino Nigra were the leading exponents at the time. A legation attaché in Constantinople in 1860, in 1862 he was called to the minister's private cabinet and was subsequently posted to St Petersburg and in 1864 was sent to Athens. He was Secretary General at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs from 1876 to 1878 and from 1878 to 1879. Later, he was nominated Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary first to Serbia (1879), then to Romania and later he became Ambassador in Madrid, London and Paris (1895), where he represented Italy for thirteen years. He was secretary at the International Peace Conferences in Algeciras (1906) and The Hague (1907). On 16 March 1879, he was created senator of the kingdom. He died in Paris in 1908.
$Tornielli.it_IT: Giuseppe Tornielli-Brusati, conte di Vergano, fu un diplomatico. Nacque a Novara nel 1836. Si laureò in Legge conseguita nel 1858. Nel 1859 accompagnò Massimo d'Azeglio nella sua missione nelle Romagne e fu segretario del governatore di Ferrara. Ammesso per concorso come volontario al ministero degli Esteri nel 1859, crebbe nella segreteria di Stato alla scuola del barone Luigi Bartolomeo Cravosio e nel clima cavouriano con Emilio Visconti Venosta e Costantino Nigra, ambasciatore a Parigi. Addetto di legazione a Costantinopoli nel 1860, nel 1862 fu chiamato al gabinetto particolare del ministro e successivamente fu destinato a Pietroburgo e nel 1864 venne inviato ad Atene. Fu segretario generale al Ministero degli affari esteri dal 1876 al 1878 e dal 1878 al 1879. Inviato straordinario e ministro plenipotenziario prima in Serbia (1879), poi in Romania e in seguito ambasciatore a Madrid, a Londra e a Parigi (1895), dove rappresentò per tredici anni l'Italia. Fu segretario alle conferenze internazionali per la pace ad Algeciras (1906) e L'Aia. Il 16 marzo 1879 fu creato senatore del regno. Morì a Parigi nel 1908.
$Tornielli.nl_NL: Giuseppe Tornielli- Brusati, graaf van Vergano, was een Italiaanse diplomaat. Hij werd in 1836 geboren in Novara en studeerde af in de Rechten in 1858. In 1859 vergezelde hij Massimo d'Azeglio, die als koninklijk gezant naar Romagna was gestuurd, en was hij secretaris van de gouverneur van Ferrara. In 1859 begon bij als vrijwilliger medewerker op het Ministerie van Buitenlandse Zaken, waar hij op het staatssecretariaat werd gevormd in het Cavouriaanse klimaat waarvan Emilio Visconti Venosta en Costantino Nigra toen de belangrijkste exponenten waren. In 1860 werd Tornielli attaché van de Piemontese legatie in Constantinopel, in 1862 werd hij benoemd in het kabinet van de minister van Buitenlandse Zaken en vervolgens werd hij als diplomaat naar Sint-Petersburg gestuurd en in 1864 naar Athene. Van 1876 tot 1878 en van 1878 tot 1879 diende hij vervolgens als secretaris-generaal bij het ministerie van Buitenlandse Zaken. Hij was eerst buitengewoon en gevolmachtigd minister in Servië (1879), daarna in Roemenië; later werd hij ambassadeur in Madrid, Londen en Parijs (1895); op die laatste post vertegenwoordigde hij Italië dertien jaar lang. Hij was secretaris op de internationale vredesconferentie in Algeciras (1906) en Den Haag (1907). Op 16 maart 1879 werd hij benoemd tot senator. Hij stierf in Parijs in 1908.

$Torti.en_GB: Giovanni Torti was an Italian poet. A pupil of Giuseppe Parini, he extolled him in La Visione (1802); in 1808 he wrote L'epistola sui sepolcri, in which he compared Ugo Foscolo with Ippolito Pindemonte. Later, when he had become friends with Alessandro Manzoni (who praised his verses), he embraced Romantic literary doctrines (Sermoni sulla poesia, 1818, which was called the Poetic Art of Romanticism). Torti is also the author of a poem in octaves, La torre di Capua (1829), the terza rima Scepticismo e religione (1836), an epistle in occasion of the death of his wife (1838), as well as a fiery Inno delle cinque giornate (1848). Fearing reprisals from the Austrians, he took the path of exile, first in Savona and then in Genoa, where he moved in March 1849. In 1850 he wrote Torna, Re Sacerdote, alla tua Roma (Come back, King Priest, to your Rome), in which he bitterly asked Pius IX, who had returned to Rome on 12 April 1850 after the fall of the Roman Republic of 1849, and regained temporal power at the price of the blood spilt by his foreign relief troops, whether his behaviour was in keeping with the message of Christ.
$Torti.it_IT: Giovanni Torti fu un poeta italiano. Allievo di Giuseppe Parini, lo esaltò in La Visione (1802); nel 1808 scrisse L'epistola sui sepolcri confrontando Ugo Foscolo con Ippolito Pindemonte. Più tardi, divenuto amico di Alessandro Manzoni (che lodò i suoi versi), accolse le dottrine romantiche (Sermoni sulla poesia, 1818, che furono detti l'Arte poetica del Romanticismo). Torti è inoltre autore d'un poema in ottave, La torre di Capua (1829), delle terzine Scetticismo e religione (1836), di un'epistola in morte della moglie (1838), nonché d'un focoso Inno delle cinque giornate (1848). Per paura di ritorsioni da parte degli austriaci prese la via dell'esilio, prima a Savona e poi a Genova, ove si trasferì nel marzo del 1849. Nel 1850 redasse Torna, Re Sacerdote, alla tua Roma, in cui amaramente chiedeva a Pio IX, rientrato a Roma il 12 aprile 1850 e riappropriatosi del potere temporale a prezzo del sangue che gli aiuti stranieri avevano fatto scorrere, se il suo comportamento si confacesse al messaggio di Cristo.
$Torti.nl_NL: Giovanni Torti was een Italiaans dichter. Hij was een leerling van Giuseppe Parini, dien hij prees in La Visione (1802). In 1808 schreef hij L'epistola sui sepolcri,waarin hij Ugo Foscolo vergeleek met Ippolito Pindemonte. Later, nadat hij bevriend was geraakt met Alessandro Manzoni (die zijn verzen loofde), omarmde hij de romantische literaire beginselen (Sermoni sulla poesia, 1818, dat de Ars Poetica van de Romantiek werd genoemd). Torti is ook de auteur van een gedicht in octaven, La torre di Capua (1829), de terzine Scepticismo e religione (1836), een epistel bij gelegenheid van het overlijden van zijn vrouw (1838), evenals een vurige Inno delle cinque giornate (1848). Uit angst voor represailles van de Oostenrijkers ging Torti in ballingschap, eerst in Savona en daarna in Genua, waarheen hij in maart 1849 verhuisde. In 1850 schreef hij Torna, Re Sacerdote, alla tua Roma (Keer terug, koning priester, naar uw Rome), waarin hij Pius IX, die zich op 12 april 1850, na de val van de Romeinse Republiek van 1849, weer in Rome had gevestigd en de wereldlijke macht had heroverd ten koste van het bloed dat door zijn buitenlandse hulptroepen was vergoten, verbitterd de vraag stelde of zijn gedrag wel te rijmen viel met de boodschap van Christus.

$Toscana.en_GB: Leopold II of Habsburg-Lotharingen was Grand Duke of Tuscany from 1824 to 1859. He initially pursued a policy of moderate reform, which culminated in the establishment of press freedom, an armed civic guard (1847) and a constitution (1848); he also participated in the First Italian War of Independence against Austria with a small contingent of soldiers and volunteers. After his power was usurped by the democratic government Guerazzi-Montanelli (January 1849), Leopold fled to Gaeta. He was reinstalled with the help of Austrian troops, a move that did not earn him any sympathy. He reversed some of his earlier reforms and refused to cut ties with Austria, even when that proved to be his only chance to keep his throne in 1859. When on 27 April 1859 the war between the Kingdom of Sardinia-Piedmont and Austria broke out (Second Italian War of Independence), Leopold fled to Vienna. From 1869 to his death, he stayed in Rome, close to the pope.
$Toscana.it_IT: Leopoldo II d'Asburgo-Lotaringa fu granduca di Toscana dal 1824 al 1859. Perseguì inizialmente una politica di riforme moderate, culminata nell'istituzione della libertà di stampa, di una guardia civica armata (1847) e di una costituzione (1848); partecipò anche alla Prima Guerra d'Indipendenza italiana contro l'Austria con un piccolo contingente di soldati e volontari. Dopo che il suo potere fu occupato dal governo democratico Guerrazzi-Montanelli (gennaio 1849), Leopoldo fuggì a Gaeta. Fu rimesso sul trono con l'aiuto delle truppe austriache, una mossa che gli tolse ogni  simpatia. Annullò alcune delle sue precedenti riforme e rifiutò di tagliare i legami con l'Austria, anche quando quella si rivelò essere la sua unica possibilità di mantenere il trono nel 1859. Quando il 27 aprile 1859 scoppiò la guerra tra il Regno di Sardegna-Piemonte e l'Austria ( Seconda Guerra d'Indipendenza Italiana), Leopoldo fuggì a Vienna. Dal 1869 alla morte soggiornò a Roma, vicino al papa.
$Toscana.nl_NL: Leopold II van Habsburg-Lorraine was groothertog van Toscane van 1824 tot 1859. Hij voerde aanvankelijk een mild hervormingsbeleid, culminerend in de invoering van persvrijheid, een gewapende burgerwacht (1847) en een grondwet (1848), en stond toe dat een klein contingent reguliere en vrijwillige soldaten uit Toscane deelnam aan de Eerste Italiaanse Onafhankelijkheidsoorlog. Na de machtsovername door de democratische regering-Guerazzi/Montanelli (januari 1849) vluchtte Leopold naar Gaeta in het Koninkrijk der Beide Siciliën. Ten slotte liet hij zich weer met hulp van Oostenrijkse troepen installeren, waarmee hij veel sympathie verspeelde. Zijn eerdere hervormingen draaide hij grotendeels terug. Hij weigerde de banden met Oostenrijk door te snijden, zelfs toen dat in 1859 zijn enige kans was om zijn troon te behouden. Toen op 7 april 1859 de oorlog tussen het Koninkrijk Sardinië-Piemonte en Oostenrijk uitbrak (Tweede Italiaanse Onafhankelijkheidsoorlog) vluchtte Leopold naar Wenen. Van 1869 tot zijn dood verbleef hij in Rome, in de nabijheid van de paus.

$Tosti.en_GB: Antonio Tosti was elected cardinal in 1838 by Pope Gregory XVI, who appointed him treasurer-general of the Apostolic Chamber from 1834 to 1845. The Pope replaced Tosti with the future cardinal-Secretary of State Giacomo Antonelli. During the Roman Republic of 1849, Tosti stayed in Rome at the hospice of San Michele a Ripa Grande, of which he had been the director since 1830. He received financial aid from triumvir of the republic Mazzini to continue paying the textile workers in the hospice and prevent unrest. He resigned years later, in 1859, after the workers organised a demonstration. The year after, Pius IX appointed Tosti as librarian and archivist of the Vatican Secret Archives. Tosti held these posts until his death and continued to live at the hospice of San Michele, where he was buried.
$Tosti.it_IT: Antonio Tosti fu eletto cardinale nel 1838 da papa Gregorio XVI, che lo nominò tesoriere generale della Camera Apostolica dal 1834 al 1845. Il papa sostituì Tosti con il futuro cardinale segretario di Stato Giacomo Antonelli. Durante la Repubblica Romana del 1849, Tosti soggiornò a Roma presso l'ospizio di San Michele a Ripa Grande, di cui era direttore dal 1830. Ricevette un aiuto finanziario dal triumviro della Repubblica Mazzini per continuare a pagare gli operai tessili dell'ospizio e prevenire disordini. Si dimise anni dopo, nel 1859, dopo che gli operai avevano organizzato una manifestazione. L'anno successivo Pio IX nominò Tosti bibliotecario e archivista dell'Archivio Segreto Vaticano. Tosti ricoprì questi incarichi fino alla morte e continuò a vivere presso l'ospizio di San Michele, dove fu sepolto.
$Tosti.nl_NL: Antonio Tosti werd in 1838 tot kardinaal benoemd door Gregorius XVI, onder wie hij, in de periode van 1834 tot 1845, de functie van thesaurier-generaal van de Apostolische Kamer bekleedde. De paus verving hem echter door de latere kardinaal-staatssecretaris Giacomo Antonelli. Tijdens de Romeinse Republiek van 1849 bleef Tosti in Rome achter, in het hospice van San Michele a Ripa Grande waarvan hij sinds 1830 directeur was. Hij ontving in deze periode financiële steun van triumvir van de republiek Mazzini waarmee hij de wolarbeiders in het hospice doorbetaalde en onrust voorkwam. Pas vele jaren later, nadat er in 1859 rellen plaatsvonden onder deze arbeiders, nam hij ontslag. Tosti werd het jaar daarop benoemd tot bibliothecaris en archivist van het Geheime Archief van het Vaticaan. Hij behield deze functies tot zijn dood en bleef woonachtig in het hospice van San Michele, waar hij ook ligt begraven.

$Uyttenhooven.en_GB: Adriaan Uyttenhooven was born to a family of notables from the province of Zeeland. He studied literature and law in Leiden, where he also obtained a doctorate in law. He was briefly a lawyer at the Dutch Supreme Court, then (15 May 1849) a clerk to the House of Representatives and, from 1851, legal secretary for 'incoming and outgoing duties and excises' at the Ministry of Finance. From June 1863 to 1866, he was Secretary-General at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, after which he returned to Finance, now as Chief Administrator. In 1869, he played an key role in the creation of the Organic Decree regulating appointments and promotions in public service. U. received numerous domestic and foreign honours, including that of Knight of the Order of the Dutch Lion (1862) and Commander in the Order of Mauritius and Lazarus of Italy. At his funeral, former foreign minister E.J.J.B. Cremers delivered a short eulogy. Uyttenhooven was also an amateur painter, and mainly a draughtsman and lithographer.
$Uyttenhooven.it_IT: Adriaan Uyttenhooven nacque da una famiglia di notabili della provincia della Zelanda. Studiò letteratura e diritto a Leida, dove conseguì anche un dottorato in giurisprudenza. Fu per breve tempo avvocato presso la Corte Suprema olandese, poi (15 maggio 1849) impiegato presso la Camera dei Rappresentanti e, dal 1851, segretario legale per 'dazi e accise in entrata e in uscita' presso il Ministero delle Finanze. Dal giugno 1863 al 1866 fu segretario generale al Ministero degli affari esteri, dopo di che tornò alle finanze, ora come amministratore capo. Nel 1869 svolse un ruolo chiave nella stesura del Decreto Organico che regolava le nomine e le promozioni nel pubblico servizio. U. ricevette numerose onorificenze nazionali ed estere, tra cui quella di Cavaliere dell'Ordine del Leone d'Olanda (1862) e di Commendatore nell'Ordine di Maurizio e Lazzaro d'Italia. Al suo funerale, l'ex ministro degli Esteri E.J.J.B. Cremers ha pronunciato un breve elogio. Uyttenhooven fu anche un pittore dilettante, e principalmente un disegnatore e litografo.
$Uyttenhooven.nl_NL:
Adriaan Uyttenhooven was afkomstig uit een Zeeuwse familie van notabelen. Hij studeerde Letteren en Rechten in Leiden en promoveerde eveneens in de Rechten. Hij was korte tijd advocaat bij de Hoge Raad, daarna (15 mei 1849) Commissies-Griffier in de Tweede Kamer en vanaf 1851 referendaris 'in- en uitgaande regten en accijnzen' aan het ministerie van Financiën. Van juni 1863 tot 1866 was hij secretaris-generaal bij Buitenlandse Zaken, waarna hij terugkeerde naar Financiën, nu als Hoofd-Administrateur. In 1869 speelde hij een belangrijke rol bij de totstandkoming van het Organieke Besluit waarmee benoemingen en bevorderingen inzake staatsbetrekkingen werden geregeld. U. ontving talloze binnen-en buitenlandse eerbewijzen, waaronder die van Ridder in de Orde van de Nederlandsche Leeuw (1862) en Kommandeur in de Orde van Mauritius en Lazarus van Italië. 
Bij zijn begrafenis hield oud-minister van Buitenlandse Zaken E.J.J.B. Cremers een korte lijkrede. Uyttenhooven was tevens amateurschilder, en vooral tekenaar en lithograaf.

$Valle.en_GB: Giovanni Piccono Della Valle was the son of Count Vittorio Amedeo and Vittoria Margherita Pascale di Nocetto. He was a Major General in the army, chief of staff at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and director of the Royal Post Office. On 1 June 1812, he married Giuseppa Teresa Trabucco di Castagnetto, by whom he had eight children. He held the Foreign Ministry of the Kingdom of Savoy between 7 October and 26 December 1817, in the vacancy between the resignation of Alessandro Count of Vallesa. and the subsequent appointment of Filippo Antonio Asinari of San Marzano. He had diplomatic duties and in 1818 was minister plenipotentiary on the occasion of a convention with the Kingdom of the Two Sicilies. When Carlo Felice ascended to the throne (25 April 1821), he entrusted Piccono della Valle with the regency of the Secretariat of State. The following year, however, he was replaced by Sallier de la Tour, because he had been jealous towards his colleagues and intolerant towards the king. Previously, Piccono had accompanied Charles Felix to Modena in 1821, in an attempt to gain control of the revolutionary uprisings there. In the Council of State he had advocated against any constitutional concessions to the liberal demands. During the reign of king Charles Albert, he would not hold any important public offices. Upon his death in 1850, Piccono was buried at Turin's monumental cemetery.
$Valle.it_IT: Giovanni Piccono Della Valle era il figlio del conte Vittorio Amedeo e di Vittoria Margherita Pascale di Nocetto. Fu Maggiore generale dell'esercito, primo ufficiale del Ministero degli esteri, e direttore delle Regie Poste nel Regno di Sardegna. Il 1 giugno 1812 sposò Giuseppa Teresa Trabucco di Castagnetto, da cui ebbe 8 figli. Resse il ministero degli esteri del Regno Sabaudo fra il 7 ottobre il 26 dicembre 1817, nella vacanza fra le dimissioni di Alessandro conte di Vallesa e la nomina successiva di Filippo Antonio Asinari di San Marzano. Ebbe incarichi diplomatici e nel 1818 fu ministro plenipotenziario in occasione di una convenzione con il Regno delle Due Sicilie. Carlo Felice di Savoia, appena salito al trono (25 aprile 1821) gli affidò la reggenza della Segreteria di Stato. Accompagnò il re a Modena nel 1821, in occasione dei moti rivoluzionari, e si espresse nel Consiglio di Stato contro ogni concessione costituzionale. Nel 1822 Piccono della Valle fu sostituito da Sallier de la Tour, perché si sarebbe mostrato geloso dei colleghi e insofferente verso il re. Durante il regno di Carlo Alberto non ebbe nessun incarico di rilievo. Al momento della sua morte nel 1850 fu seppellito nel cimitero monumentale di Torino.
$Valle.nl_NL: Giovanni Piccono Della Valle was de zoon van graaf Vittorio Amedeo en Vittoria Margherita Pascale di Nocetto. Hij was generaal-majoor in het leger, stafchef aan het Ministerie van Buitenlandse Zaken en directeur van de Koninklijke Post van het Koninkrijk Sardinië-Piemonte. Op 1 juni 1812 trouwde hij met Giuseppa Teresa Trabucco di Castagnetto, met wie hij acht kinderen kreeg. Hij leidde het Ministerie van Buitenlandse Zaken van het Koninkrijk Sardinië tussen 7 oktober en 26 december 1817, toen dat ambt vacant was na aftreden van Alessandro graaf van Vallesa, tot de benoeming van Filippo Antonio Asinari van San Marzano. Hij had diplomatieke taken en was in 1818 gevolmachtigd minister ter gelegenheid van een conventie met het Koninkrijk der Twee Siciliën. Na zijn troonsbestijging (25 aprile 1821) vertrouwde koning Carlo Felice van Savoia Piccono della Valle de leiding over het Staatssecretariaat toe. Een jaar later werd Piccono echter al vervangen door Sallier de la Tour, vanwege zijn afgunst jegens collega's en ongeduld jegens de koning. In 1821 had hij Carlo Felice van Savoia naar Modena begeleid om de revolutionaire opstanden die daar waren uitgebroken onder controle te krijgen. Daarbij had Piccono zich in de Raad van State (Consiglio di Stato) uitgesproken tegen elke vorm van constitutionele concessies. Tijdens het bewind van koning Karel Albert zou hij geen belangrijke posten bekleden. Na zijn dood in 1850 werd hij begraven op de monumentale begraafplaats van Turijn.

$VanDerBosch.en_GB: Engelbertus Batavus van der Bosch was a Dutch naval officer and minister. He rose rapidly in rank as a naval officer between 1803 and 1840 and served as director of Naval Affairs between 1840 and 1841. In 1845, he was appointed commander of Naval Forces in the Dutch East Indies, and in that capacity he also took part in the Dutch punitive expedition against rebellious Balinese princes in 1846. Van der Bosch returned to the Netherlands in 1848, and subsequently became Minister of Colonies (18 June-1 November 1849) and temporary acting Minister of the Navy (15 September-1 November 1849) in the De Kempenaer cabinet. In February 1850, he was appointed Commander of the Navy in the Dutch East Indies for a second time. He arrived in Batavia in May 1850, and died there a few months later on 11 February 1851.
$VanDerBosch.it_IT: Engelbertus Batavus van der Bosch fu un ufficiale e ministro della Marina olandese. Salì rapidamente di grado come ufficiale di Marina tra il 1803 e il 1840 e ricoprì la carica di direttore degli Affari Navali tra il 1840 e il 1841. Nel 1845 fu nominato comandante delle Forze Navali nelle Indie Orientali Olandesi e, in tale veste, prese parte anche alla spedizione punitiva olandese contro i principi ribelli balinesi nel 1846. Van der Bosch tornò nei Paesi Bassi nel 1848 e successivamente divenne Ministro delle Colonie (18 giugno-1 novembre 1849) e Ministro ad interim della Marina (15 settembre-1 novembre 1849) nel gabinetto De Kempenaer. Nel febbraio 1850 fu nominato per la seconda volta Comandante della Marina nelle Indie Orientali Olandesi. Arrivò a Batavia nel maggio 1850 e vi morì pochi mesi dopo, l'11 febbraio 1851.
$VanDerBosch.nl_NL: Engelbertus Batavus van der Bosch was Nederlands marineofficier en minister. Hij steeg tussen 1803 en 1840 snel in rang als marineofficier en was tussen 1840 en 1841 directeur Marinezaken. In 1845 werd hij benoemd tot commandant der Zeemacht in Nederlands-Indië, en in die capaciteit nam hij ook deel aan de Nederlandse strafexpeditie tegen opstandige Balinese vorsten in 1846. Van der Bosch keerde in 1848 terug naar Nederland en werd toen minister van Koloniën (18 juni-1 november 1849) en tijdelijk waarnemend minister van Marine (15 september-1 november 1849) in kabinet-De Kempenaer. In februari 1850 werd hij voor een tweede keer benoemd tot Commandant der Zeemacht in Nederlands-Indië. Hij kwam in mei 1850 aan te Batavia, en overleed daar enkele maanden later op 11 februari 1851.

$Vannicelli.en_GB: Luigi Vannicelli Casoni was governor of Rome and director-general of police from 1838 to 1842, after which he was elevated to the cardinalate by pope Gregory XVI. The latter named him apostolic envoy to Forlì in 1843 and to Bologna from 1844 to 1846. During Pope Pius IX's exile in Gaeta, Vannicelli was in his entourage. After the French occupied Rome in July 1849, he and cardinals G. Della Genga Sermattei and L. Altieri formed a triumvirate, ruling Rome until the pope's return in April 1850. That same year, Vannicelli was appointed archbishop of Ferrara, allegedly at the insistence of Cardinal G. Antonelli, who saw him as a rival and wanted to distance him from the pope. Vannicelli was strongly conservative and therefore critical of Pius' liberal policies between 1846-1848. When he was archbishop of Ferrara, he defended Pius' new policies, which were marked by an opposition to the forces of modernity (liberalism, freedom of faith and education, separation of church and state, etc.). In spite of this, Vannicelli was praised for his moderate and diplomatic stance, and was even called papabile. However, he died before there could be a conclave, on 21 April 1877 in Rome.
$Vannicelli.it_IT: Luigi Vannicelli Casoni fu governatore di Roma e direttore generale della polizia dal 1838 al 1842, dopodiché fu elevato al cardinalato da papa Gregorio XVI. Quest'ultimo lo nominò inviato apostolico a Forlì nel 1843 e a Bologna dal 1844 al 1846. Durante l'esilio di papa Pio IX a Gaeta, Vannicelli fu al suo seguito. Dopo l'occupazione francese di Roma nel luglio 1849, lui e i cardinali G. Della Genga Sermattei e L. Altieri formarono un triumvirato, governando Roma fino al ritorno del papa nell'aprile 1850. Nello stesso anno, Vannicelli fu nominato arcivescovo di Ferrara, presumibilmente su insistenza del cardinale G. Antonelli, che lo vedeva come un rivale e voleva allontanarlo dal papa. Vannicelli era fortemente conservatore e quindi critico nei confronti delle politiche liberali di Pio IX tra il 1846 e il 1848. Da arcivescovo di Ferrara, difese la nuova politica di Pio XII, caratterizzata da un'opposizione alle forze della modernità (liberalismo, libertà di fede e di insegnamento, separazione tra Stato e Chiesa, ecc.). Nonostante ciò, Vannicelli fu elogiato per la sua posizione moderata e diplomatica, e fu persino definito papabile. Tuttavia, morì prima che si potesse tenere un conclave, il 21 aprile 1877 a Roma.
$Vannicelli.nl_NL: Luigi Vannicelli Casoni was van 1838 tot 1842 onder meer gouverneur van Rome en directeur-generaal van politie. Na in 1842 tot kardinaal te zijn verheven, was hij in 1843 apostolisch gezant in Forlì en van 1844 tot 1846 in Bologna. Tijdens de ballingschap van paus Pius IX in Gaeta bevond Vannicelli zich in diens entourage. Nadat de Fransen in juli 1849 Rome hadden bezet, vormde hij samen met de kardinalen G. Della Genga Sermattei en L. Altieri een driemanschap, dat over Rome regeerde tot de terugkeer van de paus in april 1850. In datzelfde jaar werd Vannicelli tot aartsbisschop van Ferrara benoemd, naar verluidt op aandringen van kardinaal G. Antonelli, die hem als rivaal zag en van de paus wilde verwijderen. Zelf extreem conservatief, stond Vannicelli kritisch tegenover het liberale beleid dat Pius tussen 1846-1848 voerde. Toen hij aartsbisschop van Ferrara was, verdedigde hij Pius' nieuwe beleid, dat werd gekleurd door een verzet tegen de moderniteit (het liberalisme, vrijheid van geloof en onderwijs, scheiding van kerk en staat, etc.). Desondanks werd Vannicelli geprezen voor zijn gematigde en diplomatieke houding, en werd hij zelfs papabile genoemd. Hij overleed echter voor er een conclaaf kon komen, op 21 april 1877 te Rome.

$Vecchiotti.en_GB: Settimio Maria Vecchiotti was born in 1810 to Sebastiano Clementi Vecchiotti, a San Marino patrician. He studied with the fathers Filippini dell'Oratorio in Fermo and in Rome at the Collegio Capranica, where he specialised in philosophy and theology. His ties with Cardinal Pecci, who was to become Pope Leo XIII, were strong. In 1840, he was appointed canon of Loreto; in 1844 he was sent to Switzerland as Auditor of the Nunciature and in 1852 he moved to the Nunciature in France. In 1854, Pius IX wanted him in his State Secretariat as minute-taker and bishop house prelate; a year later he was appointed as Internuncio to the Royal Court in The Hague, where he conducted negotiations on the further organisation of the newly restored (1853) episcopal hierarchy in the Netherlands; he resigned from this post in 1863. Vecchiotti has been described (De Valk 1998) as the most pitiful person to have ever held this position. He made the mistake of thinking that he could claim a more active role for the internuntius in the archdiocese of Utrecht, which was then being set up. This resulted in heated arguments with Archbishop Zwijsen, who is said to have made 'mincemeat' of him. The arguments were so heated that rumours began to circulate that the internuntius was involved in the assassination attempt on Zwijsen in 1863 – a matter that has still not been clarified. Returning to Italy he became Councillor of State to Pius IX; later he was Apostolic Nuncio in Brussels, until Leo XIII appointed him Auditor at the Court of the Roman Rota in 1879. He died on 27 February 1880.
$Vecchiotti.it_IT: Settimio Maria Vecchiotti nacque nel 1810 da Sebastiano Clementi Vecchiotti, patrizio sammarinese. Compì gli studi i religiosi Filippini dell'Oratorio a Fermo e si laureò a Roma, presso il Collegio Capranica in filosofia e teologia. Forte fu il suo legame con il cardinal Pecci che sarebbe divenuto papa Leone XIII. Nel 1840 fu nominato canonico di Loreto. Nel 1844 fu inviato come Uditore della Nunziatura in Svizzera e dal 1852 entrò nella Nunziatura in Francia. Nel 1854 Pio IX lo volle nella sua Segreteria di Stato come minutante, e vescovo prelato domestico, per poi nominarlo Internunzio alla corte reale dell'Aia, dove condusse le trattative per la finalizzazione della gerarchia episcopale da poco (1853) ricostituita nei Paesi Bassi; si dimise da tale incarico nel 1863. Vecchiotti è stato definito (De Valk 1998) come il più deplorevole che abbia mai ricoperto questa carica. Commise l'errore di pensare che potesse rivendicare un ruolo più attivo per l'internunzio nell'arcidiocesi di Utrecht, allora in fase di costituzione. Il risultato furono violenti litigi con l'arcivescovo Zwijsen, che lo avrebbe 'fatto a pezzi'. Le discussioni si fecero così accese che si diffuse la voce che l'internunzio fosse coinvolto nel fallito attentato mortale compiuto nel 1863 contro Zwijsen, una questione che non è stata ancora del tutto chiarita. Tornato in Italia Vecchiotti divenne Consigliere di Stato di Pio IX e, successivamente, fu Nunzio Apostolico a Bruxelles, finché nel 1879 il a Leone XIII lo nominò Uditore al Tribunale della Santa Rota. Morì il 27 febbraio 1880.
$Vecchiotti.nl_NL: Settimio Maria Vecchiotti werd in 1810 geboren als zoon van Sebastiano Clementi Vecchiotti, een patriciër uit San Marino. Hij studeerde bij de religieuze orde van de Filippini dell'Oratorio in Fermo en in Rome aan het Collegio Capranica, waar hij zich bekwaamde in filosofie en theologie. Met kardinaal Pecci, de latere paus Leo XIII, onderhield hij in Rome nauwe banden. In 1840 werd hij benoemd tot kanunnik van Loreto; in 1844 werd hij uitgezonden als Auditor van de Nuntiatuur in Zwitserland en vanaf 1852 ging hij over naar de Nuntiatuur in Frankrijk. Paus Pius IX vroeg hem in 1854 als notulist en bisschop huisprelaat in zijn Staatssecretariaat, om hem vervolgens in 1855 te benoemen tot internuntius aan het hof van het Koninkrijk der Nederlanden in Den Haag. Daar voerde hij de onderhandelingen over de verdere inrichting van de net herstelde bisschoppelijke hiërarchie (1853) in Nederland. Hij trad terug uit deze functie in 1863. Vecchiotti is wel aangeduid (De Valk 1998) als de meest beklagenswaardige die de functie van internuntius heeft vervuld. Hij beging de fout de denken dat hij in het Utrechtse aartsbisdom-in-opbouw een actievere rol voor de internuntius kon opeisen. Het gevolg waren knallende ruzies met aartsbisschop Zwijsen die 'gehakt' van hem zou hebben gemaakt. De ruzies liepen zo hoog op dat het gerucht ging dat de internuntius betrokken zou zijn bij de moordaanslag die in 1863 op Zwijsen werd gepleegd - een kwestie die nog steeds niet is opgehelderd. Na zijn terugkeer in Italië werd hij staatsraad van Pius IX en later apostolisch nuntius in Brussel, totdat Leo XIII hem in 1879 benoemde tot auditor van het Tribunaal van de Rota Romana. Hij stierf op 27 februari 1880.

$Ventura.en_GB: Gioacchino Ventura di Raulica was a nobleman from Palermo who joined the order of the Theatines in 1817, of which he became superior general from 1830-1833. Initially, he was a follower of the French priest and writer Félicité Robert de La Lamennais and the French ultramontanists. His fame as a preacher led Pope Leo XII to appoint him professor of canon law at the Università La Sapienza in Rome. After Pius IX was elected pope in 1846, Ventura became a supporter of neo-Guelphism and urged the pope for political reforms. In 1848, he supported Sicilian separatism and represented the Sicilian revolutionary government at the papal court. After Pius had fled Rome (November 1848), Ventura supported the Roman Republic, which was proclaimed in February 1849. When the Republic fell in July 1849, he fled via Montpellier to Paris, where he arrived in early 1851. Ventura devoted the next ten years to his studies and his faith. He died at Versailles on 2 August 1861.
$Ventura.it_IT: Gioacchino Ventura di Raulica fu un nobile palermitano entrato nel 1817 nell'Ordine dei Teatini, di cui divenne superiore generale dal 1830-1833. Inizialmente, era un seguace del prete e scrittore francese Félicité Robert de La Lamennais e degli ultramontanisti francesi. La sua fama di predicatore indusse Papa Leone XII a nominarlo professore di diritto canonico all'Università La Sapienza di Roma. Dopo che Pio IX fu eletto papa nel 1846, Ventura divenne un sostenitore del neoguelfismo e sollecitò il papa a riforme politiche. Nel 1848 sostenne il separatismo siciliano e rappresentò il governo rivoluzionario siciliano presso la corte papale. Dopo la fuga di Pio IX da Roma (novembre 1848), Ventura sostenne la Repubblica Romana, proclamata nel febbraio 1849. Quando la Repubblica cadde nel luglio 1849, fuggì via Montpellier fino a Parigi, dove arrivò all'inizio del 1851. Ventura dedicò i successivi dieci anni agli studi e alla fede. Morì a Versailles il 2 agosto 1861.
$Ventura.nl_NL: Gioacchino Ventura di Raulica was een Palermitaans edelman die in 1817 toetrad tot de orde van de Theatijnen, waarvan hij van 1830-1833 generaal-overste werd. Aanvankelijk was hij een volgeling van de Franse priester en schrijver Félicité Robert de La Lamennais en de Franse ultramontanisten. Zijn faam als prediker zorgde ervoor dat paus Leo XII hem tot hoogleraar canoniek recht aan de Sapienza-universiteit in Rome benoemde. Na de verkiezing van Pius IX in 1846 werd hij aanhanger van het neowelfisme en drong hij bij de paus aan op politieke hervormingen. In 1848 steunde Ventura het Siciliaanse separatisme en vertegenwoordigde hij de Siciliaanse revolutionaire regering aan het pauselijk hof. Na de vlucht van Pius uit Rome (november 1848) koos hij spoedig partij voor de Romeinse Republiek, die in februari 1849 uitgeroepen werd. Toen de Republiek in juli 1849 gevallen was, vluchtte hij via Montpellier naar Parijs, waar hij begin 1851 aankwam. Ventura weidde zich de daaropvolgende tien jaar aan de studie en zijn geloof, en overleed op 2 augustus 1861 te Versailles.

$Villafranca.en_GB: Eugenio Emanuele Villafranca was a member of the Savoy royal family. He was born in Paris in 1816 as the son of Giuseppe Maria di Savoia-Carignano Count of Villafranca and Paolina Benedetta de La Vauguyon. In 1825 he was called back to Turin to be educated at the Jesuit college; later King Charles Albert bestowed on him the rights of prince of the blood (1834). On 29 March 1849, he was granted the title of Royal Highness.  Meanwhile, he pursued a military career in the navy, where he became commander general (eq. First Sea Lord) in 1844. In 1851 he represented the Sardinian government at the Universal Exhibition in London. He was Luogotenente (Steward) of the Kingdom during the Wars of Independence (1848-1849, 1859 and 1866); regent in Tuscany (March 1860) and Luogotenente on behalf of Sardinia in Naples (January 1861). In 1861 he took part in the siege of Gaeta where King Francis II of the Two Sicilies had taken refuge. In his last years he presided over the General State Defence Commission and the National Consortium. He died in Turin in 1888.
$Villafranca.it_IT: Eugenio Emanuele Villafranca fu membro della famiglia reale Savoia. Nacque a Parigi nel 1816 da figlio di Giuseppe Maria di Savoia-Carignano conte di Villafranca e di Paolina Benedetta de La Vauguyon. Nel 1825 fu chiamato a Torino per essere educato nel collegio dei gesuiti, e più tardi Carlo Alberto integrò nei diritti di principe del sangue (1834). Il 29 marzo 1849 ebbe il titolo di altezza reale. Nel frattempo intraprese una carriere militare. Destinato alla marina da guerra, ne divenne comandante generale nel 1844. Nel 1851 rappresentò il governo all'Esposizione universale di Londra. Fu Luogotenente del Regno durante le guerre d'indipendenza (1848-1849, 1859 e 1866); reggente in Toscana (marzo 1860) e luogotenente a Napoli (gennaio 1861). Nel 1861 partecipò all'assedio di Gaeta dove si era rifugiato il re delle Due Sicilie Francesco II. Negli ultimi anni presiedette la Commissione generale di Difesa dello Stato e il Consorzio nazionale. Morì a Torino nel 1888.
$Villafranca.nl_NL: Eugenio Emanuele Villafranca was een lid van de koninklijke familie van Savoia. Hij werd in 1816 in Parijs geboren als zoon van Giuseppe Maria di Savoia-Carignano graaf van Villafranca en Paolina Benedetta de La Vauguyon. In 1825 werd bij naar Turijn teruggeroepen om te worden onderwezen aan het jezuïetencollege; later kende koning Karel Albert hem de rechten van prins van den bloede toe (1834). Op 29 maart 1849 verkreeg Eugenio Emanuele de titel van Koninklijke Hoogheid. Intussen was hij een militaire carrière begonnen bij de Marine, waar hij in 1844 commandant der zeestrijdkrachten werd. In 1851 vertegenwoordigde hij de regering van het Koninkrijk Sardiniënop de wereldtentoonstelling in Londen. Hij was Luogotenente (Stadhouder) van het Koninkrijk tijdens de Onafhankelijkheidsoorlogen (1848-1849, 1859 en 1866); regent in Toscane (maart 1860) en Luogotenente namens Sardinië in Napels (januari 1861). In 1861 nam hij deel aan het beleg van Gaeta, waar de gevluchte koning Frans II van de Beide Siciliën zich had verschanst. In zijn laatste jaren was hij voorzitter van de Algemene Staatscommissie voor Defensie en het Nationaal Consortium. Hij stierf in Turijn in 1888.

$Visconti.en_GB: Emilio Visconti Venosta was born in Milan. He studied Law in Pavia and joined Mazzini's movement in his youth, from which he later moved away to more moderate positions. A deputy in the first Italian Parliament in 1861, he served as Minister of Foreign Affairs in the Minghetti government from March 1863 to September 1864. He was again minister from 1866 to 1867 and from 1869 until 1876. In shaping Italian foreign policy he played a decisive role. He tackled the serious political and diplomatic problems related to the Italian conquest of Rome (1870) and the Law of Papal Guarantees (1871), and settled the delicate matter of the Franco-Italian relations. Between 1873 and 1875 he worked to bring about a rapprochement with the Central Powers of Europe, establishing good diplomatic relations without engaging in a direct alliance. His was a prudent and balanced policy. In 1896 Visconti Venosta, who had been appointed senator in 1886, returned to the Foreign Ministry in the aftermath of the defeat at Adua (March 1896), and remained there until 1898. He was again Minister from 1899 to 1901. In 1901 he received the Collar in the Order of the Santissima Annunziata, the highest decoration of the Royal House of Savoy. He died in Rome in 1914.
$Visconti.it_IT: Emilio Visconti Venosta nacque a Milano. Studiò giurisprudenza a Pavia e aderì in gioventù al movimento mazziniano dal quale in seguito si allontanò spostandosi su posizioni moderate. Deputato nel primo Parlamento italiano nel 1861, ricoprì la carica di ministro degli Esteri nel governo Minghetti dal marzo 1863 al settembre 1864. Fu di nuovo ministro dal 1866 al 1867 e dal 1869 fino al 1876. Ebbe una parte determinante nell'orientare la politica estera italiana. Affrontò i gravi problemi politico-diplomatici connessi alla conquista di Roma (1870) e alla legge delle guarentigie (1871), le questioni relative ai rapporti con la Francia e si adoperò, tra il 1873 e il 1875, per un avvicinamento agli Imperi centrali volto a stabilire buoni rapporti diplomatici senza un'alleanza diretta. La sua fu una politica prudente ed equilibrata. Nel 1896 Visconti Venosta, che nel 1886 era stato nominato senatore, tornò al ministero degli Esteri all'indomani della sconfitta di Adua (marzo 1896), e vi rimase fino al 1898. Fu ancora ministro dal 1899 al 1901. Nel 1901 fu insignito del Collare dell'Annunziata. Morì a Roma nel 1914.
$Visconti.nl_NL: Emilio Visconti Venosta werd geboren in Milaan. Hij studeerde Rechten in Pavia en sloot zich in zijn jeugd aan bij de beweging van Mazzini, waarvan hij later afstand zou nemen toen hij gematigde ideeën ontwikkelde. Hij was afgevaardigde in het eerste Italiaanse parlement in 1861 en minister van Buitenlandse Zaken in de regering Minghetti, van maart 1863 tot september 1864. Hij was opnieuw minister van 1866 tot 1867 en van 1869 tot 1876. In de vormgeving van het Italiaanse buitenlandse beleid speelde Visconti Venosta een beslissende rol. Hij bood de ernstige politiek-diplomatieke problemen het hoofd die voortvloeiden uit de verovering van Rome (1870) en de de zogenaamde (Pauselijke) Garantiewet (1871), regelde de delicate kwestie van de Frans-Italiaanse betrekkingen. Tussen 1873 en 1875 werkte hij aan een toenadering tot de Centrale Mogendheden in Europa, waarmee hij goede diplomatieke betrekkingen aanknoopte zonder een direct bondgenootschap aan te gaan. Hij voerde een voorzichtig en evenwichtig beleid. In 1896 keerde Visconti Venosta, die in 1886 tot senator was benoemd, in de nasleep van de Italiaanse nederlaag bij Adua (maart 1896) terug als minister van Buitenlandse Zaken en bleef op die post tot 1898. Van 1899 tot 1901 was hij opnieuw minister. In 1901 werd hij gedecoreerd in de Orde van de Santissima Annunziata, de hoogste onderscheiding van het Koninklijk Huis van Savoia. Hij stierf in Rome in 1914.

$Vitrioli.en_GB: Diego Vitrioli was an Italian poet. In 1845, he won the first prize of the Certamen Hoeufftianum of the International Latin Poetry Competition at the Royal Academy of Sciences in Amsterdam with the poem Xiphias, a prize later won 13 times by Giovanni Pascoli. For Vitrioli, the prize earned him the appointment as lecturer Latin and Ancient Greek at the Royal College of Reggio Calabria, of which he had also been a pupil. Later, King Ferdinand II of Bourbon appointed him librarian of the Biblioteca Civica di Reggio and inspector of the Antiquities of Calabria Ultra, posts from which the Bourbon-legitimist Vitrioli was dismissed by the new Italian government in 1860. Dedicated to the study of Calabrian antiquities and especially classical literature, he left numerous epigrams in Latin distichs (some also in Greek), twenty-three elegies (the last six of which nspired by the ruins of Pompeii), lucian dialogues, letters, and Latin epigraphs. But his best work remains the Xiphias, a poem in three cantos in hexameters about swordfish fishing. He later elaborated the original text of Xiphias in no less than eight versions. In the one of 1887, the poem is structured in three parts; the third includes a eulogy of the Dutch builders of dykes against the violence of the sea and the benefactors of culture of the Certamen Hoefftianum).
$Vitrioli.it_IT: Diego Vitrioli fu un poeta italiano. Nel 1845 vinse, col poemetto Xiphias, il primo premio al Certamen Hoeufftianum del concorso internazionale di poesia Latina dell'Accademia Reale delle Scienze di Amsterdam, premio poi vinto da Giovanni Pascoli ben 13 volte. Al Vitrioli il premio valse la nomina di docente Lingua latina e Greco antico presso il Real Collegio di Reggio Calabria, di cui era stato allievo. In seguito il re Ferdinando II di Borbone lo nominò bibliotecario della Biblioteca Civica di Reggio e ispettore delle Antichità della Calabria Ultra, cariche dalle quali il legittimista Vitrioli fu nel 1860 destituito dal nuovo governo. Dedito agli studi delle antichità calabresi e soprattutto di lettere classiche, lasciò numerosi epigrammi in distici latini (alcuni anche in greco), ventitré elegie (di cui le ultime sei ispirate alle rovine di Pompei), dialoghi lucianei, lettere, epigrafi latine. Ma l'opera migliore resta lo Xiphias, poema in tre canti in esametri sulla pesca del pesce spada. In seguito, sottoporrà l'originario testo del Xiphias a un progressivo ampliamento in ben 8 versioni. In quella del 1887 il poema è strutturata in tre parti; la terza comprende un elogio degli Olandesi costruttori di dighe contro la violenza del mare e benemeriti della cultura per il Certamen Hoefftianum).
$Vitrioli.nl_NL: Diego Vitrioli was een Italiaanse dichter. In 1845 won hij de eerste prijs van het Certamen Hoeufftianum in de interantionale wedstrijd voor Latijnse poëzie van de Koninklijke Academie van Wetenschappen in Amsterdam met het gedicht Xiphias, (een prijs die later 13 keer werd gewonnen door Giovanni Pascoli). De prijs leverde Vitrioli een benoeming op tot docent Latijn en Oudgrieks aan het Koninklijk College van Reggio Calabria, waar hij ook leerling was geweest. Later benoemde koning Ferdinand II van Bourbon hem tot bibliothecaris van de Biblioteca Civica van Reggio en inspecteur van de Oudheden van Calabria Ultra, functies waaruit hij als Bourbon-legitimist in 1860 werd ontslagen door de nieuwe Italiaanse regering. Toegewijd aan de studie van de Calabrische oudheden en vooral de klassieke literatuur, liet hij talrijke epigrammen in Latijnse disticha (sommige ook in het Grieks), drieëntwintig elegieën (waarvan de laatste zes geïnspireerd door de ruïnes van Pompeii), luciaanse dialogen, brieven en Latijnse epigrafen na. Maar zijn beste werk blijft de Xiphias, een gedicht in drie canto's in hexameters over de jacht op de  zwaardvis. De oorspronkelijke tekst ervan werkte hij later uit in niet minder dan acht versies. In die van 1887 is het gedicht opgebouwd uit drie delen, waarvan het derde een lofrede bevat op de Nederlandse dijkenbouwers tegen het geweld van de zee en op de weldoeners van de cultuur van het Certamen Hoefftianum.

$Volpicelli.en_GB: After studying philosophy and mathematics at the University of Rome, Paolo Volpicelli was appointed Professor of Geometry, applied to the arts, at the Ospizio di San Michele in 1832, Professor of Physics and Chemistry at the Roman Seminary in 1836 and Professor of Experimental Physics in 1845. He held this chair until 1872, when he transferred to the chair of Mathematical Physics. At the same time, he was director of the university cabinet (museum), where he managed to expand the collection considerably. When the Accademia dei Lincei was reconstituted in 1847, he was among its first elected members. At the same time he held the position of secretary - until 1877. He published hundreds of scientific texts, devoting himself with equal interest to mathematics, (experimental) physics, geology, meteorology, optics, thermodynamics, electricity and magnetism. In 1847, Volpicelli founded a special school of artillery in Rome; it was no coincidence that in 1848 the minister of the papal government, Pellegrino Rossi, appointed him secretary of the Commission of Non-Conventional Weapons, an advisory body to the Ministry of the Armed Forces. He was a member of numerous Italian and foreign societies and academies, such as the Accademia delle Scienze in Turin and the Académie des sciences in Paris.
$Volpicelli.it_IT: Compiuti gli studi filosofici e matematici presso l'Università di Roma, Paolo Volpicelli venne nominato nel 1832 professore di geometria applicata alle arti nell'Ospizio di S. Michele, nel 1836 professore di fisico-chimica nel Seminario romano e supplente alla Cattedra di fisica sperimentale, della quale divenne titolare nel 1845. Mantenne questa cattedra fino al 1872, quando passò alla cattedra di fisica matematica. Al contempo fu direttore del gabinetto (museo) universitario, del quale riuscì ad ampliare notevolmente la dotazione di strumenti. Ristabilita nel 1847 l'Accademia dei Lincei, fu tra i primi soci ordinari eletti ed ebbe contemporaneamente l'incarico di segretario, riconfermata fino al 1877. Pubblicò centinaia di memorie scientifiche; si dedicò con uguale interesse alla matematica e alla fisica, anche sperimentale: si applicò agli studi di geologia, di meteorologia, di ottica, di termodinamica, di elettricità e magnetismo. Nel 1847 Volpicelli fondò a Roma una Scuola speciale di artiglieria, e non a caso nel 1848 il ministro del governo pontificio Pellegrino Rossi lo designò segretario della Commissione delle armi facoltative, organo consultivo del ministero delle Forze armate. Fu membro di numerose società e accademie sia italiane che estere, come l'Accademie delle scienze di Torino e l'Académie des sciences di Parigi.
$Volpicelli.nl_NL: Na zijn studies filosofie en wiskunde aan de Universiteit van Rome, werd Paolo Volpicelli in 1832 benoemd tot professor Meetkunde, toegepast op de kunsten, aan het Ospizio di San Michele, in 1836 tot hoogleraar Natuurkunde en Scheikunde aan het Romeinse Seminarie en in 1845 to hoogleraar Experimentele Natuurkunde. Hij bekleedde deze leerstoel tot 1872, toen hij overstapte naar de leerstoel Wiskundige Natuurkunde. Tegelijkertijd was hij directeur van het universitaire kabinet (museum), waarvan hij de collectie aanzienlijk wist uit te breiden. Toen de Accademia dei Lincei in 1847 opnieuw werd opgericht, behoorde hij tot de eerste gekozen leden. Tegelijkertijd bekleedde hij - tot 1877 - de functie van secretaris. Hij publiceerde honderden wetenschappelijke teksten, waarbij hij zich met evenveel interesse wijdde aan wiskunde, (experimentele) natuurkunde, geologie, meteorologie, optica, thermodynamica, elektriciteit en magnetisme. In 1847 richtte Volpicelli in Rome een speciale school voor artillerie op; het was geen toeval dat de minister van de pauselijke regering, Pellegrino Rossi, hem in 1848 benoemde tot secretaris van de Commissie van Non-Conventionele Wapens, een adviesorgaan van het Ministerie van de Strijdkrachten. Hij was lid van talloze Italiaanse en buitenlandse genootschappen en academies, zoals de Accademia delle Scienze in Turijn en de Académie des sciences in Parijs.

$Vos.en_GB: Jacob Willemszoon de Vos was the son of a well-known Baptist preacher in Amsterdam. After Latin school, he went to work for the insurance agency of his unmarried uncle Jacob de Vos (1733-1833); from 1828, his sons Jacob and Chris joined the agency as well. Jacob Willemsz took over an important collection of old drawings from his uncle and expanded the collection. He was also a talented draughtsman himself (he was an apprentice at the Felix Meritis society), and an amateur musician. He held several positions in the Amsterdam art world: he was secretary of the Fourth Class of the Dutch Royal Institute of Sciences, Letters and Fine Arts and vice-chairman of the board of the Dutch Royal Academy of Arts. In 1837, he made premises (Slijkstraat) available for the Dutch Royal Academy of Arts, free of charge, and worked on the establishment of a graphics department. He showed himself a warm advocate of history painting, a conviction that would later be embodied by the establishment of the history gallery of his son Jacob Jacobsz.
$Vos.it_IT: Jacob Willemszoon de Vos era il figlio di un noto ministro mennonita di Amsterdam. Dopo la scuola di latino andò a lavorare presso l'ufficio assicurativo dello zio Jacob de Vos (1733-1833), non sposato; Dal 1828 vi si unirono anche i figli Jacob e Chris. Jacob Willemsz acquisì un'importante collezione di vecchi disegni da suo zio e la ampliò. Fua anche un talentuoso disegnatore (era studente presso la compagnia Felix Meritis) e musicista dilettante. Ricoprì diversi incarichi nel mondo dell'arte di Amsterdam: fu segretario di quarta classe del Reale Istituto di Scienze, Letteratura e Belle Arti e vicepresidente del consiglio di amministrazione della Royal Academy of Arts. Nel 1837 mise a disposizione gratuitamente per quest'ultimo un edificio (Slijkstraat) e si adoperò per allestire un dipartimento grafico. Si dimostrò un appassionato sostenitore della pittura storica, una convinzione che si sarebbe incarnata nella galleria storica di suo figlio Jacob Jacobsz.
$Vos.nl_NL: Jacob Willemszoon de Vos was de zoon van een bekende doopsgezinde predikant in Amsterdam. Na de Latijnse school ging hij werken voor het assurantiekantoor van zijn ongehuwde oom Jacob de Vos (1733-1833); vanaf 1828 traden daar ook zijn zoons Jacob en Chris toe. Van zijn oom nam Jacob Willemsz een belangrijke verzameling oude tekeningen over en breidde de verzameling uit. Zelf was hij ook een getalenteerd tekenaar (hij was leerling bij de maatschappij Felix Meritis) en amateurmusicus. In de Amsterdamse kunstwereld bekleedde hij verschillende functies: hij was secretaris van de Vierde Klasse van het Koninklijk Instituut van Wetenschappen, Letterkunde en Schoone Kunsten en vice-voorzitter van de raad van bestuur van de Koninklijke Academie van Beeldende Kunsten. Voor die laatste stelde hij in 1837 kosteloos een pand (Slijkstraat) beschikbaar en spande hij zich in voor de oprichting van een grafische afdeling. Hij betoonde zich een warm pleitbezorger van de historieschilderkunst, een overtuiging die zou worden belichaamd door de historische galerij van zijn zoon Jacob Jacobsz.

$Vries.en_GB: Jeronimo de Vries attended Latin school in Amsterdam and then studied literature at the Athenaeum Illustre. He later obtained a doctorate in Law at the university of Harderwijk. He spent his career at the secretariat of the city of Amsterdam, from 1814 as 'chief clerk', where he was effectively considered the 'fifth mayor' (alongside the four mayors in name). He was very active in education and poor relief, including as a member of the municipal schooling committee, curator of the city's poor relief and member of the Maatschappij van Weldadigheid (Society of Benevolence). He also made a name for himself as a literary scholar with reviews and treatises on classical Latin literature and, in particular, modern Dutch poetry. But above all, he was known as an art critic, dealer and collector. He was a member of the Concordia et libertate and Felix Mertitis societies and a member of the Second Class of the Royal Institute. Until 1852, he was secretary of the Academy of Fine Arts in Amsterdam, and from 1844 he was a member of the advisory committee of the Trippenhuis, the predecessor of the Rijksmuseum.
$Vries.it_IT: Jeronimo de Vries frequentò la Scuola Latina ad Amsterdam e successivamente studiò lettere all'Athenaeum Illustre. Successivamente conseguì il dottorato in giurisprudenza all'università di Harderwijk. Trascorse la sua carriera presso la segreteria della città di Amsterdam, dal 1814 come “griffier en chef” (cancelliere capo), ricoprendo di fatto il ruolo di “quinto sindaco” (oltre ai quattro sindaci nominali). Fu molto attivo nell'istruzione e nell'assistenza ai poveri, tra l'altro come membro della commissione scolastica comunale, curatore dell'assistenza ai poveri della città e membro della Maatschappij van Weldadigheid (Società di Beneficenza). Inoltre, si fece un nome come letterato con recensioni e trattati sulla letteratura latina classica e, soprattutto, sulla poesia olandese moderna. Ma era noto soprattutto come critico, mercante e collezionista d'arte. Era membro delle società Concordia et libertate e Felix Mertitis, nonché membro della Seconda Classe dell'Istituto Reale. Fino al 1852 fu segretario dell'Accademia delle Belle Arti di Amsterdam e dal 1844 fece parte della commissione consultiva del Trippenhuis, il precursore del Rijksmuseum.
$Vries.nl_NL: Jeronimo de Vries doorliep de Latijnse school in Amsterdam en studeerde daarna letteren daarna aan het Athenaeum Illusttre. Later promoveerde hij in Harderwijk in de Rechten. Zijn carière bracht hij door aan de secretarie van de stad Amsterdam, vanaf 1814 als 'griffier en chef', waarbij hij de facto als 'vijfde burgermeester' gold (naast de vier burgermeester in naam). Hij was zeer actief in onderwijs en armenzorg, onder meer als lid van de stedelijke schoolcommissie, curator van de stadsarmenzorg en lid van de Maatschappij van Weldadigheid. Daarnaast maakte hij naam als letterkundige met besprekingen en verhandelingen over klassieke Latijnse literatuur en vooral moderne Nederlandse dichtkunst. Maar vooral ook was hij bekend als kunstcriticus, -handelaar en -verzamelaar. Hij was lid van de sociëteiten Concordia et libertate en Felix Mertitis, en lid van de Tweede Klasse van het Koninklijk Instituut. Tot 1852 was hij secretaris van de Academie van Beeldende Kunsten in Amsterdam, vanaf 1844 zat hij in de commissie van advies van het Trippenhuis, de voorloper van het Rijksmuseum.

$Vrolik.en_GB: Like his father Gerard (1775-1859), Willem Vrolik was a Dutch professor of Anatomy and Medicine. After his doctorate in 1823, he established himself in Amsterdam as a physician while also continuing research. With H.C. Mulder and G.J. van Hall, he founded the journal Bijdragen tot de natuurkundige wetenschappen (1826-1832). In 1828, he was appointed professor at the University of Groningen, a position he left to take part in the Ten-Day Field Campaign (1831) as a volunteer lieutenant with a company of students from Groningen and Franeker. Upon his return, he became professor of Anatomy, Physiology and Natural History in Amsterdam. In addition to his teaching and research, he was secretary of the Royal Academy of Sciences. He also directed the Vrolikianum or Museum Vrolik of anatomy, founded by his father. Willem expanded its collection, especially in the fields of animal anatomy, congenital anomalies and, later, skulls and plaster busts of 'human races' - subjects on which he also published.  The museum still exists, see https://www.museumvrolik.nl/.
$Vrolik.it_IT: Come suo padre Gerard (1775-1859), Willem Vrolik fu professore olandese di Anatomia e Medicina. Dopo il dottorato nel 1823, si stabilì ad Amsterdam come medico, continuando al contempo la ricerca. Con H.C.
